superEntry.entry:
alphabetical letter q c
The twenty-first letter of the alphabet: called qaAfN. Respecting its pronunciation as the title of the fiftieth chapter of the Kur-án, see SAd, in art. Swd. It is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, and not with the breath only]; its place of utterance is between the root of the tongue and the uvula, in the furthest part of the mouth; and it is of the strongest of the letters, and of the most certain of them in sound. (TA at the commencement of bAb AlqAf.) It is sometimes pronounced like the Pers. G, i. e. AlkaAfu Almamozuwjapu biAlqaAfi; in which case it is termed AlqaAfu AlmaqoEuwdapu [?]: this mode of pronouncing it is well known as of the dial. of the people of El-Yemen [and others]: Ibn-Khaldoon says that it is of the dial. of Mudar; and that some of the people of the [Prophet's] house are so extravagant as to assert that recitation in prayer is not rightly but with this letter thus pronounced. (MF and TA voce julRanaArN.) It has been substituted for one letter, i. e. k, [as some say,] in the instance of Oukonapu AlTRaAYiri [for which they sometimes said Ouqonap]. (MF and TA at the commencement of bAb AlqAf. [It is there added that a pl. of Oukonap has been heard, but not of Ouqonap, and this is a sign of the originality of the former: but OuqanaAtN is mentioned as pl. of Ouqonap in art. Aqn in the TA.])

1 qaOaba AlTRaEaAma c
1. qaOaba AlTRaEaAma, (As, S, O, K,) aor.
qaAa^a
, inf. n. qaOobN, (K,) He ate the food. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b2- And qaOaba AlmaMCa He drank the water; as also qaYibahu: (K:) or he drank all the water that was in the vessel. (As, S, O, K.) ― -b3- And qaYiba mina AlXRaraAbi, aor.
qaAa^a
, inf. n. qaOobN and qaOabN, (K, TA,) the latter thus (muHarRakap), agreeably with analogy, (TA, [but in the CK qaMb,]) He became filled with the beverage; (Lth, K;) as also qaOaba minohu: (Lth:) or he drank the beverage: (TA:) and, or simply qaYiba, like SaYiba, (S,) he drank much water. (S, TA.)

qaWuwbN c
qaWuwbN: see miqoOabN.

UinaMCN qawoOabN c
UinaMCN qawoOabN and qawoOabiIRN↓ A vessel that takes, or receives, much water: (O, K:) the latter epithet expl. by Lth as signifying taking, or receiving, much. (L.)

qawoOabiIRN c
qawoOabiIRN: see what next precedes.

miqoOabN c
miqoOabN (S, O, K) and qaWuwbN↓ (K) One who drinks much water: (S, O:) or one who drinks much. (K.)

1 qabRa c
1. qabRa, aor.
qabiba
, (M, K,) inf. n. qabiybN, (M,) or qubuwbN, (so in the K, [but see the next sentence,]) and qabRN, (TA,) said of a number of men (qawomN), They raised a clamour, or confusion of cries or shouts or noises, in contention, or litigation, (M, K,) or in dispute. (M.) And qabRa, aor.
qabiba
, inf. n. qabiybN (S, M, O, K,) and qabRN, (M, K,) said of a lion, (S, M, O, K,) and of a stallion [camel], (M, K,) He made the gnashing (qaboqabap [inf. n. of qaboqaba↓], S, O, or qaEoqaEap, M, K) of his canine teeth to be heard: (S, M, O, K:) and in like manner the verb (M, K) with the same inf. ns. (M) is said of the canine tooth of the stallion [camel] and of the lion, (M, K,) meaning it made a sounding, and a gnashing: (K:) and some expl. qabiybN in a general manner, saying that it signifies a sounding, or sound: (M:) qaboqabapN also, and qaboqaAbN, [both inf. ns. of qaboqaba↓,] (M,) or the former and qabiybN, (TA,) signify the sounding [or gnashing] of the canine teeth of the stallion [camel]: and his braying: or, as some say, the reiterating of the braying: (M, TA:) and qbqbp↓ and qabiybN signify the sounding of the chest or belly of the horse. (S, M, O.) ＝ -A2- And qabRa, aor.
qabiba
, inf. n. qubuwbN, said of flesh-meat, It lost its moisture, (S, M, O, K,) or fresh-ness: (M, K:) and in like manner said of dates (tamor), (S, M, O, Msb, [in my copy of the last of which the inf. n. is said to be qabiyb,]) and of the skin, and of a wound: (S, O:) and hence said of the back of a man who had been beaten with the whip or some other thing, meaning the marks of the beating thereof became in a healing state, and dried. (As, O, TA.) And qabRati AlrRuTabapu, (M, TA,) thus correctly, but in copies of the K qabRabat↓, (TA,) [and the CK has AlrRaTobapu for AlrRuTabapu,] is said to signify The fresh ripe date became somewhat dry after the ripening: (M, TA:) or became dry. (K.) ― -b2- And qabRa AlnRabotu, aor.
qabiba
and
qabuba
, [the latter anomalous,] inf. n. qabRN, The plant dried up. (M, L, K.) ＝ -A3- qabRa, (M, MA,) aor. yaqabRu, (M,) inf. n. qababN, (S, * M, MA, O, * K, *) He was, or became, slender in the waist, (S, * M, MA, O, * K, *) lank in the belly: (S, * M, O, * K: *) and qabibato, uncontracted, as in some other instances, said of a woman [as meaning she was, or became, slender in the waist, lank in the belly], is mentioned by IAar: (M:) and some say, of the belly of the horse, qabRa, (M, TA,) meaning his flanks became lank; (M;) or his flanks adhered to his HaAlibaAni [dual. of HaAlibN, q. v.]: (TA:) or one says, [app. of a horse,] qabRa baTonuhu, (K, TA,) inf. n. qabRN; (TA;) and qabiba, (K, TA,) inf. n. qababN, in the original uncontracted forms, anomalously, (TA,) meaning his belly became lank. (K, TA.) And one says also, qubRa baTonuhu, i. e. His (a horse's) belly was, or became, firmly compacted, so as to have a round form: and qabRahu means He caused it to be so: (O, TA:) the aor. of the latter is
qabuba
, and the inf. n. is qabRN. (TA.) ＝ -A4- qabRa AlXRaIoCa He collected, or gathered together, the extremities of the thing; as also qabRabahu↓. (M, TA.) ＝ -A5- And qabRahu, aor.
qabuba
, (S, M, O,) inf. n. qabRN, (M, K,) He cut it off; (S, M, O, K; *) and AqtbRhu↓ signifies the same: (M, K: *) or, [app. the latter,] as some say, peculiarly the hand, or arm: (M:) one says, AqtbR fulaAnN yada fulaAnK Such a one cut off the hand, or arm, of such a one: (As, S, O:) or AiqotibaAbN signifies any cutting off that does not leave aught. (M.) ＝ -A6- See also the next paragraph.

2 qbRb c
2. qbRb He (a man) made a qubRap [q. v.]: (K:) or so qabRa↓: (TA:) and qbRb qubRapF, (M, TA,) inf. n. taqobiybN, (TA,) he made, (M,) or constructed, (TA,) a qabRap. (M, TA.) [Hence,] AlhawaAdiju tuqabRabu [The women's camel vehicles of the kind called hwAdj have dome-like, or tent-like, coverings made to them]. (S, O.) ― -b2- [Hence also,] qbRb Zahorahu [He (a man) made his back round like a dome, lowering his head]. (S and K in art. dbx.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in two places, near the middle and near the end.

5 tqbRb qubRapF c
5. tqbRb qubRapF He entered a qubRap [q. v.]. (M, K.)

8 Uiqotababa
8: see 1, near the end. ― -b2- IAar says, El- 'Okeylee used not to discourse of anything but I wrote it down from him; wherefore he said, UilRaA QnotaqarahaA UlRaA QqotabRahaA walaA nuqaArapF maA taraka EinodiI qaAbRapF↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) He did not leave with me any approved and choice word but he cut it off for himself [or appropriated it to his own use], nor any such expression but he took it for himself. (M, TA.)

R. Q. 1 qaboqaba c
R. Q. 1. qaboqaba, and its inf. ns.: see 1, former half, in three places. Said of a stallion [camel], (O, TA,) it signifies [also] He brayed: (O, K, * TA:) and, said of a lion, (S, M, TA,) he roared; (S, K, * TA;) and he uttered a sound; (K, TA;) and (TA) he made a grating sound with his canine teeth: (M, TA:) and, said of the faroj of a woman by reason of the act of UiylaAj, it made a sound. (IAar, O.) And, said of a sword, in a striking [therewith], It made a sound like qabo [q. v.]. (A.) ＝ -A2- Also, (said of a man, O) He was, or became, foolish, stupid, or unsound in intellect or understanding. (O, K.)

R. Q. 2 jayoXN yataqaboqabu c
R. Q. 2. jayoXN yataqaboqabu An army of which one part presses upon another. (TA in art. jEb.)

qabo c
qabo, (M, A, K,) or qabo qabo, (TA,) an expression imitative of The sound of the fall of a sword [upon an object struck therewith] (M, A, * K, TA) in fight. (TA.)

qabRN c
qabRN The perforation in which runs [or rather through which passes] the pivot of the maHaAlap [or great pulley]: (M, K:) or the hole which is in the middle of the bakorap [or sheave] (M, A, K) and around which the latter revolves: (A:) or the [sheave or] perforated piece of wood which revolves around the pivot: and its pl., in these senses, is OaqubRN, only: (M:) or the piece of wood above the teeth of the maHaAlap: (K, TA:) or [this is app. a mistake, or mistranscription, and the right explanation is] the piece of wood [i. e. the sheave] (S, O, TA) in the middle of the bakorap, (S, O,) above which are teeth (S, O, TA) of wood, (S, O,) the teeth of the mHAlp [between which teeth runs the well-rope]; thus says As. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse of Zuheyr cited voce vinaAyapN.] ― -b2- And The head [or truck] of the daqal [or mast] of a ship. (Az, TA in art. rnH.) ― -b3- And [app. as being likened to the pivot-hole of the sheave of a pulley,] (tropical:) A head, chief, or ruler, (S, M, A, O, K,) of a people, or party: (M, A:) or the greatest head or chief or ruler; (M;) or such is called AlqabRu AlOakobaru; (S, O;) and this appellation means the Xayox [or elder, &c.,] upon [the control of] whom the affairs of the people, or party, turn. (A.) And, (K,) some say, (M,) (assumed tropical:) A king: (M, K:) and, (K,) some say, (M,) a xaliyfap [q. v.]. (M, K.) [See also qibRN.] ― -b4- And [hence, perhaps,] (assumed tropical:) A faHol [i. e. stallion, or male,] of camels and of mankind. (O, K.) ― -b5- Also (assumed tropical:) The back-part of a coat of mail: so called because that part is its main support; from the qabR of a pulley. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) The piece, or pieces, inserted [i. e. sewed inside, next to the edge,] in the jayob [or opening at the neck and bosom] of a shirt. (A 'Obeyd, S, M, O, K.) [And in the present day it is likewise used to signify The collar of a shirt or similar garment; as also qabRapN↓.] ＝ -A2- Also The part between the two hips: (M, K:) or, between the two buttocks: (K:) or qabRu AldRuburi means what is between the two buttocks. (M.) See also qibRN. ＝ -A3- And The hardest, or most severe, (M, O, K,) and largest, (M, K,) of lujum [i. e. bits, or bridles; pl. of lijaAmN, q. v.]. (M, O, K.) ＝ -A4- And A certain measure for corn, or grain, or other kinds of the produce of land. (TA.) ＝ -A5- watarN qabRN means [app. A bow-string] of which the several TaAqaAt [or component fascicles of fibres or the like] are even. (A.)

qibRN c
qibRN, with kesr, The Xayox [or elder, &c.,] of a people, or party: (S, O, K:) but he is rather called qabR, with fet-h, as mentioned above. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And The bone that projects from the back, between the two buttocks; (S, O, K;) i. q. EajobN: (TA:) one says, Oaloziqo qibRaka biAlOaroDi, (S, O, TA,) but it is said that in a copy of the T, in the handwriting of its author, it is qabRaka↓, with fet-h, (TA,) [as it is also in a copy of the A.] i. e. [Make thou] thy Eajob [to cleave to the ground], (A, TA,) meaning (tropical:) sit thou. (A.)

qabRapN c
qabRapN: see qabRN, last quarter.

qubRapN c
qubRapN A certain kind of structure, (S, M, A, O, Msb, TA,) well known; (M, A, Msb, TA;) and applied to a round bayot [i. e. tent, or pavilion], well known among the Turkumán and the Akrád; (Msb;) it is what is called a xaroqaAhap [an Arabicized word from the Pers. xarokaAh]; (Mgh, Msb;) and signifies any round structure: (Mgh:) it is said to be a structure of skins, or tanned hides, peculiarly; (M, TA;) derived from qabRa AlXRaIoCa and qabRabahu meaning “ he collected, or gathered together, the extremities of the thing: ” (M:) accord. to IAth, it is a small round tent of the kind called xibaMC; of the tents of the Arabs: in the 'Ináyeh it is said to be what is raised for the purpose of the entering thereinto; and not to be peculiarly a structure: (TA:) [also a dome-like, or tent-like, covering of a woman's camel-vehicle of the kind called hawodaj: and a dome, or cupola, of stone or bricks: and a building covered with a dome or cupola:] the pl. is qibaAbN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and qubabN. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qubRapu AlsRanaAmi (assumed tropical:) [The round, protuberant, upper portion of the camel's hump]. (A, voce qaHadapN.) ― -b3- qubRapu AlUisolaAmi is an appellation of El-Basrah. (M, K.) ― -b4- And AlqubRapu is the name by which some of the Arabs call (assumed tropical:) The thirteen stars that compose the constellation of Corona Australis; because of their round form. (Kzw.)

qibRapu AlXRaApi c
qibRapu AlXRaApi, also pronounced without teshdeed [i. e. qibap], The Hafiv [q. v.] of the sheep or goat, (S, O, K,) which has OaTobaAq, [see, again, HafivN,] (S, O,) and which is the receptacle whereto the feces of the stomach finally pass. (TA.) [See also art. wqb.]

qubaAbN c
qubaAbN Sharp; (O, K;) applied to a sword and the like: (K:) from qabRa “ he cut off. ” (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A thick, large, nose. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- And, (M, O,) or qibaAbN↓, (K,) A species of fish, (M, O, K,) which is eaten, resembling the kanoEad. (M, O.)

qibaAbN c
qibaAbN: see what next precedes.

qabiybN c
qabiybN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. ＝ -A2- Also Dry herbage: like qafiyfN. (M.) ― -b2- And [The preparation of curd called] OaqiT of which the dry has been mixed with the fresh. (M, K.)

AlqabRaAbu c
AlqabRaAbu The lion; as also Almuqaboqibu↓. (O, K: in the CK the latter is written Almuqaboqab.)

HimaAru qabRaAna c
HimaAru qabRaAna [The wood-louse; thus called in the present day;] a certain insect, or small creeping thing; (S, O, K;) mentioned in art. Hmr [q. v.]; (Msb;) also called Eayoru qabRaAna; (K;) a small, smoothish, blackish thing, the head of which is like that of the [beetle termed] xunofasaMC, and long, and its legs are like those of the xnfsMC, than which it is smaller; and it is said that what is called Eyr qbRAn is party-coloured, black and white, with white legs, having a nose like that of the hedge-hog; when it is moved, it feigns itself dead, so that it appears like a [small] globular piece of dung; but when the voice is withheld, it goes away: (M, TA:) MF says that the appellation Eyr qbRAn is used only in poetry, in a case of necessity, for the sake of the metre; and is not mentioned in the lexicons of celebrity [except the K]. but it is mentioned in the M and the L: he says also that what is called HimaAru qabRaAna is said to be a species of the [beetles termed] xanaAfis [pl. of xunofasaMC] found between Mekkeh and El-Medeeneh: (TA:) [accord. to Dmr, it is a kind of six-footed insect, round, smaller than the black beetle, with a shield-shaped back, bred in moist places: (Golius:)] it is related on the authority of Jáhidh that one species thereof is called Oabuw XaHomK, which is the small [species] thereof; and that the people of El-Yemen apply the appellation HmAr qbRAn to a certain insect, or small creeping thing, above the size of a locust, of the same sort as the faraAX [generally meaning moth]: in the Mufradát of Ibn-El-Beytár, it is said that what is called HmAr qbRAn is also called HimaAru Albayoti: the reason for the appellation [HmAr qbRAn] seems to be because its back resembles a qubRap: (TA:) qabRaAn in this case is of the measure faEolaAn, from qabRa, (S, O, K,) because the Arabs imperfectly decline it, and they use it determinately; if it were of the measure faERaAl, they would decline it perfectly; the pl. is Humuru qabRaAna. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- qabRaAnN, syn. with qusoTaAsN, see in art. qbn.

AlqubRiyRuwna c
AlqubRiyRuwna, [in the CK AlqubiyRuwna,] occurring in a trad., in the saying xayoru AlnRaAsi AlqubRiyRuwna, means, (Th, O, K,) if the trad. be correct, (Th, O,) Those who continue uninterruptedly fasting [except in the night] until their bellies become lank: (Th, O, K:)
or, accord. to one relation, it is AlmuqabRabuwna↓, which means the same. (TA.)

AlqaAbRu c
AlqaAbRu and qaAbRa: see qubaAqibN, in three places.

qaAbRapN c
qaAbRapN A drop of rain: (AZ, ISk, S, M, A, O, K:) so in the saying maA raOayonaA AlEaAma qaAbRapF [We have not seen this year a drop of rain]: (AZ, ISk, S, O:) and maA OaSaAbatonaA AlEaAma qaAbRapN [Not a drop of rain has fallen upon us this year]. (ISk, S, M, * A, * O.) ― -b2- And Thunder; (A, K;) or the sound of thunder: so in the saying maA samiEonaA AlEaAma qaAbRapF [We have not heard this year the sound of thunder]; (ISk, S, M, A, * O;) accord. to As; but only he has related this. (ISk, S, O.) ＝ -A2- See also 8.

qaboqabN c
qaboqabN The belly; (S, M, O, K;) as also qaboqaAbN↓: (Suh, TA:) from qaboqabapN↓, [an inf. n. of R. Q. 1, q. v., and] a word imitative of the sounding [or rumbling] of the belly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And The wood of a horse's saddle: so in the saying,
yuTayRiru AlfaArisu lawo laA qaboqabuhu
[He would make the horseman to fly off, were it not for the wood of his saddle]. (M. [But in this sense it is app. a mistranscription for qayoqabN.]) ― -b2- And A species of trees; as also qaboqabaAnN↓. (M. [But in this sense both are app. mistranscriptions, for qayoqabN and qayoqabaAnN.])

qiboqibN c
qiboqibN A certain marine shell (O, K) wherein is a flesh [i. e. mollusk] which is eaten. (O.)

qaboqabapN c
qaboqabapN: see qaboqabN.

qaboqabaAnN c
qaboqabaAnN: see qaboqabN.

qaboqaAbN c
qaboqaAbN an inf. n. of R. Q. 1. [q. v.] ― -b2- Also A camel that brays much. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- And One who talks much; as also qubaAqibN↓: (M, * K, TA:) or one who talks much, whether wrongly or rightly: (M, * TA:) or one who talks much and confusedly. (M, K, * TA.) ― -b4- And A liar. (O, K.) ― -b5- See also qaboqabN. ― -b6- Also The faroj [meaning external portion of the organs of generation] (M, O, K) of a woman: (O:) or [a vulva] such as is [described as being] waAsiEN kaviyru AlmaMCi, (O, K,) [because] UicaA Oawolaja AlrRajulu cakarahu fiyhi qaboqaba OaIo SawRata. (IAar, O.) And they also used it as an epithet; [but in what sense is not expl.;] saying cakarN qaboqaAbN. (M.) ― -b7- And The [clog, or] wooden sandal: (O, K:) [app. because of the clattering sound produced by it:] of the dial. of El-Yemen: (O, TA:) [but now in common use; applied to a kind of clog, or wooden patten, generally from four to nine inches in height, and usually ornamented with mother-ofpearl, or silver, &c.; used in the bath by men and women; and by some ladies in the house:] in this sense the word is said to be post-classical. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) accord. to Az, (O,) The xarazap [app. a polished stone, or a shell,] with which cloths are glazed: (O, K:) but this is called qayoqaAb. (O.)

qubAqibN c
qubAqibN: see qaboqaAbN. ― -b2- Also, as an epithet applied to a man, (K,) i. q. jaAfK [Coarse, rough, or rude, of make, or of nature or disposition; &c.]. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- And AlqubaAqibu signifies AlEaAmu Almuqobilu [i. e. The year that is the next coming]: (K:) or [this is a mistake occasioned by an omission, and] its meaning is AlEaAmu AlRaciI baEoda AlEaAmi Almuqobili [the year that is after that which is the next coming]; you say, laA Mtiyka AlEaAma walaA qaAbila walaA qubaAqiba [I will not come to thee this year, nor next year, nor the year after the next]; and AO cites as an ex.
AlEaAmu waAlmuqobilu waAlqubaAqibu
[This year, and the next year, and the year after the next]: (S:) or qubaAqibN [without the art. Al and perfectly decl.] signifies [thus, i. e.] AlEAmu AlRaciI yaliI qaAbila EaAmika, and is a proper name of the year; whence the saying of Khálid Ibn-Safwán to his son, when he reproved him, UinRaka lano tufoliHa AlEaAma walaA qaAbilFA walaA qubaAqibFA walaA muqaboqibFA↓ [Verily thou wilt not prosper this year, nor next year, nor the year after the next, nor the year after that]; every one of these words being the name of the year after the year; thus related by As, who says that they know not what is after that: (M:) IB says that the statement of J is what is commonly known; i. e., that qubaAqib means the third year [counting the present year as the first], and that Almuqaboqibu↓ means the fourth year: but some make AlqaAbRu↓ the third year; and AlqubaAqibu, the fourth year; and Almuqaboqibu↓, the fifth year: (TA:) [thus Sgh says,] AlqaAbRu↓ is the third year: and Khálid Ibn-Safwán [is related to have] said, walaA qubaAqiba yaA bunaIRa UinRaka laA tufoliHu AlEaAma walaA qaAbila walaA qaAbRa↓ walaA muqaboqiba↓ [O my child (lit. my little son), verily thou wilt not prosper this year, nor next year, nor the year after the next, nor the year after that, nor the year after that]; (O, K; *) every one of these words being the name of the year after the year. (O.)

OaqabRu c
OaqabRu Lank in the belly: (S, O:) or slender in the waist, lank in the belly: (M:) fem. qabRaMCu, (S, M, A, O, K,) applied to a woman, (S, A, O,) meaning slender in the waist; (K;) or lank in the belly; (TA;) or lank in the belly, slender in the waist: (A:) and pl. qubRN, (S, A, O, K,) applied to horses, (S, A, O,) meaning lean, or light of flesh: (S, O:) and some say that OaqabRu applied to a horse signifies lank in his flanks. (M.)

muqabRabN c
muqabRabN, applied to a house, or chamber, Having a qubRp [q. v.] made above it. (S, O, K.) [And in like manner applied to a woman's camel-vehicle of the kind termed hawodaj: see 2. ― -b2- And it is also an epithet applied to a solid hoof; meaning Round like a cupola: see mufijRN, and see the first sentence in art. qEb.] ＝ -A2- surRapN muqabRabapN, (M, K, TA,) in a copy of the K erroneously written muqaboqabap, (TA,) A lean navel; as also maqobuwbapN↓. (M, K, TA.) ― -b2- See also AlqubRiyRuwna.

surRapN maqobuwbapN c
surRapN maqobuwbapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

muqaboqibN c
muqaboqibN: see AlqabRaAbu: ＝ -A2- and see also qubaAqibN, in four places.

qabojN c
qabojN, (S, M, MA, L, Msb, K, &c.,) or, accord. to MF, qabajN, (TA,) a Pers. word, arabicized, (S, M,) originally kabok, (M,) or kaPok, (MA,) The Hajal [i. e. partridge, or partridges]; (S, M, MA, L, Msb, K;) a coll. gen. n.: (S:) n. un. qabojapN; (S, MA, Msb;) which is applied to the male and to the female; (S, Msb, K;) yaEoquwbN being specially applied to the male. (S, Msb: [but see yaEoquwbN:]) pl. qibaAjN. (MA: in which qabojN is also termed a pl.) ― -b2- And The karawaAn [q. v., a name now given to the stone-curlew, or charadrius œdicnemus]. (M, L, TA.)

1 qabuHa c
1. qabuHa, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
qabuHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. quboHN↓, (Msb, K,) [or this, accord. to the S, seems to be a simple subst.,] and qaboHN (K) and qabaAHapN (S, K) and qubuwHapN and qubuwHN and qubaAHN, (K,) He, or it, (a form, and an action, L, and anything, T,) was, or became, bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous; contr. of Hasuna. (S, Msb, K, TA, &c.) One says of a man, qabuHa waXaquHa [app. using the latter v. as an imitative sequent]: and jaMCa biAlqabaAHapi waAlXRaqaAHapi [He did, or said, what was bad or evil &c.]. (K in art. XqH.) And AuqobuHo Uino kunota qaAbiHFA↓ Be thou bad or evil &c., if thou be desirous of becoming so: and qawoqa maA qabuHa maA huwa biqaAbiHK↓ He is not becoming bad &c., or will not become bad &c., above the degree in which he has become so: and in like manner one says in similar cases. (Lh, L.) ＝ -A2- laA taqobaHuwA Alwajoha, occurring in a trad., means Say not ye that the face is qabiyH [i. e. unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous]; because God formed it: or the meaning is, say not ye qabaHa QllRehu wajoha fulaAnK [expl. in what follows]. (L.) ― -b2- And qabaHahu QllRehu, (S, A, Msb, K, TA, &c., [in the CK qabRaHahu,]) aor.
qabaHa
, (Msb,) inf. n. qaboHN and qubuwHN, (AZ, L, TA,) God removed him, or may God remove him, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) far, (A, TA,) from good, or prosperity, (S, Msb, K,) or from all that is good; (L, TA;) [or from success, or the attainment of that which he deserves or seeks; (see the pass. part. n.;)] like as one does the dog and the pig: (AZ, L, TA:) [or God drove him away, or may God drive him away, like a dog: or God rendered him, or may God render him, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous, in form: (see, again, the pass. part. n.:)] and QllRehu qabRaHahu↓ has a similar, but intensive, signification. (Msb.) One says, qaboHFA lahu [an elliptical expression, a verb and its agent being understood, i. e., with these supplied, (May God decree) removal far from good, &c., to him; or (cause) removal &c. (to cleave) to him; meaning may removal &c. betide him]; (S;) and quboHFA↓ (S, A) also, (S,) with damm; (A;) [i. e. foulness,
unseemliness, unsightliness, ugliness, or hideousness;] and lahu waXuqoHFA quboHFA↓; (L, K, TA;) and qaboHFA lahu waXaqoHFA; in which XqHA is [said to be] an imitative sequent. (L, TA: but see art. XqH.) ― -b3- qabaHotu lahu wajohahu, [thus,] without teshdeed, means I said to him, qabaHa QllRehu wajohaka [i. e. May God remove thee far from good, &c., for wajohaka is here put for nafosaka, the phrase being] from AlqaboHu signifying “ the removing far [from good, &c.]. ” (AA, L. [See an ex. in a verse cited in art. sbH, conj. 2.]) ＝ -A3- And qabaHa (IAar, L, K, TA, [accord. to the CK qbRH, and so in one of two copies of the A, but the former is the right, as is shown by the form of the aor. in an ex. in the TA,]) He broke a purulent pustule (in his face, L,) in order that the matter might come forth: (L, K, TA:) or he squeezed a purulent pustule to express its contents before it was ripe: (A, TA:) and [in like manner] he broke an egg, (K,) or anything. (L.)

2 qbRHhu c
2. qbRHhu He (i. e. God) rendered him, or it, bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous. (L.) ― -b2- See also the preceding paragraph, near the middle. ― -b3- And He rejected, or reprobated, what he said, as bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (L.) ― -b4- And qbRH Ealayohi fiEolahu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqobiyHN, (S, K,) He showed, or declared, his deed to be bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly: (K:) said when a deed is such as is blamed. (Msb.)

3 qAbHhu c
3. qAbHhu, (A,) inf. n. muqaAbaHapN, (K, TA,) with which mukaAbaHapN is syn., (TA,) He reviled, or vilified, him, being reviled, or vilified, by him; or he vied, or contended, with him in reviling, or vilifying (A, K. *)

4 AqbH c
4. AqbH He did [or said] what was bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- maA OaqobaHa wajohahu is said in reviling a man [as meaning How foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous, is his face!]. (Ham p. 138.)

10 AstqbHhu c
10. AstqbHhu He regarded him, or it, as bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous; (TA;) contr. of AstHsnhu. (S, * K.)

quboHN c
quboHN [either an inf. n. or a simple subst.; much used as a simple subst., and maqaAbiHu↓, q. v., may be an anomalous pl. thereof, like as maHaAsinu is said to be of its contr. HusonN]: see 1, first sentence; and again, in two places, in the latter half.

AlqabaAHu c
AlqabaAHu: see the next following paragraph.

qabiyHN c
qabiyHN Bad, evil, abominable, foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous; contr. of HasanN; (S, L, Msb, K, &c.;) applied to a form, and to an action, (L,) and to anything: (T:) pl. qibaAHN and qabaAHaI and qaboHaI: fem. qabiyHapN; pl. qabaAYiHu and qibaAHN. (K.) ― -b2- naAqapN qabiyHapN AlXRuxobi A she-camel having wide orifices to her teats. (A, K.) ― -b3- AlqabiyHu [is said to signify] The extremity of the bone of the elbow; (S, TA;) so in the T; and the Uiborap is another small bone, the head of which is large, and the rest of it small, [the former, i. e. the head.] compactly joined to the qabiyH: (TA:) or [it is more correctly expl. as] the extremity of the bone of the upper half of the arm, next the elbow; (K, TA;) the extremity next the shoulderjoint being called AlHasanu, because of the abundance of the flesh that is upon it: (TA:) or the lower part of the upper half of the arm; the upper part being called AlHasanu: (Fr. TA:) or the qabiyHaAni are the two slender ends that are at the heads of the ciraAEaAni [here meaning the two bones of the fore arm; (TA:) or the qabiyH is the place of junction [of the bones] of the shank and the thigh, (K, TA,) which are termed qabiyHaAni; (TA;) and it is also called AlqabaAHu↓: (K, TA:) accord. to A'Obeyd, kisoru qabiyHK, (L, TA,) which is composed of two syn. words, one prefixed to the other, governing it in the gen. case, (L,) signifies the bone of the saAEid [here meaning the upper half of the arm] from the part next the middle to the elbow. (L, TA; and thus it is expl. in the S and K in art. ksr.)

qubRaAHN c
qubRaAHN A bear (K, TA) that is extremely aged, or old and weak. (TA.)

qaAbiHN c
qaAbiHN [as part, n. of qabuHa]: see 1, first quarter, in two places.

maqobuwHN c
maqobuwHN, of which the pl. occurs in the Kur [xxviii. 42]. (S, L, Msb,) Removed (S, Msb, K, TA) far (TA) from good, or prosperity, (S, K,) or from all that is good: (L, TA;) or from success, or the attainment of that which he desires or seeks; (Msb;) like as are the dog and the pig: (AZ, L, TA:) or driven away like a dog: (ISd, TA:) or rendered foul, unseemly, unsightly, ugly, or hideous, in form. (I'Ab, TA.) [See also maXoquwHN, in the first paragraph of art. XqH.]

maqaAbiHu c
maqaAbiHu Bad, evil, abominable, foul, or unseemly, qualities or dispositions [&c.]; contr. of [maHaAsinu and] mamaAdiHu. (L. [See quboHN.])

1 qabara c
1. qabara, aor.
qabura
and
qabira
, inf. n. qaborN (S, Msb, K) and maqobarN, (K,) He buried a corpse; (S, Msb, K:) concealed it in the earth. (TA.)

4 Aqbrhu c
4. Aqbrhu He made him to be buried: so in the Kur, lxxx. 21: (Fr, S:) where it is meant that man is not made by God to be thrown, when dead, to the dogs, (S,) or to the birds and wild beasts. (Fr.) ― -b2- He ordered that he should be buried. (S, Mgh, Msb.) ― -b3- [He permitted that he should be buried.] The tribe of Temeem said to El-Hejjáj, who had slain Sálih the son of 'Abder-Rahmán, OaqobironaA SaAliHFA, meaning, Permit us to bury Sálih. (S, * TA.) You say also Aqbr Alqawoma, meaning, He gave them their slain that they might burg him. (K.) ― -b4- He assigned to him, or made for him, a grave (ISk, S, Msb, K) to be buried in it: (S:) he made him to have a grave. (Mgh.) ― -b5- Accord. to some, He ordered him to dig a grave. (TA.)

qaborN c
qaborN A grave, tomb, sepulchre, or place of burial, of a human being: (K:) pl. qubuwr. (S, Msb, K.)

qubarN c
qubarN: see qabRarN.

qubRarN c
qubRarN (S, Msb, K) and qubarN↓ (K) and qunoburaMCu↓ (S, K) and funoburN↓, this last occurring in a Rejez, to be cited below, (S,) The [lark;] a kind of bird, (S, K,) resembling the HumRarap; (TA;) a kind of small bird; (Msb:) n. un. qubRarapN (S, Msb, K) and qubarapN (K) and qunoburapN, (S, Msb,) which last is the form used by the vulgar, (S,) or it is not allowable, or it is a form of weak authority, (K,) and is also pronounced qunobarapN: (Msb:) pl. of qnbrAC, (S, K,) and of qnbrp, (Msb,) qanaAbiru. (S, Msb, K.) AO cites, from a Rejez of Jendel Ibn-El-Muthennà Et- Tahawee,
jaMCa AlXRitaMCu waQjovaOalRa Alqunoburu
[The winter came, and the lark plumed himself]. (S.)

qunoburN c
qunoburN: see qubRarN.

qunoburaMCu c
qunoburaMCu: see qubRarN.

maqobarN c
maqobarN and maqoburN: see maqoburapN.

maqoburapN c
maqoburapN and maqobarapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and maqobirapN and miqobarapN (K) and maqobarN↓, (Lth, S, Mgh,) with fet-h only, (Mgh,) this last occurring in poetry, (S,) but agreeable with analogy, (IB,) and maqoburN↓. (MF, and TA voce OaluwkN, [under which see some remarks on words of this form in the present work,]) A cemetery, burial-place, or place of graves: (Msb, K:) or the place of a grave: (Mgh:) or the last of the above words has this latter signification: (Lth:) pl. (of mqbrp and mqbr, Mgh) maqaAbiru. (S, Mgh, Msb.)

maqobariIRN c
maqobariIRN and maqoburiIRN applied to a man [A keeper of a cemetery: or of a grave or tomb: or a gravedigger]. (S.)

1 qabasa naArFA c
1. qabasa naArFA, aor.
qabisa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. qabosN, (T, K,) He took fire, minohu [from him;] (K;) as also AqtbshA↓: (S, K:) or he took fire from the main mass thereof; (Msb;) as also Aqtbs↓ [alone]. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qabasa EilomFA, (and mina AlEilomi, TA,) (assumed tropical:) He acquired knowledge, minohu [from him;] (Ks, K, TA;) as also Aqtbshu↓: (Ks, S, K, TA:) or he learned knowledge; as also Aqtbs↓. (Msb.) ― -b3- [Hence also, qabasa HumRaI (assumed tropical:) He caught a fever from another; as also AqtbshA↓.] You say, hecihi HumRaI qabosK (assumed tropical:) This is a fever caught from another; not accidentally inbred: (A, TA:) but Sgh explains it differently, as signifying an accidental fever. (TA.) And AlHumRaI mino gayorihi walamo Aqtbs↓ taEoriDo lahu mino nafosihi (assumed tropical:) [He caught the fever from
another; and it did not accidentally come to him from himself]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- qabasa minohu naArFA, aor.
qabisa
, inf. n. qabosN, [He sought from him fire; (see its part. n., below;)] (S;) [and so Aqtbsh↓, for Aqtbs minohu naArFA; for you say,] AiqotabasonaA fulaAnFA faOabaI An yuqobisanaA, meaning, [We sought fire from such a one, and he refused] to give us fire. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, qabasa EilomFA (assumed tropical:) He sought knowledge; (see, again, its part. n., below;) and so Aqtbshu↓; as appears from an explanation of the part. n. of this latter also; and from the saying,] OataAnaA fulaAnN yaqotabisu AlEiloma faOaqobasonaAhu, meaning, (assumed tropical:) [Such a one came to us seeking knowledge, and] we taught him. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, qabasa AlnRaAra He lighted, or kindled, the fire. (IKtt.) ＝ -A4- See also 4, passim.

4 Aqbshu c
4. Aqbshu He gave him a qabas [a brand, or burning stick, or burning piece of fire-wood]: (S, K:) or he gave him fire: and qabasahu↓ he brought him fire: (TA:) and Aqbshu naArFA (Ks, S, Msb) he gave him fire; (S, * Msb, TA;) as also naArFA qabasahu↓. (Yz, Ks, IAar, S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Aqbshu (assumed tropical:) He taught him: (K:) and Aqbshu EilomFA, (Yz, Ks, IAar, S, A, Msb,) and xayorFA, (A, TA,) (assumed tropical:) he taught him knowledge, (S, * Msb, TA,) and (assumed tropical:) good; (TA;) as also EilomFA qabasahu↓, (Ks, IAar, S, A, Msb, TA,) and xayorFA: (A:) the latter verb is sometimes thus used; (IAar, TA;) or is allowable: (Ks, TA:) or only the former: (A:) [but it seems to be indicated in the TA, that you say. xayorFA qabasahu↓ as meaning (assumed tropical:) he brought him good:] and you say also maAlFA qabasahu↓ [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) he gave him property]. (IAar, TA.) ＝ -A2- Aqbs fulaAnFA naArFA He sought fire for such a one. (Yz, * S, * K.)

8 Uiqotabasa
8: see 1, passim.

qabasN c
qabasN Fire: (TA:) or a live coal: (Bd, xx. 10:) or [more commonly, and more properly, like nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN;] a firebrand (XuEolapN mino naArK, T, S, A, Msb, K, * and Bd ubi supra,) taken from the main mass of fire; (T, A, Msb, * K;) as also muqotabasN↓ and miqobasN↓ (A) and miqobaAsN↓: (S, A, Msb, K:) the last two [properly] signify a thing [such as a stick, or piece of fire-wood,] with which one has taken fire: (TA:) and qabasN is also explained as signifying a live coal, or piece of fire, (jicowapN mino naArK,) which one takes upon the end of a stick: (TA:) [and qabosapN↓ also signifies the same; as appears from an application thereof in the K, art. jcw, where Aljicowapu is explained by Alqabosapu mina AlnRaAri; and from the saying,] maA OanaA UilRaA qabosapN mino naArika [lit., I am nought but a piece from thy fire; app. meaning, my subsistence, or the like, is derived from thee]. (A, TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Alee, HatRaI OaworaI qabasa AlqaAbisi (assumed tropical:) So that he manifested a light of truth to the seeker thereof. (TA.)

qabosapN c
qabosapN [inf. n. of un. of 1; A single act of taking fire; &c. Hence the saying,] maA zurotuka UilRaA kaqabosapi AlEajolaAni [I did not visit thee save like the hasty person's single act of taking fire]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qabasN.

qaAbisN c
qaAbisN [act. part. n. of 1; Taking fire; a taker of fire; &c. Hence the saying,] maA Oanota UilRaA kAlqaAbisi AlEajolaAni [Thou art none other than like the hasty taker of fire]. (A.) ― -b2- [(assumed tropical:) Acquiring, or learning, knowledge; an acquirer, or a learner, of knowledge.] ＝ -A2- Seeking, or a seeker of, fire: pl. OaqobaAsN; its only broken pl. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) Seeking, or a seeker of, knowledge; as also muqotabisN↓. (TA.) ― -b3- AlqawaAbisu [pl. of AlqaAbisu, like as AlfawaArisu is pl. of AlfaArisu,] (assumed tropical:) Those who teach men what is good. (TA.)

maqobisN c
maqobisN The place of the fire-brand: i. e., firewood that has been lighted: or charcoal that has become hard; opposed to HumamapN, which is [a piece of] charcoal that does not hold together: pl. maqaAbisu. (Msb.)

miqobasN c
miqobasN: see qabasN.

miqobaAsN c
miqobaAsN: see qabasN.

muqotabasN c
muqotabasN: see qabasN.

muqotabisN c
muqotabisN: see qaAbisN.

1 qabaSahu c
1. qabaSahu, aor.
qabiSa
, (M, A, K,) inf. n. qaboSN, (S, M,) He took it with the ends of his fingers; (S, M, A, K;) the action which it denotes being less than that termed qaboDN; (M;) the latter signifying the “ taking with the whole of the hand; ” (Bd, xx. 96;) as also qbSRhu↓, (Ibn-'Abbád, K,) inf. n. taqobiySN. (TA.) Thus, accord. to one reading, [in the Kur, xx. 96,] faqabaSotu qaboSapF mino Oavari AlrRasuwli; (S, M, A, TA;) and, accord. to another, quboSapF; (TA;) [in each] with S [in both instances] instead of D, with which the passage is commonly read; (TA;) meaning, [And I took with the ends of my fingers somewhat] of the dust from the footstep of the horse of the messenger Gabriel. (Jel.) [But see qbD.] You say also, quboSapF UiqotabaSotu↓ [I took for myself somewhat with the ends of my fingers]. (A.) And mino OanowaArika jiYotu liOaqotabisa↓ waOaqotabiSa mino MvaArika (tropical:) [I came to acquire of thy lights of knowledge, and pick up somewhat of thy traditions]. (A.)

2 qabRaSa
2: see 1.

8 UiqotabaSa
8: see 1, in two places.

qaboSN c
qaboSN: see qiboSN, throughout.

qiboSN c
qiboSN A great number (AO, S, M, K) of men or people; (S, K;) as also qaboSN↓: (M, TA:) thus applied it is like a dim. applied to that which is esteemed great. (El-Fáïk, O.) You say, UinRahumo lafiI qiboSi AlHaSaI Verily they are numerous as the pebbles. (TA.) And huwa fiI qiboSi AlHaSaI, and qaboSihaA↓, He is in, or among, a multitude that cannot be numbered. (O, TA.) [See also a verse of ElKumeyt cited in the first paragraph of art. vrw.] ― -b2- A place where a number is collected together of ants; as also qaboSN↓: (M:) and of bees; as also the latter word: (TA:) or where a great number of ants is collected together: (El-'Eyn, TA:) or where a great quantity of sand is collected together; as also the latter word. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

qaboSapN c
qaboSapN What one takes with the ends of his fingers; as also quboSapN↓, (K,) and qabiySapN↓: (S, Msb:) [in the L, qubayoSapN; but this is the dim. of the first and second of the above words:] or, accord. to some, the first is a noun signifying the act [of so taking]: (M:) and the second, (M,) or this and the first also, (K,) signifies what one's two hands carry, of food, or wheat: (M, K:) the pl. of quboSapN↓ is qubaSN. (TA.)

quboSapN c
quboSapN: see qaboSapN, throughout.

qabiySN c
qabiySN: see what next follows.

qabiySapN c
qabiySapN: see qaboSapN. ― -b2- Also, (M, K,) and qabiySN↓, (M, TA,) Dust, or earth, (M, K,) and pebbles, (Ibn-'Abbád, K, TA,) collected together. (M, K, TA.)

qaAbiSapN c
qaAbiSapN sing. of qawaAbiSu; which signifies Bodies [of men]; syn. TawaAYifu; and a number collected together. (TA.)

1 qabaDahu c
1. qabaDahu, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb,) or qabaDahu biyadihi, (O, K,) aor.
qabiDa
, (A, Msb, K,) inf. n. qaboDN, (S, Msb,) He took it with his hand, (A, O, K,) by actual touch, or feel: (O:) or the former signifies he closed his hand upon it: (Lth:) [he grasped it; griped it; clutched it; seized it:] or he took it with the whole of his hand: (Bd, xx. 96:) or i. q. Oajacahu [he took it in any manner: he took it with his hand: he took possession of it: and he received it]: (S, M, Mgh, Msb:) and qabaDa Ealayohi, and bihi, (M,) or qabaDa Ealayohi biyadahi, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) he grasped it, clutched it, laid hold upon it, or seized it, with his hand; syn. Oamosakahu: (A, K:) or he seized it (OanoHaI Ealayohi) with the whole of his hand: (M:) or he closed, or contracted, his fingers upon it: (Mgh, Msb:) it is also said, by MF, that some assert qaboDN to signify the “ taking with the ends of the fingers; ” but this is a mistranscription, for qaboDN, with the unpointed S. (TA [in which it is said, in another place in this art., that taqobiyDN↓ has also this last signification; but this is evidently, in like manner, a mistranscription, for taqobiyDN.]) You say, qabaDa AlmataAEa [He took, or received, the commodity, or the commodities, or goods]. (A.) And qabaDa minohu AldRayona [He took, or received, from him the debt]. (M, K, in art. qDI; &c.). And it is said in the Kur, [xx. 96,] faqabaDotu qaboDapF mino Oavari AlrRasuwli, (M,) and, accord. to an extraordinary reading, qabiyDapF↓, (B,) meaning [And I took a handful] of the dust from the footstep of the hoof of the horse of the messenger [Gabriel]: (IJ, M:) and UiqotabaDa↓
mino Oatarihi qaboDapF signifies the same as qabaDa: and qabaSa [q. v.] is [said to be] a dial. form thereof. (TA.) And you say, qabaDa AlTRaAYira He collected, or comprehended, the bird in his grasp. (A.) And qabaDa EalaI Eurofi Alfarasi [He grasped, or laid hold upon, the mane of the horse]. (A.) ― -b2- It is also used metaphorically, to denote the having an absolute property in a thing, to dispose of it at pleasure, without respect to the hand; as in the phrase qabaDotu AlOaroDa, and AldRaAra, (tropical:) I had, or took, or got, possession of the land, and of the house. (TA.) And [in like manner] it is said in a trad., yaqobiDu QllRehu AlOaroDa, and AlsRamaMCa, (assumed tropical:) God will comprehend, or collect together, [within his sole possession, (see quboDapN,)] the earth, and the heaven. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, qabaDa EalaI gariymihi (tropical:) [He arrested his debtor: used in this sense in the present day]. (A.) And qabaDa QllRehu ruwHahu (tropical:) God took his soul. (TA.) And qabaDahu QllRehu (tropical:) God caused him to die. (Msb.) And qubiDa (tropical:) He (a man, S, M, A) died: (S M, A, * K:) and also (assumed tropical:) he (a sick man) was at the point of death; in the state of having his soul taken; in the agony of death. (L, TA.) And qabaDotuhu Eani AlOamori (assumed tropical:) I removed him from the thing, or affair. (Msb.) ― -b3- qabaDahu, aor. as above, (M, K,) and so the inf. n., (S, M, Mgh,) also signifies the (assumed tropical:) contr. of basaTahu; (S, * M, Mgh, * K;) and so qbRDhu↓, (IAar, M,) inf. n. taqobiyDN. (TA.) [As such, (assumed tropical:) He contracted it; or drew it together.] You say, qabaDa rijolahu wabasaTahaA (tropical:) [He contracted his leg, and extended it]. (A.) And qabaDa kafRahu [He clenched his hand]. (S, Mgh, Msb, K, in art. brjm.). And qabaDa yadahu Eanohu (assumed tropical:) [He drew in his hand from it: or] he refrained from laying hold upon it. (K.) Whence the saying in the Kur, [ix. 68,] wayaqobiDuwna Oayodiyahumo, meaning (assumed tropical:) [And they draw in their hands, or refrain,] from expenditure, or from paying the [poor-rate called] zakaAp. (TA.) You say also, janaAHahu qbRD↓ (assumed tropical:) He (a bird) contracted his wing: (M:) or qabaDa, or qabaDa janaAHahu, (assumed tropical:) he contracted his wing to fly. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) qabaDa, aor. as above; (S, K;) or qabuDa (M;) [or both;] inf. n. [of the former] qaboDN (S, K,) and [of the latter, as indicated in the M,] qabaADapN (S, M, A, K) and qabaADN; (M;) (tropical:) He (a bird, S, K, and a horse, A, and a man, S, or other [animal], K,) was quick, (S, M, A, K,) in flight, or in going or pace. (K.) yaqobiDona, said of birds, in the Kur, [lxvii. 19,] is [said to be] an ex. of this signification. (S, K. *) You say also, qabaDati AlUibilu (tropical:) The camels were quick in their pace; at every spring therein, putting their legs together. (A.) And UinoqabaDa↓ (tropical:) He, or it, (a company of men, M,) went, or journeyed, and was quick. (Lth, M, K.) And fiI fulaAnN UinoqabaDa↓ HaAjatihi (tropical:) Such a one was quick, and light, or active, in accomplishing his want. (A.) And qaboDN also signifies i. q. nazowN (assumed tropical:) [The act of leaping, &c.]. (TA.) ― -b4- [Also, as contr. of basaTahu,] (assumed tropical:) He collected it together. (Az.) And hence, (Az,) qabaDa AlUibila, (Az, M,) aor.
qabiDa
, inf. n. qaboDN (Az, S, M) (assumed tropical:) He drove (Az, S, M) the camels violently, or roughly, (Az, M.) or quickly: (S:) because the driver collects them together, when he desires to drive them; for when they disperse themselves from him, the driving of them is difficult: (Az, TA:) and bihaA UinoqabaDa↓ [signifies the same, or, agreeably with an explanation given above, (tropical:) he went quickly with them]. (M.) And AlEayoru yaqobiDu EaAnatahu (assumed tropical:) The he-ass drives away his she-ass. (M.) ― -b5- [As such also,] qabaDahu; (A;) and qbRDhu↓, (S, M, K,) inf. n. taqobiyDN; (S;) (tropical:) He, or it, drew it, collected it, or gathered it, together; contracted it, shrank it, or wrinkled it. (S, M, A, * K.) You say, qabaDa wajohahu (tropical:) He, or it, contracted, or wrinkled, his face]. (A.) And qabaDati AlnRaAru Aljilodapa (tropical:) [The fire contracted, shrank, or shrivelled, the piece of skin]. (A.) And qabRaDa↓ maA bayoni Eayonayohi (assumed tropical:) He contracted, or wrinkled, the part between his eyes. (M, TA.) And yawomN yuqabRiDu↓ maA bayona AlEayonayoni (assumed tropical:) [A day that contracts, or wrinkles, the part between the eyes]; a metonymical phrase, denoting vehemence of fear, or of war. (M, TA. *) And in like manner you say, AlHaXaI yawomN yuqabRiDu↓ (assumed tropical:) [A day that contracts the bowels]. (M.) [And hence qabaDa, aor. and inf. n. as first mentioned, (assumed tropical:) It (a medicine, or food, &c.,) astringed, or constipated. And (assumed tropical:) It (food) was astringent in taste; as also taqabRaDa↓.] ― -b6- As such also, qabaDahu, signifies (assumed tropical:) He straitened it; scanted it; made it scanty. (Msb, TA.) You say, qabaDa QllRehu Alrizoqa, aor. and inf. n. as first mentioned, (assumed tropical:) God straitened, scanted, or made scanty, the means of subsistence. (Msb.) And it is said in the Kur, [ii. 246,] waQllRehu yaqobiDu wayabosuTu (assumed tropical:) And God straitens, or scants, or makes scanty, the means of subsistence, to some, (Bd, Msb, * TA, *) or withholds the means of subsistence from whom He will, (Jel,) and amplifies, enlarges, or makes ample or plentiful, the same, (Bd, Msb, Jel, TA,) to some, (Bd, TA,) or to whom He will. (Jel.) ― -b7- [As such also, (assumed tropical:) He abridged his liberty.] You say, fulaAnN yabosuTu gabiydahu vumRa yaqobiDuhumo (tropical:) [Such a one enlarges the liberty of his slaves; then abridges their liberty]. (A.) ― -b8- [As such also, (tropical:) He, or it, contracted his heart; i. e. distressed him; grieved him.] You say, UinRahu yaqobiDuniI maA yaqobiDuka wayabosuTuniI maA yabosuTuka (tropical:) Verily what distresses thee, or grieves thee, distresses, or grieves, me; and what rejoices thee rejoices me]. (A.) [And it is related in a trad., that Mohammad said, faATimapu minRiI yaqobiDuniI maA qabaDahaA wayabosuTuniI maA basaTahAa (tropical:) [Fátimeh is as though she were a part of me: what hath distressed her, or grieved her, distresses, or grieves, me; and what hath rejoiced her rejoices me]. (TA.) Or the phrase UinRahu layaqobiDuniI maA qabaDaka, mentioned by Lth, means (assumed tropical:) Verily what hath annoyed and angered thee annoys and angers me. (Az, TA.) qaboDN and basoTN are terms applied by the investigators of truth among the Soofees to two contrary states of the heart, from both of which it is seldom or never free: the former being an affection of the heart withholding it from dilatation and joy; whether the cause thereof be known, as the remembrance of a sin or an offence, or of an omission, or be not known; and some of them make other divisions thereof. (TA.) [In like manner] you say also, EanRaA famaA qabaDaka AinoqabaDotu↓ (tropical:) [Thou shrankest from us: and what made thee to shrink?]. (A.) ― -b9- [As such also, (tropical:) He, or it, made him close-fisted, tenacious, or niggardly.] You say, Alxayoru yaqobiDuhu waAlXRarRu yabosuTuhu (tropical:) [Wealth makes him close-fisted, tenacious, or niggardly; and poverty makes him open-handed, liberal, or generous]. (A.)

2 qabRaDa
2: see a remark appended to the first sentence in this art.: ― -b2- see also fabaDahu as contr. of basaTahu, in six places. ― -b3- qabRaDahu AlmaAla, (S, * M, K, *) or AlmataAEa, (A,) inf. n. taqobiyDN, (S, K,) He gave to him, (S, M, K,) in his grasp, or possession, (K,) i. e. to him who should receive it, (S,) the property, (S, M,) or commodity, or commodities, or goods; (A;) i. e. he transferred it to his possession; (TA;) [lit. he made him to take it, to take it with his hand, to grasp it, or to receive it;] as also UiyRaAhu OaqobaDahu↓. (A.)

3 qAbDhu c
3. qAbDhu, inf. n. muqaAbaDapN (AZ, A) and qibaADN, (Er-Rághib, TA in art. XrI,) He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him. (AZ, in TA, art, xwS.) [See also qaAyaDahu.]

4 AqbDhu AlmataAEa c
4. AqbDhu AlmataAEa [or AlmaAla]: see 2. ＝ -A2- AlqbDhu He put, or made, a handle to it, (S, M, A, K,) namely a knife, (S, M, A,) and a sword. (S, K.)

5 tqbRD c
5. tqbRD quasi-pass. of qabRaDahu as contr. of basaTahu; (M;) as also AinoqabaDa↓ is of qabaDahu in the same sense, (S, * M, K, *) being contr. of AinobasaTa. (S, K.) [As such,] both signify (assumed tropical:) It became drawn, collected, or gathered, together; or it drew, collected, or gathered, itself together; or contracted; or shrank; syn. of the former, tajamRaEa; (TA;) and of the latter, AinoDamRa [which also signifies it became drawn and joined, or adjoined, to another thing; &c.]. (O, K.) So the latter signifies in the phrase fiI HaAjatiI AnqbD↓ (assumed tropical:) [It became comprised in, or adjoined to, the object of my want]. (O.) ― -b2- [As such also,] the former signifies (tropical:) It (a man's face, A, or the part between the eyes, M,) became contracted, or wrinkled; (M, A; *) and in like manner a piece of skin, in, or upon, a fire; meaning it became contracted, shrunken, or shrivelled; it shrank: (so in different copies of the S:) or it (skin, K, or the skin of a man, TA) became contracted, or shrunken; (K, TA;) and so an old man. (A.) ― -b3- [As such also,] taqbRD Eanohu (tropical:) He shrank, or shrank with aversion, from him, or it; (S, M, A, K;) as also Eanohu AinoqabaDa↓: (A:) [see an ex. of the latter near the end of 1.] AlAinoqibaADu↓ Eani AlnRaAsi also signifies (assumed tropical:) The withdrawing, removing, or retiring, from men. (TA.) And Eani AlOamori AinoqabaDa↓ (assumed tropical:) He removed, or became
removed, from the thing, or affair. (Msb.) ― -b4- tqbRD EalaI AlOamori (tropical:) He paused, or waited, at the thing, or affair; syn. tawaqRafa. (M, A.) ― -b5- tqbRD Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) He leaped, or sprang, towards him. (Sgh, K.) ― -b6- See also 1; last third of the paragraph.

6 tqAbD AlmutayaAyiEaAni c
6. tqAbD AlmutayaAyiEaAni [The two parties in an affair of traffic bartered, or exchanged commodities, each with the other: see 3]. (A.)

7 AnqbD c
7. AnqbD It (a thing) became maqobuwD [meaning taken, taken with the hand, grasped, or received]. (S.) ― -b2- See also 5, in six places. ― -b3- And see 1, in three places, about the middle of the paragraph.

8 AqtbDhu linafosihi c
8. AqtbDhu linafosihi [He took it, took it with his hand, grasped it, clutched it, seized it, took possession of it, or received it, for himself]. (A.) See an ex. in 1, before the first break in the paragraph.

qaboDN c
qaboDN The act of taking, taking with the hand; [grasping; clutching; seizing;] taking possession of; or receiving. (S, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence], Possession; (S, TA;) as also qaboDapN↓: (S, M, Mgh, Msb, TA:) or the latter is a n. un. [signifying an act of taking, or taking with the hand; a grasp; a seizure; &c.]. (TA.) You say, SaAra AlXRaIoCu fiI qaboDika, and qaboDatika↓, The thing became in thy possession. (S, M. *) And hecihi AldRaAru fiI qaboDiI, (TA,) and qaboDatiI↓, (M, TA,) This house is in my possession; (M, TA;) like as you say, fiI yadaI. (TA.)

qabaDN c
qabaDN i. q. maqobuwDN; (Mgh, K;) like hadamN in the sense of mahoduwmN, and nafaDN in the sense of manofuwDN; (TA;) meaning What is taken, of articles of property (S, M) of people: (S:) what is collected, (Lth,) or taken and collected, (Mgh,) of spoils, before they are divided. (Lth, Mgh.) You say, daxala maAlu fulaAnK fiI AlqabaDi The property of such a one entered into what was taken of the articles of property of the people. (S.) And UiToraHahu fiI AlqabaDi (A, Mgh) Throw thou it among the things that have been taken: (Mgh:) said to Saad Ibn-Abee- Wakkás, when he slew Sa'eed Ibn-El-'Ás, and took his sword: so in a trad. (TA.) And in another trad. it is said, juEila salomaAnu EalaI qabaDK Selmán was set over spoils that were taken and yet undivided, to guard and divide them. (Mgh.)

qaboDapN c
qaboDapN: [pl. qabaDaAtN:] see qaboDN, in three places. ― -b2- See also quboDapN, in four places. ― -b3- And see maqobiDN. ― -b4- Also, [The measure of a man's fist, from side to side;] four finger-breadths; (Mgh, Msb, voce jariybN;) the sixth part of the common ciraAE [or cubit: but in the present day, the measure of a man's fist with the thumb erect; which is about six inches and a quarter]: pl. qabaDaAtN. (Mgh, Msb, vocibus ciraAEN and jariybN.)

quboDapN c
quboDapN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) [A handful;] what one takes with the hand, or grasps; (S, K;) mino kacaA [of such a thing]; (Mgh;) as, for instance, mino sawiyqK [of meal of parched barley]; (S;) or mino tamorK [of dates]; (S, A, Msb;) i. e. kafRAF; (S;) as also qaboDapN↓; (S, M, A, K;) but the former is the more common; (S, K;) and qabiyDapN↓: (B:) or the first is a subst. in the sense of maqobuwDN, and the second is a n. un.: (TA:) the pl. of the first is qubaDN. (TA.) You say also, kafRiI hecaA qaboDapu↓ This is the quantity that my hand grasps. (M.) See two other exs. of the second word, and an ex. of the third, in 1, before the first break in the paragraph. It is also said in the Kur, [xxxix. 67,] waQloOaroDu jamiyEFA yawoma AlqiyaAmapi qaboDatuhu↓, i. e. quboDatuhu, for qaboDapN is an inf. n. [of un.] used as a subst., or is for caAtu qaboDapK, (Bd,) and the literal signification is, [And the earth altogether shall be] his handful [on the day of resurrection]; (Bd, Jel;) meaning in his possession (Jel, TA) alone, (TA,) and at his free and absolute disposal: (Jel:) Th says, that this is like the phrase hecihi AldRaAru fiI qaboDatiI, meaning as explained above, voce qaboDN; but this opinion is not valid:) (M:) another reading is qaboDatahu↓, in the accus. case, (M, Bd,) as an adv. n.; that which is determinate being thus likened to what is vague; (Bd;) and this is allowed by some of the grammarians; but it is not allowed by any one of the grammarians of El-Basrah. (M.) It is also said, in the trad. of Bilál and the dates, fajaEala yajiIoCu bihi qubaDFA qubaDFA [And he set about bringing them (the pronoun referring to AltRamor the dates) handfuls by handfuls]. (TA.)

qubaDapN c
qubaDapN, (K,) or qubaDapN rufaDapN, (S, M, A, TA,) to this latter, not to the former alone, the following explanation applies, (TA,) A man who lays hold upon a thing, and then leaves it without delay. (S, M, A, K.) And the former, A pastor who draws his sheep or goats together, not going far and wide in pasturing them: (S:) or who manages well (A, K) for his sheep or goats, (K,) or for his beasts, collecting them together, and, when he finds a place of pasture, spreads them abroad: (A:) and the latter, a pastor who manages well, and is gentle with his pasturing beasts, collecting them together and driving them, when their place of pasturage becomes wanting in herbage, and, when they light upon a piece of herbage, leaves them to spread abroad and pasture at pleasure: (Az, TA:) or who collects together his camels, and drives them until he brings them whithersoever he will. (M.) [See also art. rfD.]

qabiyDN c
qabiyDN: see qaAbiDN, in three places.

qabiyDapN c
qabiyDapN: see quboDapN, in two places.

qabRaADN c
qabRaADN: see qaAbiD; each in two places.

qabRaADapN c
qabRaADapN: see qaAbiDN; each in two places.

qaAbiDN c
qaAbiDN Taking with the hand: [or in any manner: taking possession of: receiving: (see 1:)] grasping, clutching, or seizing, with the hand: and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] qabRaADN↓: (K:) or the latter is of the dial. of the people of El-Medeeneh, applied to him who [grasps or] collects everything: (Aboo-'Othmán El-Mázinee:) and qbRaADapN↓ [which is doubly intensive]; (K;) the p in this last not denoting the fem. gender. (TA.) qaAbiDu AlOarowaAHi [(tropical:) The taker of the souls] is an appellation of [the Angel of Death,] 'Izrá-eel, or 'Azrá-eel. (TA.) And AlqaAbiDu, one of the names of God, signifies (tropical:) The Withholder [or Straitener or Scanter] of the means of subsistence, and of other things, from his servants, by his graciousness and his wisdom: and the Taker of souls, at the time of death. (TA.) ― -b2- A bird (assumed tropical:) contracting his wing to fly. (TA.) And hence, (TA,) qaAbiDN (S, K) and qabiyDN↓ (S, A, K) A bird, (K,) or horse, (A,) or other [animal], (K,) (tropical:) quick (A, K) in flight, or in going or pace: (K:) or a man (assumed tropical:) light, or active, and quick: (S:) and [hence, app.,] the latter also signifies (assumed tropical:) an intelligent man, who keeps, or adheres, to his art, or work. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.) And AlXRadRi qabiyDu↓ A horse, (S, K, in [some of] the copies of the K “ a man, ” which is a mistake, though it seems to be also applied to a man, TA,) or a beast of carriage, (L,) (assumed tropical:) quick in the shifting of the legs from place to place [in running]. (S, L, K.) ― -b3- A camel-driver (assumed tropical:) driving quickly; a quick driver; and in like manner, [but in an intensive sense,] qabRaADN↓, and [in a doubly intensive sense] qabRaADapN↓: (S:) or the last signifies (assumed tropical:) driving away vehemently; the p denoting intensiveness; and is applied to an ass driving away his she-ass, and to a camel-driver. (M.) [See an ex. of the first, voce EaAYiDF, in art. EwD.] ― -b4- [Applied to medicine, food, &c., (assumed tropical:) Astringent, or constipating.]

maqobaDN c
maqobaDN A place of taking, taking with the hand, [grasping, clutching, seizing,] or receiving: extr. [in form, for by rule it should be maqobiDN]. (M.) See also what next follows.

maqobiDN c
maqobiDN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and maqobaDN↓, (Lth, M, Msb, K,) but the former is the more common and the better known, (Lth,) and miqobaDN↓, (M, K,) and with p, (K,) i. e. maqobiDapN↓, and miqobaDapN↓, (M,) The handle; or part where it is grasped, (S, M, A, * Mgh, * Msb, K,) by the hand, (Msb,) or with the whole hand; (S;) of a sword, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and qaboDapN↓ is said to signify the same; (TA;) or of a knife, (M, A,) and of a bow, (S, A,) and of a whip, (A,) &c., (K,) or of anything: (M:) or maqobiDapN↓ or miqobaDapN↓ signifies the place of the hand of a spear or spear-shaft: (ISh:) pl. maqaAbiDu. (A.)

miqobaDN c
miqobaDN: see maqobaDN.

maqobiDapN c
maqobiDapN and miqobaDapN: see maqobiDN, in two places.

maqobuwDN c
maqobuwDN pass. part. n. of qabaDahu. See qabaDN, and quboDapN. ― -b2- (tropical:) Taken to the mercy of God; (A;) dead. (S.)

mutaqabRiDN c
mutaqabRiDN: see what next follows.

munoqabRiDN c
munoqabRiDN, (O, TS,) or mataqabRiDN↓, (K,) A lion prepared to spring: (K:) or a lion drawn together: and one prepared to spring: (O, TA:) but the conjunction should rather be omitted. (TA.)

1 qabaTahu c
1. qabaTahu, aor.
qabiTa
, so in the margin of a copy of the S, (TA,) inf. n. qaboTN, (TS, O, K,) He collected it together, or comprehended it, with his hand: (TS, O, K:) [like qabaDahu:) in the TS given as on the authority of IDrd: in the O as on that of IF. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, inf. n. as above, He mixed it. (TA.)

2 qabRaTa
2: [qbRT wajohahu He contracted his face much; made it much contracted, or very austere or morose:] taqobiyTu Alwajohi is syn. with taqobiyTuhu; (Yaa- koob, K;) and is formed from the latter by transposition. (TA.)

AlqiboTu c
AlqiboTu [The Copts; often called by themselves AlquboTu;] a certain people, or nation, in Egypt; (TA;) the original, or genuine, people of Egypt; (S, K, TA;) the Christians of Egypt: (Msb:) n. un. qiboTiIRN↓; (S, Msb, K;) fem. with p: (Msb, K:) you say UimoraOapN qiboTiyRapN [A Copt woman]: (Msb:) and jamaAEapN qiboTiyRapN and OaqobaATN [A company of Copts; AqbAT being a pl. of qiboTN]. (TA.) [See quboTiIRN.] Authors differ respecting their pedigree: some say, that AlqiboTu was son of HaAm [or Ham], son of nuwH [or Noah]: the author of the Shejereh, that miSoraAYiym [or Mizraïm] the son of HAm left issue from luwciym [or Ludim], and that lwcym are the qiboT of Egypt, in the Sa'eed: Aboo-Háshim Ahmad Ibn-Jaafar El-'Abbásee, the genealogist, says, that they are the children of qiboT son of miSor son of quwT [a mistranscription for fuwT, the Phut of the English Bible, A. V.,] son of HAm: and this is verified by Ibn-El-Joowánee the genealogist. (TA.)

quboTiIRN c
quboTiIRN A kind of thin, or fine, (Mgh, Msb,) white, (Mgh,) cloth, (Mgh, Msb,) of linen, (Msb,) made in Egypt; so called in relation to the qiboT, irregularly, to distinguish between it and the man, who is called qiboTiIRN: (Mgh, Msb:) so says Lth, respecting these two forms: (TA:) you also say, viyaAbN qiboTiyRapN↓, with kesr; but when you convert the rel. n. into a subst, you say quboTiyRapN, with damm, to distinguish the subst. from the rel. n. without vyAb; like as you say, rimaAHN xaTRiyRapN, and xiTRiyRapN, with kesr, when you do not mention the rmAH: so says Kh: (Msb in art. xT:) it is said in the K, that AlquboTiyRapu, with damm, signifies a kind of cloths, so called in relation to the qiboT; and sometimes it is with kesr; which is a plain assertion that the form with damm is the more common: but in the S it is said, that AlqiboTiyRipu signifies certain white, thin, or fine, cloths, of linen, made in Egypt; and sometimes it is with damm, because they make a change in the rel. n., as in suholiIRN and duhoriIRN, which (as SM adds) are from saholN and dahorN; and this indicates that the regular form, with kesr, is the more common: (TA:) the pl. is qabaATiIRN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and qabaATiI: (K [but the latter, being indeterminate, should be written qabaATK, like mahaArK &c.:]) Sh says, that the qabaATiIR are a kind of cloths inclining to fineness and thinness and whiteness. (TA.)

qiboTiIRN c
qiboTiIRN and qiboTiyRapN: see AlqiboTu and quboTiIRN.

qubayoTaMCu c
qubayoTaMCu: see what next follows.

qubRaATN c
qubRaATN: see what next follows.

qubRayoTN c
qubRayoTN: see what next follows.

qubRayoTaI c
qubRayoTaI and qubayoTaMCu↓, the former with teshdeed and with a short final alif, and the latter without teshdeed and with a long final alif, (S, Msb, K, *) and qubRayoTN↓ and qubRaATN↓, (S, K,) i. q. naATifN; (S, Msb, K;) [described by Golius, on the authority of an Arabic and Persian vocabulary, entitled ktAb AlsAmI fI AlAsAmI, as a very white kind of sweetmeat, which consists of juice of grapes, with an addition of other things, cooked so that it becomes white and hard:] derived from qaboTN signifying the act of “ collecting together. ” (TA.)

qunRabiyTN c
qunRabiyTN: see art. qnbT.

dictScrap.label: qbE qbl qbn qbw: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qatRa c
1. qatRa, (M, K, *) or qatRa AlHadiyva or AlOaHaAdiyva, (S, O, TA,) aor.
qatuta
, (S, M, O,) inf. n. qatRN, (S, M, O, K,) with which qitRiytaI↓ is syn. [either as an inf. n., app. in an intensive sense, or as a simple subst.]; (O, K;) and so too is taqotiytN [as inf. n. of qtRt↓], (K,) or so is taqotiytu AlHadiyvi; (O;) and so is qatoqatapN [as inf. n. of qatofata↓], (K,) or so is qatoqatapu AlHadiyvi; (O;) i. q. namRa, (M,) or namRa AlHadiyva (S, O, K, * TA) or AlOaHaAdiyva, (S, O, TA,) i. e. [He uttered calumny; or] he made known, divulged, or told, discourse, or conversation, in a malicious, or mischievous, manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like; (TA;) or qatRa AlHadiyva signifies he falsified and embellished discourse, or conversation: (A:) it is said that AlqatR, which signifies AlnRamiymapu [i. e. the uttering, or utterance, of calumny], (M, L,) [and] so does AlqitRiytaI↓, (S,) is from AlHadiyva tqtRt↓, meaning he sought time after time to obtain a knowledge of discourse, or conversation, and listened thereto: (M, L:) and AlqitRiytaI↓ signifies [also] the seeking time after time to obtain a knowledge of namaAYim [i. e. calumnies, pl. of namiymapN]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And qatRN [app. as an inf. n.] signifies The lying, or uttering of falsehood: (K:) [or] a prepared lying. (M.) ― -b3- And qatRahu, (K, TA,) inf. n. qatRN, (TA,) signifies qadRahu [meaning He cut it out, or shaped it, in any manner, whether lengthwise or otherwise]. (K, TA.) One says, huwa Hasanu AlqatRi, meaning Hasanu AlqadRi [i. e. He is goodly, or beautiful, in conformation]: and a poet says,
kaOanRa vadoyayohaA UicaA maA QboranotaI
HuqRaAni mino EaAjK OujiydaA qatRaA
meaning qadRFA and xaroTFA [i. e. As though her two breasts, when they come forth unexpectedly (a meaning of AbrntI expl. in the L, in art. brt, on the authority of Lh, but it is here expl. in the TA as signifying AntSb, so that the phrase may be rendered either when appearing unexpectedly, or when standing out), were two round boxes of ivory, excellently cut out, or shaped, and made smooth in their surfaces]: (O, TA: *) regarding them as one member, he has made the verb singular. (O.) ― -b4- Also He prepared, disposed, or arranged, it; or put it into a right, or good, state. (M, K.) ― -b5- And He collected it together by little and little. (M, K.) ― -b6- And He made it, or made it to appear, to be little; syn. qalRalahu. (M, K.) And qatRa Oavarahu, (M, K,) aor.
qatuta
, inf. n. qatRN, (M,) He followed, or followed after, his track, or footsteps, in pursuit; or endeavoured to track him, or trace him. (M, K.) ― -b7- And qatRN signifies also The following the footsteps of a man secretly, in order to know what he desires [to do]. (O, K.) ― -b8- And A pastor's smelling the odour of a camel (O, K) that is mahoyuwm (K) [i. e.] that is smitten by the [disease termed] huyaAm. (O, TA. [Freytag, supposing mahoyuwm in this explanation in the K to be syn. with haAYim, renders the verb as meaning He (a pastor) smelt the urine of a straying camel, that he might know its way.]) ＝ -A2- See also the next paragraph.

2 qatRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence. ＝ -A2- taqotiytN also signifies The collecting of odoriferous substances, or aromatics, (O, K,) of all sorts, in a cooking-pot, (O,) and cooking them: (O, K:) and one does not say qutRita except of olive-oil when it is thus prepared [i. e. it means it was, or has been, cooked with all sorts of odoriferous substances, or aromatics]: thus says Khálid Ibn-Jembeh: IF adds that AlzRayoti qatRu↓ is like taqotiytuhu [in meaning]: and Zj says that AldRuhona AiqotatRu↓ means the same as qatRatRuhu [i. e. I cooked the oil with all sorts of odoriferous substances, &c.]. (O.) [See also muqatRatN, below.]

5 taqatRaRa
5: see 1, first sentence.

8 AiqotatRahu c
8. AiqotatRahu He, or it, extirpated, or eradicated, him, or it. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 2.

R. Q. 1 qatoqata c
R. Q. 1. qatoqata, inf. n. qatoqatapN: see 1, first sentence.

qatRN c
qatRN inf. n. of qatRa [q. v.]. (S, M, O, K.) ＝ -A2- And i. q. fiSofiSapN, (S, M, O, Msb,) or UisofisatN, (Mgh, K,) both of which signify the same, i. e. A certain food, or fodder, of beasts, as is said in the Nh; (TA;) [a species of trefoil, or clover;] or (M, K) when dry: (M, Mgh, O, Msb:) accord.
to Sb, a pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.], (M,) sing., or n. un., qatRapN, (T, S, M, O,) like as tamorapN is of tamorN. (T, S, O.) ― -b2- And A certain wild grain, not raised by man; which the people of the desert, on the occasion of a year of drought, when they are destitute of milk and dates and the like for their food, bruise and grind; being content therewith notwithstanding its coarseness. (T, Msb, TA.)

qatuwtN c
qatuwtN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

qatRaAtN c
qatRaAtN (S, M, A, O, K) and qatuwtN↓ and qitRiytaI↓, (M, K,) this last being used as an inf. n. and as an epithet, (TA,) A man wont to calumniate; or to make known, divulge, or tell, discourse, or conversation, in a malicious, or mischievous, manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like; (S, * M, * A, * O, * K, * TA;) [or wont to falsify and embellish discourse, or conversation: (see 1:)] or who listens to the discourse, or conversation, of others, without their knowing; (M, K, TA;) whether he make it known in the manner explained above, or not: (M, * K, * TA:) or qatRaAtN, accord. to Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, signifies one who hears the discourses, or conversations, of men, and informs their enemies: or, as some say, one who is with a people, or party, and calumniates them: (TA:) it is said in a trad. (S, O) of the Prophet (O) that the qatRaAt will not enter Paradise: (S, O:) the epithets qatRaAtapN and fatuwtN↓ are applied to a woman: (M, TA:) and the pl. of qatRaAtN is qutRaAtN, with damm. (TA.)

qitRiytI c
qitRiytI: see 1, in three places: ― -b2- and see qatRaAtN.

muqatRatN c
muqatRatN Oil, (M, A, Mgh,) or olive-oil, (O, K,) perfumed, or rendered fragrant, (M, A, Mgh, O,) by its being (Mgh, O) cooked with sweet-smelling plants: (M, Mgh, O, K:) or mixed with other oils of fragrant odour: (Th, M, K: *) or olive-oil cooked with sweet-smelling plants, not mixed with perfume: so says IAth: or olive-oil boiled over the fire with odoriferous substances, or aromatics. (TA.) [See also its verb.]

qawolN maqotuwtN c
qawolN maqotuwtN i. q. makocuwbN [meaning makocuwbN fiyhi A saying in which a falsehood, or lie, is told]; (M, TA;) i. e. a false saying, or lie: (TA:) or a saying that is falsified, or embellished with lies: (JK:) or a misreported saying; a reported saying that is misrepresented: (TA:) it occurs in the saying (O, TA) of Ru-beh, (O,)
qulotu waqawoliI Einodahumo maqotuwtu
[I said, and my saying was in their estimation false, or falsified, &c.]. (O, TA.)

1 qatobN c
1. qatobN The feeding (O, K) a guest (O) with [the intestines called] OaqotaAb [pl. of qitobN or of qitobapN] roasted, or broiled: (O, K:) an inf. n. of which the verb is qataba. (TK.)

2 qutRiba kaAhiluhu c
2. qutRiba kaAhiluhu, said of a man, (assumed tropical:) He was, or became, such as is termed OajonaOu. (JK. [See rajulN muqatRabu AlkaAhili, below.] ― -b2- And one says, fiI kaAhili Alfarasi taqotiybN i. e. janaON (tropical:) [app. meaning In the withers of the horse is a bending over the breast]. (A.)

4 Oaqotabotu AlbaEiyra c
4. Oaqotabotu AlbaEiyra, (S, A,) inf. n. UiqotaAbN, (S, K,) I bound upon the camel the [saddle called] qatab. (S, A, K.) ― -b2- Hence, (A,) Aqtbhu yamiynFA, (T, A, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (tropical:) He imposed upon him a hard, or severe, oath; (T, A, O, K; *) as though he put upon him a [saddle of the kind called] qatab: and in like manner, Aqtbhu fiI Alyamiyni: (A:) and Aqtb Ealayohi fiI Alyamiyni. (T, O.) And Aqtbhu AldRayonu (tropical:) Debt, or the debt, pressed heavily upon him. (A.)

qitobN c
qitobN (Ks, S, O, Msb, K) and qitobapN↓ (As, S, ISd, O, Msb, K) and qatabN↓ (TA) i. q. miEFI [i. e An intestine of those into which the food passes from the stomach]: (S, O, Msb, K:) or (S, O, K,) as AO says of the first of these words, (S, O,) an intestine of the belly that winds round, or takes a coiled form; (S, O, K;) and such as take this form are [also] called the HawaAyaA; but the OamoEaMC are the OaqoSaAb: (S, O:) qitobN is of the fem. gender: (Ks, S, O:) and its pl. is OaqotaAbN: (Ks, S, O, Msb:) or the sing. of this pl. is qitobapN↓: and the dim. is qutayobapN↓. (As, S, O, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- And qitobN signifies also All the apparatus, or furniture, of the saAniyap [i. e. camel, or she-camel, upon which water is drawn] (S, ISd, O, K;) consisting of the OaEolaAq [pl. of EalaqN q. v.] of the sAnyp, and the ropes thereof. (S, ISd, O.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph, in two places.

qatabN c
qatabN A small raHol [or camel's saddle], (S, O,) or a small [camel's saddle such as is called UikaAf, (ISd, K,) of a size corresponding to the hump: (S, ISd, O, K:) or [a sort of pack-saddle for a camel; i. e.] the UikaAf that is put upon such beasts [or camels] as transport burdens: (A:) or [simply] i. q. UikaAfN; as also qitobN↓; but the former is the more common: (K:) or the qitob↓ is only what belongs to the saAniyap [meaning as expl. in the next preceding paragraph], (As, TA,) or to the camel that draws water (lilobaEiyri AlsRaAniI); (JK;) and the UikaAf belongs to the ass, or is common to the ass and the mule and the camel: (TA:) the qanab belongs to the camel: (Msb:) the word thus applied is sometimes fem., though more commonly masc.: and its dim. is qutayobapN↓: (TA:) the pl. is OaqotaAbN, (Sb, A, Msb, K, TA,) only, (Sb, TA.) It is said in a trad. that the woman on the occasion of her bringing forth used to be seated upon a qatab, in order that her parturition might be more easy. (O.) ― -b2- huwa qanabN yaEaDRu biAlgaAribi (tropical:) [lit. He is a saddle that pinches the fore part of the hump] and qatabN miloHaAHN (tropical:) [a pinching, galling, saddle] are said of an importunate person. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also qitobN.

qatibN c
qatibN [in the O without any vowel-sign] Narrow, or contracted, (O, K, TA,) in disposition, (TA,) quickly excited to anger. (O, K, TA.)

qitobapN c
qitobapN: see qitobN, in two places.

qatuwbN c
qatuwbN: see the paragraph here following.

qatuwbapN c
qatuwbapN Camels upon which the [kind of saddle called] qatab is bound: (S, A, O, K, TA:) or a camel upon which the qatab may be put: (Lh, TA:) the p is affixed because the word is similar to HaluwbapN and rakuwbapN, (S, O, TA,) having the signification of a pass. part. n.; but one may elide the p, saying qatuwbN↓. (TA.) It is said in a trad., laA Sadaqapa fiI AlUibili Alqatuwbapi, meaning There is no poor rate in the case of the working camels, (O, TA,) but only in the case of the pasturing. (O.) And you say, kaOanRiI lahumo qatuwbapN wakaOanRa maWuwnatahumo EalaIRa makotuwbapN (tropical:) [I am as though I were to them a working camel, and as though their food were prescribed as incumbent on me]. (A.)

qutayobapN c
qutayobapN a dim. n.: see qitobN: ＝ -A2- and qatabN.

muqotabN Ealayohi c
muqotabN Ealayohi (tropical:) One upon whom is imposed a hard, or severe, oath. (T, O, TA.)

rajulN muqatRabu AlkaAhili c
rajulN muqatRabu AlkaAhili (tropical:) i. q. OajonaOu [app. meaning A man having a bending of the upper part of the back over the breast]. (JK, A. *)

1 qatidati AlUibilu c
1. qatidati AlUibilu, (L, K, TA,) aor.
qatada
, (K, TA,) inf. n. qatadN, (TA,) The camels had a complaint (L, K, TA) of their bellies (L, TA) in consequence of eating of the trees called qataAd [q. v.]. (L, K, TA.)

2 AltRaqotiydu c
2. AltRaqotiydu [or taqotiydu AlqataAdi] signifies The cutting of the trees called qataAd [q. v.], and burning them, (L, K,) i. e. burning [off] their thorns, (L,) and then giving them as fodder to the camels, (L, K,) which fatten upon them on the occasion of drought: (L:) one says, qtRd AlqataAda, inf. n. as above, He (a man) scorched, or slightly burned, the extremities of the qtAd with fire: (O:) the man comes, in the year of drought, and kindles fire among them, so that he burns their thorns, then he feeds his camels therewith: (T, O, TA:) one says of him who does this, qtRd Uibilahu [i. e. He fed his camels with qtAd thus prepared]: so says Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) and the act [of burning &c.] is called AltRaqotiydu. (T, TA.)

qatadN c
qatadN (S, O, L) and qatidN↓ (Kr, L) The wood of a [camel's saddle that is called] raHol: (S, O, L:) or one of the things that compose the apparatus of a raHol: or the whole apparatus thereof: (L:) pl. [of mult.] qutuwdN and [of pauc.] OaqotaAdN (S, O, L) and OaqotudN: (L:) but accord. to the Basrees, qutuwdN, signifying the pieces of wood of a raHol, has no singular. (Ham p. 662.)

qatidN c
qatidN [part. n. of qatida said of a camel: see 1]. One says UibilN qatidapN, and qataAdaI, [the latter being pl. of the former,) Camels having a complaint (Ks, S, O, K) of their bellies (Ks, S, O) in consequence of eating of the trees called qataAd: (Ks, S, O, K:) like as one says ramivapN and ramaAvaI. (Ks, S, O.) ＝ -A2- See also qatadN.

qataAdN c
qataAdN [a coll. gen. n., The tragacanth-tree;] a species of thorny tree; this is the larger sort; (S;) a species of thorny and hard tree, which bears a pod, and of which the fruit is like that of the samur [or gum-acacia-tree], growing in Nejd and Tihámeh; n. un. with p; (L;) it is a species of hard tree having thorns like needles; (K;) a species of tree having thorns like needles, and a small dust-coloured leaf, and a fruit growing therewith of the same colour, resembling the date-stone; (AHn, O, * L;) the large qtAd [thus described] produces large wood, and its thorns are curved and short, and it is of the [class termed] EiDaAh; (Aboo-Ziyád, L;) or it is not reckoned among the EiDaAh: (AHn, L: [but this assertion may perhaps be meant to apply to the smaller sort: respecting the larger, see also 1 and 2:]) the smaller sort is a species of tree of which the fruit is a bladder (nufRaAxap) like that of the EuXar [q. v.]; (S, O, L;) accord. to the ancient Arabs of the desert, it is not tall, being of the size of a man sitting; (L;) and this sort grows upwards, no part of it spreading, consisting of twigs, or shoots, in a collected state, every one of which is full of thorns from its top to its bottom. (Aboo-Ziyád, L.) It is said in a prov., mino duwnihi xaroTu AlqataAdi [expl. in art. xrT, first paragraph]. (S, L.)

Uibil qataAdiyRapN c
Uibil qataAdiyRapN Camels that eat the trees called qataAd. (AHn, K.)

qutaAYidapN c
qutaAYidapN, (S, O, K,) occurring in a verse of 'AbdMenáf Ibn-Riba [cited in art. AcA, p. 40, col. iii.], (S, O,) is the name of a certain Eaqabap [or mountain-road], (S, O, K,) or a vaniyRap [which is said by some to be syn. with Eaqabap]; (K;) [and if so, it is properly imperfectly decl.;] or any vaniyRap is called qutaAYidapN. (K.)

1 qatara c
1. qatara, aor.
qatira
(S, Msb, K) and
qatura
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. qatorN and qutuwrN; (TK;) and qatira, aor.
qatara
; (S, K;) It (roast meat, S, Msb, K, and a cookingpot, and burnt bone, and a perfume with which one fumigates, K, or aloes-wood, TA) exhaled its scent, smell, or odour; (S, Msb, K;) as also qtRr↓, inf. n. taqotiyrN. (K.) ― -b2- qatarati AlnRaAru The fire smoked. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qatara, aor.
qatura
and
qatira
, inf. n. qatorN and qutuwrN, It (sustenance) was barely sufficient; (K;) as also Oaqotara↓. (CK: but this latter is omitted in the TA; and in a MS. copy of the K I find in its place Oqotaru, as a syn. of qaAtirN and qatuwrN.) [This signification is implied in the K, but not expressed, and I think it doubtful.] ― -b2- qatara EalaI EiyaAlihi, aor.
qatura
and
qatira
inf. n. qatorN and qutuwrN; (S, Msb;) and qtRr↓ Ealayohimo, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqotiyrN; (S, Msb;) and Aqtr↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiqotaArN; (S, Msb;) He scanted his household, stinted them, or was niggardly or parsimonious towards them, in expenditure; (S, Msb, K;) like qadara: (S, art. qdr:) as though he took only the qutaAr [or scent] of a thing.
