(El-Basáïr.) walamo yaqoturuwA in the Kur, xxv. 67, signifies walamo yaqoturuwA EamRaA yajibu Ealayohimo mina AlnRafaqapi [Nor are sparing of what is incumbent on them, of expenditure]. (Fr.) You say also QllRehu rizoqahu Oaqotara↓ God made his means of subsistence strait, and scanty. (IAth.) And qutira Ealayohi rizoquhu His means of subsistence were scanted, or straitened, to him, like fudira; (S, art. qdr;) and rizoquhu taqatRara↓ [signifies the same]. (TA in art. Hrf, &c.)

2 qtRr c
2. qtRr, inf. n. taqotiyrN: see 1. ― -b2- He excited, or raised, the scent termed qutaAr. (S.) ― -b3- qtRr liloOasadi He put for the lion some flesh-meat (S, K) in the pitfall, (S,) that he might perceive its scent. (S, K.) ― -b4- qtRr lilowaHoXi He (a hunter, TA) fumigated [himself or his clothes] with camels' dung, in order that the wild animals might not perceive his (the hunter's) smell, (K, TA,) and flee from him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qtRr EalaI EiyaAlihi: see 1.

4 Aqtrt c
4. Aqtrt She (a woman) fumigated herself with aloes-wood. (S, K.) ― -b2- Aqtr AlnRaAra He made the fire to smoke. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Aqtr ElI EiyaAlihi: and Aqtr AllReh rizoqahu: see 1. ― -b2- Also Aqtr He was, or became, poor, needy, or indigent: (S, K:) or his property became small, though some of it yet remained to him. (TA.) A poet says,
lakumo qiboSuhu mino bayoni OavoraI waOaqotaraA
meaning OatoraI waOaqotara mino bayoni mano [Ye have its multitude of people, of those who have become wealthy and of those who have become poor]. (S.) [Cited voce varaA. See another ex. in a verse cited in art. EI, conj. 4.] ＝ -A3- See also 8.

5 taqatRara
5: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also 8.

8 Aqttr c
8. Aqttr, (Msb,) or Aqttr fiI qutorapK, (A, L, TA,) in the K, fiyhaA Oafotara↓, but this is a mistake, (TA,) He concealed, or hid, himself in a qutorap. (A, L, Msb, TA.) And lilSRayodi tqtRr↓ He hid himself in a qutorap to deceive the wild animals, or game. (TA.)

qatorN c
qatorN What is barely sufficient, of sustenance; as also taqotiyrN↓: (K:) or what is barely sufficient to sustain life, of expenditure. (Lth.)

qutorN c
qutorN: see quturN. ＝ -A2- A side, quarter, tract, or region; (S, K;) a dial. form of quTorN; (S;) as also quturN↓: (K:) either side of a man: (JK, L:) pl. OaqotaArN. (TA.)

qatarN c
qatarN and qatarapN↓, (K,) or the latter, and the former is its pl., (S,) [or rather the former is a coll. gen. n., and the latter is the n. un.,] and qatorapN↓, (K,) Dust; syn. gubaArN, (S,) or gabarahN: (K:) so in the Kur, lxxx. 41: (AO, S:) or the dust of an army: (Nh:) or dust-colour overspread with blackness: (T, TA:) or blackness and darkness. (Bd, Jel, lxxx. 41.)

quturN c
quturN [and app. qutorN↓, like quTurN and quTorN,] Aloes-wood with which one fumigates. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qutorN.

qatorapN c
qatorapN: see qatarN.

qutorapN c
qutorapN The naAmuws [or lurking-place] of a hunter, (S, K,) which prevents his scent (qutaAr) [from being perceived by the wild animals]; (El-Basáïr:) the covert of a hunter, in which he hides himself from the game, or wild animals; such as a booth of reeds, and the like; (Msb;) a well, [or pit] which a hunter digs for himself that he may lie in wait therein: (AO:) pl. qutarN. (Msb, TA.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) Straitness of the means of subsistence. (TA.)

qatarapN c
qatarapN: see qatarN.

qutaArN c
qutaArN The scent, smell, or odour, of roast meat; (El-Fárábee, S, Msb, K;) or of flesh-meat when roasted upon live coals: this is the sense in which the Arabs use it: (T, TA:) [or] it signifies also that of a cooking-pot: and of burnt bone: (K:) and of aloes-wood, (S,) or of baxuwr, (K,) i. e., aloes-wood which is burnt and with which one fumigates: (TA:) or the last odour of aloes-wood when one fumigates with it: (Fr, in the Kitáb el-Masádir:) or it has not this signification of the odour of aloes-wood, but the Arabs compare the liking of men in a time of dearth for the scent of roast meat to their liking for the odour of aloeswood: (T, TA:) or it signifies the smoke of cooked food: (Msb:) and the scent, or smell, of a man. (El-Basáïr.) ― -b2- It is also sometimes applied by the Arabs to Fat: and flesh. (TA.)

qatuwrN c
qatuwrN Barely sufficient sustenance; as also qaAtirN↓, (K,) and Oafotaru↓. (So in one copy of the K; but see 1.) [This signification is implied in the K, but not expressed; and I think it doubtful.] ― -b2- [One who scants his household;] niggardly, or parsimonious [towards his household in expenditure]; (K;) as also, [though not in so strong a sense,] muqotirN↓ (TA) [and qaAtirN↓].

qaAtirN c
qaAtirN Flesh-meat exhaling its scent, smell, or odour [in roasting]: (S:) and having a scent by reason of its greasiness. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qatuwrN, in two places.

Oaqotaru c
Oaqotaru: see qatuwrN.

taqotiyrN c
taqotiyrN: see qatorN, and 2.

muqotirN c
muqotirN A woman fumigating herself with aloeswood. (S.) ＝ -A2- See also qatuwrN.

kibaMCN muqatRarN c
kibaMCN muqatRarN [A kind of aloes-wood made to exhale its odour]. (S.)

dictScrap.label: qtrd: See the more correct form in art. qvrd.
qtE qtl qtm qtn qtw: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qavRa c
1. qavRa, as an inf. n., of which the verb is qavRa, aor.
qavuva
, (M, O, TA,) signifies The collecting (O, TA) of maAl [i. e. cattle, or other property], (TA,) and (O, TA) so qivRiyvaI, (O, K, TA,) with kesr, (TA, but written in the O qavRyvI,) used in relation to mAl: (K, TA:) or the collecting of a thing largely, or abundantly. (IDrd, M, O, TA.) And The drawing, or dragging, along, (M, K,) of a thing. (M.) And The driving along. (M, K.) One says, jaMCa fulaAnN yaquvRu maAlFA [Such a one came] drawing, or dragging, along, (S, O,) and driving along, (O,) mAl [i. e. cattle]. (S, O.) And jaMCa yaquvRu dunoyaA EariyDapN [He came] drawing, or dragging, along [ample worldly property]. (M.) And qavRa AlsRayolu AlguvaMCa [The torrent] drove along [the rubbish, and scum, and rotten leaves mixed with the scum, or the like]. (TA.) ― -b2- And The pulling out, or up; or uprooting, or eradicating; (O, K, TA;) as also AiqotivaAvN↓. (K, TA.) One says, AqtvR↓ HajarFA mino makaAnihi (O, TA) He pulled out, or up, a stone from its place: (O:) and Alqawoma mino AqtvR↓ OaSolihimo [He extirpated the people, or party]; (O, * TA;) as also AijotavRahumo: and AuqotuvRa↓ and AujotuvRa It was uprooted: qavRN and javRN are one [in meaning]. (TA.) ― -b3- And The eating [a thing]. (O.)

8 Uiqotavava
8: see above, in four places, in the last two sentences but one. ― -b2- One says also, AqtvR yadahu He cut off [his hand, or arm]. (O.)

quvaAvN c
quvaAvN [and quvaAvapN↓] Household-goods, or utensils and furniture; (M, O, K;) and the like. (M.) One says, jaAWuwA biquvaAvihimo and biquvaAvatihimo↓ [lit. They came with their household-goods, &c.,] meaning they left not anything behind them. (M.)

qaviyovN c
qaviyovN Shoots of palm-trees when they are first pulled off from the mother-trees: as also javiyovN. (O, TA.) ― -b2- [And] Alqaviyvu signifies What become scattered at the bases of grape-vines: [or] accord. to AZ, as mentioned by El-Fárisee, what become scattered at the bases of the branches of palm-trees. (M.)

qavaAvapN c
qavaAvapN: see qaviyvapN, in two places.

quvaAvapN c
quvaAvapN: see quvaAvN, in two places.

qaviyvapN c
qaviyvapN A collective body (O, K) of men; (O;) and qavaAvapN↓ signifies the same. (K.) One says, Ainotaqala Alqawomu biqaviyvatihimo [and biqavaAvatihimo↓ (in the O erroneously written qavaAviyhimo)] The people, or party, removed with their collective body. (O.)

maqavRapN c
maqavRapN Multitude: (As, O, K, TA:) like mafavRapN. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN cuw maqavRapK Such a one has a multitude, or large number [of adherents or the like]. (O.) And maA Oakovara maqavRatahumo [How numerous is their multitude!]. (O.)

4 AqvOt AlOaroDu c
4. AqvOt AlOaroDu, (AZ, S, O,) or AqvO AlmakaAnu, (K,) The land, or the place, abounded with the [species of cucumber called] qivRMC. (AZ, S, O, K.) And AqvO Alqawomu The people had abundance of qvRMC. (S, O, K.)

qivRaMCN c
qivRaMCN (S, O, Msb, K) and quvRaMCN, (O, Msb, K,) the former of which, with kesr, in the more common, (Msb, TA,) [A certain vegetable,] well-known: (K, TA:) [a species of cucumber; cucumis sativus β fructu flavo majore: (Delile's Floræ Ægypt. Illustr., no. 928:]) or the [cucumber called] xiyaAr [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) or a general name for the xiyaAr, the Eajuwr [q. v.], and the faqRuws [or faqRuwS q. v.]: but some apply the name to a species resembling the xyAr: (Msb, TA:) and it is said that it is lighter (OaxafRu) than the xyAr: also that Eajuwr signifies large qivRMC: (TA:) the n. un. is qvRMCp. (S, O, Msb.) ― -b2- qivRaMCu AlHimaAri see voce EaloqamN.

maqovaOapN c
maqovaOapN and maqovuWapN, (S, O, K, TA,) or OaroDN maqovaOapN and maqovuWapN, (Msb,) A place, or land, of qvRMC, (S, Msb, K,) where qvRMC are sown and grow. (TA.)

1 qavada c
1. qavada, aor.
qavida
, (TK,) inf. n. qavodN, (K,) He ate the [plant, or vegetable, called] qavadN. (K.)

8 Aqtvd c
8. Aqtvd He cut (L, K) as one cuts the qvd. (L.)

qavadN c
qavadN [a coll. gen. n.] A certain plant resembling the qivRaMC [a kind of cucumber]: (S, L, K:) or a species of the qvRMC: (L, K:) or the round qvRMC: (IDrd, L:) or the xiyAr: (L, K:) or the xyAr bAcrnq [Persian baAdo ranoko]: (T, L:) n. un. with p. (L, K.)

Q. 1 qavorada c
Q. 1. qavorada He (a man) had much milk and OaqiT. (TA.) [Also sometimes written qtrd with t, as are the other forms of the root mentioned below.]

quvorudN c
quvorudN, and qivoridN↓ and qavoradN↓ and quvaAridN↓ Household-goods, or utensils and furniture: (K:) AA says that quvorudN has this signification: others say qivoridN↓ and quvaAridN↓; i. e., i. q. qrnXwX. (IAar, L.)

qavoradN c
qavoradN and quvaridN↓ and quvaAridN↓ and muqavoridN↓ A man possessing many sheep or goats and lambs or kids: (K:) or possessing much of household-goods, or utensils and furniture, (K,) and of bad articles of this kind. (TA.) See also quvorudN ― -b2- And qavoradN Portions of wool, (K,) and of hair, and of soft camel's hair, (TA,) and such articles of householdgoods or utensils and furniture as are not carried away on departing, or migrating, (K,) but are left in the abode. (TA.)

qivoradN c
qivoradN Dry rotten leaves, or other rubbish, at the foot of a vine. (K.) ― -b2- A multitude of men. (K.) ― -b3- And see quvorudN.

quvaridN c
quvaridN see qavoradN.

qavaAridu c
qavaAridu (in SM's copy of the K, quvArd,) The lower parts of the shirt, and the like. (K.)

quvaAridN c
quvaAridN see quvorudN and qavoradN.

muqavoridN c
muqavoridN see qavoradN.

dictScrap.label: qvE qvmqvE qvm: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qaHRa c
1. qaHRa, (L, K, TA,) [sec. pers., app., qaHuHota,] aor. yaquHRu, (L,) inf. n. qaHaAHapN and quHuwHapN, He, or it, was, or became, such as is termed quHR [i. e. pure, sheer, mere, unmixed, unmingled, unadulterated, or genuine; said of, or in relation to, meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness, and generosity, liberality, or nobleness, and anything]. (S, L, K.)

R. Q. 1 qaHoqaHapN c
R. Q. 1. qaHoqaHapN [an inf. n. of which the verb is qaHoqaHa] signifies The laughing of the ape or monkey. (L, K.) [Compare with this qahoqahapN.] ― -b2- And The voice's being, or becoming, reiterated in the throat, or fauces. (L, K.) And it is similar to buHRapN [which means A hoarseness, roughness, harshness, or gruffness, of the voice]. (L.) [But both of these significations are also assigned in the L to faHofaHapN, with f; to which alone, of these two words, they may perhaps belong.]

quHRN c
quHRN Pure, sheer, mere, unmixed, unmingled, unadulterated, or genuine; (As, S, A, K;) in, or in respect of, (As, S, A,) or applied to, (K,) meanness, sordidness, or ignobleness, and generosity, liberality, or nobleness, (As, S, A, K,) and anything: (K:) fem. quHRapN: and pl. OaqoHaAHN. (S, A.) One says laYiymN quHRN [One that is mean, sordid, or ignoble,] in whom is nought of generosity, liberality, or nobleness. (A.) And EabodN quHRN A pure, or mere, slave; one that is of purely servile condition; (S;) or such as is termed qinRN [which means the same; or one born of slave-parents; &c.]. (A.) And EarabiIRN quHRN A pure, or genuine, Arabian; one of pure Arabian race; fem. EarabiyRapN quHRapN: (S, A, TA:) as also kuHRN and kuHRapN; in which the k is a substitute for the q; for they said OaqoHaAHN, but not OakoHaAHN: [i. e. kuHRu is not a dial. var. of quHRN, because the former has no pl.:] or OakoHaAHN is
used as a pl. of kuHRN. (L in art. kH.) And OaEoraAbiIRN quHRN and quHaAHN↓ (K, TA) A pure, or genuine, Arab of the desert: or one who has not entered the towns, nor mixed with their inhabitants: (TA:) pl. OaEoraAbN OafoHaAHN. (S, TA.) And fulaAnN mino quHRi AlEarabi (ISk, A, * TA) and kuHRihimo, (ISk, TA) Such a one is of the pure, or genuine, of the Arabs. (ISk, A, * TA.) ― -b2- Also Coarse, rough, or rude, in make, or in nature or disposition; applied to a man; (Lth, S, K;) as though he were purely so; (S;) and to other than man. (Lth, K.) ― -b3- And (hence, TA) Unripe, applied in this sense to a melon, or water-melon, (Lth, A, K, TA,) because of its dryness: (A:) or one in its last state: but Az says that Lth has erred in explaining the word in the former of these senses, and that the correct word is fijRN. (TA.)

quHaAHu OamorK c
quHaAHu OamorK The root, foundation, origin, or source, of a thing or an affair; its essence, or very essence; or what is, or constitutes, its most essential, or elementary, part; the ultimate element to which it can be reduced or resolved; its utmost point or particular; or its principal, or best, part; syn. OaSoluhu (Kr, L, K, TA) and faSRuhu (K, TA) and xaAliSuhu. (L, K, TA.) One says, SaAra UilaI quHaAHi AlOamori He reached, or arrived at, the root, &c., of the affair. (L.) And laqad waqaEotu biquHaAHi qurRika, as also waqaEotu biqurRika, I have become acquainted with (Ealimotu) all that thou knowest, nothing thereof being hidden from me. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) And laOaDoTarRanRaka UilI quHaAHika I will assuredly make thee to have recourse to thine utmost effort, or endeavour, i. e. UilaI jahodika: or, as IAar says, lA DTrRnRk AlI turRika waquHaAHika, i. e. UilaI OaSolika. (L. [See OaSolN.]) ― -b2- See also quHRN, latter half.

qaHiyHN c
qaHiyHN. [It is said in the K, AlqaHiyHu fawoqa AlEabRi waAljaroEi: but it appears from a statement in the TK that these words are a mistake copied from the Moheet of Ibn-'Abbad, founded upon a mistranscription of AlquHoquHu fawoqa AlqibRi. See what next follows.]

quHoquHN c
quHoquHN [The ischium; i. e.] the bone that surrounds the posterior pudendum, (S, K,) somewhat above the qibR [or end of the rump-bone]: (S:) or the part where the two hip-bones meet, internally: or [rather] what intervenes between the two hipbones, and surrounds the xaworaAn [or anus, or part in which is the anus]; the xwrAn being between the quHoquH and the EuSoEuS: or the lower part of the Eajob [or rump-bone, or root of the tail], in the integuments (TibaAq) of the two hip-bones; somewhat above the qibR: or the bone upon which is the place wherein the penis is inserted, next, or near, to the lower part of the rakab [or pubes]: it is said in the T that it is no part of the extremity of the backbone, and that its place of junction, or meeting, is outside the EuSoEuS: also, that the upper part of the EuSoEuS is the Eajob, and its lower part is the canab: or the ESES is the internal extremity of the backbone, and the Ejb is its external extremity, and the xaworaAn is the dubur: (L, TA:) or, accord. to IAar, i. q. EuSoEuSN. (O voce EukodapN.)

qarabN qaHoqaAHN c
qarabN qaHoqaAHN and muqaHoqiHN↓ [A night's journey to water] that is hard, or difficult. (K.)

muqaHoqiHN c
muqaHoqiHN: see what next precedes.

1 qaHaba c
1. qaHaba, aor. yaqoHubu, (S, ISd, O, Msb, K,) with damm, (S,) like yakotubu, (O,) the verb being of the class of naSara, (K,) inf. n. quHaAbN (S, * O, * K) and qaHobN, (K,) both of the inf. ns. mentioned by ISd; (TA;) and qHRb↓, inf. n. taqoHiybN; (K;) He coughed; (S, ISd, O, K;) said of a camel, but only of one that has the disease termed nuHaAz, or such as is soft and plump; (ISd, TA;) and of a man, or of an old man, and of a dog: (TA:) or quHaAbN signifies the coughing of horses and of camels and sometimes of human beings: (S, O, TA:) or it is originally of camels, and metaphorically of others than camels: in the T it is expl. in a general manner, without restriction, as syn. with suEaAlN: (TA:) or qaHaba signifies saEala mino luWomihi [app. meaning he coughed by reason of his ungenerousness; as an ungenerous man is wont to do when a request is made to him]. (Msb.) [See also quHaAbN below.]

2 qaHRaba
2: see the preceding paragraph.

qaHobN c
qaHobN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]. (ISd, K.) ＝ -A2- And Attacked by coughing; (AZ, O, K;) applied in this sense to an old man. (O.) ― -b2- And, applied to a man, and so qaHobapN applied to a woman, Who coughs much, and is extremely aged, or old and infirm: or [simply] who coughs much, whether or not extremely aged or old and infirm. (TA.) ― -b3- The former signifies also Advanced in age; (O, K;) applied to an elder; like qaHorN and qaHomN: (O:) and the latter, aged, or extremely aged, or old and infirm, applied to a woman; (T, O, K, TA;) like qaHomapN: (T, TA:) and advanced in age as applied to a ewe or she-goat (T, ISd, TA) and other kind of animal: (ISd, TA:) and the people of El-Yemen thus name a woman advanced in age: (T, TA:) or they thus name a woman; and they say, laA taviqo biqawoli qaHobapK [Confide not thou in the saying of a woman]. (A, TA.) ― -b4- And the former, (A,) or the latter, (IDrd, O, K,) In a corrupt, or disordered, state of the interior of the body, (IDrd, A, O, K,) by reason of disease (daMC), (IDrd, O, K,) or by reason of medicine (duwaMC [app. a mistranscription for daMC]). (So in a copy of the A.) ― -b5- And qaHobapN signifies also A prostitute, or fornicatress: (IDrd, T, ISd, O, Msb, K, TA:) accord. to IDrd, from the same word in the sense next preceding; (O, Msb;) but the Arabs knew not this appellation: (O:) or because, in the Time of Ignorance, the prostitute used to give permission to those who desired her by her coughing; (Az, TA;) or because she makes a sign by coughing, or by making a reiterated hemming in her throat: (ISd, Msb, K, TA:) or, (K, TA,) accord. to J (Msb, TA) and others, (TA,) it is post-classical: (S, O, Msb, K, TA:) but Ibn-Hilál says, in the Kitáb es-Siná'ateyn, that it is a proper [not a tropical] appellation of her who makes gain by prostitution: (TA:) the pl. is qiHaAbN, like kilaAbN pl. of kalobapN. (Msb.)

qaHobapN c
qaHobapN fem. of qaHobN [q. v.] ＝ -A2- And A cough: [and so quHaAbN used as a simple subst.:] thus in the phrase bihi qaHobapN [In him is (i. e. he has) a cough]: (K, TA:) and thus in the phrase biAldRaAbRapi qaHobapN [In the beast, or horse or the like, is a cough]. (TA.)

quHaAbN c
quHaAbN an inf. n. of 1 [q. v., and often used as a simple subst., like qaHobapN q. v.]. (ISd, K, &c.) ― -b2- And A corrupt, or disordered, state of the interior of the body. (IDrd, Msb, TA.) One says to him who is hated, (T, TA,) or to the elder, (TA,) waroyFA waquHaAbFA [May God inflict upon thee an abscess, and a corrupt, or disordered, state of the interior of the body]: (T, TA:) and to him who is beloved, (T, TA,) or to the young man, (TA,) EamorFA waXabaAbFA [May God grant thee continuance of life, and youthful vigour]. (T, TA.)

suEaAlN qaAHibN c
suEaAlN qaAHibN A vehement coughing. (K.)

1 qaHada c
1. qaHada, aor.
qaHada
, (K,) inf. n. qaHodN; (K, * TK;) and AqHd↓; (TA;) He (a camel) became in the state of having a qaHadap [q. v.], (K, TA,) meaning, a hump like a cupola; so accord. to ISd: (TA:) or became large in the qHdp, (K, TA,) after smallness [thereof]: (TA:) and qaHadato, inf. n. quHuwdN; and qaHidato; (IKtt, L;) and AqHdt↓; (S, IKtt, L;) she (a camel) became in the state of having a qaHadap: (ISd, L:) or became large in her hump; (S, IKtt;) [i. e.] became such as is termed miqoHaAd; (L;) [and] so AstHqdt↓: (A, TA: *) or AqHdt↓ signifies she continued always to have a qHdp, even when she had become lean. (L.)

4 OaqoHada
4: see above, in three places.

10 UisotaqoHada
10: see the first paragraph.

qaHadN c
qaHadN: see qaHadapN.

qaHodapN c
qaHodapN, (S, O, K,) originally qaHidapN, like as one says EaXorapN and EaXirapN, (S, O, TA,) and faxocN and faxicN, (TA,) the medial radical being made quiescent for the purpose of alleviating the utterance, (S, O, TA,) applied to a she-camel, (K,) or to a bakorap [or youthful she-camel, (S, O,) Large in the hump: (S, * O:) or large in the qaHadap [q. v.]: (K:) and mqoHaAdN↓ is applied to a
she-camel (S, O, K) in the former sense, (S, O, *) or in the latter sense; (A, * K;) and its pl. is maqaAHiydu. (A, O, K.)

qaHadapN c
qaHadapN The base of the hump of a camel; (S, A, O, L, K;) [as also qaHadN↓, mentioned by Freytag as occurring in the Deewán of the Hudhalees, and I find qHd (thus without any syll. sign) expl. as having this meaning (as well as qHdp) in a copy of the A;] and so maqoHadapN↓: (O, K:) [respecting which last, SM, having overlooked it in the O, observes, in the TA, “ so in all the copies ” (meaning of the K) “ in our hands; but I have not found it in the books of strange words, nor in the L; and it appears to be maHoqid; for it is said in the L that IAar mentions maHofid [with f] as having this meaning, that the like of this is mentioned on the authority of Aboo-Nasr, and that IAar says that maHotid and maHofid and maHoqid and maHokid are all syn. with OaSolN; but Az says that mHqd is not mentioned with mHtd in the book of Aboo-Turáb: ”] or the portion of the hump, (K, TA,) i. e. (TA) the portion of the fat of the hump, (Lth, O, L, TA,) that is between the maOonataAni [app. here meaning the two anterior upper portions of the lumbar region, next the back-bone]: (Lth, O, L, K, TA:) or the hump (A 'Obeyd, O, L, K, TA) itself: (TA:) or a hump like a cupola: (ISd, TA:) or the qubRap [or round, protuberant, upper portion] of the hump: (A:) pl. [of mult.] qiHaAdN (S, O, K) and [of pauc.] OaqoHudN. (K.)

qaHRaAdN c
qaHRaAdN A solitary man, who has neither brother nor offspring: (IAar, Sh, O, K, TA:) and waAHidN qaAHidN↓ signifies [the same, or the like; i. q.] SunobuwrN: (IAar, Sh, T, O:) [see also SaAxidN:] accord. to the K, qaAHidN↓ in this case is an imitative sequent to waAHidN, and so accord. to the M: and it is said in the T that AA mentions this phrase, as on the authority of Abu-l-'Abbás, with f, saying waAHidN faAHidN; but that it is correctly as mentioned [and expl.] by Sh, on the authority of IAar; i. e. that one says waAHidN qaAHidN↓, and SaAxidN. (TA.)

qaAHidN c
qaAHidN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

AlqimaHodapu c
AlqimaHodapu: see what next follows.

AlqamaHoduwapu c
AlqamaHoduwapu, (S, O,) and AlqimaHodapu↓, the latter like EiraDonap [in form], and mentioned by Ibn- 'Abbád, (O,) [words] in which the m is argumentative, (S, O,) [or, accord. to the K, it is radical,] What is behind the head; (S, O;) said by AZ to be the part of the bone of the head that protuberates over the back of the neck; the haAmap [or crown] being above it, and the qacaAl, which is next to the maqadR [or maqacR, i. e. the part between the two ears, behind], being beneath it: (O:) pl. [of both] qamaAHidu (S, O) and [of the former] qamaHoduwaAtN [also]. (O.) See also art. qmHd.

maqoHadapN c
maqoHadapN: see qaHadapN.

miqoHaAdN c
miqoHaAdN: see qaHodapN.

1 qaHaTa AlmaTaru c
1. qaHaTa AlmaTaru, aor.
qaHaTa
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. quHuwTN, (Sh, S,) or qaHoTN; (Msb, K;) and qaHiTa, aor.
qaHaTa
, (Fr, S, Msb,) inf. n. qaHaTN; (Fr, Msb;) but the former is said by ISd, to be the more approved, (TA,) and qaHuTa; (Msb;) quHiTa, mentioned by AHn, and IB, but the latter says, quHiTa AlqaToru; and OaqoHaTa↓, also mentioned by AHn; (TA;) The rain was withheld, (Sh, AHn, S, Msb, K,) being wanted. (Sh.) An Arab of the desert said to 'Omar, qaHiTa AlsRaHaAbu, meaning The clouds were withheld. (TA.) ― -b2- qaHaTa AlEaAmu, aor.
qaHaTa
, inf. n. qaHoTN; and qaHiTa, aor.
qaHaTa
, inf. n. qaHaTN; and quHiTa, inf. n. quHuwTN; (K, * TA;) and OaqoHaTa↓; (K;) The year was one of drought; without rain: (K:) and OakoHaTa signifies the same. (TA.) You say also, kaAna celika fiI UiqoHaATi↓ AlzRamaAni, and UikoHaATihi, meaning That was in the distressing state of the time, or season. (Ibn-ElFaraj.) ― -b3- qaHaTat AlOaroDu, aor.
qaHaTa
; (IDrd;) or quHiTat; (Msb, TA;) and AqHTt↓ [app. in the act. and pass. forms, though the pass. form seems to be of doubtful authority, as will be seen from what follows]; (Msb;) The land received no rain: (Msb, TA:) but it is asserted that one says qaHaTa, with fet-h, of rain; and qaHiTa, with kesr, of a place. (IB.) ― -b4- qaHiTa AlnRaAsu, like samiEa [in form], (K, TA,) not otherwise; (TA;) [unless in the pass. form; for] you say also, (K,) quHiTuwA; (S, Msb, K,) and OuqoHiTuwA↓; (Msb, K;) but these two are rare; (K;) or they are not allowable; (M;) and OaqoHaTuwA↓; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) and qaHaTa Eanohumu AlmaTaru; (Mgh;) The people suffered, or were afflicted with, drought, or want of rain; (S, Msb, K, TA;) they had no rain; (TA;) rain was withheld from them. (Mgh, Msb.)

4 AqHT c
4. AqHT: see 1, throughout. ― -b2- OaqoHaTa, said of a man, also signifies (tropical:) Semen non emisit: (Mgh, Msb:) or inivit et semen non emisit: (K:) from the same verb in the last of the senses explained in the preceding paragraph. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- OaqoHaTa QllRehu AlOaroDa God afflicted the land with drought; by withholding rain from it. (Msb, K.)

qaHoTN c
qaHoTN: see 1. ― -b2- Drought; dearth; scarcity: (S, TA:) and (assumed tropical:) paucity of good in anything. (ISd, TA.) You say also, lahu quHoTFA↓, like suHoqFA, and buEodFA, in the accus. case as [though it were] an inf. n.; meaning May drought, or dearth, or scarcity, betide him: and (tropical:) cessation of good, or welfare: and (tropical:) unfruitfulness in respect of good works. (TA.)

quHoTFA lahu c
quHoTFA lahu: see qaHoTN.

qaHiTN c
qaHiTN: see qaHiyTN.

qaHiyTN c
qaHiyTN Rain withheld. (Fr, Msb.) Also, and qaHiTN↓, applied to a year, and to a beating, Distressing; severe; vehement. (K.)

zamanN qaAHiTN c
zamanN qaAHiTN, (K, TA,) and EaAmN muqoHiTN↓, (TA,) A time, and a year, of drought; in which is no rain: (K, * TA:) pl. of the former epithet qawaAHiTu. (K.)

muqoHiTN c
muqoHiTN: see qaAHiTN.

baladN maqoHuwTN c
baladN maqoHuwTN, (Msb,) and OaroDN maqoHuwTapN, (TA,) A country, and a land, that has received no rain: (Msb, TA:) pl. maqaAHiyTu. (Msb.)

dictScrap.label: qHf fHl qHm: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qadRahu c
1. qadRahu, aor.
qaduda
, (S, M, O, L, Msb,) inf. n. qadRN; (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K;) and qdRdhu↓, (M, L,) [but this app. has an intensive signification, or denotes repetition of the action, or its relation to several objects,] inf. n. taqodiydN; (L, K;) and AqtdRhu↓, (M, L,) inf. n. AiqotidaAdN; (K;) He cut it in an enlongated form; or lengthwise: (IDrd, M, L, K:) or slit, split, clave, rent, or divided, it, (namely, a thong, &c., S, O, L, and a garment, or piece of cloth, L,) lengthwise: (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K:) and he cut it off entirely: (M, L, K:) or he cut it, or cut it off, in an absolute sense: (TA:) he cut it, namely, a skin: and he rent it, namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, or the like. (L.) One says, Darabahu biAlsRayofi faqadRahu biniSofayoni [He smote him with the sword and clave him in halves,] (L, Msb, *) or qadRahu niSofayoni. (A.) And qadRa Alqalama waqaTRahu [He slit the writing-reed, and nibbed it, or cut off its point breadthwise, or crosswise]: (A, TA:) [for] qaTRahu is opposed to qadRahu: (S and TA in art. qT:) and both of these verbs occur in a trad. describing 'Alee's different modes of cutting [with the sword] when contracting himself and when stretching himself up. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] qadRa, (S, M, A, L,) inf. n. qadRN, (M, L, K,) (tropical:) He clave, cut through by journeying, or passed through, the desert, (S, M, A, O, L, K,) and the night. (M, L) ― -b3- And qadRa bihi AlTRariyqu, (so in a copy of the M,) or qadRatohu AlTRariyqu, (so in the L and TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M, L, TA,) i. q. qaTaEahu (M) or qaTaEatohu (L, TA) (tropical:) [The road cut him off, app. from his companions, or from the object of his journey: compare qaTaEa bihi and quTiEa bihi]. ― -b4- And qadRa AlkalaAma, (M, L,) inf. n. as above, (M, L, K,) i. q. qaTaEahu (M, L, K *) and XaqRahu (M, L) [both of which explanations may here mean, as qaTaEa AlkalaAma generally does, (assumed tropical:) He cut short, or broke off, the
speech; or ceased from speaking: or both may here mean, as qaTaEa AlkalaAma sometimes does, he articulated speech, or the speech: compare this latter rendering with an explanation of XaqRaqa AlkalaAma]. ― -b5- [qadRahu also signifies He cut it out, or shaped it, in any manner, whether lengthwise or otherwise; like qatRahu: see this latter, and a verse cited as an ex. of its inf. n.: and see also a saying near the end of the first paragraph of art. frI. Hence] qudRa fulaAnN qadRa AlsRayofi [Such a one was shaped with the shaping of the sword] means (tropical:) such a one was made goodly, or beautiful, in respect of AltRaqoTiyE [i. e. conformation, or proportion, &c., like as is the sword]. (S, O, L, TA.) [See also qadRN, below.] ― -b6- And qudR means also (assumed tropical:) He suffered a pain [app. what may be termed a cutting pain] in the belly, called qudaAd. (M, L, K.)

2 qadRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- [Hence,] qdRd, (as implied in the L,) or qdRd AllRaHoma, (A, O, *) inf. n. taqodiydN, (O, L,) He made qadiyd [i. e. he cut flesh-meat into strips, or oblong pieces, and spread them in the sun, or salted them and spread them in the sun, to dry]. (L.) ＝ -A2- qdRd Ealayhi, said of a garment, It fitted him, or suited him, in size and length. (L, from a trad.)

4 AqdR Ealayohi c
4. AqdR Ealayohi, said of food, (assumed tropical:) It occasioned him a pain in the belly, termed qudaAd. (IKtt, TA.)

5 taqadRaRa
5: see 7. ― -b2- tqdRd said of a garment, or piece of cloth, It was, or became, much slit or rent. or ragged, or tattered, (O, K, TA,) and old and worn out. (TA.) ― -b3- And, said of flesh-meat, quasi-pass. of 2, [i. e. It was, or became, cut into strips, or oblong pieces, and spread in the sun, or salted and spread in the sun, and so dried.]. (O.) ― -b4- And, said of a company of men (qawomN), It became separated (S, M, O, L, K) into qidad [or parties, &c., pl. of qidRapN, q. v.]. (M, L.) ― -b5- Also, said of a thing, (TA,) [perhaps from the same v. said of flesh-meat,] It was, or became, dry; or it dried, or dried up. (K, TA.) ― -b6- And tqdRdt said of a she-camel, She became somewhat lean (O, K) after having been fat: (O:) or she became fat, (TA,) or began to become fat, after having been lean. (K, TA.)

7 AnqdR c
7. AnqdR, (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K,) and tqdRd↓, (M, L, K,) [but the latter app. has an intensive signification, or is said of a number of things,] the former said of a skin, and of a garment, or piece of cloth, (A,) not said of aught except some such thing as a bag for travelling-provisions and for goods or utensils &c., and such as clothing, (O,) It became cut in an elongated form; or lengthwise: (L, K:) or became slit, split, cloven, rent, or divided, lengthwise: (S, M, A, O, L, Msb, K:) or became cut off entirely: (M, L, K:) or became cut, or cut off. (TA.)

8 Uiqotadada
8: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AqtdR AlOumuwra means (tropical:) He considered the affairs, forcasting their issues, or results, and discriminated them: (S, O, K:) or he devised the affairs, and considered what would be their issues, or results. (M.)

10 AstqdR c
10. AstqdR (tropical:) It contained, or continued in one manner, or state. (Ibn-'Abbád, A, O, K,) lahu to him. (A.) And (assumed tropical:) It (an affair, TA) was, or became, uniform, or even in its tenour. (Ibn- 'Abbád, O, K, TA.) And AstqdRt AlUibilu (assumed tropical:) The camels went on undeviatingly, in one course, way, or manner: (O, K:) so says AA. (O.)

qado c
qado is a noun and a particle: (S, O, Mughnee, K:) and as a noun it is used in two ways. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b2- (I) It is a noun syn. with Hasobu; (S, O, Mughnee, K;) generally used indeclinably; (Mughnee, K;) thus accord. to the Basrees; with the d quiescent; (TA;) because resembling qado the particle in respect of the letters composing it, and many other particles in respect of its form, (Mughnee, TA,) such as Eano and balo &c.: (TA:) one says, qado zayodK dirohamN [The sufficiency of Zeyd (i. e. what is sufficient for Zeyd) is a dirhem], (Mughnee, K,) with the d quiescent; (Mughnee, * K, * TA;) and qadiI (S, O) and qadoniI (S, O, Mughnee) [both] meaning HasobiI [My sufficiency (i. e. what is sufficient for me)]; (S, O;) the n in qadoniI being inserted in order to preserve the quiescence [of the final letter of the noun] because this is the original characteristic of what they make indeclinable; (Mughnee;) but the insertion of the n in this case is anomalous, for it is [by rule] only added in verbs, by way of precaution, [to prevent the confusion of the pronominal affix of the verb and that of the noun,] as in DarabaniI: (S, O:) [see, however, in the next sentence, an explanation of qadoniI accord. to which the n is inserted regularly:] accord. to Yaakoob, using qado in the sense of Hasobu, one says, maA laka EinodiI UilRaA hecaA faqado i. e. faqaTo [There is nothing for thee with me, or nothing due to thee in my possession, except this, and it is a thing sufficient, or it is enough, faqaTo being held to signify properly faHasobu, but it is commonly used as meaning and no more]; and he asserts it [i. e. qado] to be a substitute [for qaTo]: (M:) and it is also used declinably; (Mughnee, K;) thus accord. to the Koofees; (TA;) but this is rare: (Mughnee:) one says qadu zayodK, making it marfooa, (Mughnee, K,) like as one says Hasobuhu; and qadiI without n [as mentioned above,] like as one says HasobiI. (Mughnee.) ― -b3- (2) It is also a verbal noun, syn. with yakofiI: one says, qado zayodFA dirohamN [A dirhem suffices, or will suffice, Zeyd], and qadoniI dirohamN [A dirhem suffices, or will suffice, me]; (Mughnee, K;) like as one says yakofiI zayodFA dirohamN, and yakofiyoniI dirohamN. (Mughnee, K. *) ＝ -A2- As a particle, it is used peculiarly with a verb, (Mughnee, K,) [i. e.] as such it is not preposed to anything except a verb, (S, O,) either a pret. or an aor., (TA,) from which it is not separated unless by an oath, (Mughnee,) such as is perfectly inflected, enunciative, (Mughnee, K,) not an imperative, (TA,) affirmative, and free from anything that would render it mejzoom or man- soob, and from what is termed Harof tanofiys [i. e. sawofu and its variants]: and it has six meanings. (Mughnee, K.) ― -b2- (1) It denotes expectation: (M, Mughnee, K:) and when it is with an aor., this is evident; (Mughnee;) one says qado yaqodamu AlgaAYibu, (Mughnee, K,) meaning It is expected that the absent will come: (TA:) and most affirm that it is thus used with a pret.: (Mughnee:) accord. to some, (M,) it is used in reply to the saying lamRaA yafoEalo [i. e. “ He has not yet done ” such a thing, which implies expectation that he would do it]; (S, M, O;) the reply being, qadofaEala [Already he has done the thing]: (M:) and Kh asserts that it is used in reply to persons expecting information; (S, M, * O, Mughnee;) [for to such] you say, qado maAta falaAnN [Already such a one has died]; but if one inform him who does not expect it, he does not say thus, but he says [merely] maAta fulaAnN: (S, O:) thus some say qado rakiba AlOamiyru [Already the commander has mounted his horse] to him who expects his mounting: some, however, disallow that qado is used to denote expectation with the pret. because the pret. denotes what is already past; and hence it appears that those who affirm it to be so used mean that the pret. denotes what was expected before the information: (Mughnee: [in which it is added, with some other observations, that, in the opinion of its author, it does not denote expectation even with the aor.; because the saying yaqodamu AlgaYibu denotes expectation without qado:]) MF says, What we have been orally taught by the sheykhs in ElAndalus is this, that it is a particle denoting the affirmation of truth, or certainty, when it occurs before a pret., and a particle denoting expectation when it occurs before a future. (TA.) ― -b3- (2) It denotes the nearness of the past to the present: (O, Mughnee, K:) so in the saying qado qaAma zayodN [Zeyd has just, or just now, stood; a meaning often intended by saying merely, has stood]; (Mughnee, K;) for this phrase without qd may mean the near past and the remote past; (Mughnee;) and so in the saying of the muëdhdhin, qado qaAmati AlSRalaApu [The time of the rising to prayer has just come, or simply has come]: (O:) [and, when thus used, it is often immediately preceded by the pret. or aor. of the verb kaAna; thus you say, kaAna qado cahaba He had just, or simply had, gone away; and yakuwnu qado cahaba He will, or shall, have just, or simply have gone away:] and accord. to the Basrees, except Akh, it must be either expressed or understood immediately before a pret. used as a denotative of state; as in [the saying in the Kur ii. 247,] wamaA lanaA OalRaA nuqaAtilu fiI sabiyli QllRehi waqado OuxorijonaA mino diyaArinaA waOabonaAYinaA [And what reason have we that we should not fight in the cause of God when we have been expelled from our abodes and our children?]; and in [the saying in the Kur iv. 92,] Oawo jaAWuwkumo HaSirato Suduwruhumo Ono yuqaAtiluwkamo [Or who come to you, their bosoms being contracted so that they
are incapable of fighting you, or their bosoms shrinking from fighting you]; but the Koofees and Akh says that this is not required, because of the frequent occurrence of the pret. as a denotative of state without qado, and [because] the primary rule is that there should be no meaning, or making, anything to be understood, more especially in the case of that which is in frequent use: (Mughnee:) Sb [however] does not allow the use of the pret. as a denotative of state without qado; and he makes HSrt Sdwrhm to be an imprecation [meaning may their bosoms become contracted]: (S in art. HSr; in which art. in the present work see more on this subject:) and the inceptive la is prefixed to it like of the saying, UinRa zayodFA laqado qaAma [Verily Zeyd has just stood, or has stood]; because the primary rule is that it is to be prefixed to the noun, and it is prefixed to the aor. because it resembles the noun, and when the pret. denotes a time near to the present it resembles the aor. and therefore it is allowable to prefix it thereto. (Mughnee.) [See also the two sentences next after what is mentioned below as the sixth meaning.] ― -b4- (3) It denotes rareness, or paucity; (Mughnee, K;) either of the act signified by the verb, (Mughnee,) as in [the saying], qado yaSoduqu Alkacuwbu [In some few instances the habitual liar speaks truth]; (Mughnee, K;) or of what is dependent upon that act, as in [the saying in the Kur xxiv. last verse,] qado yaEolamu maA Oanotumo Ealayohi [as though] meaning OanRa maA humo Ealayohi huwa OaqalRu maEoluwmaAtihi [so that it should be rendered At least He knoweth that state of conduct and mind to which ye are conforming yourselves]: but some assert that in these exs. and the like thereof it denotes the affirmation of truth, or certainty; [as will be shown hereafter;] and that the denoting of rareness, or paucity, in the former ex. is not inferred from qado, but from the saying Alkacuwbu yaSoduqN. (Mughnee.) ― -b5- (4) It denotes frequency; (Mughnee, K;) [i. e.] sometimes (S, O) it is used as syn. with rubRamaA [as denoting frequency, as well as with rubRamaA in the contr. sense, mentioned in the next preceding sentence]: (S, M, O:) thus in the saying (S, M, O, Mughnee, K) of the Hudhalee, (M, Mughnee,) or 'Abeed Ibn-El-Abras, (IB, TA,)
qado Oatoruku Alqirona muSofarRFA OanaAmiluhu
[Often I leave the antagonist having his fingers' ends become yellow]. (S, M, O, Mughnee, K.) ― -b6- (5) It denotes the affirmation of truth, or certainty: thus in [the saying in the Kur xci. 9,] qado OafolaHa mano zakRaAhaA [Verily, or certainly, or indeed, or really, he prospereth, or will prosper, who purifieth it; (namely, his soul;) each pret. here occupying the place of a mejzoom aor.]: (Mughnee, K:) and thus accord. to some in [the saying in the Kur xxiv. last verse, of which another explanation has been given above,] qado yaEolamu maA Oanotumo Ealayohi [Verily, or certainly, &c., He knoweth that state of conduct and mind to which ye are conforming yourselves]. (Mughnee.) ― -b7- (6) It denotes negation, (Mughnee, K,) accord. to ISd, (Mughnee,) occupying the place of maA, (M,) in the saying, qado kunota fiI xayorK fataEorifahu, (M, Mughnee, K,) with tErf mansoob, [as though meaning Thou wast not in prosperity, that thou shouldst know it,] (Mughnee, K,) heard from one of the chaste in speech: (M:) but this is strange. (Mughnee.) ― -b8- [When it is used to denote the nearness of the past to the present, as appears to be indicated by the context in the O,] qado may be separated from the verb by an oath; as in qado waQllRehi OaHosanota [Thou hast, by God, done well] and qado laEamoriI bitRu saAhirFA [I have, by my life, or by my religion, passed the night sleepless]. (O, Mughnee. [In the latter, this and what here next follows are mentioned before the explanations of the meanings of the particle; probably because the meaning in these cases can hardly be mistaken.]) And the verb may be suppressed after it, (M, * O, Mughnee,) when its meaning is apprehended, (O,) or because of an indication; (Mughnee;) as in the saying of En-Nábighah (M, O, Mughnee) Edh-Dhubyánee, (O,)
Oafida AltRaraHRulu gayora OanRa rikaAbanaA
lamRaA tazulo biriHaAlinaA wakaOano qadi
[The time of departure has drawn near, though the camels that we ride have not left with our utensils and apparatus for travelling, but it is as though they had (left)]; meaning kaOano qado zaAlato. (M, O, Mughnee.) ― -b9- If you make qado an Aisom [i. e. a subst. or a proper name], you characterize it by teshdeed: therefore you say, katabotu qadRFA HasanapF [I wrote a beautiful qd]; and so you do in the case of kaIo and huwa and lawo; because these words have no indication of what is deficient in them [supposing them to be originally of three radical letters], therefore it is requisite to add to the last letter of each what is of the same kind as it, and this is incorporated into it: but not in the case of A; for in this case you add C; thus if you name a man laA, or maA, and then add at the end of it A, you make it C; for you make the second A movent, and A when movent becomes C: (S, O:) so says J, [and Sgh has followed him in the O,] and such is the opinion of Akh and of a number of the grammarians of El-Basrah [and of El-Koofeh (MF)], and F has quoted this passage in the B and left it uncontradicted: but IB says, (TA,) [and after him F in the K,] this is a mistake: that only is characterized by teshdeed of which the last letter is infirm: you say, for huwa, (IB, K,) used as the name of a man, (IB,) huwRN, (IB, K,) and for lawo you say lawRN, and for fiI you say fiIRN; (IB;) and such is characterized by teshdeed only in order that the word may not be reduced to one letter on account of the quiescence of the infirm letter [which would disappear] with tenween [as it does in damN and yadN &c.]: (K:) but as to qado, if you use it as a name, you say qadN; (IB, K;) and for mano you say manN, and for Eano you say EanN; (K;) like yadN (IB, K) and damN &c.: (K:) F, however, [following IB,] is wrong in calling J's statement a mistake; though the rule given by him [and IB] is generally preferred. (MF, TA.)

qadRN c
qadRN The skin of a lamb or kid: (M, A, L, Msb, K:) or [only] of a kid: (S, O, L:) or, accord. to IDrd, a small skin, but of what kind he does not say: (M, L:) pl. (of pauc., S) OaqudRN and (of mult., S) qidaAdN (ISk, S, M, L, Msb, K) and [of pauc. also] OaqidRapN, which is extr. (M, L.) Hence the saying, fulaAnN maA yaEorifu AlqadRa mina AlqidRi↓ Such a one knows not the skin of a lamb, or kid, from the thong. (A.) And hence, (O, K,) it is said in a prov., (S, M, A, O,) maA yajomalu qadRaka UilaI Oadiymika (S, M, A, O, K) What approximates thy skin of a lamb, or kid, to thy hide [of a full-grown beast]? meaning, accord. to Th, (assumed tropical:) what makes the great to be like the little? (M: [or the little to be like the great?]) or meaning what induces thee to make thy small affair [appear] great? (S:) or what approximates thy small [affair] to thy great? (O, K:) applied to him who transgresses his proper limit; (M, O, K;) and to him who compares the contemptible with the noble. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also qidRN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also (assumed tropical:) The measure, quantity, size, or bulk, (M, L, Msb, K,) of a thing: (M, L:) (tropical:) the conformation, or proportion, syn. taqoTiyE, (S, M, A, O, L, K,) of a thing, (M, L,) or of a young woman, (A,) or of a man: (K:) (tropical:) the stature, syn. qaAmap, (S, A, O, L, K,) of a man: (K:) (assumed tropical:) his justness of form, or symmetry: (M, L, K:) and (assumed tropical:) his figure, person, or whole body: (M, L:) pl. [of pauc.] OaqudRN (M, L, K) and OaqidRapN, (K,) which is extr., (TA,) and [of mult.] quduwdN (M, L, K) and qidaAdN. (K.) One says, hecaA EalaI qadRi caAka (assumed tropical:) This is equal in measure, quantity, size, or bulk, to that; is like that. (Msb.) And XaIoCN Hasanu AlqadRi (assumed tropical:) A thing goodly, or beautiful, in respect of conformation, or proportion. (L.) And jaAriyapN Hasanapu AlqadRi (tropical:) A young woman goodly, or beautiful, in respect of stature, and of conformation, or proportion. (A.) And gulaAmN Hasanu AlqadRi (assumed tropical:) A young man goodly, or beautiful, in respect of justness of form, or symmetry, and in person, or the whole of his body. (M, L.) ＝ -A3- See, again, qidRN. ＝ -A4- By the phrase yaA wayola qadRK, addressed to Mikdád, in a verse of Jereer, is meant yaA wayola miqodaAdK [O, woe to thee Mikdád]; the poet restricting himself to some of the letters [of the name]: an instance [more obviously] of a similar kind is salRaAm used by El- Hoteiäh for sulayomaAn. (O.)

qudRN c
qudRN A certain marine fish, (O, K,) the eating of which is said to increase [the faculty of] AljimaAE. (O.)

qidRN c
qidRN A thing that is maqoduwd [i. e. cut in an elongated form, &c.]. (M, L.) ― -b2- [And hence] A thong cut from an untanned skin, (S, M, * A, O, * L, Msb, K,) with which sandals or shoes are sewed, (M, * L, Msb,) and with which a captive
is bound; (A;) pl. OaqudRN: (S, O, L:) and [as a coll. gen. n.] thongs, cut from an untanned skin, with which camels' saddles and [the vehicles called] maHaAmil are bound: (M, L:) and qidRapN↓ [of which the pl. is qidadN] is a more special term, (S, O, L,) signifying a single thong of this kind. (K.) See an ex. voce qadRN. ― -b3- And (hence, L) A whip; (O, L, K;) as also qadRN↓. (K.) Thus in the trad., laqaAbu qawosi OaHadikumo wamawoDiEu qidRihi fiI AljanRapi xayorN mina AldRunoyaA wamaA fiyhaA, (O, * L,) or qadRihi↓, (K,) i. e. Verily the space that would be occupied by the bow of any one of you, and the place that would be occupied by his whip, in Paradise, are better than the present [sublunary] world and what is in it: or qidRh may here have the meaning next following. (L.) ― -b4- A sandal; because cut in an elongated form from the skin: (O, L:) or a sandal not stripped of the hair, in order that it may be more pliant. (IAar, O, L.) ― -b5- And A vessel of skin. (S, O, K.) One says, maA lahu qidRN walaA qiHofN He has not a vessel of skin nor a vessel of wood: (S, O, M:) or a skin nor a fragment of a drinking-cup or bowl. (M.) ― -b6- Xadiydu AlqidRi occurs in a trad. as some relate it, meaning Having a strong bowstring: but accord. to others, it is Xadiydu AlqadRi↓, meaning strong in pulling the bow. (L.)

qidRapN c
qidRapN: see qidRN. ― -b2- Also A piece of a thing. (M, L.) ― -b3- And hence, (M,) A party, division, sect, or distinct body or class, of men, holding some particular tenet, or body of tenets, creed, opinion, or opinions, (S, M, O, L, Msb, K,) accord. to some, (Msb,) of whom each has his own, (S, O, L, K,) or of which each has its own, (Msb,) erroneous opinion: (S, O, L, Msb, K:) pl. qidadN. (Msb.) Hence, kunRaA TaraAYiqa qidadFA, (S, L, O, K,) in the Kur [lxxii. 11], (L, O,) said by the Jinn, (Fr, L,) We were parties, or sects, differing in their erroneous opinions, or in their desires: (Fr, O, L, K:) or separate [sects]; Muslims and not Muslims: (Zj:) or diverse, or discordant, or various, sects; Muslims and unbelievers. (Jel.) And one says, SaAra Alqawomu qidadFA The people became divided, or different, in their states, or conditions, and their desires, or erroneous opinions. (L.)

qadaAdN c
qadaAdN The hedge-hog: ― -b2- and The jerboa. (O, K.)

qudaAdN c
qudaAdN A pain [app. what may be termed a cutting pain] in the belly. (S, M, O, L, K.) HabanFA waqudaAdFA is a form of imprecation, meaning [May God inflict upon thee] dropsy, and a pain in the belly. (L.)

qadiydN c
qadiydN, (S, M, O, L, K,) or laHomN qadiydN, (Msb,) Flesh-meat cut into strips, or oblong pieces: (M, L, K:) or cut, (M,) or cut into oblong pieces, and spread, or spread in the sun, to dry: (M, L, K:) or salted, and dried in the sun: (L:) i. q. laHomN muqadRadN: (S, O, L:) qadiydN is of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN. (L.) ― -b2- vawobN qadiydN A garment, or piece of cloth, [slit, or rent, and] old and worn out. (S, O, L, K.)

qudayodN c
qudayodN A small misoH [or garment of thick, or coarse, hair-cloth], (M, * K, * TA,) such as is worn by persons of low condition. (TA.)

qadiydiyRuwna c
qadiydiyRuwna, (IAth, O, K, TA,) thus accord. as a trad., in which it occurs is related, (IAth, TA,) not to be pronounced with damm, (K,) or, as some say, it is [qudayodiyRuwna, i. e.] with damm to the q and fet-h to the [first] d, (IAth, TA,) and thus in the handwriting of Z in the “ Fáïk, ” (O,) [and thus I find it in a copy of the A,] The followers of an army, consisting of handicraftsmen, (A, IAth, O, K, TA,) such as the repairer of cracked wooden bowls, and the farrier, (O, K, TA,) and the blacksmith: (O, TA:) of the dial. of the people of Syria: as though they were called by the former appellation because of the tattered state of their clothing; (O;) or by the latter as though, by reason of their low condition, they wore the small misoH called qudayod; or from AltRaqadRudu, because they disperse themselves in the provinces on account of need, and because of the tattered state of their clothing; and the diminutive form denotes mean estimation of their condition: (IAth, TA:) a man (IAth, O, TA) of them (O) is reviled by its being said to him yaA qadiydIRu (IAth, O, TA) and yA qudayodiIRu: (IAth, TA:) and it is commonly used in the language of the Persians also. (O.)

qayoduwdN c
qayoduwdN A she-camel long in the back: (O, K:) but this is said to be derived from Alqawodu, like Alkayonuwnapu from Alkawonu: (L:) [see art. qwd:] pl. qayaAdiydu. (K. [In the O the pl. is written qanaAdiydu.])

maqadRN c
maqadRN (tropical:) A road: (A, K, TA:) because it is cut: so in the phrase mafaAzapN musotaqiymapu AlmaqadRi (tropical:) [A desert, or waterless desert, whereof the road is straight, or direct]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The rima vulvæ of a woman. (M, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The part of the back of the neck that is between the ears. (K, L.) [A dial. var. of, or a mistake for, maqacRN.]) ― -b4- And i. q. qaAEN, i. e. (assumed tropical:) An even, or a plain, place. (S, M, O, L.)

miqadRN c
miqadRN, like midaqRN [in measure], (K, [in a copy of the M, erroneously, maqadR,]) or miqadRapN↓, (L,) The iron instrument with which skin is cut (yuqadRu). (L, * K, * TA.)

miqadRapN c
miqadRapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

maqadRiIRN c
maqadRiIRN Wine of El-Makadd, a town of the region of the Jordan, (K,) or, as is said in the Marásid and the Moajam, near Adhri'át, in the Howrán; (TA;) wrongly said by J to be without teshdeed to the d, for the wine called maqadaIRN is different from that called maqadRiIRN: (K:) or it is wine boiled until it is reduced to half its original quantity; likened to a thing that is divided (qudRa) in halves; so accord. to Rejá Ibn-Selemeh, and in the Nh and Ghareebeyn; and sometimes it is pronounced without teshdeed to the d. (TA.)

1 qadaHa AldRuwdu c
1. qadaHa AldRuwdu, (S, A,) [aor.
qadaHa
,] inf. n. qadoHN, (Lth, S, Mgh,) The worm, or worms, effected a cankering, or corrosion, (Lth, S, A, Mgh,) fiI AlXRajari, [in the trees], (Lth, S, Mgh,) or fiI AlEuwdi [in the wood], (A,) and fiI AlOasonaAni [in the teeth]. (Lth, S, A, Mgh.) And qudiHa and qudiHa fiyhi, inf. n. as above, It (the tree, and the tooth,) became cankered, or corroded. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qadaHa fiyhi, (Msb, K,) or fiI EiroDihi, and fiI saAqihi, (A,) aor.
qadaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. as above, (Msb,) from the incidency of the qawaAdiH [or canker-worms] in the saAq [or stem] of the tree, (A,) (tropical:) He impaired, injured, detracted from, impugned, or attacked, his honour, or reputation; blamed, censured, or reproached, him; found fault with him; or spoke against him. (A, Msb, K.) And qadaHa fiI nasabihi (tropical:) He found fault with, or spoke against, his parentage, genealogy, or pedigree. (S, A, Msb.) And qadaHa fiI EadaAlatihi (assumed tropical:) He impugned his rectitude as a witness, mentioning something that should have the effect of causing his testimony to be rejected. (Msb.) And qadaHa fiI saAqi Oaxiyhi (tropical:) He acted dishonestly, or insincerely, towards his brother, and did that which was displeasing to him, or that which he hated. (L, TA.) And fulaAnN yafutRu fiI EaDudi fulaAnK wayaqodaHu fiI saAqihi (assumed tropical:) [Such a one seeks to injure such a one by diminishing, or impairing, (in number or power) the people of his house, or his aiders, or assistants; and blames, censures, or reproaches, him]: by EaDudihi being meant Oaholi bayotihi; and by nafosihi saAqihi. (IAar, T. [See EaDudN.]) ― -b3- qadaHa fiI AlqidoHi, (A, K, TA,) aor. as above, (TA,) He (a maker of arrows, A) made a hole in [the end of] the [arrow in the state in which it is termed] qidoH with the tang of the iron head [for the insertion of the said tang]: (A, K, TA:) which hole is termed maqodaHN↓. (A, TA.) ― -b4- qadaHa xitaAma AlxaAbiyapi He broke the sealed clay upon the mouth of the [wine-jar called] xAbyp. (TA. [Accord. to the TA, a verse of Lebeed cited voce Oadokanu presents an ex. of the verb in this sense: but see the explanation given in art. dkn.]) ― -b5- qadaHa AlEayona [He (the operator termed qadRaAH↓, A) performed upon the eye the operation of couching;] he extracted from the eye the corrupt fluid. (S, A. [See naqaba AlEayona.]) ― -b6- qadaHa AlnRaAra, (S, L,) aor. and inf. n. as above, He struck, or produced, fire with a flint &c.: (L:) or qadaHa AlnRaAra mina AlzRanodi [or AlzRanodapi i. e. He produced fire from the piece of stick, or wood, called znd, or rather from that called zndp]; as also AqtdHhA↓: (A:) or qadaHa biAlzRanodi, and AqtdH↓, (K,) or AlzRanoda AqtdH↓, (S,) He endeavoured to produce fire with the znd. (K.) AuHonu liI OaqodaHo laka [app. Bend thou to me branches and I will produce fire for thee to kindle them] is a prov., meaning kuno liI Oakuno laka [Be thou a
helpmate for me and I will be a helpmate for thee]. (TA.) See also another prov. cited and expl. voce difolaI. ― -b7- qadaHa AlXRaIoCu fiI SadoriI (assumed tropical:) The thing made an impression in my bosom, or mind. (L.) ― -b8- qadaHa, (S, A, L,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (L;) and AqtdH↓; (S, A, L, K;) He laded out broth [&c.] (S, A, L, K) with a ladle. (A.) And qadaHa Alqidora He laded out what was in the cookingpot. (L.) And qadaHa maA fiI Oasofali Alqidori He laded out with pains what was in the bottom of the cooking-pot. (L.) And qadaHa maA fiI Oasofali AlbiYori [He laded out what was in the bottom of the well]. (A.) ＝ -A2- qadaHato Eayonuhu, (S, A,) inf. n. qadoHN; (K;) and qdRHt↓, (S,) inf. n. taqodiyHN; (K;) (assumed tropical:) His eye sank, or became depressed, (S, A, K,) so that it became like the qadaH [q. v.]. (A. [See an ex. of the latter v. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. slb.])

2 qadRaHa
2: see above, last explanation. ＝ -A2- qdRH farasahu, (S,) inf. n. taqodiyHN, (K,) (tropical:) He made his horse lean, lank, or slender: (S, K, * TA:) or qadRaHotu xayoliI, inf. n. as above, (tropical:) I made my horses to be [like the arrows termed] qidaAH in slenderness. (A.)

3 muqaAdaHapN c
3. muqaAdaHapN is (tropical:) syn. with muqaAdaEapN, [so in a copy of the A, an evident mistranscription for muqaAcaEapN, with c,] from AlqadoHu meaning “ the act of blaming, censuring, ” &c., syn. AlTRaEonu: thus in the saying, jarato bayonahumaA muqaAdaHapN (tropical:) [A mutual reviling, and vying in foul, or unseemly, speech or language, occurred between them two]. (A.) ― -b2- And qAdHhu signifies (tropical:) naAZarahu [app. as meaning jaAdalahu i. e. (tropical:) He contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, with him: &c.]. (A.)

5 tqdRH c
5. tqdRH: see 5 in art. qrH.

6 tqAcHA c
6. tqAcHA (tropical:) [app. They contended in an altercation, or disputed, or litigated, each with the other]. (A: there immediately following qaAdaHahu as meaning naAZarahu.)

7 AnqdHt AlnRaAru mina AlEuwdi c
7. AnqdHt AlnRaAru mina AlEuwdi Fire was, or became, struck, or produced, from the wood, or stick. (L in art. Sld.)

8 UiqotadaHa
8: see 1, latter half, in three places. ― -b2- AqtdH bizanodihi is [also] a tropical phrase [meaning (tropical:) He endeavoured to avail himself of his (another's) instrumentality: or he availed himself thereof: see the phrase OanaA muqotadiHN bizanodika in art. znd]. (A.) ― -b3- And AqtdH AlOamora means (tropical:) He considered, and looked into, the affair, seeking to elicit what would be its issue, or result. (A, K, TA.) ― -b4- See also 1, again; last quarter.

10 AstqdH zinaAdahu c
10. AstqdH zinaAdahu [lit. signifies He asked, or demanded, that his (another's) zinaAd (pl. of zanodN q. v.) should produce fire: and] is a tropical phrase [meaning (tropical:) He asked, or demanded, that he might avail himself of his (another's) instrumentality]. (A.)

qadoHN c
qadoHN and qaAdiHN↓, [the former, in the CK, in this case, erroneously, with fet-h to the d,] A canker, or corrosion, incident in trees and in teeth: (L, K:) [the former is originally an inf. n.: and] each, in the sense here expl., an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates: (L:) [they are therefore more properly to be expl. as meaning a thing that cankers, or corrodes: and ↓the latter signifies also rottenness, decay, corruption, or unsoundness: (L:) and blackness that appears in the teeth: (S:) and a crack, or fissure, in wood, or in a stick, or rod; (S, L, K;) and so the former word. (K.) ― -b2- Uborapu AlqadoHi: see miqodaHN.

qidoHN c
qidoHN An arrow, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) [i. e.] the pared wood, or rod, of an arrow, (Mgh,) before it has been furnished with feathers and a head: (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.:) or an arrow when straightened, and fit to be feathered and headed: (T, voce bariIRN, q. v.:) or a rod that has attained the desired state of growth, and been pruned, and cut according to the required length for an arrow: (AHn:) and [particularly] such as is used in the game called Almayosir: (S, L:) pl. qidaAHN, (S, A, Mgh, L, K,) a pl. of mult., (TA,) and [of pauc., and accord. to the L of qidoHN in the last of the senses expl. above,] OaqoduHu (S, L, K) and OaqodaAHN (L, TA) and OaqaAdiyHu, (S, L, K,) which last is a pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of OaqodaAHN]. (L.) [One says, in speaking of the arrows used in the game called Daraba biAlqidaAHi Almayosir, and Daraba AlqidaAHa: and in speaking of the two arrows used in practising sortilege, Daraba biAlqidoHayoni: see art. Drb, p. 1778, col. iii.] SadaqaniI wasoma qidoHihi (tropical:) He told me truly what was the brand of his gaming-arrow] is a prov.; meaning he told me the truth: (A, * TA:) so says AZ: (TA:) or it means he told me what was in his mind: the wsm of the qdH is the mark that denotes its share [of the slaughtered camel]; and the sign is sometimes made by means of fire. (Meyd.) And they say, OaboSiro wasoma qidoHika (tropical:) [See, or look at, the brand of thy gaming-arrow]; (TA;) which is [also] a prov.; (A;) meaning know thyself. (A, TA.) And qidoHu Qboni muqobilK (assumed tropical:) [The gaming-arrow of Ibn-Mukbil, which seems to have been one remarkable for frequent good luck,] is a proverbial expression relating to goodness of effect. (TA.)

qadaHN c
qadaHN [A drinking-cup or bowl;] a certain vessel (Msb, K) for drinking, (S, Mgh,) well known, (Msb,) large enough to satisfy the thirst of two men: (A 'Obeyd, K:) or a small one and a large one: (K:) [in the K voce EulobapN, it is applied to a vessel used for milking, sometimes made of camel's skin and sometimes of wood: it was used for drinking and for milking:] pl. OaqodaAHN. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) It is said in a trad., laA tajoEaluwniI kaqadaHi AlrRakibi [Make not ye me to be like the drinkingcup of the rider on a camel]; meaning, make not ye me to be last in being mentioned; because the rider on a camel suspends his qdH on the hinder part of his saddle when he is finishing the puttingon of his apparatus, (Mgh, TA,) placing it behind him. (TA.) ― -b2- Also A certain measure of capacity, in Egypt, containing two hundred and thirty-two daraAhim. (Es-Suyootee in his “ Husn el-Mohádarah. ” See UirodabRN, in art. rdb.)

qadoHapN c
qadoHapN A single act of striking, or producing, fire. (IAth, K, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) An elicitation, by examination, of the real state or nature of a case or an affair. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- And A single act of lading out broth [&c. with a ladle]. (L, in so in the CK.) ― -b4- See also what next follows.

qudoHapN c
qudoHapN A ladleful of broth: (S, L, K:) and some say that qadoHapN↓ signifies the same. (L.) You say, OaEoTiniI qudoHapF mino maraqatika Give thou to me a ladleful of thy broth. (S.)

qidoHapN c
qidoHapN The act of striking or producing, fire (IAth, K, TA) with the miqodaHapN. (IAth, TA.) Hence the saying, lawo XaMCa QllRehu lajaEala lilnRaAsi qidoHapa ZulomapK kamaA jaEala lahumo qidoHapa nuwrK [If God had willed, He had assigned to men the faculty of producing darkness, like as He has assigned to them the faculty of producing light]: (K, TA:) a trad. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] (assumed tropical:) Consideration and examination of an affair, to elicit what may be its issue, or result. (K, TA.)

qaduwHN c
qaduwHN and OaqodaHu↓, (K,) or qaduwHN OaqodaHu↓, (A,) (tropical:) The cubaAb [i. e. common fly, or flies]: (A, K, TA:) which one never sees otherwise than as though producing fire with the two fore legs [by rubbing them together like as one rubs together the zanod and the zanodap]. (TA. [But in a verse cited by Meyd in his Proverbs, instead of AlqdwH AlAqdH↓, we find AlqaduwH AlOaqoraH; and he says that AlOaqoraHu (q. v.) is from AlquroHapu, and that every cubaAb has upon its face a quroHap (or white mark): see that verse in Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 48: and see also EM, p. 228.]) ＝ -A2- qaduwHN also signifies A well (rakiIRN) of which the water is laded out with the hand: (S, K:) or a well (biYorN) of which the water is not taken otherwise than by successive ladings [with the hand]. (A.)

quduwHN c
quduwHN The pieces of wood of the [camel's saddle called] raHol [for which the TA has rml, but the right reading is shown by the context]: a word having no singular. (TA.)

qadiyHN c
qadiyHN Broth: (K: [app. because laded out:]) or some broth remaining in the bottom of the cooking-pot: (A:) or what remains in the bottom of the cooking-pot and is laded out with pains; (S, L, K;) as also maqoduwHN↓. (L.)

qidaAHapN c
qidaAHapN The art, or craft, of making vessels such as are called OaqodaAH [pl. of qadaHN]. (K.)

qadRaAHN c
qadRaAHN: see 1, latter half: ― -b2- and see qadRaAHapN. As an epithet applied to a zanod [q. v.], (K in art.
xwr,) it signifies That produces much fire. (TK in that art.) ― -b3- See also miqodaHN. ＝ -A2- Also A maker of vessels such as are called OaqodaAH [pl. of qadaHN]. (K.) ＝ -A3- And a subst. signifying The blossoms of plants before they open: (TA:) or the extremities of fresh, juicy, plants: (K:) or the extremities, consisting of fresh, juicy, leaves, of plants: (TA:) or soft, or tender, suckers or offsets, of [the species of trefoil, or clover, called] fiSofiSap: (Az, K, TA:) of the dial. of El-'Irák: n. un. qadRaAHapN↓. (TA.)

qadRaAHapN c
qadRaAHapN A stone from which one strikes fire; (As, S, A, K;) and so qadRaAHN↓. (T, S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also qadRaAHN, last sentence.

qaAdiHN c
qaAdiHN: see qaAdiHapN: ― -b2- and see also qadoHN, in two places. ― -b3- hecaA maMCN laA yanaAmu qaAdiHuhu [This is water of which the lader-out will not sleep] is said in describing such [water] as is little in quantity. (A, TA.)

qaAdiHapN c
qaAdiHapN [A canker-worm;] the worm (Lth, S, Mgh, L, K) that cankers, or corrodes, trees and teeth: (Lth, * Mgh, * L, TA:) [coll. gen. n. qaAdiHN↓; occurring in the K in art. xrb, &c.:] pl. qawaAdiHu. (L.) One says, qado OasoraEato fiI OasonaAnihi AlqawaAdiHi [The canker-worms have quickly come into his teeth]. (L.)

OaqodaHu c
OaqodaHu: see qaduwHN, in three places.

maqodaHN c
maqodaHN: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

miqodaHN c
miqodaHN [A couching-needle; called thus, and Uiborapu AlqadoHi↓, in the present day. ― -b2- Also], (K, and so in some copies of the S,) and miqodaHapN↓, (A, TA, and so in other copies of the S,) and miqodaAHN↓, and qadRaAHN↓, (K,) The thing (S, A, K) of iron (A, K) with which one strikes fire. (S, A, K.) ― -b3- And the first, A ladle; (S, A, K;) as also miqodaHapN↓. (A.) sataOotiyka bimaA fiI qaEorahaA AlmiqodaHapu↓ [The ladle will bring to thee what is in the bottom thereof] is a prov., meaning, that to which thou art blind will become apparent, or manifest, to thee. (A.)

miqodaHapN c
miqodaHapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

xayolN muqadRaHapN c
xayolN muqadRaHapN (tropical:) Horses that are lean, lank, or slender; as though made slender [like the arrows termed qidaAH: see 2]. (TA.)

EayonN muqadRiHapN c
EayonN muqadRiHapN (assumed tropical:) An eye that is sunk or depressed [so as to be like the qadaH: see 1, last signification]. (TA.) And xabolN muqadRiHapN (assumed tropical:) Horses whose eyes are sunk or depressed. (TA.)

miqodaAHN c
miqodaAHN: see miqodaHN.

maqoduwHN c
maqoduwHN, applied to broth: see qadiyHN.

XajarN mutaqaAdiHN c
XajarN mutaqaAdiHN Trees having soft, weak, branches, which, when the wind puts them in motion, blaze forth with fire; but which when used for producing fire for a useful purpose, yield no fire at all: whence one says to him who has no ground of pretension to respect or honour, nor parentage, genealogy, or pedigree, of a sound quality, zanodaAka lilomutaqaAdiHi (assumed tropical:) [lit. Thy two pieces of stick, or wood, for producing fire pertain to the trees that have soft and weak branches, &c.]. (TA.)

1 qadarotu AlXRaIoCa c
1. qadarotu AlXRaIoCa, aor.
qadira
and
qadura
, [or the former only accord. to the Mgh., as will be seen by what follows,] inf. n. qadorN, (S, Msb,) is from AltRaqodiyru, (S,) [or] it signifies the same as qdRrtu↓ AlXRaIoCa, inf. n. taqodiyrN: (Msb:) [which latter phrase is afterwards mentioned in the S, but unexplained: the meaning is, I measured the thing; computed, or determined, its quantity, measure, size, bulk, proportion, extent, amount, sum, limit or limits, or number:] AlXRaIoCa qdRr↓ signifies he computed, or determined, or computed by conjecture, the quantity, measure, size, bulk, proportion, extent, amount, sum, or number, of the thing, (Hazarahu,) in order that he might know how much it was. (IKtt.) It is said in a trad., UicaA gumRa Ealayokumu AlhilaAlu faQqodiruwA lahu, and faQqoduruwA; (S, Msb; *) or Uino gomRa Ealayokumo faQqodiruwA, with kesr to the d; (Mgh, Msb; *) for faQqoduruwA, with damm, is wrong; (Mgh;) and Ks. say, that you say qadarotu AlXRaIoCa, aor. Oaqodiruhu, with kesr, and that he had not heard any other aor.: (TA:) the meaning of the trad. is, [When the new moon (of Ramadán) is hidden from you by a cloud or mist, or if it be so hidden,] compute ye (qadRiruwA↓) the number of the days to it, (Mgh, Msb,) and so complete Shaabán, making it thirty days: (S, * Mgh, * Msb:) or, as some say, compute ye (qadRiruwA) the mansions of the moon, and its course in them [to it, i. e., to the new moon]. (Msb.) See also 5. ― -b2- [Hence, app., the saying,] Ouqoduro bicaroEika bayonanaA See thou and know thy rank, or estimation, among us. (AO.) ― -b3- Hence also,] maA qadaruwA QllReha HaqRa qadorihi [Kur., vi. 91, and other places, meaning, And they have not estimated God with the estimation that is due to Him: or] and they have not magnified, or honoured, God, with the magnifying, or honouring, that is due to Him: (S, K:) for qadorN signifies [also] a magnifying, or honouring: (K:) or have not assigned to God the attributes that are due to Him: (Lth:) or have not known what God is in reality. (El-Basáïr.) ― -b4- qadara AlXRaIoCa biAlXRaIoCi, aor. [
qadira
and]
qadura
, (L,) inf. n. qadorN; (L, K;) and bh qdRrhu↓; (L;) He measured the thing by the thing: (L, K: *) and EalaI mivaAlihi qdRrhu↓ he measured it by its measure: (S, K, art. qys:) and bayona AlOamorayoni qdRr↓ he measured, or compared, the two things, or cases, together; syn. qaAyasa; (K, art. qys;) and so bayonahumaA qaAdara↓. (L, art. qys.) ― -b5- [Hence, app.,] qadara AlOamora, (L, K,) and UilaI AlOamori, (L,) aor.
qadira
(L, K,) and
qadura
, (L,) inf. n. qadorN; (L, K;) [and qdRrhu↓;] He thought upon the thing, or affair, (L,) and considered its end, issue, or result, (L, K,) and measured, or compared, one part of it with another; (L;) he measured it, compared one part of it with another, considered it, and thought upon it. (L.) See also 2. ― -b6- qadarotu Ealayohi AlvRawoba, (S, K, *) inf. n. qadorN, (S,) I made the garment according to his measure; adapted it to his measure: (S, K: *) [and qadarotu Ealayohi AlXRaIoCa app. signifies I made the thing according to his, or its, measure; proportioned, or adapted, the thing to him, or it; for wSfth, by which it is explained in the TA, seems to be, as IbrD thinks, a mistake for waDaEotuhu:] and AlXRaIoCa qdRr↓ signifies, in like manner, he made the thing by measure, or according to a measure; or proportioned it; syn. jaEalahu biqadarK: (IKtt:) the primary meaning of taqodiyrN↓ is the making a thing according to the measure of another thing. (Bd- xv. 60.) ― -b7- [Hence,] qadara QllRehu celika Ealayohi, aor.
qadira
and
qadura
, inf. n. qadorN and qadarN, (K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Lh, Msb,) and maqodarapN; (S [unless this be a simple subst.];) and Elyh qdRrhu↓, (K,) [which is more common,] inf. n. taqodiyrN; (TA;) and lahu; (K;) [God decreed, appointed, ordained, or decided, that against him; and for him, or to him; accord. to an explanation of qadarN in the K: or decreed, &c., that against him; and for him, or to him; adapting it to his particular case; accord. to an explanation of qadarN by Lth, and of qadorN and qadarN in the S, and of qadarN in the Msb: see qadorN, below.] You say also qadara QllRehu lahu bixayorK [God decreed, &c., for him, good]. (K.) ― -b8- Also, qadara, (K,) aor.
qadira
and
qadura
, inf. n. qadorN, (TA,) He [God] distributed, divided, or apportioned, [as though by measure,] sustenance, or the means of subsistence. (K, TA. In the CK, the verb is qadRara.) Hence, say some, the appellation of layolapu Alqadori, [in the Kur, ch. xcvii.,) as being The night wherein the means of subsistence are apportioned. (TA.) See also qadorN, below. ― -b9- Also, aor.
qadira
and
qadura
, but the former is that which is adopted by the seven readers [of the Kur-án], and is the more chaste, (Msb,) He (God) straitened, or rendered scanty, [as though He measured and limited,] the means of subsistence: (Bd, xiii. 26, and other places; and Msb:) and qudira Ealayohi rizoquhu, [see Kur, lxv. 7,] inf. n. qadorN, his means of subsistence were straitened to him; like qutira. (S, TA.) You say qadaru Ealayohi AlXRaIoCa, aor.
qadira
and
qadura
, (Lh, TA,) inf. n. qadorN (K,) and qadarN and qudorapN; (Lh, TA;) and qdRr↓, inf. n. taqodiyrN; (K;) He rendered the thing strait, or distressing, to him. (Lh, K, * TA.) And qadara EalaI EiyaAlihi He scanted his household; or was niggardly or parsimonious towards them, in expenditure; like qatara. (S.) It is said in the Kur, [xxi. 87,] faZanRa Oano lano naqodira Ealayohi And he thought that we would not
straiten him: (Fr, AHeyth:) or the meaning is, lano nuqadRira Ealayohi maA qadRaronaA mino kawonihi fiI baToni AlHuwti, for naqodir is syn. with nuqadRir; (Zj;) and this is correct; i. e., we would not decree against him what we decreed, of the straitness [that should befall him] in the belly of the fish: it cannot be from Alqudorapu [meaning power, or ability]; for he who thinks this is an unbeliever. (Az, TA.) ― -b10- Also, qadarahu, aor.
qadira
, inf. n. qadaArahN; (K;) and qdRrhu↓; (TA;) He prepared it. (K, TA.) ― -b11- And the former, He assigned, or appointed, a particular time for it. (K.) ＝ -A2- qadarotu EalaI AlXRaIoCi, aor.
qadira
(S, Msb, K) and
qadura
, (Ks, K,) but the former is that which is commonly known, (TA,) inf. n. qudorapN and qidoraAnN, (S, K,) with kesr, (K,) but the latter is written in a copy of the T, qadaraAnN, (TA,) [and in one copy of the S qudoraAnN,] and qadorN (Ks, Fr, Akh, K) and maqodurapN and maqodarahN and maqodirahN (S, K) and miqodaArN (K) and maqodarN (TA) and qadaArN (Sgh, K) and qidaArN; (Lh, K;) and qadirotu Ealayohi, aor.
qadara
, (S, K, *) a form of weak authority, mentioned by Yaakoob, (S,) and by Sgh from Th, and said by IKtt, to be of the dial. of Benoo-Murrah, of Ghatafán, (TA,) inf. n. qadarN (Ks, Fr, Akh, K) and qadaArapN and quduwrahN and quduwrN, (K, TA,) these four are of qadira; (TA;) and all that are here mentioned as from the K, are inf. ns.; (TK;) and Elyh Aqtdrt↓; (S, K, * TA;) or this has a stronger signification; (IAth;) I had power, or ability, to do, effect, accomplish, achieve, attain, or compass, &c., the thing; I was able to do it, I was able to prevail against it. (Msb, K, * TA.) You say maA liI Ealayoka maqoduwrapN, and maqodarapN, and maqodirapN, i. e. qudorapN, [I have not power over thee.] (S.) And in like manner, Almaqoduwrapu tucohibu AlHafiyZapa [Power drives away that care which one has of what is sacred, or inviolable, or of religion, to avoid suspicion]. (S.) ― -b2- See also qudorapN, below. ＝ -A3- qadara and Aqtdr↓ are like Tabaxa and UiTRabaxa [meaning He cooked, and he cooked for himself, in a qidor, or cooking-pot]. (S, TA.) You say qadara Alqidora, (K, * TA,) aor.
qadura
and
qadira
, inf. n. qadorN, (K,) He cooked [the contents of] the cooking-pot. (K, * TA.) And OamaraniI Oano Oaqodura laHomFA He ordered me to cook a cooking-pot of flesh-meat. (TA, from a trad.) And Oamo taXotawuwna Oataqotadiruwna↓ Do ye cook [for yourselves] in a cooking-pot, or roast? (S.)

2 qdRr c
2. qdRr, inf. n. taqodiyrN: see 1, in most of its senses. ― -b2- He meditated, considered, or exercised thought in arranging and preparing, a thing or an affair; (T, K, * El-Basáïr;) either making use of his reason, and building thereon; the doing of which is praiseworthy; or according to his desire or appetite; as in the Kur, lxxiv. 18 and 19; the doing of which is blameable; (ElBasáïr;) or by means of marks, whereby to cut it. (T.) ― -b3- He intended a thing or an affair; he determined upon it. (T.) [Said of God, He decreed, appointed, ordained, destined, predestined, or predetermined a thing.] ― -b4- [Hence, app., qdRr kacaA, in grammar, He meant, or held, or made, such a thing to be supplied, or understood. You say taqodiyruhu kacaA Its (a phrase's) implied, or virtual, meaning, or meaning by implication, is thus. And yuqadRaru bikacaA Its implied meaning is to be expressed by saying thus. And taqodiyrFA is said in the sense of implicatively, or virtually, as opposed to lafoZFA or literally. ― -b5- And He supposed such a thing.] ― -b6- He made; syn. jaEala and SanaEa. Ex., in the Kur, [xli. 9,] waqadRara fiyhaA OaqowaAtahaA And He made therein its foods, or aliments. And it is said in the Kur, [x. 5,] waqadRarahu manaAzila And hath made for it [the moon] mansions. (TA.) ― -b7- He knew. So in the Kur, xv. 60; and lxxiii. 20, according to the Basáïr. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qdRrhu, inf. n. taqodiyrN, He asserted him to be, or named him, or called him, a qadariIR: (Fr, Sgh, K:) but this is post-classical. (TA.) ＝ -A3- qdRrhu, (Msb,) or Aqdrhu↓, (K,) [the latter of which is the more common,] He empowered him; enabled him; rendered him able. (Msb, K.) You say Aqdrhu QllRehu EalaI kacaA God empowered him, enabled him, or rendered him able, to do such a thing. (K, * TA.)

3 qAdr bayona AlOamorayoni c
3. qAdr bayona AlOamorayoni: see 1. ― -b2- qaAdarotuhu, (K,) inf. n. muqaAdarapN, (TA,) I measured myself, or my abilities, with him, or his, (qaAyasotuhu,) and did as he did: (K:) or I vied, or contended, with him in power, or strength. (A, TA.)

4 Oaqodara
4: see 2.

5 taqadRara
5: see 7. ― -b2- kaAna yataqadRaru fiI maraDihi Oayona OanaA Alyawoma [He (Mohammad) used to compute, or reckon, in his mind, in his disease, Where am I to-day?] i. e., he used to compute, or reckon, (yuqadRiru,) [in his disease,] the days of his wives, when it was his turn to visit each of them. (TA, from a trad.) See also 1. ― -b3- tqdRr It (a thing, S,) became prepared, (S, K,) lahu for him. (S.)

7 Anqdr c
7. Anqdr (S, K) and tqdRr↓ (A) It (a garment) agreed with, or was according to, the measure (S, A, K.) You say tqdRr AlvRawobu Ealayohi The garment agreed with, or was according to, his measure. (A.)

8 Aqtdrhu c
8. Aqtdrhu He made it of middling size; expl. by jaEalahu qadorFA. (JK, TA. [In the latter, the explanation is without any syll. signs; but in the former I find it fully pointed, and immediately followed by XaIoCN muqotadarN, thus pointed, and explained as signifying “ a thing of middling size, whether in length or tallness or in width or breadth. ”]) ＝ -A2- See also 1, last two significations.

10 Astqdr QllReha xayorFA c
10. Astqdr QllReha xayorFA He begged God to decree, appoint, ordain, or decide, for him good. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- OalRehumRa UinRiI Oasotaqodiruka biqudoratika O God, I beg Thee to give me power to do it, by Thy power. (TA, from a trad.)

qadorN c
qadorN The quantity, quantum, measure, magnitude, size, bulk, proportion, extent, space, amount, sum, or number attained, of a thing; (S, Msb, K;) as also qadarN↓ (Msb, K) and qudorN↓ (Fr, Sgh, K) and miqodaArN↓. (Msb, K.) You say hecaA qadoru hecaA, and qadaruhu↓, This is the like of this [in quantity, &c.; is commensurate with, or proportionate to, this; and so hcA hcA bimiqodaAri↓]. (Msb.) And humo qadoru miAYpK, and mAYp qadaru↓, They are as many as a hundred. (Z, Msb.) And Oaxaca biqadori HaqRihi, and biqadarihi↓, and bimiqodaArihi↓, He took as much as his due, or right. And qaraOa biqadori AlfaAtiHapi, and biqadarihaA↓, and bimiqodaArihaA↓, He read as much as the Fátihah. (Msb.) And Oaqamotu Einodahu qadora Oano yafoEala kacaA I remained at his abode long enough for him to do thus. (Meyd, TA.)
