Hence, (TA,) OuqoruSiyhi biAlmaACi, (S, Mgh, * Msb, * TA,) or bAlmAC qarRiSiyhi↓, (S, M, TA,) said in a trad., (S, M, Msb,) respecting the menstrual blood, (S, M,) accord. to different relations: (S, TA:) the latter means, Separate thou its particles [so I here render qaTRiEiyhi] with water; (A'Obeyd, S, TA;) and the former has a similar [but less intensive] meaning: (TA:) or the former means, wash it with the ends of thy fingers; (S, Msb;) and remove it with the nail or the like: (Msb:) or take it [off] with the ends of the fingers: (Mgh:) or rub it hard with the ends of the fingers and the nails, and pour upon it water, so as to remove it and the mark of it. (Az, in Msb, art. Ht; and IAth, * in TA, in the present art.) ― -b7- You say also, qaraSa AlEajiyna, (A,) inf. n. qaroSN; (K;) or qrRShu↓; (M;) He cut the dough to spread it out: (M, A:) or the former, [simply,] he spread out the dough: (K:) or qaraSati AlEajiyna, aor.
qaruSa
, inf. n. as above, (S, TA,) she cut the dough, (S,) or spread it out and cut it, (TA,) into pieces, each such as is termed quroSap: (S, TA:) and qurRSthu↓, (S, Msb,) inf. n. taqoriySN, (S, K,) she cut it into many pieces, (S, Msb, K,) each such as is termed quroSap, (S,) or quroS. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- qariSa, aor.
qaraSa
, (K,) inf. n. qaraSN, (TK,) signifies daAma EalaI AlmunaAfarapi waAlgiybapi (tropical:) [He continued in a course of mutual aversion and defamation]. (K, TA.)

2 qarRaSa
2: see 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b2- qrRS AlmaMCa (tropical:) He cooled the water; or made it cold; as also with s: (TA:) or he made the water cold so that its coldness pinched, or pained. (A.) ― -b3- qrRS AllRabana (tropical:) He rendered the milk biting to the tongue; or acid.] (TA.) See qaAriSN.

3 qaAoraSa
3: [qArShu, inf. n. muqaAraSapN, originally, He pinched him, being pinched by him. ― -b2- And hence, (tropical:) He regarded him with mutual aversion, and mutually defamed him; or exchanged bad words with him; for] AlmuqaAraSapu signifies AlmunaAfarapu waAlgiybapu: (TA:) or the speaking bad words, one to another. (KL.) You say, bayonahumaA muqaAraSaAtN (tropical:) [Between them two are mutual aversions and defamations]. (A, TA.) See also 6.

6 raOayotuhumaA yataqaAraZaAni vumRa raOayotuhumaA yataqaAraSaAni c
6. raOayotuhumaA yataqaAraZaAni vumRa raOayotuhumaA yataqaAraSaAni (tropical:) [I saw them two eulogizing each other: then I saw them two regarding each other with aversion, and defaming each other, or speaking bad words, each to the other]. (A, TA.) See 3.

quroSN c
quroSN and quroSapN↓ A round cake (K, * TA,) of bread; (S, K, TA;) syn. xubozapN (K, TA) and ragiyfN: (TA:) or such as is very small: (TA:) [or, accord. to present usage, small, but thick:] the former word is the more common: (TA:) or a [round] piece of dough: (M, A: *) [and any similar thing, small, and of a round, flattened form:] pl., (of the former, S, Msb,) OaqoraASN [a pl. of pauc.] and qiraSapN (S, M, Msb, K) and qiraASN, (M, TA,) [both pls. of mult.;] and (of quroSapN, S, TA,) quraSN; (S, K;) and OaqoriSapN [is a pl. of pauc. of either]. (K, art. bt.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened to the thing above mentioned, (M,) AlquroSu, (M, TA,) or quroSu AlXRamosi, (S, A, TA,) or AlquroSapu↓, (K,) The disk (Eayon) of the sun: (S, M, K, TA:) and sometimes the sun, as a common, or general, term: (M:) or the disk (Eyn) of the sun when it is setting: (TA:) you say, gaAba quroSu AlXRamosi [the disk of the sun set, or disappeared]: (A, TA:) or the Eyn of the sun is called quroSap↓, with p, at the setting. (Lth, TA.) ― -b3- See also muqarRaSN. ― -b4- [quroSu XahodK or EasalK A honey-comb: or the same, and XahodK quroSapu↓ or EasalK, a portion of a honey-comb: pl. qiraSap.]

qaroSapN c
[qaroSapN inf. n. of un. of qaraSahu; A pinch, or a pinching: &c.: pl. qaraSaAtN.] You say, qaraSahumu AlbaEuwDu qaraSaAtK raqaSuwA minohaA raqaSaAtK (tropical:) [The gnats bit them with several bitings, in consequence of which they danced with several dancings.] (A, TA.)

quroSapN c
quroSapN: see quroSN, in four places.

qaruwSN c
qaruwSN: see qarRaASN, in two places.

qariySN c
qariySN A kind of condiment, or seasoning; (Lth, M, K;) called in the dial. of Keys qariysN, q. v. (TA.)

qarRaASN c
qarRaASN [an intensive epithet from qaraSahu; That pinches much: &c.: as also qaruwSN↓. ― -b2- And hence,] lijaAmN qarRaASN and qaruwSN↓ (tropical:) A bit that hurts the beast of carriage. (A, TA.)

qaAriSN c
qaAriSN [act. part. n. of qaraSahu; Pinching: &c. (See an ex. voce mawoquwSN.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Biting; applied to a flea, &c. ― -b3- And hence,] (tropical:) A certain insect, like the baqR [q. v.,] (K,) that bites. (TA.) ― -b4- [Hence also, (tropical:) Pinching, or paining;] applied to cold. (A, TA.) ― -b5- And, applied to milk, (As, S, A, K,) and beverage, (M,) or such as is termed nabiyc, (A, TA,) (tropical:) That bites the tongue: (As, S, M, A, K:) or, when applied to milk, it is to camels' milk in particular, and signifies sour: (M, TA:) in the K is added, or sour milk upon which much fresh is milked so that the acidity goes away: but this is a mistake; for it is an explanation, given by Sgh, of the epithet mumaHRalN, occurring in a verse of Abu-n-Nejm, where it is coupled with qaAriSN. (TA.) It is said in a proverb, EadaA AlqaAriSu faHazara (tropical:) What was biting to the tongue attained to an excessive degree, so that it became acid: meaning, the affair, or case, became distressing. (S.) ― -b6- [Hence also,] qaAriSapN [for kalimapN qaAriSapN] (tropical:) A saying that hurts; (S, M, A;) or that pains; (Msb;) or that troubles and pains one (K, * TA) like the pinching of the body: (TA:) pl. qawaAriSu. (S, A, K.)

miqoraSapN c
miqoraSapN A receptacle for milk, in which it is rendered biting to the tongue, or acid: (yuqarRaSu fiyhi:) pl. maqaAriSu. (TA.)

muqarRaSN c
muqarRaSN Cut in pieces, [by being] taken between two things. (M, TA.) ― -b2- A woman's ornament round like a quroS: (IF, K:) or set, or adorned, with jewels: (IDrd, M:) such is also called quroS↓. (TA.) [This latter name is now applied
to A round convex ornament, generally composed of diamonds set in gold; but sometimes of thin embossed gold, usually with a false emerald set in the centre; worn upon the crown of the headdress by women. For further descriptions, and a figured specimen of each kind, see my work on the Manners and Customs of the Modern Egyptians, Appendix A.]

1 qaraDahu c
1. qaraDahu, aor.
qariDa
, (S, M, A, &c.,) inf. n. qaroDN, (S, M, Msb,) He cut it; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely a thing, (S, Msb,) or a garment, or piece of cloth, (A, Mgh,) with the miqoraAD, (A, Mgh, Msb,) and with the miqoraADaAni; (Msb;) and in like manner, [or as signifying he cut it much, or frequently, or repeatedly,] you say, qrRDhu↓, (M, TA,) inf. n. taqoriyDN: (TA:) this is the primary signification. (TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) said of a rat, or mouse, (A'Obeyd, S, A, Mgh, Msb,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (S, * Msb, TA,) He [cut it with his teeth; gnawed it; or] ate it; (Msb;) namely a garment, or piece of cloth, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) and bread, &c. (TA.) You say also qaraDahu binaAbihi He cut it with his canine tooth, or fang. (A.) And qaraDa AlbaEiyru jarRatahu, (M, TA,) aor. as above, (A, TA,) and so the inf. n., (TA,) The camel chewed his cud: (M, A, TA:) or returned it [to his mouth, to be chewed again, or to his stomach]. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] qaraDa ribaATahu, (S, M, A, K,) [lit.] He cut, or severed, his bond, i. e. the bond of his heart; and consequently, (TA,) (assumed tropical:) he died; (IAar, M, K, TA;) as also qaraDa alone, (S, [in which the former is not explained] O, Msb, K,) and qariDa: (IAar, O, K:) or (assumed tropical:) he was at the point of death. (K.) And you say, jaMCa waqado qaraDa ribaATahu (AZ, Az, S, &c.) (assumed tropical:) He came harassed, or distressed, or fatigued, and at the point of death: (AZ, Az:) or (tropical:) harassed, or distressed, by thirst, or by fatigue: (A:) or (assumed tropical:) in a state of intense thirst and hunger: (M:) said of a man: (S:) mentioned in the S in such a manner as [appears] to indicate that the verb has here the first of the significations mentioned in this art.; but this is not the case [as is shown in the S itself in art. rbT]. (TA.) See also 7. ＝ -A2- [Hence also,] qaraDotu AlwaAdiI (assumed tropical:) I passed through, or across, the valley. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur, [xviii. 16,] waUicaA garabato taqoriDuhumo caAta AlXRimaAli (assumed tropical:) And when it [the sun] set, to leave them behind on the left; to pass by and beyond them, leaving them on its left: (S, K:) so explained by AO, or by A'Obeyd: (so accord. to different copies of the S,) to leave them and pass by them on the left; not falling upon them at all: (Jel:) or to turn aside, or away, from them, on the left: (Msb:) or to be over against them, on the left: from qaraDotuhu, meaning Hacawotuhu, i. e. I was over against him, or it; as also OaqoraDotuhu↓. (JK.) And a man says to his companion, Hast thou passed by such and such a place? and the man asked says qaraDotuhu caAta Alyamiyni layolFA (assumed tropical:) [I passed by it, leaving it behind, on the right, by night]. (S.) The Arabs say, qaraDotuhu caAta Alyamiyni, and caAta AlXRimaAli, and qubulFA, and duburFA, (assumed tropical:) I was over against him, or it, on the right, and on the left, and before, and behind. (Fr.) You say also, qaraDa AlmakaAna, (M, Msb, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He turned aside, or away, from the place. (M, Msb, K.) And qaraDa fiI AlOaroDi (assumed tropical:) He traversed the land. (Z.) And qaraDa fiI sayorihi, (M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He turned to the right and left in his going or journeying. (M, K.) And qariDa, like samiEa, (assumed tropical:) He, or it, passed away from a thing to another thing. (IAar, Sgh, L, K.) ＝ -A3- Hence also, (TA,) qaraDa AlXRiEora, (S, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (S, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S,) (tropical:) He said, spoke, uttered, or recited, poetry; or he poetized, or versified; syn. qaAla AlXRiEora: (A'Obeyd, S, K:) or he composed poetry according to rule: (Msb:) because poetry consists of cut feet: or because it is called qariyD as being likened to the cud: (A:) or because it is language cut out: (Msb:) or as being likened to a garment; as though the poet cut it and divided it into portions; although MF denies that this phrase is from qaraDa as signifying “ he cut: ” he has also assigned to qaroDu AlXRiEori a signification which belongs to taqoriyDN, q. v. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Hence also, qaraDahu as syn. with qaAraDahu, q. v. (TA.)

2 qarRaDa
2: see 1, first signification. ＝ -A2- taqoriyDN also signifies (assumed tropical:) The art of poetry: (M, TA:) or the criticism thereof; the picking out the faults thereof; and the discriminating, by consideration, of what is good thereof from what is bad, both expressed and speculative. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also, like taqoriyZN; (assumed tropical:) The act of praising: or dispraising: (S, TA:) or it has both these contr. significations; (K, TA;) relating to good and to evil; whereas tqryZ relates only to praise and good. (TA.) You say, fulaAn yuqarRiDu SaAHibahu (assumed tropical:) Such a one praises his companion: or dispraises him. (S.)

3 qArDhu c
3. qArDhu, inf. n. muqaAraDapN and qiraADN, (M,) [He lent to him, and received from him, a loan: or it signifies, or signifies also,] i. q. OaqoraDahu, q. v. (L, TA.) ― -b2- qiraADN (S, A, Msb, K) and muqaAraDapN, (S, A, K,) with the people of El-Hijáz, (TA,) also signify i. q. muDaArabapN; (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as though it were a contract for traversing the land [for traffic], (K,) from AlqaroDu fiI AlsRayori, or, as Z says, from AlqaroDu fiI AlOaroDi, meaning “ the traversing the land, ” like as mDArbp is from AlDRarobu fiI AlOaroDi; (TA;) and the form of the contract is what is shown by the following explanation. (K.) You say, qaAraDotuhu, (S, A, Mgh,) or qaAraDotuhu mina AlmaAli, (Msb,) I gave to him property (S, A, Mgh, K *) muDaArabapF, (A, Mgh,) [i. e.] that he might traffic with it, on the condition that the gain should be between us, and the loss should fall upon the property. (S, K. [See also DaArabahu.]) ― -b3- qArDhu, (S, K,) inf. n. muqaAraDapN, (TA,) also signifies (tropical:) He requited him; he compensated him; (S, K;) and so qaraDahu↓, (S, K,) inf. n. qaroDN. (TA.) Hence the saying of Abu-l-Wardà, (TA,) Uino qaAraDota AlnRaAsa qaAraDuwka waUino tarakotahumo lamo yatorukuwka waUino harabota minohumo Oadorakuwka (tropical:) (A, * TA) [If thou requite men their evil deeds, they will requite thee; and if thou leave them, they will not leave thee; and if thou flee from them, they will overtake thee]: meaning if thou do evil to them, they will do the like thereof to thee; and if thou leave them, thou wilt not be safe from them, for they will not let thee alone; and if thou revile them and injure them, they will revile thee and injure thee: he said this intending thereby to censure them: and it is from the signification of “ cutting. ” (TA.) [See also qaroDN, below.] You say also, fulaAnN yuqaAriDu AlnRaAsa, inf. n. muqaAraDapN, (tropical:) Such a one accords, or agrees, with men. (A.) And qaAraDotuhu AlzRiyaArapa (tropical:) [I interchanged visiting with him]. (A.)

4 AqrDhu c
4. AqrDhu He cut off for him a portion, to be requited, or compensated, for it. (Sgh, K.) [And hence,] He gave him, or granted him, a qaroD [or loan, or the like]; (S, M, A, * Mgh, * K;) and qaAraDahu↓ signifies the same as AqrDhu. (L, TA.) You say also, AqrDhu AlmaAla, (M, Msb,) wagayorahu, (M,) [He lent him the property, &c.;] he gave him the property, &c., as a qaroD; (M;) he gave him the property, [&c.,] to demand its return. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxiii. 20,] waOaqoriDuwA QllReha qaroDFA HasanFA [lit. And lend ye to God a good loan; meaning (assumed tropical:) give ye to God good service for which to be requited]: (S, TA:) it is not here said UiqoraADFA because the simple subst. [as distinguished from the inf. n.] is what is meant. (TA.) And again, in the same, [ii. 246, and lvii. 11,] mano caA QlRaciI yuqoriDu QllReha qaroDFA HasanFA, meaning, accord. to Aboo-Is-hák the Grammarian, (assumed tropical:) [Who is he who will offer unto God] a good action or gift, or anything for which a requital may be sought? or, as Akh says, (assumed tropical:) Who will do a good action by following and obeying the command of God? (TA.) The Arabs say, qado OaqoraDotaniI qaroDFA HasanFA (assumed tropical:) Thou hast done to me a good deed [which I am bound to requite]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., OaqoriDN EiroDaka liyawomi faqorika (assumed tropical:) [Lend thou thine honour for the day of thy poverty]; meaning, when a man defames thee, do not thou requite him, but reserve his recompense undiminished for thee, as a loan for the payment of which he is responsible, that thou mayest receive it from him in the day of thy need thereof: (TA:) [but see EiroDN.] ― -b2- [And hence,] OaqoraDaniI AlXRaIoCa He gave, or paid, to me the thing. (M.) ＝ -A2- maA Ealayohi maA yuqoriDu Eanohu AlEuyuwna fayasoturuhu (assumed tropical:) [There is not upon him what will turn aside, or away, from him the eyes, and cover him]. (Ibn- 'Abbád, Sgh.) ＝ -A3- See alse 1, latter half.

6 taqaAoraDa
6: [taqaAraDaA They lent and received loans, each to and from the other.] ＝ -A2- [And hence,] humaA yataqaAraDaAni Alxayora waAlXRarRa (assumed tropical:) [They two interchanged good and evil, each with the other]; (IKh, S, K;) as also ytqArZAn: (IKh:) [but see the latter in its proper place.] And humaA yataqaAraDaAni AlmadoHa, (AZ,) or AlvRanaMCa, (A, Msb,) or AlvRanaMCa bayonahumo, (TA,) [or bayonahumaA, (in the M, humo yataqaAraDuwna AlvRanaMCa bayonahumo,)] (tropical:) They praise each other; (AZ, Msb;) as also ytqArZAn: (AZ:) or they requite, or compensate, each other with praise. (TA.) And AlqironaAni yataqaAraDaAni AlnRaZara (assumed tropical:) The two opponents, or adversaries, look askance, with anger, each at the other: (S, K:) and yataqaAraDuwna naZarFA (assumed tropical:) They look with enmity and vehement hatred, one at another. (TA.) And humo yataqaAraDuwna AlzRiyaArapa (tropical:) [They interchange visiting]. (A.) El-Kumeyt, says,
yataqaAraDu AlHasana Aljamiyla mina AltRaOalRufi waAltRazaAwuro
meaning, Interchanging what is good and comely, of sociable conduct and mutual visiting. (O.) ― -b2- El-Hasan El-Basree, being asked whether the companions of the Apostle of God used to jest, or joke, answered, (TA,) naEamo wayataqaAraDuwna, (K, * TA,) i. e. Yes, and they used to recite poetry [one to another]: (TA:) from qariyDN as signifying “ poetry. ” (K.)

7 AnqrDwA c
7. AnqrDwA (assumed tropical:) They passed away, or perished, [as though cut off,] (S, K,) all of them, (K,) not one of them remaining; (S;) as also quriDuwA↓ [perhaps a mistake for qariDuwA: see 1]. (TA.)

8 AqtrD c
8. AqtrD He received what is termed qaroD [a loan, or the like], (S, Msb, K,) i. q. Aisotalafa; (A;) minohu from him. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A2- AqtrD EiroDahu (assumed tropical:) He defamed him, or spoke evil of him, behind his back or in his absence, or otherwise; syn. AigotaAbahu: (K:) as though he cut off [somewhat] from his honour. (TA.)

10 AstqrD mino fulaAnK c
10. AstqrD mino fulaAnK, (S, Msb, *) or AstqrDhu, (A, Mgh,) He sought, or demanded, of such a one what is termed qaroD [a loan, or the like]. (S, A, * Mgh, * Msb.) ― -b2- [And hence,] AisotaqoraDotuhu AlXRaIoCa I sought, or demanded, of him the gift, or payment [in advance], of the thing. (M.)

qaroDN c
qaroDN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and qiroDN↓; (Ks, S, M, K;) or, accord. to Th, the former is an inf. n., and the latter a simple subst., but this [says ISd] does not please me; (M;) or the former is an inf. n. used as a subst.; (Mgh;) or a subst. from OaqoraDotuhu AlmaAla; (Msb;) [A loan: and the like:] a piece of property which a man cuts off from his [other] articles of property, and which, itself, he receives back; [in rendering the explanation in the Mgh, for the words fayuEoTiyh EynFA in my copy of that work; I read fayuqoDaAhu EayonFA, which makes this agreeable with explanations given in other works;] but what is due to the one from the other as a debt is not so called; (Mgh, [see dayonN;]) what one gives, (S, Msb, K,) to another, (Msb,) of property, (S, Msb,) to receive it back, (S, K,) or to demand it back: (Msb:) or a thing that one gives to be requited for it, or to receive it back: (TA in art. frD:) or a thing of which men demand the payment [or restitution], one of another: (M, L:) or a thing which a man gives, or (assumed tropical:) does, to be requited for it: (Aboo-Is-hák the Grammarian, and TA:) pl. quruwDN. (M, Msb.) You say, Ealayohi qaroDN [He owes a loan], and quruwDN [loans]. (A.) ― -b2- Hence, (S, TA,) (tropical:) What one does, in order to be requited it, of good, and of evil. (S, K, TA.) See three exs. above, under 4. The Arabs also say, qado OaHosanota qaroDiI, meaning (assumed tropical:) Thou hast done to me a good deed [which I am bound to requite]. (TA.) And laka EinodiI qaroDN HasanN, and qaroDN sayRiYN (assumed tropical:) I owe thee a good deed, and an evil deed. (Aboo-Is-hák the Grammarian, and TA.)

qiroDN c
qiroDN: see qaroDN.

qariyDN c
qariyDN The cud: (Lth, A:) or what the camel returns [to his mouth, to be chewed again, or to his stomach,] of his cud; (S, K;) as also maqoruwDN↓: (S:) or it is applied to the cud (jirRap) of the camel, and signifies chewed: or, accord. to Kr, this is fariyDN, with f. (M.) And hence, accord. to some, the saying HaAla AljariyDu duwna AlqariyDi [explained in art. jrD]: but accord. to others, the last word in this saying has the signification next but one following. (S.) ＝ -A2- The sound, or voice, of a man in dying. (Er-Riyáshee, in TA, art. jrD.) ＝ -A3- (tropical:) Poetry: (S, M, A, Msb, K:) so called for one or another of the reasons mentioned under 1, last sentence but one; (A, Msb, TA;) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) El-Aghlab El-'Ijlee distinguishes between it and rajaz. (IB.)

quraADapN c
quraADapN [Cuttings; clippings; and the like;] what falls by the action termed AlqaroD; (S, A, * Mgh, * K;) as, for instance, of gold, (S, TA,) and of silver; and of a garment, or piece of cloth, which a tailor cuts with his shears; (TA;) and of this last, and of bread, (JK, TA,) &c., (TA,) by the gnawing (qaroD) of a rat, or mouse: (JK, A, Mgh, TA:) pl. quraADaAtN. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] Oaxaca AlOamora biquraADatihi (assumed tropical:) He took the thing, or affair, in its fresh state. (M, L.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] quraADapu AlmaAli (assumed tropical:) [The refuse, or] what is bad, vile, paltry, or of no account, of property. (TA.) ― -b4- quraADapN also relates to an evil action, and an evil saying, which one man directs against another. (TA.) [What is meant by this is not clear to me.]

qarRaADapN c
qarRaADapN A certain creeping insect (duwayobRap) that eats wool. (TA.) ― -b2- [And hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A man who defames others, or speaks evil of them, behind their backs, or otherwise; syn. mugotaAbN lilnRaAsi. (TA.)

Aibonu miqoraDK c
Aibonu miqoraDK, (S, M, A, Msb,) [in one copy of the S, Abn muqoriDK, and in another, Abn muqarRaDK,] like miqowad, (Msb,) [A species of weasel;] a certain small beast (duwayobRap), (S, M, Msb,) called in Persian dalahN, (S, Msb,) or dalRahN, (as in one copy of the S,) whence the arabicized word dalaqN, (Msb,) which kills pigeons, (S, M, A,) seizing upon their throats, and it is a species of rat; (A;) the longbacked quadruped that kills pigeons: (Lth, O, Msb:) this last explanation is given by the author of the Bári', after saying that it is a small beast (dwybRp), like the cat, which is in houses, and, when angry, gnaws clothes: (Msb:) accord. to some, i. q. AlnRimosu [q. v.]: (Msb:) pl. banaAtu miqoraDK. (A, (Msb.)

muqarRiDaAtu AlOasaAqiI c
muqarRiDaAtu AlOasaAqiI A [kind of] small creeping thing (duwayobRap), which makes holes in, and cuts, skins used for water or milk. (M.)

miqoraADN c
miqoraADN is the sing. of maqaAriyDu; (S, Msb, K;) and a pair thereof is called miqoraADaAni: (Msb, K:) the miqoraAD is [A single blade of a pair of shears or scissors;] a thing with which one [shears, or clips, or] cuts; and when you speak of the two together, you do not say miqoraADN, as the vulgar say, but miqoraADaAni; (Msb;) which last is syn. with jalamaAni [a pair of shears]; a word, accord. to the lexicologists having no sing.; but Sb mentions miqoraADN, thus using the sing. form: (M:) or miqoraADN and miqoraADaAni signify the same; [a pair of shears;] like jlamN and jalamaAni, and qalamN and qalamaAni: (Msb in art. jlm:) or miqoraADN signifies jalamN SagiyrN [a small pair of shears; i. e. a pair of scissors]: (JK:) 'Adee Ibn-Zeyd uses the expression XaforataA miqoraADK [the two blades of a pair of shears or scissors] in a poem; (IB;) and other poets use the sing., mqrAD: (TA:) and miforaASN, with f and S, signifies the same. (IB.) Hence the saying, lisaAnu fulaAni miqoraADu AlOaEoraADi (tropical:) [The tongue of such a one is the detractor of reputations]. (TA.)

maqoruwDN c
maqoruwDN pass. part. n. of qaraDahu. ― -b2- See qariyDN.

qiroDiYN c
qiroDiYN One of the strange species of trees of the desert; (AA, O, K, TA;) a certain plant that attaches itself to trees, and wraps itself about them; (TA;) a species of plant (AHn, O, TA) the flower of which is yellower than the waros, (AHn, O, K, TA,) and which grows at the base, or on the stem, of the salam and samur and EurofuT (O, TA) and the like: (O:) n. un. with p. (O, K, TA.)

Q. 1 qaroDabahu c
Q. 1. qaroDabahu He cut it; (S, K;) and so qaroSabahu; (K in art. qrSb;) but the former is the more approved: (TA in that art.:) and [the inf. n.] qaroDabapN signifies the cutting vehemently. (TA in the present art.) [See also qiroDaAbN, below; first
sentence.] ― -b2- And He separated it; or separated it into several, or many parts; or dispersed it; i. e., a thing. (K.) ― -b3- And He collected it together; namely, flesh-meat in a cooking-pot: thus it has two contr. significations. (K.) ― -b4- And He ate it entirely; namely, flesh-meat: (K:) and in like manner, qaroDaba AlXRaApa, said of the wolf, he ate entirely the sheep, or goat. (TA.) And [the inf. n.] qaroDabapN is said to signify The [eating indiscriminately,] not clearing, or freeing, the moist, or tender, from the dry, or tough, by reason of vehement voracity. (TA.) ― -b5- And qrDb said of a man, He ate a dry, or tough, thing. (S, O, K.) ― -b6- And He (a man) ran in the manner termed EadowN: (K:) or qaroDabapN signifies [a running] such as falls short of what is termed EadowN. (O.)

qiroDibN c
qiroDibN The refuse remaining in the sieve, that is thrown away. (O, K, TA.)

qiroDaAbN c
qiroDaAbN A sharp sword; as also quroDuwbN↓: (O:) or both signify a very sharp sword; (K;) as also quraADibN↓: (TA in art. qrTb:) or the first signifies, (S,) or signifies also, (O,) a sharp sword, that cuts bones. (S, O.) Both the first and second of these words are compounded from qaraDa and qaDaba, which signify “ he cut. ” (O.) ― -b2- And One who eats much: (TA:) or, as also quroDuwbN↓ and qiroDaAbapN↓ and quraADibN↓ and muqaroDibN↓, one who leaves nothing uneaten by him. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And A man who eats what is dry, or tough. (Th, S, O, K.) ― -b4- And AlqiroDaAbu signifies The lion. (O, K.) ― -b5- And qiroDaAbN and quroDuwbN↓ signify A thief, or robber: pl. qaraADibapN. (S, O, K.) And both words, (the latter, S, O, K, and the former also, K, TA,) sometimes, (S,) A poor man; (S, O, K, TA;) a pauper: (TA:) pl. as above. (K, TA.) ― -b6- maA razaOotuhu qiroDaAbFA means I did not get, or obtain, or take, from him, or it, anything. (O, K.)

quroDuwbN c
quroDuwbN: see the next preceding paragraph, in three places.

qiroDaAbapN c
qiroDaAbapN: see qiroDaAbN; the second in two places.

quraADibN c
quraADibN: see qiroDaAbN; the second in two places.

muqaroDibN c
muqaroDibN: see qiroDaAbN; the second in two places.

2 qrRT AljaAriyapa c
2. qrRT AljaAriyapa, (S, K,) inf. n. taqoriyTN, (TA,) He adorned the girl, or young woman with the [ornament called] quroT. (S, * K.) A rájiz says, addressing his wife, (S, TA,) who had asked him to adorn her with a pair of ornaments of the kind so called, (TA,)
qarRaTaki QllRehu EalaI AlEayonayoni
EaqaAribFA suwdFA waOaroqamayoni
(assumed tropical:) [May God suspend to thee, upon the two eyes, black scorpions, and two black and white serpents]. (S, TA.) [See also another tropical usage of the verb voce XanRafa.] ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) qrRT Alfarasa (tropical:) He put, or threw, the bridle (lijaAm) upon the horse's head; (S, TA;) this is what is meant by the explanation OalojamahaA in the K: (TA:) or he placed the horse's reins behind his ears, in putting the bridle on his head: (Sgh, K: *) or it has the former of the meanings explained above, and also signifies, he (the rider) stretched forth his hand so as to put it upon the back of the horse's head, upon the place where the EicaAr is tied, while the horse was running: (IDrd:) or he incited the horse to the most vehement running; (TA, and so in the CK, excepting that Alxayola is there put in this instance in the place of Alfrs;) because, when his running is vehement, the rein is extended upon the ear, and so becomes like the quroT: accord. to the A, qrRT Alfarasa EinaAnahu means (tropical:) he slackened the horse's rein so that it fell upon, or against, the part behind the ear, the place of the quroT, in urging him to run. (TA.) ― -b3- And hence, (A,) qarRaTotu Uilayohi rasuwlFA (tropical:) I hastened to him a messenger: (Ibn- 'Abbád, TA:) or I dismissed (lit. flung) in haste to him a messenger: a phrase doubly tropical. (A, TA.) And hence taqoriyTN is used by the vulgar to signify the act of (tropical:) notifying: and (tropical:) desiring to hasten: and (tropical:) straitening: and (tropical:) confirming, or corroborating, in an affair or a command: in all which senses it is trebly tropical. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qrRT Ealayohi (tropical:) He gave him little; (K, TA;) or by little and little. (TA.) [This is said in the TA to be from AlqiraATu; app. meaning from AlqiraATu as a dial. var. of AlqiyraATu: but IDrd says, that from this phrase is derived AlqyrAT.] ＝ -A3- [He cut, or clipped, money.]

5 tqrRTt AljaAriyapu c
5. tqrRTt AljaAriyapu The girl adorned herself with the [ornament called] quroT. (S, * TA.)

quroTN c
quroTN [An ear-ring, or ear-drop;] i. q. XanofN: (K:) or the thing that is suspended to the lobe of the ear; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) such as a silver bead fashioned like a pearl, or a pendant of gold; the Xnf being that which is in the upper part of the ear: (TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaqoriTapN (Mgh, Msb) and OaqoraATN, (K,) and [of mult.] qiraTapN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and qiraATN (S, K) and quruwTN. (K.) It is said in a proverb, xucohu walawo biquroTaI maAriyapa [Take thou it, although by means of giving for it the two earrings of Máriyeh]; (TA, S, K, in art. mrI;) i. e., take thou it at all events: (K in art. mrI:) this Máriyeh, respecting whom authors differ, was the first Arab woman who wore ear-rings, and her ear-rings are said to have been of great value. (TA.) ― -b2- AlquroTu (tropical:) The Pleiades (AlvRurayRaA): so called by way of comparison. (TA.) ＝ -A2- A certain plant, like the ruTubap [or raTobap, a species of trefoil, or clover], except that it is superior in size, or quality, to the latter, (AHn, K,) and larger in the leaves, fed upon by horses and the like; (AHn, TA;) in Persian Xabocar [or Xabodar]. (AHn, K.) [See birosiymN.]

qiraATN c
qiraATN: see what next follows.

qirRaATN c
qirRaATN: see what next follows.

qiyraATN c
qiyraATN (S, Msb, K) and qirATN↓, (K, TA,) like kitaAbN, (TA,) or qirRaATN↓; (as in some copies of the K) which last is the original form, as is shown by its pl., qaraAriyTu, (S, Msb,) and by its dim., qurayoriyTN, (Msb,) the same change being made in this instance as is made in diynaArN; (S, Msb;) in the ancient Greek language, [ κεράτιον,] said to signify A grain of the xuronuwb [or carob-tree]: (Msb:) [and hence, the weight thereof; a carat; i. e. four grains;] the half of a daAniq, (S, Msb,) accord. to the ancient Greeks: (Msb voce dAnq, q. v.) or it is a weight differing in different countries; in Mekkeh being the twenty-fourth part of a deenár; and in El-'Irák, the twentieth part thereof: (K:) or the twentieth part of a deenár in most countries; but accord. to the people of Syria, the twenty-fourth part thereof. (IAth.) As occurring in a trad., (S, TA,) in which it is said, that he who attends a corpse until it is prayed over shall have a qiyraAT, and he who attends it until it is buried shall have qiyraATaAni, (TA,) qyrAT is explained as meaning, The like of Mount Ohod; (S, TA;) [i. e. a very great reward;] and qyrATAn as meaning the like of two great mountains. (TA.) ― -b2- qiyraATN is also applied by accountants to The twenty-fourth part of a thing; because twenty-four is the first number that has an eighth and a sixth and a fourth and a third and a half without a fraction. (Msb.)

qurayoriyTN c
qurayoriyTN dim. of qiyraATN. (Msb.)

jaAriyapN muqarRaTapN c
jaAriyapN muqarRaTapN A girl having [or being adorned with] the [ornament called] quroT. (K.)

Q. 1 qaroTasa c
Q. 1. qaroTasa, (Msb, K,) inf. n. qaroTasapN, (Msb,) He (an archer) [and it (an arrow)] hit the qiroTaAs [or target]. (Msb, K.) It is also allowable to say, qaroTasati AlrRamoyapu The shot went right to the qiroTaAs. (Msb.)

Q. 2 taqaroTasa c
Q. 2. taqaroTasa He perished. (Sgh, K.)

qaroTasN c
qaroTasN and qiroTasN: see qiroTaAsN.

qiroTaAsN c
qiroTaAsN Paper; syn. kaAgadN: (K:) or such as is made of the barodiIR [or papyrus], found in Egypt: (TA:) [and particularly a roll, or scroll, thereof: see also TuwmaArN, and surofapN:] what one writes upon: (S, Msb:) also written quroTaAsN; (S, Msb, K;) but the former is the better known, (Msb), or the former only is of established authority, for El-Járabardee says the contrary of the latter; (MF;) and qaroTaAsN; (Lh, ISd, K;) but this is not mentioned by most of the lexicographers; (MF;) and qaroTasN↓ signifies the same; (AZ, S, Msb, K;) and so does qiroTasN↓. (K [app. on the authority of El-Fárábee and Aboo-'Alyà; but the
names are imperfectly written in the TA.]) ― -b2- qiroTaAsN also signifies A writing, or book, (SaHiyfapN,) of whatever thing it be: (K:) pl. qaraATiysu. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, A butt, or target, to shoot at; (S;) a piece of skin, (Msb,) or any skin, (K,) set up for persons contending in shooting. (Msb, K.) ― -b4- And A kind of burod [q. v.] of the fabric of Egypt. (K, TA.) ― -b5- And A white, or fair, girl, of tall stature. (IAar, K.) ― -b6- And A camel such as is termed Mdam. (Sgh, K.) ― -b7- And A young she-camel. (IAar, K.)

daAbRapN qiroTaAsiyRapN c
daAbRapN qiroTaAsiyRapN A beast of carriage in whose whiteness is no mixture of any other colour. (K.)

muqaroTisN c
muqaroTisN An archer [and in like manner an arrow] hitting the qiroTaAs. (Msb.) And ramoyapN muqaroTisapN A shot going right to the qiroTaAs. (TA.)

1 qaraZahu c
1. qaraZahu, aor.
qariZa
, inf. n. qaroZN, He tanned it, (Msb, TA,) namely, a skin, or hide, (Msb,) or a skin for water or milk, (TA,) with qaraZ, q. v. infra: (Msb, TA:) or he dyed it therewith. (TA.) ― -b2- He plucked it, or gathered it, from the tree; namely, what is called qaraZ. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- qaraZotuhu a dial. var. of qaraDotuhu, in the phrase qaraZotuhu caAta AlXRimaAli, q. v. (Fr, K.) ― -b2- And [in like manner as a dial. var. of qaraDotuhu,] I cut it, or made it and cut it according to a measure and pattern. (Fr.) ＝ -A3- qariZa, aor.
qaraZa
, He was, or became, a lord, master, chief, or man of rank or quality, after being in a base or abject state. (IAar, O, K; and T in art. qrD.)

2 qrRZhu c
2. qrRZhu, inf. n. taqoriyZN, He took extraordinary pains, or exceeded the usual degree, in tanning it, namely, a skin, or hide, with qaraZ. (Z.) ― -b2- [And hence, (see 6,)] (tropical:) He praised, or eulogized, him, he, the latter, being living; (S, K, TA;) taOobiynN signifying the “ doing so when the man is dead; ” (S;) the former signifies he did so truly or falsely. (K.) And fulaAnN yuqarRiZu SaAHibahu, and yuqarRiDuhu, (tropical:) Such a one praises his companion, falsely or truly. (AZ, S, TA.) And yuqarRiZuniI bimaA layosa fiIRa (tropical:) [He praises me for that which is not in me]. (TA, from a trad.) ― -b3- And He praised him immoderately: like frRThu. (O in art. frT.) ― -b4- Also, [like qrRDhu,] (assumed tropical:) He dispraised him: (Kitáb el-Addád, cited by Freytag:) or it relates only to praise and good; but taqoriyDN relates to good and to evil. (TA in art. qrD.)

6 humaA yataqaAraZaAni AlmadoHa c
6. humaA yataqaAraZaAni AlmadoHa (tropical:) They two praise each other; (S, K, TA;) from 2 in the first of the senses assigned to it above; each embellishing the other like as the qaAriZ embellishes the skin, or hide; (Z, TA;) and ytqArDAn is like it: (TA;) and you say also, humaA yataqaAraZaAni Alxayora wAlXRarRa [They two interchange good and evil, each with the other]; as also ytqArDAn: (IKh, in TA, art. qrD:) or taqaAruZN relates only to praise and good; but taqaAruDN, to good and evil. (TA.)

qaraZN c
qaraZN, accord. to some, (Msb,) The leaves of the salam [mimosa flava], (Lth, S, Mgh, K,) with which they tan; (Lth, S, Mgh;) but this assertion is [said to be] inaccurate; for the leaves are called xabaT, and camels are fed with them, and they are not used for tanning: some say, that it is a kind of tree; but this also is inaccurate; for one says, “ I plucked, or gathered, qaraZ; ” and trees are not plucked, or gathered: (Msb:) AHn [contradicts this, however, for he applies this word to a kind of tree, and] says, it is the best of things with which hides are tanned in the land of the Arabs; and these are tanned with its leaves and its fruit: [the pods of the sanoT, which is also called qaraZ, are used for tanning;] and in one place he says, it is a large kind of trees, having thick stems (swq [app. a mistranscription for Xawok, thorns,]) resembling the walnut-tree, [in the Mgh, evidently from the same source, “ or, as some say, a large kind of trees, having thick thorns (Xwok), resembling the walnut-tree, ”] the leaves of which are smaller than those of the apple-tree, and it has grains which are put into balances [for weights, like as are those of the carob-tree]: it grows in the low plains: (TA:) or a kind of tree, whereof the sanoT [mimosa Nilotica, also called acacia Nilotica,] is a species: (M, K, in art. snT:) [or,] correctly speaking, it is [the fruit, or seed with its pericarp, of that tree;] a well-known grain, which comes forth in envelopes, like lentils, from the trees called EiDaAh; (Msb;) or, [to speak more precisely,] the fruit of the sanoT, whence is expressed OaqaAqiyaA [acacia, i. e. succus acaciæ]; (K;) which is termed EuSaArapu AlqaraZi, [and when inspissated, rubRu AlqaraZi,] and has an acrid property; the best thereof is that which is sweet in odour, heavy, hard, and green; and it strengthens relaxed members, when cooked in water, and poured upon them: (Ibn-Jezleh, TA:) [the last application is that which commonly obtains in the present day: see also 'Abd-el-Lateef, pp. 48-52 of the Arabic text, and De Sacy's translation and notes:] the n. un. is qaraZapN: (AHn, Mgh, Msb:) and the dim. of this is qurayoZapN. (AHn, Msb.) Hence bilaAdu AlqaraZi, applied to El-Yemen, because the qaraZ grows there [most plentifully]. (S.) See also SamoEN.

qaraZiIRN c
qaraZiIRN The dye (Sibog [a mistranscription for diboE i. e. tan]) of the qaraZ. (TA.) ― -b2- See also maqoruwZN. ― -b3- UibilN qaraZiyRapN Camels that eat qaraZ. (TA.) ― -b4- kbX qaraZiIRN and quraZiIRN A ram of El-Yemen; because the qaraZ grows there [most plentifully]. (S, K.)

qarRaAZN c
qarRaAZN A seller of qaraZ. (Msb, K.)

qaAriZN c
qaAriZN A plucker, or gatherer, of qaraZ. (S, Msb, K.) It is said in a proverb, (S,) laA Mtiyka Oawo yaWuwbu AlqaAriZu AlEanaziIRu [I will not come to thee unless the gatherer of qrZ, of the tribe of 'Anazeh, return]: (S, K, but in the latter AlEnzI is omitted:) and Aboo-Dhu-eyb says,
waHatRaI yaWuwba AlqaAriZaAni kilaAhumaA
[And until the two gatherers of qrZ return, each of them]: (S:) the qaAriZaAni were two men of the tribe of 'Anazeh, who went forth in search of qaraZ, and did not return. (S, K.) We also find in the M, laA Mtiyka AlqaAriZa AlEanaziIRa, i. e. I will not come to thee as long as the gatherer of qrZ, of the tribe of 'Anazeh, is absent: AlqArZ AlEnzI being made to occupy the place of AldRahora, and being put in the accus. case as an adverbial expression, by an extension of the signification, of which there are parallel instances. (TA.)

taqoriyZ c
taqoriyZ: see 2. [Used as a subst., (tropical:) An encomium, or eulogy, on a living person: pl. taqaAriyZu and taqoriyZaAtN.]

muqoraZN c
muqoraZN: see what next follows.

maqoruwZN c
maqoruwZN A skin, or hide, tanned with qaraZ; (S, Msb, K;) as also qaraZiIRN↓; and AHn mentions, on the authority of Aboo-Mis-hal, muqoraZN↓, as though from OaqoraZahu, which, he says, we have not heard: (TA:) or dyed therewith. (K.)

dictScrap.label: qrE qrfqrE qrf: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
Q. 1 qarofaSa
Q. 1: [qarofaSa: see qurofuSaMCu, below.] ＝ -A2- qarofaSahu, (JK, TA,) inf. n. qarofaSapN (JK, S, K) and qirofaASN, (TA,) He bound his arms beneath his legs: (JK, K:) or he drew him together, (namely, a man,) binding his legs and arms. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qarofaSapN also signifies A certain mode of coitus, in which the woman's extremities are drawn together, so that the man makes fast here arms beneath her legs: (JK, K:) transmitted by Ibn-'Abbád. (TA.)

Q. 2 taqarofaSato c
Q. 2. taqarofaSato She (an old woman) wrapped herself up in her clothes. (JK, K.)

qurofuSaI c
qurofuSaI and its variations: see what follows.

qurofuSaMCu c
qurofuSaMCu, with damm, (K,) [in a copy of the S written without any vowel-sign to the f,] or qurofaSaMCu, (so in a copy of the S) or both, (El-Ashmoonee, in his Expos. of the Alfeeyeh of Ibn- 'Akeel,) and qurufoSaMCu, with damm to the q and r, (IJ, K,) and qurofuSaI, (S, * K,) and qirofiSaI, (Fr, K,) and qaroqaSaI, (K,) of all which the first is the most chaste, (TA,) [all inf. ns., of which the verb, accord. to analogy, is qarofaSa, but I have met with no instance of its occurrence,] A certain mode of sitting; (S;) the sitting upon the buttocks, making the thighs cleave to the belly, and putting the arms round the shanks, (A'Obeyd, S, K,) like as a man binds himself with a piece of cloth round his back and shanks; his arms being in the place of the piece of cloth: (A'Obeyd, S:) or the sitting upon the knees, bending down, (munokabRFA, [in the L mutRakiYFA, which is a mistranscription,]) making the belly cleave to the thighs, and putting the hands under the arm-pits; (Abu-l-Mahdee, S, K;) a mode of
sitting of the Arabs of the desert: (S:) or the sitting upon the legs, putting the knees together, and contracting the arms to the breast. (IAar, TA.) You say, qaEada AlqrfSMCa He sat in the manner above described. (IAar, S.)

dictScrap.label: qrq qrmqrq qrm: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
Q. 1 qaromada c
Q. 1. qaromada He plastered a pool, (S, L,) or a tank, or cistern, (L,) with the burnt stones called qaromadN: (S, L:) or he plastered thickly. (TA, art. kls.) ― -b2- He constructed a building with such stones. (L.) ― -b3- [He smeared a garment with saffron, or perfume. See muqaromadN.]

qaromadN c
qaromadN A kind of stones, (S, L, K,) which have holes, (L, K,) and upon which a fire is lighted and kept up until they are thoroughly burnt, (S, L, K, *) when they are used for plastering pools, (S, L,) and tanks, or cisterns, (L,) and for building; (L, K;) as also qiromiydN↓: (L:) or a thing [or substance] like gypsum, with which one plasters: (TA:) and qaromadN (L, K) or qiromiydN↓ (Msb) signifies anything (L) with which one plasters, or smears, (L, Msb, K,) for the purpose of ornament, (Az, L, Msb,) as gypsum, and saffron, (L, Msb, K,) and perfume, &c. (Msb.) ― -b2- Rocks, or masses of stone. (L.) ― -b3- Baked pottery. (L, K.) ― -b4- Also qaromadN (L, K) and qiromiydN↓ (IAar, As, S, L, Msb, K) [coll. gen. ns.: the n. un. of the latter, qiromiydapN, occurs in the M and TA, voce UirodabRapN:] Baked bricks: (S, L, Msb, K:) or the baked bricks of baths; in the dial. of Syria: (As, L:) or large baked bricks: (S, voce UirodabRapN:) or the large baked bricks of houses: (IAar, L:) or a thing resembling baked brick: (TA:) originally Greek, [ κεραμίσ,] (L, Msb,) used by the Arabs in ancient times: (L:) pl. of the latter, qirAmiydu: (IAar, As, S, L:) which is the word in common use. (TA.) ― -b5- Also qiromiydN↓ i. q. UirodabRapN, (K,) i. e., A [cover for a] wide sink-hole (baAluwEap) made of baked clay: (TA:) [but see UirodabRapN].

quromuwdN c
quromuwdN The male mountain-goat: (L, K:) or a mountain-kid: pl. qaraAmiydu, (AO, Az, S, L,) with which qaraAhiydu is syn. (Az, L) ― -b2- The fruit of the gaDaAp: (L, K:) or a species thereof; as also quromuwTN. (T, L.)

qiromiydN c
qiromiydN: see qiromadN, in four places. ＝ -A2- The female mountain-goat, OurowiyRapN: or this word is corruptly written [for UirodabRapN]. (K.)

muqaromadN c
muqaromadN: see the verb, of which it is the pass. part. n. ― -b2- A building constructed with baked bricks (MjurR [or qiromiyd]) or (in the K, and) with stones: (S, L, Msb, K:) or lofty, or high. (K.) ― -b3- A building thickly plastered. (TA, art. kls.) ― -b4- Narrow: (TA:) or made narrow. (L.) ― -b5- A garment smeared with saffron and perfume: (L, Msb:) or smeared with the like of saffron. (K. [in the CK, for biXibohi AlzEfrAni is put yuXobihu AlzEfrAna.])

qiromizN c
qiromizN, a Persian word, arabicized; (TA;) [The insect called coccus: and particularly the coccus baphica, or coccus ilicis; commonly called by us, from the Persian and Arabic, kermes: and also applied to that species which is the true cochineal:] a certain Armenian dye, (Lth, K,) of a red colour, (Lth, TA,) obtained from the expressed fluid of a kind of worm found in the woods of Armenia: (Lth, K:) such is said to be the case: and in some of the correct copies of the K we find the following addition: it is said to be red like the lentil, in the form of grains: it falls upon a species of balRawT, [or oak,] in the month of McaAr, [or March, O. S.,] and if not gathered, it becomes a flying thing, and flies: it is used as a dye for animal substances, such as wool and skill, but not cotton. (TA.)

qiromiziIRN c
qiromiziIRN Dyed with qiromiz: or resembling the colour of that dye: (the book entitled mA lA ysE AlTbyb jhlh, by Ibn-El-Kutbee; cited by Golius:) [in the present day, crimson; or of a deep red colour.]

Q. 1 qaromaTa c
Q. 1. qaromaTa, (TA,) [or, as is implied in the S, qaromaTa fiI AlxaTRi, or fI xaTRihi,] inf. n. qaromaTapN, (S, K,) He made the lines near together in writing: (S:) or he made the characters fine, or slender, or minute, (K, TA,) and the letters and lines near together. (TA.) ― -b2- qrmT fiI xaTowihi, (TA,) [or, as implied in the S, fI AlmaXoIi, or fI maXoyihi,] inf. n. as above, (S, K,) He (a man, TA) contracted his steps in walking or going: (S, K, TA:) and in the same sense qrmT is said of a camel. (TA.)

Q. 3 UiqoranomaTa c
Q. 3. UiqoranomaTa, (S,) or UiqoramRaTa, (K,) [the former being the original form,] It (skin, S, TA) became contracted, or shrivelled: (K, TA:) or became drawn together, one part to another. (S, TA.) ― -b2- He (a man, AA) became angry. (AA, K.)

qaromaTRiIRN c
qaromaTRiIRN One of the qaraAmiTap↓ [or Karmathians]; (S, K;) i. e. of the people [or sect] thus called. (K.) [See De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, 2nd ed., ii. 97.]

qaromaTiyTN c
qaromaTiyTN One who contracts his steps in walking or going. (K, * TA.)

AlqaraAmiTapu c
AlqaraAmiTapu: see qaromaTiIRN.

dictScrap.label: qrn: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
qaronabN c
qaronabN The jerboa; or a rat, or mouse; syn. qaOorapN: or the young one generated between it and a jerboa: (K:) and frnb [i. e. fironibN, with kesr,] is a dial. var. thereof. (So in the TA. [But I incline to think that qaronabN is a mistranscription for fironibN.])

quronubN c
quronubN The flank: (IAar, O, K:) or a flabby flank. (TA.)

qaranobaI c
qaranobaI An insect resembling the [beetle called] xunofasaMC, or somewhat larger than the latter, with long hind-legs: (As, T, TA:) or an insect with long hind-legs, resembling the xnfsMC, (S, O, Meyd,) but somewhat larger, (S, O,) having a speckled back. (Meyd.) It is said in prov., AlqaranobaI fiI Eayoni OumRihaA HasanapN [The karembà in the eye of its mother is beautiful]. (S, O, Meyd. [Mentioned in the S and O, in art. qrb.]) [See Aibonu AlfaAsiyaMCi, in art. fsw.]

qaronabiyTN c
qaronabiyTN: see qunRabiyTN, in art. qnbT.

qaronasa c
qaronasa: see qrnS.

Q. 1 qaronaSa AlbaAziIa c
Q. 1. qaronaSa AlbaAziIa He acquired for himself, permanently, for the chase, the hawk, or falcon, (S, K, TA,) by tying it up in order that its feathers might drop off. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qaronaSa AlbaAziI The hawk, or falcon, became a permanent acquisition for the chase: the verb being intrans. as well as trans. (K.) Lth mentions it as being written with s [i. e. qaronasa]. (TA.)

baAzN muqaronaSN c
baAzN muqaronaSN A hawk, or falcon, permanently acquired for the chase, (S, TA,) by the means mentioned above. (TA.)

dictScrap.label: qrw qrIqrw and qrI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qazRa c
1. qazRa, [sec. pers., app., qazuzota,] aor.
qazuza
, inf. n. qazaAzapN, He felt, or had a sense of, or was moved with, shame, or pudency; his soul shrank from foul things: (M:) and [in like manner] tqzRz↓ he was scrupulous in shunning, or avoiding, unclean things, or impurities; (S, M;) he removed himself far from such things; (S, Mgh, K;) and quzRN [an inf. n. of qazRa] signifies the same as taqazRuzN. (K, TA.) You say also, qazRa mina AldRanasi, inf. n. quzRN, He removed himself far from what was unclean. (TK.) And qazRato nafosiI Eani AlXRaIoCi, and qazRatohu, with and without a prep., (M, TA,) inf. n. qazRN, (M, K,) My soul, or mind, refused the thing, or rejected it; (M, K, * TA;) a meaning said by IKtt to be of the dial. of El-Yemen: (TA:) and it loathed the thing; which latter is the more common signification: (M, TA:) and [in like manner] Eani AlXRaIoCi tqzRz↓ he did not eat the thing, nor drink it, willingly: (M, TA:) end mino tqzRz↓ Oakoli AlDRabRi wagayorihi [he loathed, or shunned, or
avoided, the eating of the lizard called DbR &c.]. (S, Mgh, TA.)

5 taqazRaRa
5: see 1, in three places.

qazRN c
qazRN A quality, or thing, that is to be loathed, or shunned, or avoided, for its uncleanness, in food; as also quzRu↓ and qazaAzapN↓. (M, TA.) See also 1. ＝ -A2- A man who feels, or has a sense of, or is moved with, shame, or pudency; whose soul shrinks from foul things: (M, TA:) and, as also quzRN↓ and qizRN↓, a man scrupulous in shunning, or avoiding, unclean things, or impurities; (S;) who removes himself far from such things; (S, K;) who does not eat nor drink a thing willingly: (M:) and the same three epithets, (TA,) and qazazN↓ (K) and quzRaAzN↓, (IAar, K,) a man well-bred, or polite, (ZariyfN,) who guards against vices or faults, and shuns acts of disobedience and afflictions, not through pride: (K, TA;) fem. qazRapN and quzRapN and qizRapN: (M, K: *) the pl. of qazRN is OaqizRaMCu, which is anomalous. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- I. q. UiboriysamN [Silk: or raw silk:] (K:) or a kind thereof: (S:) or that whereof Abrysm is made; (Lth, Az, Msb, TA;) wherefore some say, that qzR and Abrysm are like wheat and flour: (Msb:) a Persian word, [originally qazo,] (M, TA,) arabicized: (S, M, Msb:) pl. quzuwzN. (M, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence, duwdu AlqazRi The silk-worm.]

quzRN c
quzRN: see qazRN; the first in three places, and the second in two.

qizRN c
qizRN: see qazRN; the first in three places, and the second in two.

qazazN c
qazazN: see qazRN; the first in three places, and the second in two.

qazaAzapN c
qazaAzapN: see qazRN, and see also 1.

qazRaAzN c
qazRaAzN A seller of qazR, q. v. (K.)

quzRaAzN c
quzRaAzN: see qazRN.

1 qazaHa Alqidora c
1. qazaHa Alqidora: see 2. ＝ -A2- qazaHati Alqidoru, [aor.
qazaHa
,] inf. n. qazoHN and qazaHaAnN, The cooking-pot made what came forth [or overflowed] from it to drip, or fall in drops. (AZ, K, TA.) ― -b2- And qazaHa bibawolihi, (S, A, Mgh, K,) and qaziHa bihi, (A, Mgh, K,) aor. of each
qazaHa
, (K,) inf. n. qazoHN (S, K) and quzuwHN; (K;) and bh qzRH↓, inf. n. taqoziyHN; (A;) said of a dog, (S, A, Mgh, K,) He ejected his urine, (S, Mgh, TA,) and sprinkled it: (S:) or raised his hind leg, and emitted his urine: (TA:) or ejected his urine with an impetus, or in several discharges. (K, accord. to different copies; as is said in the TA.) ― -b3- qazaHa OaSola AlXRajarapi: see 2. ＝ -A3- qazaHa also signifies It (a thing, TA) was or became, high, or elevated. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And qazaHato, said of a plant or tree [nabotapN or XaHarapN], It had, or produced, what is termed a taqoziyH [q. v.]. (TA.)

2 qzRH Alqidora c
2. qzRH Alqidora, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoziyHN; (S;) and qazaHahaA↓, (Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
qazaHa
, (K,) [inf. n. qazoHN, as indicated in the K;] [He put into the cooking-pot seeds for seasoning, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) called qizoH. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qzRH kalaAmahu (tropical:) He seasoned [meaning he embellished] his speech, or language; syn. tawobalahu. (TA in art. tbl.) taqoziyHu AlHadiyvi mans (tropical:) The embellishing of discourse (K, TA) without lying therein. (TA.) ― -b3- qzRH OaSola AlXRajarap, in copies of the K incorrectly qazaHa↓, without tesh-deed, (TA,) He made water upon (bawRala) the root, or stem, of the tree: (K, TA:) or he put urine at the root of the tree to render its fruit abundant. (JK.) ― -b4- See also 1.

5 tqzRH AlnRabaAtu c
5. tqzRH AlnRabaAtu, (K, TA,) and AlXRajaru, (TA,) The herbage, and the trees, branched forth into many branches. (K, TA.)

qazoHN c
qazoHN: see qizoHN. ― -b2- Also The urine of the dog. (K.)

qizoHN c
qizoHN (IAar, S, Msb, K) and qazoHN↓ (IAar, K) Seeds that are used in cooking, for seasoning food; syn. taAbalN; (S, K;) or OabozaArN; (Msb;) that are put into the cooking-pot; such as cuminsees and coriander-seeds: pl. OaqozaAHN: (TA:) and taqaAziyHu↓ (a pl. that has no sing., TA) signifies the same as [OaqozaAHN, i. e.] OabaAziyru. (S, K, TA.) ― -b2- And the former (qizoHN) signifies also Onion-seed: (K, TA:) so in the dial. of Syria. (TA.) ― -b3- And The dung of the serpent: (K, TA:) pl. OaqozaAHN, as above. (TA.)

qawosu quzaHa c
qawosu quzaHa, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) which is [an appellation applied to The rainbow] in the sky, (S,) i. e. certain streaks of an arched form appearing in the sky in the days of the [season called] rabiyE, after rain, red and yellow and green, (TA,) is imperfectly decl. [accord. to general usage], (S,) [that is to say,] it is a compound of two words whereof the latter is inseparable from the former, so that one may not say taOamRalo quzaHa famaA Oaboyana qawosahu [Consider thou Kuzah, for how plain is his bow!], (TA,) and the latter word is said to be the name of a certain devil, as such, imperfectly decl., (TA, Msb,) assigned to the same class as zuHal, which, as Mbr says, is imperfectly decl. as being a proper name and deviating from its original form: (TA:) it is said in a trad., Say not ye qawosu quzaHa, for quzaHu is the name of a devil, but say qawosu QllRehi: (Msb, TA:) or quzaHu is the name of a certain angel who is charged with the management of the clouds: or the name of a certain king of the 'Ajam [i. e. Persians or foreigners]: (K: [but SM remarks upon this last saying as being very strange, deemed improbable by his sheykh (MF), and not found by himself in any book except the K:]) or quzaHu is the name of a mountain in El-Muzdelifeh, and the word qawos was prefixed to it because this was the first place over which the qws thus called appeared in the Time of Ignorance: (TA:) or quzaH thus used is from quzoHapN, (Msb, K, TA,) of which quzaHN is pl., (Msb,) and which signifies a streak of yellow and of red and of green, (Msb, K, TA,) which are the colours that are in the [said] qws; (TA;) and if so, it is perfectly decl. [i. e. one says qawosu quzaHK]: (Msb:) or it is from qazaHa signifying it was, or became, high, or elevated: (K, TA:) Dmr strangely asserts that qws qzH is a mistake, and that it is correctly qawosu qazaEK, from qazaEN signifying “ clouds. ” (MF, TA.)

quzoHapN c
quzoHapN A streak of yellow and of red and of green: (Msb, K:) pl. quzaHN. (Msb.)

quzaAHN c
quzaAHN A certain disease that attacks sheep or goats. (K.)

maliyHN qaziyHN c
maliyHN qaziyHN [Seasoned with salt and with the seeds called qizoH;] two epithets applied to food: (A:) accord. to the K, the latter is an imitative sequent: but, correctly, each has its own proper meaning: as is said in the L, the former is from AlmiloHu; and the latter, from AlqizoH. (TA.)

qazRaAHN c
qazRaAHN One who sells the seeds called qizoH, that are used in cooking, for seasoning food. (K.)

qaAziHN c
qaAziHN A hard penis: (K, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates. (TA.) ― -b2- siEorN qaAziHN (tropical:) A dear [or high] current price. (K. [For siEorN, Freytag appears to have read XaEiyrN.])

qawaAziHu AlmaMCi c
qawaAziHu AlmaMCi The bubbles of water, (K, TA,) that become inflated, and pass away. (TA.)

taqoziyHN c
taqoziyHN A thing upon the head of a plant or tree, (K, TA,) that divides into several divisions, (K, * TA,) like the paw of the dog: (K, TA:) a subst. like tamotiynN and tanobiytN. (TA.)

taqaAziyHu c
taqaAziyHu (a pl. that has no sing., TA): see qizoH.

miqozaHapN c
miqozaHapN, (S, K,) and accord. to some maqozaHapN also is allowable, (MF,) [A vessel, or other receptacle, for the kind of seeds called qizoH, that are used in cooking, for seasoning food;] a thing like a mimolaHap. (S, K.)

muqazRaHN c
muqazRaHN A species of trees (XajarN) resembling the fig, (K, TA,) of the strange trees of the desert, having short branches, (Mgh, TA,) at the heads of which are what resemble the paw of the dog: so says IAar. (Mgh.) AlXRajarahu AlmuqazRaHapu, behind which it is forbidden, in a trad., to perform prayer, (TA,) or the performing of prayer towards which is said in a trad. to be disapproved, is said to be A tree of the sort abovementioned: so says Az: (Mgh:) or, as some
say, a tree that branches forth into many branches: (TA: [see 5:]) or a tree at which the dogs and the beasts of prey have emitted their urine may be meant thereby. (Mgh, TA.)

dictScrap.label: qzE qzl qzmqzE qzl qzm: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qasRahu c
1. qasRahu, aor.
qasusa
, (M,) inf. n. qasRN (S, M, A, K) and qusRN and qisRN (A, K) and qasasN, (M, [in which this and the first only are mentioned, accord. to a copy of a portion in my possession,]) He sought after, or pursued, it: and he did so repeatedly, or by degrees, and leisurely, or repeatedly and by degrees and leisurely: (S, M, A, K:) as also tqsRshu↓. (A, * K.) [See also qaSRahu, which, accord. to the TA, is a dial. form of qasRahu.] You say, AlOaxobaAra tqsRs↓ [He sought after, or sought after repeatedly, &c., news, or tidings]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, app.,] qasRN signifies Calumniation; or malicious and mischievous misrepresentation; (S, M, K;) as also qusRN and qisRN; (K;) and the spreading, or publishing, of discourse, and speaking evil of men behind their backs, or in their absence: (TA:) [probably inf. ns., of which the verb is qasRa; perhaps a trans. verb; for] qasRahumo signifies He hurt them, or annoyed them, by foul speech; (K;) as though he sought, or sought repeatedly, or by degrees and leisurely, or repeatedly and by degrees and leisurely, after that which would hurt them, or annoy them. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] qasRa maA EalaI AlEaZomi, (A, K,) mina AllRaHomi, (A,) aor.
qasusa
, inf. n. qasRN; (TA;) and qasoqasahu↓; (K;) or qasoqasa AlEaZoma; of the dial. of El-Yemen; (M;) He sought, or sought repeatedly, or by degrees and leisurely, or repeatedly and by degrees and leisurely, after the meat that was upon the bone, so as not to leave any of it: (A:) or he ate the flesh that was upon the bone, and extracted its marrow: (M, K:) and maA EalaI AlmaAYidapi qasoqasa↓ he ate what was upon the table. (M.) ＝ -A2- qasRa, [of which the sec. pers. is app. qasusota, and the aor.
qasusa
,] (TK,) inf. n. qusuwsapN↓ and qisiysapN↓, accord. to all the copies of the K, [so says SM, in the TA, but in the CK qusRuwsap↓ and qisRiysap↓, and in a MS copy of the K I find the latter written qasiysap↓,] but correctly qisRiysRapN↓, as written by Lth, (TA,) He became a qasR [or qisRiys]: (K, * TK:) or qasuwsapN↓ and qisiysRapN↓ [so in a copy of the M, but in a copy of the A qusuwsiyRapN↓ and qisRiysiyRapN↓, which I hold to be the correct forms of these two words, the former from the pl. of qasRN and the latter from qisRiysN,] are simple substs., (M,) and you say, [using them as such,] lahu AlqusuwsiyRapu and AlqisRiysRapu To him belongs the rank, or office, of qasR or qisRiys. (A.)

5 taqasRaRa
5: see qasRahu, in two places. ― -b2- tqsRs OaSowaAtihumo (S, M, A *) biAllRayoli, (S, A,) or AlSRawota taqasoqasa↓, (K,) He listened to, or endeavoured to hear, (S, M, A, K,) their voices, (S, M, A, *) or the voice, (K,) by night, or in the night. (S, M, A.)

8 Aqs c
8. Aqs He (a lion) sought what he might eat. (M.)

R. Q. 1 qasoqasa c
R. Q. 1. qasoqasa, inf. n. qasoqasapN, He asked, or inquired, respecting the affairs of others. (M: but only the inf. n. is there mentioned.) ― -b2- See also 1, in two places.

R. Q. 2
R. Q. 2: see 5.

qasRN c
qasRN and qisRiysN↓, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) and sometimes the latter is without teshdeed in the sing., [i. e., qisiysN↓, vulgo qasiysN↓,] though the pl. is with teshdeed, like as the Arabs sometimes make OataAtiynu pl. of OatuwnN, (Fr,) [Syr. ???, a ??? consenuit, (Golius,)] The head, or chief, of the Christians, in knowledge, or science: (A, K:) or one of the heads, or chiefs, of the Christians, (S, M,) in religion and knowledge or science: (S:) or the learned man of the Christians: (Msb:) or an intelligent, an ingenious, or a clever, and a learned, man: (M:) [in the present day applied to a Christian presbyter, or priest: see jaAvaliyqN:] pl. (of the first, Msb) qusuwsN, (Msb, K,) and (of the second, M, Msb) qisRiysuwna (Fr, M, Msb, K) and qasaAqisapN, (Fr, and so in some copies of the K,) contr. to rule, (TA,) or qasaAwisapN, (M, Sgh, and so in some copies of the K,) contr. to rule, (M,) one of the seens [in the original form, which is qasaAsisapN,] being changed into wáw. (CK [but in the copies of the K which have qasaAqisapN, we find added “ and the seens being many, ” meaning, in the original form qasaAsisapN, or in qisRiysN, “ they change one of them into wáw. ”]) ＝ -A2- qasRN also signifies Hoar-frost, or rime. (A, K.) See qasRiIRN.

qasiysN c
qasiysN and qisiys: see qasRN.

qasuwsapN c
qasuwsapN and qusuwsapN: see qasRa.

qasiysapN c
qasiysapN and qisiysapN: see qasRa.

qusuwsiyRapN c
qusuwsiyRapN: see qasRa.

qisiysiyRapN c
qisiysiyRapN: see qasRa.

qasRiIRN c
qasRiIRN, (S, A, Mgh,) coll. n. qasRiyRapN, (M, Mgh, K,) also pronounced with kesr to the q, [qisRiIRN and qisRiyRapN,] (K,) in the latter manner by the relaters of traditions, but by the people of Egypt with fet-h, (A'Obeyd, S,) A kind of cloths, or garments, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) of flax (A, TA) mixed with silk, brought from Egypt, (S, M, A,) and forbidden to be worn [by the Muslims]: (S, M, Mgh:) so called in relation to a district, (A' Obeyd, S,) or place, (M, K,) or town or village, upon the shore of the sea, (A,) called AlqasRu, (A'Obeyd, S, M, K,) or qasRN, (M, A, Mgh,) between El-'Areesh and El-Faramà, (K,) in Egypt, (A'Obeyd, S, Mgh,) seen by A'Obeyd, but not known to As: (S:) or so called in relation to qasRN↓, meaning “ hear-frost, ” or “ rime; ” because of the pure whiteness thereof: (A:) or [originally] qazRiIRN, (A.) and qazRiyRapN, (Sh, K,) from qazRN, meaning “ a kind of silk; ” (TA;) the z being changed into s: (Sh, K:) it was said to 'Alee, What are qasRiyRap? and he answered, Cloths, or garments, that come to us from Syria, or from Egypt, ribbed, that is, figured after the form of ribs, and having in them what resemble citrons. (Mgh.)

qasRaAsN c
qasRaAsN A calumniator; a slanderer: (M:) or one who inquires respecting news, and then makes it known, divulges it, or tells it, in a malicious or mischievous manner, so as to occasion discord, dissension, or the like, (TA, voce qatRaAtN.)

qisRiysN c
qisRiysN: see qasRN.

qusRuwsapN c
qusRuwsapN: see qasRa.

qisRiysapN c
qisRiysapN: see qasRa.

qisRiysiyRapN c
qisRiysiyRapN: see qasRa.

qasoqasN c
qasoqasN: see qasoqaAsN.

qasoqaAsN c
qasoqaAsN A seeker, or one who seeks repeatedly or leisurely, without inadvertence; as also qasoqasN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- One who inquires respecting the affairs of others. (M.)

1 qasaba c
1. qasaba, aor.
qasiba
, It (water) ran, or flowed: (S, O, K:) or it ran, or flowed, with a sound, beneath trees or leaves. (So accord. to different copies of the A.) ― -b2- And qasabati AlXRamosu The sun began to set. (K.) ＝ -A2- qasubN, aor.
qasuba
, inf. n. qusuwbapN (A, O, K) and qusuwbN, (K,) It was, or became, hard: (O, K:) or hard, and dry, or tough: you say, qasuba AltRamoru The dates were, or became, hard, and dry, or tough. (A, TA.)

qasobN c
qasobN Hard. (S, O, K.) You say, UinRahu laqasobu AlEilobaMCi [Verily he is hard in respect of the tendon, or sinew, of the neck.] (TA.) ― -b2- And Hard, and dry, or tough; (TA;) and so qasiybN↓. (A, TA.) tamorN qasobN signifies Hard, and dry, or tough, dates, (S, Mgh, * O, K,) that crumble in the mouth and have hard stones: (S, Mgh, O:) [see an ex. in a verse cited in art. rmI, conj. 4:] or [simply] dry, or tough, dates: n. un. with p: (Msb:) or bad dates, (A,) or so qusaAbapN↓. (K.) ― -b3- See also qisoyabRN.

qasuwbN c
qasuwbN A xufR [or boot]; (IAar, O, K;) accord. to IAar, i. q. qafoXN [expl. by him as meaning a short boot] and nixaAfN [expl. by him as syn. with xufRN]. (TA.) [See also qasRuwbN.]

qasiybN c
qasiybN A current, or flow, of water: (ISk, S, O:) or its current, or flow, with a sound: (K:) or its current, or flow, beneath trees: (A, TA:) or its sound beneath leaves (T, A) or rubbish. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qasobN.

qusaAbapN c
qusaAbapN: see qasobN.

qisoyabRN c
qisoyabRN Long, and hard, or strong; (S, O, K, TA;) as applied to anything; and so qasobN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And A tall man. (TA.)

qasRuwbN c
qasRuwbN Boots: a word having no [proper] singular. (ISd, K.) [The word used in the sing. sense is qasuwbN, without teshdeed.]

qaAsibN c
qaAsibN [or cakarN qaAsibN?] i. q. guromuwlN mutomahilRN, (O, K, [AlmutamahRilu in the CK is a mistake for AlmutomahilR,] i. e. cakarN SulobN [Penis durus]. (TA.)

qayosabN c
qayosabN A species of Xajar [meaning plants]; (IDrd, O, K; *) of the [kind termed] HamoD; (K;) said by AHn to be the ASl [app. OaSol, and, if not a mistranscription, meaning best sort,] of the HamoD; (TA;) or, as he says, (O, TA,) in one place, (TA,) on the authority of certain of the Arabs of the desert, of 'Omán, (O,) the qayosabap is a plant (Xujayorap, O, or Xajarap, TA) which grows in the manner of slender stalks, from one root or stem, and rises to the measure of a cubit, (O, TA,) having a leaf intensely green, round, and somewhat long, (O,) the flower of which is like that of the violet, (O, TA,) exactly; (O;) and it serves as fuel in its fresh, or moist, state, like as does the dry. (TA.)

cakarN qayosabaAnN c
cakarN qayosabaAnN [in the CK qayosabaAnu] Penis durus et crassus. (K.)

muqasRabN c
[muqasRabN said by Freytag to occur in the Deewán of Jereer as an epithet applied to poison, signifying Having things whereby its potency is augmented mixed with it, is evidently a mistranscription for muqaXRabN.]

1 qasaHa c
1. qasaHa, aor.
qasaHa
, inf. n. qasaAHapN and qusuwHapN, It was, or became, hard, firm, or tough. (S, [in two copies belonging to me, but omitted in a third,] K.) ― -b2- And qasaHa He twisted a rope. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, aor. as above, inf. n. qusuwHN, (TA,) and OaqsH↓ (in some copies of the K AqtsH↓, TA,) He (a man) was much, or frequently, excited by vehement lust: (S, [in two copies belonging to me, but omitted in a third,] K:) or was excited by vehement lust. (TA.)

3 qAsaHahu c
3. qAsaHahu He treated him with dryness and hardness, or niggardliness; syn. yaAbasahu. (L, K.)

4 OaqosaHa
4: see 1.

8 UiqotasaHa
8: see 1.

qasaHN c
qasaHN, (K,) and qusuwHN↓, and qasaAHN↓, (TA,) Dryness, syn. yubosN; ― -b2- or the remains of vehement lust, (K,) or its continuance, or its intenseness. (L.)

qaAsiHN c
qaAsiHN A hard and strong spear. (TA.) ― -b2- A thick or coarse garment, syn. galiyZN. (K.) ＝ -A2- Also, and qusaAHN↓, and maqosuwHN↓, A man in a state of excitement, or frequently in a state of excitement, by vehement lust. ISd knows no way of accounting for the last of these epithets but by supposing it to be used for the act. part. n., like maOotiyRFA in the Kur, xix, 62, for MtiyFA. (TA.)

qasaAHN c
qasaAHN: see qasaHN.

qusaAHN c
qusaAHN: see qaAsiHN ― -b2- [You say also] UinRahu laqusaAHN maqosuwH↓ (T, K) Verily he is dry or hard. (TA.)

qusuwHN c
qusuwHN: see qasaHN.

maqosuwHN c
maqosuwHN: see qaAsiHN and qusaAHN.

1 qasarahu EalaI AlOamori c
1. qasarahu EalaI AlOamori, (S, K,) aor.
qasira
, (M, S, TA,) inf. n. qasorN; (S, TA;) and Ealayohi Aqtsrhu↓; (S, K;) He made him to do the thing against his will; (S;) he forced him to do the thing: (S, K:) or qasarahu ElI AlAmr has the former of these two significations; (TA;) and qasarahu and Aqtsrhu↓ signify he overcame him; he overpowered, subdued, or oppressed, him; (M, TA;) and tqsRrhu↓ signifies the same as Aqtsrhu. (TA.)

5 taqasRara
5: and 8: see 1.

qasowarN c
qasowarN (S, TA) and qasowarapN, (K, TA,) the former a coll. gen. n., and the latter the n. un., (M,) A certain plant, (S, M, K,) which grows in plain, or soft, land; (M, K;) a sour plant, of the kind called najiyl, which is like the jumRap [or full and long hair of the head] of a man, and becomes tall and large, of which camels are greedily fond, (AHn, M,) and which fattens them, and makes them plentiful in milk. (Az, TA.) Lth is in error in saying that the former signifies a huntsman, or hunter; for it signifies a plant, as IAar and AHn and others have said. ＝ -A2- See also qasowarapN, in two places.

qasowarapN c
qasowarapN Mighty; (M, K;) that overpowers, or subdues, others: (M, TA:) also strong; applied to a man: and courageous: (TA:) pl. qasaAwiru. (M.) ― -b2- A lion; as also qasowarN↓: (S, M, K:) because he overcomes and overpowers. (TA.) So in the Kur, [lxxiv. 51,] kaOatRahumo HumurN musotanofirapN farRato mino qasowarapK [As though they were asses taking fright and running away at random that have fled from a lion]. (S, M.) Or it has here the signification next following. (S.) ― -b3- Hunters that shoot, or cast: (S, K:) sing. qasowarN↓; (K;) accord. to Lth.; [and in the M it is said that qasowarN↓ signifies a shooter, or caster: or, accord. to some, a hunter:] but this is a mistake; for qswrp is a coll. n., having no sing.; and Fr says, that in the verse of the Kur cited above, it means shooters, or casters of missile weapons: it is also related of 'Ikrimeh, that it was said to him that qswrp signifies, in the Abyssinian language, a lion; but he said that is signification is that given above on the authority of Fr, and that the lion in the Abyssinian language is called Eanobasap: and Ibn-'Arafeh says qswrp is of the measure faEowalapN from Alqasoru; and that the meaning [in the Kur] is, as though they were asses made to take fright and run away by shooting or hunting &c. (TA.) Or, accord. to I'Ab, in the passage above cited, it has the signification here next following. (IKt, TA.) ＝ -A2- The sound of men, (IKt, K, TA,) and their voices, or cries. (IKt, TA.)

qawosarapN c
qawosarapN and qawosarRapN dial. forms of qawoSarapN and qawoSarRapN, which see. (M, K.)

1 qasaTa c
1. qasaTa, (S, M, &c.,) aor.
qasiTa
, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. qusuwTN (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and qasoTN, (Mgh, Msb, K,) He declined, or deviated, from the right course; acted unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically. (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, in two places: ＝ -A3- and see 2.

2 qsRThu c
2. qsRThu, (IAar, M, TA,) inf. n. taqosiyTN, (IAar, TA,) He distributed it; or dispersed it. (IAar, M, TA.) It is implied in the K that the verb in this sense is qasaTa↓, of three letters [only, without teshdeed]. (TA.) You say, qsRT AlmaAla biyonahumo He distributed the property among them. (TA.) And qsRT AlxaraAja Ealayohimo He assigned the several portions which each one of them should pay of the [tax called] xrAj: (TA:) or qsRT AlxaraAja, inf. n. as above, signifies he assessed, or apportioned, the xrAj (Mgh, Msb) with equity and equality, (Mgh,) to be paid at certain times. (Msb.) ― -b2- qsRT EalaI EiyaAlihi AlnRafaqapa, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He was niggardly, or parsimonious, towards his household in expenditure. (K, * TA.)

4 AqsT c
4. AqsT, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) inf. n. UiqosaATN, (Mgh, K,) He acted equitably, or justly, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in his judgment or the like; (M, TA;) as also, (Msb, K,) accord. to IKtt, (Msb,) qasaTa↓, aor.
qasiTa
(Msb, K) and
qasuTa
, (K,) but the former of these aors., as well as the former verb, is the more known, (TA,) inf. n. qasoTN, (Msb, TA,) or qisoTN [q. v. infra]; (M, K;) or UiqosaATN is only in division: (TA:) thus the latter of these two verbs is made to have two contr. significations: (Msb, TA:) in the former of them, accord. to some, the O has a privative effect, [so that the verb properly signifies he did away with, or put away, injustice, or the like,] as [it has in AXkAh] in the phrase XakaI Uilyasohi faOaXokaAhu [he complained to him and he made his complaint to cease]. (TA.) It is said in the Kur,
[iv. 3,] waUino xifotumo OalRaA tuqosiTuwA fiI AlyataAmaI [And if ye fear lest ye should not act equitably with respect to the orphans]: (Mgh:) or, accord. to one reading, taqosuTuwA↓, with damm to the s. (TA.) And you say also, OaqosaTotu bayonahumo [I acted equitably between them], and Uilayohimo [towards them]. (TA.)

5 taqasRaTuwA AlXRaIoCi bayonahumo c
5. taqasRaTuwA AlXRaIoCi bayonahumo They divided the thing among themselves (Lth, S, * M [in which last bynhm is omitted] and O, L, K) equitably, (M, O,) or equitably and equally, (L,) or with equality. (Lth, K.) You say also, AlmaAla bayonahumo UiqotasaTuwA↓ They divided the property among themselves; (TK;) UiqotisaATN being syn. with UiqotisaAmN. (K.)

8 UiqotasaTa
8: see 5.

qusoTN c
qusoTN a dial. var. of kusoTN, or, accord. to Yaakoob, the q is a substitute [for k]; (M;) said by IF to be Arabic; (Msb;) [Costus; so in the present day;] a certain substance, (AA, Msb,) or perfume, (Mgh,) or wood, (M,) or a certain Indian wood, and also Arabian, (K,) with which one fumigates; (AA, M, Mgh, Msb;) well known; (Msb;) also called kusoTN and kuXoTN (AA) and quXoTN: (TA in art. qXT:) or a wood which is brought from India, and which is put into the substances used for fumigating, and into medicine: (Lth:) or a certain drug of the sea: (S:) [it is said in the S and TA, voce HinozaAbN, that the carrot of the (jazaru AlbaHori) is called qusoTN:] in a trad., AlqusoTu AlbaHoriIRu [or qusoT of the sea] is mentioned as one of the best of remedies: and in another trad., qusoT is coupled by the conjunction w with OaZofaAr, or, accord. to one relation thereof, is prefixed to the latter word, governing it in the gen. case: and IAth says, that it is a sort of perfume: but some say that it is aloes-wood (Euwd, q. v.): [see also ZafaAriIRN:] and others, a well-known drug, of sweet odour, with which women and infants are fumigated: (TA:) it is diuretic, beneficial to the liver in a high degree, and for the colic, and for worms, and the quartan fever, as a beverage; and for rheum, and defluxions, and pestilence, when the patient is fumigated therewith; and for the [leprous-like disorder called] bahaq, and the [discolouration of the face termed] kalaf, when applied as a liniment; (K;) and it confines the bowels, expels wind, strengthens the stomach and heart, occasions pleasurable sensation, is an ingredient in many sorts of perfume, and is the best of perfumes in odour when one fumigates therewith. (TA.)

qisoTN c
qisoTN Equity; justice: (S, * M, Mgh, Msb, K: *) [an inf. n. having no proper verb, or] a subst. from OaqosaTa. (Mgh, Msb.) ＝ -A2- Equitable; just: (S, * M, K:) an inf. n. used as an epithet, like its syn. EadolN; (M, K;) and [therefore] applied alike to a sing. n. [and to a dual] and to a pl.: (K:) you say miyzaAnN qisoTN an equitable, or a just, balance; and miyzaAnaAni qisoTN; and, agreeably with the usage of the Kur, xxi. 48, mawaAziynu qisoTN. (M.) ＝ -A3- A portion, share, or lot; (S, M, Msb, K;) of a thing; (K;) and pertaining to a person: (TA:) pl. OaqosaATN. (Msb.) You say, wafRaAhu qisoTahu He gave him in full his portion, share, or lot. (TA.) And Oaxaca kulRN mina AlXRurakaMCi qisoTahu Every one of the partners took his portion, or share. (TA.) ― -b2- A portion, or piece. (So accord. to an explanation of the pl., OaqosaATN, in the TA.) ― -b3- The means of subsistence: (K:) or the portion thereof which is the share of every created being. (TA.) yaxofiDu AlqisoTa wayarofaEuhu, said of God, in a trad., has been explained as meaning He maketh the portion of the means of subsistence which is the share of any created being little, and maketh it much. (TA.) [See, below, another meaning which is assigned to it in this instance; and see also art. xfD.] ― -b4- A quantity, (K, TA,) of water only; or any quantity, of water and of other things. (TA.) ― -b5- A measure with which corn is measured, (S, Mgh, K,) which holds (K) half of a SaAE; (S, Mgh, K;) six thereof making a faroqa: (S:) accord. to Mbr, four hundred and eighty-one dirhems. (TA.) Sometimes it is used for performing the ablution termed wuDuwoC: and hence it is said in a trad., UinRa AlnRisaMCa mino Oasofahi AlsRufahaMCi UilRaA SaAHibapa AlqisoTi waAlsRiraAji; (K;) the qisoT being here the vessel in which the wDwC is performed; (TA;) the meaning app. being, [Women are of the most lightwitted of the lightwitted,] except she who serves her husband, and assists him to perform the wDwC, [so I render tuwaDRiYuhu,] and takes care of the vessel which he uses for that purpose, and stands at his head with the lamp: (K:) or who performs his affairs with respect to his wDwC and his lamp. (Nh.) ― -b6- A [mug of the kind called] kuwz; (M, K;) so called by the people of the great towns: (M:) now applied to one with which olive-oil is measured. (TA.) ― -b7- A balance, or weighing-instrument. (K.) Some say that this is its meaning in the phrase mentioned above, yaxofiDu AlqisoTa wayarofaEuhu He depresseth the balance, and raiseth it: alluding to the means of subsistence which He decrees. (TA.)

qaAsiTN c
qaAsiTN Declining, or deviating, from the right course; acting unjustly, wrongfully, injuriously, or tyrannically: pl. qaAsiTuwna (S, M, Mgh, TA) and qusRaATN. (TA.) You say, huwa qaAsiTN gayoru muqosiTK He is declining, or deviating, from the right course; &c.: not acting equitably, or justly. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [lxxii. 15,] OamRaA QloqaAsiTuwna fakaAnuwA lijahanRama HaTabFA [As for the deviators from the right course, they shall be fuel for hell]. (S, M, Mgh.) [See also EaAdilN.] ― -b2- AlqaAsiTuwna is also specially applied to The party of Mo'áwiyeh; (Mgh;) the people of Siffeen. (TA.) ― -b3- [And it has the contr. meaning, i. e. Acting equitably, or justly. See, again, EaAdilN.]

OaqosaTu c
OaqosaTu More [and most] equitable, just, or right: occurring in the Kur, ii. 282, and xxxiii. 5: (TA:) formed from the triliteral verb [qasaTa], not from the quadriliteral [OaqosaTa], as some assert it to be, holding it anomalous. (MF.)

taqosiyTN c
taqosiyTN The register in which is written a man's portion, or share, (qisoT,) of property &c.: a subst., like tamotiynN. (TA.)

muqosiTN c
muqosiTN Acting equitably, or justly. (S, M.) It is said in the Kur, [v. 46, and xlix. 9, and lx. 8,] UinRa QllReha yuHibRu AlmuqosiTiyna [God loveth those who act equitably, or justly]. (S, M.) ― -b2- AlmuqosiTu is one of the names of God, meaning The Equitable. (TA.)

qusoTaAsN c
qusoTaAsN and qisoTaAsN A balance, or instrument for weighing: (S, Msb, K; and Bd in xvii. 37:) or the most even and most just kind thereof: or such as is just, of whatever kind it be: (K:) or i. q. qabRaAnN [a steelyard]: or, as Lth thinks, the iron of the qbRAn: or i. q. XaAhiynN [the beam of a balance]: (TA:) or i. q. farasoTuwnN [an arabicized Persian word, signifying a public standard of weights or measures]: (Zj, TA:) also written qSTAs: (K:) said to be Arabic, from AlqisoTu, meaning “ justice: ” (Msb:) or a Greek word arabicized; (IDrd, Msb, K;) and its being so does not impugn the truth of the Kur-án's being [altogether] Arabic; for when a foreign word is used by the Arabs, and made by them conformable with their language in respect of desinential syntax and determinateness and indeterminateness and the like, it becomes Arabic: (Bd, ubi supra:) pl. qasaATiysu. (Msb.)
