superEntry.entry:
1 qaXobN c
1. qaXobN signifies The act of mixing. (S, Mgh, O, K.) You say, qaXaba, aor.
qaXiba
, inf. n. qaXobN, He mixed. (K.) And quXiba, said of anything, It was mixed. (M.) ― -b2- And qaXabahu, aor. and inf. n. as above, He corrupted, or vitiated, it: (K, TA:) or he mixed it (i. e. anything) with a thing that corrupted, or vitiated, it. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] qaXaba AlTRaEaAma, (S, M,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He poisoned the food; (S;) he mixed the food with poison; as also qXRbhu↓: (M, TA:) or qaXaba signifies he mixed poison, and so prepared it that it should take effect upon the body. (IAar, TA.) ― -b4- And qaXabahu, (S, O, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., He gave him poison to drink; (S, O, K;) and (TA) so lahu qXRb↓. (M, TA.) And qaXaba AlnRasora He put poison on flesh-
meat for the vulture, that he might eat it and die, and he might take his feathers. (AA, TA.) ― -b5- And [hence] qaXabaniI riyHuhu; (K, TA;) and (TA) ryHh qaXRabaniI↓, inf. n. taqoXiybN; (S, TA;) His, or its, odour annoyed me: (S, K, TA:) as though meaning it poisoned me. (S, TA.) qaXabahu and qXRbhu↓ both signify He, or it, annoyed him. (Mgh.) And qaXabahu AldRuxaAnu means The smoke annoyed him by its odour; and oppressed, or overpowered, him. (O.) qaXobN [in a case of this kind], (O, K,) as inf. n. of qaXaba, aor.
qaXiba
, (K,) means The affecting [a person] with what is displeasing, or hateful, and with what is deemed unclean, or filthy: (O, K: [in the former AlqaXobu is expl. by the words AlASAbpu bmA yukorahu wyusotaqocaru; which, as well as what here follows, shows that an assertion in the TK (copied from the TA, and adopted by Freytag) respecting the explanation in the K, is erroneous:]) and hence the saying of 'Omar, when he perceived the odour of perfume from Mo'áwiyeh when the latter was a pilgrim, mano qaXabanaA [i. e. Who has affected us with what is displeasing &c.?]; likening the odour of perfume in this case to a stink. (O.) ― -b6- qaXobN also signifies The depriving [one] of reason; (K, TA;) from the same word as signifying the act of “ corrupting, ” or “ vitiating: ” (TA:) and its verb is qaXaba, aor.
qaXiba
. (K, TA.) 'Omar said to one of his sons, qaXabaka AlmaAlu (M, O, TA) i. e. Wealth has deprived thee of thy reason: (M:) or has corrupted, or vitiated, thee, and deprived thee of thy reason. (O, TA.) ― -b7- And qaXabahu, (S, M, O, K,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (M, K,) (assumed tropical:) He spoke evil of him: (S, O:) (tropical:) he aspersed him, or upbraided him, (M, K, TA,) biXaIoCK with a thing; (K, TA;) and so qXRbhu↓, inf. n. taqoXiybN: (accord. to some copies of the K, and said in the TA to be agreeable with usage:) and (tropical:) he reproached him with disgraceful conduct. (M, K, TA.) You say, qaXabahu biqabiyHK (tropical:) He charged, or upbraided, him with something bad, evil, abominable, or foul. (S, O, TA.) And qaXabahu biXarRK (assumed tropical:) He cast upon him an evil imputation that was a mark whereby he should, or would, be known. (M, TA.) And qaXabahu biEayobi nafosihi (assumed tropical:) He imputed to him, or charged him with, his own vice, or fault. (IAar, TA.) And qaXabanaA (assumed tropical:) He reproached, or upbraided, us with, or accused us of, a thing that was not in us: (O:) [or] he commanded us to forbear from a thing that was not in us. (TA.) And qaXaba, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) He forged, or fabricated, a lie, or falsehood. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- qaXaba AilsRayofa, (O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) He polished the sword; (O, K;) removed its qiXob [i. e. rust]. (O.) ＝ -A3- And qaXaba, (S, M, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above; (M, K;) or qaXiba, with kesr; (O, as on the authority of Fr;) He (a man, S, M, O) gained, or acquired, praise or blame; (Fr, S, M, O, K;) as also AqtXb↓. (S, M, K.) ＝ -A4- qaXuba, (Th, M, K,) aor.
qaXuba
, inf. n. qaXaAabpN, (K,) It (a garment, Th, M, TA) was new and clean: (Th, M, TA:) or it was white and clean. (K, TA.) ― -b2- And qaXuba, (thus written in my copy of the TA,) or qaXiba, (thus in a copy of the M,) It (a thing) was, or became, unclean, dirty, or filthy. (M, TA.)

2 qXRb c
2. qXRb: see the preceding paragraph, in five places. ― -b2- Also, He rendered a thing unclean, dirty, or filthy. (M, TA.)

4 maA OaqoXaba bayotahumo c
4. maA OaqoXaba bayotahumo How unclean, dirty, or filthy, is their tent or house! (O,) or, what surrounds their tent or house, by reason of the human excrement, or ordure! (TA.)

8 UiqotaXaba
8: see 1, last sentence but two.

10 AstqXbhu c
10. AstqXbhu He deemed it (i. e. a thing) unclean, dirty, or filthy. (M, TA.)

qaXobN c
qaXobN inf. n. of qaXaba [q. v.] ― -b2- [The explanations of this word by Golius and Freytag, by the former as an epithet applied in two contr. senses to a sword, and by the latter as a subst. (from a misstatement in the TK mentioned above), are erroneous.]

qiXobN c
qiXobN Poison; (S, M, Mgh, O, K;) because consisting of things mixed together; (Mgh;) as also qaXabN↓: (M, K:) pl. of the former OaqoXaAbN. (S, M.) ― -b2- And [hence, app.,] A certain plant, (M, O, K,) resembling the maqir, (M, [which is generally said to mean the aloe, and by AHn to be a certain plant consisting of leaves without branches, agreeably with what follows, in the O and K resembling the mafod,]) from the middle whereof there rises a stalk, which, when it grows tall, bends down its top by reason of its succulence, or suppleness; having upon its head a fruit (vamarapN, M, O, [in the TA Eqdp,]) with which birds of prey are killed, (M, O,) being poisoned therewith by its being put into flesh and thrown where they alight: he who prepares it stops up his nose; if he do not, it injures him; and people fear to pasture their cattle near to the places of its growth lest the animals should come in contact with it and should break it or bruise it and it should exhale its odour upon them and kill them: thus says AHn, on the authority of some one or more of the Arabs of the desert, of the Saráh (AlsRaraAp). (O.) ― -b3- And Anything unclean, dirty, or filthy; as also qaXabN↓: (M, TA:) or anything that is deemed unclean, dirty, or filthy. (Mgh.) ― -b4- Rust (K, TA) upon iron: (TA:) or dirt upon a sword. (A, TA.) ― -b5- The refuse, that is thrown away, as being of no good, of TaEaAm [i. e. wheat, or other food]. (M, TA.) ― -b6- See also [the pl.] OaqoXaAbN, voce qaAXibN. ― -b7- Also, i. e. qiXobN A man in whom is no good; (K, TA;) and (TA) so qiXobN xiXobN; (S, M, O, TA;) or this means with whom is no good: the latter word is an imitative sequent. (TA in art. xXb.) [See also qiXobapN.] ― -b8- And Dry, or tough, and hard. (M, TA. [Like qasobN.]) ＝ -A2- And AlqiXobu signifies The nafos [here meaning jasad, i. e. body, as is shown below, voce qaAXibN]. (O, K.)

qaXabN c
qaXabN: see qiXobN, in two places.

qaXibN c
qaXibN: see qaXiybN.

qiXobapN c
qiXobapN A low, vile, ignoble, or mean, man, (IDrd, M, O, K, TA,) possessing no good: (TA:) of the dial. of El-Yemen. (IDrd, M, O, TA.) [See also qiXobN, last quarter.] ― -b2- And The young one of the ape, or of the monkey: (M, O, K:) so, IDrd says, some assert; (O;) but he doubted its correctness; (M, O, TA;) and the right word is qiXRapN. (M, TA.)

qaXiybN c
qaXiybN Food mixed with poison: (M, TA:) and anything poisoned; as also muqaXRabN↓. (Nh, TA.) [Hence,] nasorN qaXiybN A vulture for which poison is mixed in flesh-meat, which he eats, and which kills him; and then his feathers are taken: (S, O:) a vulture killed by means of galovaI [q. v.]. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- And White, (O, K,) and clean. (K.) ― -b2- And, (S, M, O, K,) as also qaXibN↓, (M,) New: (S, M, O, K:) ― -b3- and Old, and worn-out: (M, O, K:) thus having two contr. meanings: (O, K:) the former used alike as masc. and fem.; applied to a garment; and its pl. is quXubN [and by contraction quXobN, mentioned by Golius on the authority of Meyd]. (M.) ― -b4- And the former, applied to a sword, (S, O, K,) Polished: (K:) or recently polished: (S, O:] ― -b5- and, (O, K,) so applied, (A, O, K,) Rusty: (O, K:) or dirty: (A:) thus, again, having two contr. meanings. (O, K)

quXobaAniyRataAni c
quXobaAniyRataAni (occurring in a trad., O) Two old and worn-out [garments of the kind called] burdehs (burodataAni): (O, K, TA:) or, as some say, new: (Nh, TA:) the assertion that quXobaAnN is a pl. of qaXiybN, and that quXobaAniyRapN is a rel. n. from this pl., is one upon which no reliance is to be placed, (O, K,) for a rel. n. is not formed from a pl. [unless from a pl. of the class of OanoSaArN]: it is an innovated form of rel. n. (O.)

qaAXibN c
qaAXibN [act. part. n. of qaXaba; Mixing: &c.]. ― -b2- One who imputes to others, or charges them with, vices, or faults, that are in himself. (IAar, TA.) ― -b3- And A tailor (O, K) who ejects his OaqoXaAb↓, i. e. the knots of the threads, [meaning who spits them out,] when he ejects them. (O.) ＝ -A2- And [A man] weak in respect of the body (DaEiyfu AlnRafosi); (K, TA;) i. e. (TA) one whose qiXob [meaning body] is weak, or emaciated; (O, TA;) by his fiXob being meant his nafos [as syn. with jasad]. (O.)

muqaXRabN c
muqaXRabN Poison with which medicaments [or drugs] are mixed to render it potent. (Ham p. 331.) See also qaXiybN, first sentence. ― -b2- And, (M, K,) or muqaXRabu AlHasabi, (S,) (tropical:) A man whose grounds of pretension to respect are mixed (S, M, K, * TA) with ignobleness. (M, TA.)

1 qaXadahu c
1. qaXadahu i. q. kaXaTahu. (K.)

8 AqtXd c
8. AqtXd He collected clarified butter. (L.)

qiXodapN c
qiXodapN The dregs, or sediment, remaining at the bottom of fresh butter when it is cooked with meal of parched barley or wheat (sawiyq) to be made into clarified butter: (S, M, L:) or the dregs, or sediment, remaining at the bottom of fresh butter when it is cooked with meal of parched barley or wheat (swyq) and with dates; as also quXaAdapN↓: (K:) or the dregs, or sediment, of clarified butter: (Ks, L:) or (in the K, and) thin fresh butter: (L, K:) it is also called qilodapN, and kudaAdapN, (Ks, L,) and UivorN, and OulaAqapN, and xulaASapN; and remains at the bottom of the cooking-pot, after the butter has been clarified, mixed with hairs and pieces of wood &c. (AHeyth, L.) ― -b2- Also, A certain herb, abounding with milk (L, K) and grease. (L.)

quXaAdapN c
quXaAdapN: see qiXodapN.

1 qaXarahu c
1. qaXarahu, aor.
qaXira
and
qaXura
, inf. n. qaXorN; and qXRrhu↓, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoXiyrN; (S;) He divested or stripped it of, or stripped off or removed from it, namely a branch, (S, Msb,) or other thing, (S,) its qiXor [i. e. peel, rind, bark, coat, covering, husk, shale or shell, crust, scab, skin, or outer integument, or superficial part; he, or it, pared, peeled, rinded, barked, decorticated, husked, shelled, scaled, flayed, skinned, or excoriated, it; he, or it, stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed, its outer covering or integument, or superficial part]; (S, Msb;) but the ↓latter verb has an intensive signification; (Msb;) [or denotes frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many objects, as well as muchness;] he pared off, or removed, its peel, rind, bark, or the like, (liHaMCahu,) or its skin: (M, K:) [and he pared, peeled, stripped, scraped, or rubbed, it off; namely, anything superficial, and generally a thing adhering to the surface of another thing, as, for instance, peel and the like, and a scab, and skin, and mud. One says of a fruit, or the like, yuqoXaru Eano HabRapK, Its covering, being removed, shells off from a grain or the like.] ― -b2- qaXarahu biAlsRawoTi [He excoriated him with the whip]. (TA, art. Hmr.) ― -b3- qaXarahu biAllRisaAni (assumed tropical:) [He galled him, as though he flayed him, with the tongue; i. e., with reproof, &c.] (TA, ibid.) ＝ -A2- qaXira, aor.
qaXara
, It (a date) had a thick skin. (TA.) ＝ -A3- qaXira, (TA,) [aor.
qaXara
,] inf. n. qaXarN, (S, TA,) He had his nose excoriated by intense heat: or (tropical:) he was intensely red, as though he were flayed, (M,) or as though his scarf-skin were peeled off. (TA.)

2 qaXRara
2: see 1.

5 taqaXRara
5: see 7.

7 AnqXr c
7. AnqXr and tqXRr↓ quasi-passives of qaXarahu and qaXRarahu, respectively; [It became divested, or stripped, of its peel, rind, bark, coat, covering, husk, shale or shell, crust, scab, skin, or superficial part; it became pared, peeled, rinded, barked, decorticated, husked, shelled, scaled, flayed, skinned, or excoriated; its superficial part became stripped off, scraped off, rubbed off, abraded, or otherwise removed: and it peeled off; it scaled off, or exfoliated:] (S, M, K:) both signify the same: (S:) [or the latter, as quasipass. of qXRrh, has an intensive signification; or denotes frequency, or repetition, of the action, or its application to many subjects, as well as muchness: and the same also signifies it became divested, or stripped, of its peel, &c. part after part: and it peeled off, or scaled off, part after part.]

quXorN c
quXorN. ― -b2- AlquXoraAni [dual], with damm, (K,) or AlqiXoraAni↓, (so written in a copy of the M,) The two wings, (K,) or the two thin wings, (M,) of the locust. (M, K.)

qiXorN c
qiXorN The covering of a thing, whether natural or accidental; (M, K;) i. e., of anything; (M;) [the exterior part, peel, rind, bark, coat, crust, integument, skin, or covering, of a branch, plant, fruit, or the like; a coat such as one of those of an onion or other bulbous root, as is shown in the K, voce muSRaAxN; a case, husk, shale, shard, or shell, such as covers a seed or seeds or an egg; a crust, a scab, a substance consisting of scales or laminæ and any similar thing, that peels off from the skin &c.; the skin of fruits &c.;] of a branch [and the like], the part which is like the skin of a human being; and hence the qiXor of a melon and the like: (Msb:) pl. quXuwrN. (S, M, Msb, K.) qiXorapN↓ is a more particular term [signifying A piece, or particle, of peel, rind, bark, &c.]: (S:) and likewise signifies the skin of a haborap [or piece of flesh-meat] which remains when its liquor has been sucked; as also quXorapN↓. (M.) quXaArN↓ also signifies the same as qiXorN: and likewise the skin [or slough] of a serpent. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qitorN also signifies (tropical:) The dress, or apparel, of a man; (S;) any dress, or apparel: (M, K:) and a garment; (TA;) as also qiXorapN↓: (M, TA:) and the pl. is quXuwrN. (M, K.) You say, Ealayohi qiXorN HasanN (tropical:) [Upon him is goodly apparel]. And xaraja bayona qiXoratayoni naZiyfatayoni (tropical:) He went forth in two clean garments. (TA.) And in a trad. of Keyleh it is said, kunotu UicaA raOayotu rajulFA caA ruwaMCK wacaA qiXorK TamaHa baSariI Uilayohi (tropical:) [I used, when I saw a man of goodly aspect, and of apparel, to raise my eyes towards him]. (S.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] quXaArN↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) The refuse, or lowest or basest or meanest sort, of mankind, or of people. (IAar, in TA, arts. bXr and xXr.) See also quXaArahN. ― -b4- And see quXorN.

tamorN qaXirN c
tamorN qaXirN Dates, or dried dates, having much qiXor [or skin]; (S, M, K;) as also qaXiyrN↓. (TA.) See qaXira.

quXorapN c
quXorapN: see qiXorN: ― -b2- and see qaAXirapN.

qiXorapN c
qiXorapN: see qiXorN, in two places.

quXarapN c
quXarapN: see qaAXirapN.

quXaArN c
quXaArN: see qiXorN, in two places.

qaXuwrN c
qaXuwrN A medicine with which the face is peeled, in order that it may become clear (M, K) in complexion. (M.) See qaAXirapN.

qaXiyrN c
qaXiyrN: see qaXirN.

quXaArapN c
quXaArapN Peel, rind, bark, or the like, (liHaMC,) or skin, pared off, or removed, from a thing; (M, K;) [parings, or bits, or particles, of a thing, that fall off, or are pared off.]

qaAXirapN c
qaAXirapN [A XajRap (or wound upon the head) which merely peels off the external skin; also termed HaAriSapN; (see XajRapN;)] the first XajRap, (S, K,) because it peels off the skin, (S,) or which peels off the skin. (K.) ― -b2- A woman who peels her face, (K,) i. e., the external skin of her face, with medicine [called qaXuwrN], in order that her complexion may become clear; (K, TA;) and who rubs her face, or the face of another, with [the kind of liniment called] gumorap; (TA;) as also maqoXuwrapN↓: (K:) which latter [also] signifies a woman to whom this is done. (TA.) The qaAXirap and the maqoXuwrapN are cursed in a trad. (M, K.) ― -b3- maTorapN qaAXirapN, (S,) and quXorapN↓, and quXarapN↓, (M, K, TA,) A rain that pares, or strips, the surface of the earth, (S, M, K, TA, [in the K, maTarN yaqoXiru is put in the place of maTorapN taqoXiru, in the M]) and removes the pebbles from the ground, being a rain that falls with vehemence. (TA.) ― -b4- sanapN qaAXirapN, (TA,) and qaAXuwrapN↓, (S, M, K,) and qaAXuwrN↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) A year that strips, or strips off, everything: (M, K:) or that strips, or strips off, men; and camels or the like: (M:) a year of sterility, drought, or dearth. (S.) See also OaqoXaru.

qaAXuwrN c
qaAXuwrN and qaAXuwrapN: see qaAXirapN.

OaqoXaru c
OaqoXaru A thing having its peel, rind, bark, or the like, pared off. (M, K.) ― -b2- One whose nose is excoriated by intense heat: (M, K: *) or (so accord. to the M; but in the K, and) (tropical:) one intensely red, (S, M, K,) as though he were flayed, (M,) or as though his scarf-skin were peeled off. (TA.) ― -b3- Ground partly bare of herbage and partly producing herbage: and ground bare of herbage. (TA.) ― -b4- XajarapN qaXoraMCu A tree peeled, or barked: (M:) or as though part of it were peeled, or barked, (M, K,) and part not. (M.) ― -b5- HayRapN qaXorMCu A serpent casting off its slough, or having its slough cast off; syn. saAlixN: (M, K:) or as though having part of its slough cast off, and part not. (TA.) ― -b6- EaAmN OaqoXaru A severe year. (TA.) See also qaAXirapN.

muqaXRarN c
muqaXRarN A thing having its peel, rind, bark, or the like, pared off, or removed; peeled, rinded, barked, &c. (TA.) See 1. ― -b2- fusotuqN muqavRarN Shelled pistachio-nuts; (S, TA;) and so muqasRarN alone, by predominant usage. (Z, TA.)

maqoXuwrapN c
maqoXuwrapN: see qaAXirapN.

muqotaXirN c
muqotaXirN (tropical:) Naked. (K, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) An aged man: because he finds his garments heavy to him, and throws them from him. (TA.)

1 qaXaTa c
1. qaXaTa, (M, Msb, TA,) aor,
qaXiTa
, (Msb,) inf. n. qaXoTN, (M, Msb, K,) i. q. kaXaTa, (M, K, *) said (M, Msb,) by Yaakoob, (M,) to be a dial. var. of the latter; (M, Msb;) of the dial. of Temeem and Asad; the latter being of the dial. of Keys; the q not being a substitute for the k; (M;) He removed, put off, took off, or stripped off, (M, Msb, * K,) a thing; (M, Msb;) as, for instance, the housing, or covering, from (Eano) a horse; (M;) and a roof [from a chamber or the like]. (TA.) And qiXaATN, [inf. n. of the pass. form quXiTa, It was, or became, removed, &c.,] is syn. with, (K,) being a dial. var. of, (M,) kiXaATN, (M, K,) in the sense of UinokiXaAfN. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [lxxxi. 11,] accord. to the reading of 'AbdAllah Ibn-Mes'ood, waUicaA AlsRamaMCu quXiTato, with q, (M,) meaning the same as kuXiTato, i. e. And when the heaven shall be removed from its place, like as a roof is removed from its place. (Zj.) You say also, qaXaTa AldRaAbRapa [He removed the housing, or covering, from the beast of carriage]; the verb thus used, also, being a dial. var. of kaXaTa; and qXRThA↓, inf. n. taqoXiTN, signifies the same. (TA.) And AlrRajulu quXRiTa↓ The man was spoiled, despoiled, or plundered. (TA.) ― -b2- qaXoTN also signifies The act of beating, [app. so as to excoriate,] with a staff, or stick. (Yaakoob, K.)

2 qaXRaTa
2: see 1, in two places.

5 taqaXRaTa
5: see 7.

7 AnqXTt AlsRamaMCu c
7. AnqXTt AlsRamaMCu, and tqXRTt↓, (tropical:) The sky became clear; became free from clouds or mists. (K, * TA.)

quXoTN c
quXoTN a dial. var. of qusoTN, q. v. (TA.)

qiXoTapN c
qiXoTapN a dial. var. of qanodapN [app. meaning Sugarcandy]. (TA.) ― -b2- [In the present day, applied to Cream.]

qaXRaATN c
qaXRaATN A great spoiler, despoiler, or plunderer; one who spoils, despoils, or plunders, much, or frequently; syn. salRaAbN. (TA.)

muqaXRaTN c
muqaXRaTN: see maqoXuwTN, in two places.

daAbRapN maqoXuwTN EanohaA c
daAbRapN maqoXuwTN EanohaA [for maqoXuwT EanohaA AljulRu] and muqaXRaTN↓ [A beast of carriage having its housing, or covering, removed from it]. (TA.) You say also, rajulN muqaXRaTN↓, meaning A man spoiled, despoiled, or plundered. (TA.)

Q. 4 UiqoXaEarRa c
Q. 4. UiqoXaEarRa, said of the skin, (S, K,) It quaked; shuddered; was, or became, affected by a tremor, quaking, or quivering. (K.) [And in like manner said of a man, (see the part. n., below,) i. e. He quaked, or shuddered.] ― -b2- It (the skin) dried up (qafRa) by reason of mange, or scab. (TA.) ― -b3- UiqoXaEarRati AlOaroDu The earth became of a colour inclining to that of dust, or ashes, (UirobadRat,) and contracted, by reason of drought. (TA.) ― -b4- AqXErRt AlsRanapu (tropical:) The year became one of drought. (K, * TA:)

Oaxacatohu quXaEoriyrapN c
Oaxacatohu quXaEoriyrapN (S, K) A tremor, quaking, or quivering, of the skin seized him. (K.)

muqoXaEirRN c
muqoXaEirRN, applied to a man, [Having a quaking or shuddering of the skin,] has for its pl. qaXaAEiru, without the m because it is augmentative. (S.)

superEntry.entry:
1 qaSRahu c
1. qaSRahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qaSuSa
, inf. n. qaSRN, (M, Msb,) He cut it; (S, Msb;) or he clipped it, or shore it, or cut off from it; (A, K;) namely, hair, (S, M, A, K,) and wool, (M,) and plumage, (A,) and a nail of a finger or toe; (M, K;) with the miqaSR, q. v.: (A, K:) as also qSRShu↓, (M, A,) and, by permutation, qaSRaAhu: (M:) or these two forms have an intensive signification: or you say, AlZRufora wanaHowahu qaSRayotu↓, meaning, I pared the nail and the like. (Msb.) ― -b2- Also, He (a weaver) cut off from it, namely, a garment, or piece of cloth, its unwoven end, or extremity, consisting of warp without woof. (M.) ― -b3- And He cut off the extremities of his ears. (IAar, M.) quSRiyhi occurs in a trad., as meaning, Take thou from the extremities of his ears. (TA.) [But this may be from the root qSw, q. v.] ― -b4- And [hence,] qaSRa QllRehu xaTaAyaAhu (assumed tropical:) God diminished, or took or deducted from, [the account of] his sins. (TA, from a trad.) ＝ -A2- qaSRa Oavarahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qaSuSa
, (M, TA,) inf. n. qaSaSN, (S, M, A, O, L, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K qaSiySN, but the former is the right, (TA,) and qaSRN, (T, M, K,) He followed, or followed after, his track, or footsteps, in pursuit; endeavoured to trace him, or track him; (S, M, A, Msb, K, &c.;) or he did so by degrees: (TA:) or by night: or at any time: (M, TA:) which last is the correct explanation: (TA:) and qaSRahu signifies the same, (A, TA,) and so Avrh AqtSR↓, (S, K,) and Avrh tqSRS↓: (S, M, K:) and qasRa is a dial. form of the same. (TA.) You say, xaraja fulaAnN qaSaSFA fiI Oavari fulaAnK Such a one went forth following, or following after, the footsteps of such a one, in pursuit. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xviii. 63,] (S,) faQrotadRaA EalaI MvaArihimaA qaSaSFA (S, K) And they both returned by the way by which they had come, retracing their footsteps. (K, TA.) ― -b2- [And hence,] qaSRa Ealayohi Alxabara, (S, M, Msb, * K, *) and AlHadiyva, and AlrRuWoyaA, (A,) aor.
qaSuSa
, (M, TA,) inf. n. qaSaSN, (M, TA,) or this is a subst. put in the place of the inf. n. so that it has become predominant over it, (S,) and qaSRN, (M, TA,) or the latter only is the inf. n., and the former is [only] a subst., (Msb,) He related to him the piece of news, or information, (S, M, Msb,) and the tradition, or story, and the dream, (A,) in its proper manner (EalaI wajohihi): (S, Msb:) or he made it known [to him]: (K:) and AlHadiyva AqtSR↓ he related the tradition, or story, in its proper manner (EalaI wajohihi); (S, K, TA;) as though he followed its traces, in pursuit, and related it accordingly: (TA:) [i. e., he pursued the course of the tradition, or story:] and Alxabara tqSRS↓ he pursued, or sought after, the particulars of the news, or information, gradually, and deliberately. (M.) qaSRa is also said to signify He recited, or delivered, a [discourse such as is termed] xuTobap. (TA.) And it is said in the Kur, [xii. 3,] naHonu naquSRu Ealayoka OaHosana AlqaSaSi We explain unto thee with the best explanation: (K, TA:) or, as some say, qaSRN is the inf. n. of the verb used in this sense, and qaSaSN is a subst. [syn. with qiSRapN, q. v.]. (TA.) And in a trad. respecting the Children of Israel it is said, lamRaA qaSRuwA halakuwA: or lamRaA halakuwA qaSRuwA: accord. to different relations: meaning, When they relied upon words, and neglected works, they perished: or when they perished, by neglecting works, they inclined to, and relied upon, stories. (TA.) ＝ -A3- qaSRahu Almawotu, and qaSRahu EalaI Almawoti, or mina Almawoti: see 4.

2 qSRShu c and qaSRaAhu
2. qSRShu qaSRaAhu: see I, first signification. ＝ -A2- qSRS, (S,) inf. n. taqoSiySN, (A, K,) He plastered, or built, (TA,) a house, (S, K, TA,) and a tomb, which it is forbidden to do, (A, TA,) with gypsum; (TA;) syn. jaSRaSa: (S, K:) of the dial. of El-Hijáz. (TA, art. jS.)

3 qASRhu c
3. qASRhu, (Msb,) inf. n. muqaASRapN (A, Mgh, Msb) and qiSaASN, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) [which latter is the more common,] He (the relation of a slain man, A, Mgh, TA, or one who has been wounded, Mgh, [or mutilated,]) retaliated upon him by slaying him, or wounding him, (S, * Mgh, Msb, K,) or mutilating him, (S, * Msb, K, *) so as to make him quit, or even, with him. (Mgh.) See also 8. ― -b2- Hence, (A, Mgh,) (tropical:) He made him quit, or even, with himself: used in a general way. (Mgh.) You say, qASR SaAHibahu, (S, Mgh, Msb, * K,) inf. ns. as above, (Msb,) (tropical:) He made his fellow quit, or even, with him, (Mgh,) in a reckoning, (S, Mgh, K,) or other thing, (S, K,) by withholding from him the like of what the latter owed to him; (Mgh;) he made a debt which his fellow owed him to be as a requital of a like debt which he owed his fellow: [but Fei adds,] this is taken from UiqotiSaASu AlOavari: and hence the former signification, relating to retaliation of slaughter and
wounding and mutilation, which, however, is the predominant signification. (Msb.) You say also, qaASaSotuhu bimaA kaAna liI qabolahu, [or, more probably, qibalahu, or perhaps Ealayohi,] (tropical:) I withheld from him the like of what he owed me. (A, TA.) ISd says, (TA,) The phrase quwSRa zayodN maA Ealayohi has been mentioned; and means, in my opinion, (assumed tropical:) Zeyd was reckoned with for what he owed: though made trans. without a particle, as implying the meaning of Ougorima and the like. (M, TA.)

4 AqSRhu c
4. AqSRhu, inf. n. UiqoSaASN, He retaliated for him; (M;) as also AqtSRhu↓; (A; [so in a copy of that work; but I think it is a mistake for AqSRhu, or for AqtSR lahu, q. v.]) or AqtSR minohu. (TA [but this seems to be a mistake for AqtSR lahu.]) You say, AqSR fulaAnFA mino fulaAnK He (a governor, or prince,) retaliated for such a one upon such a one, (S, K,) by wounding the latter like as he had wounded the former, (S, Msb, K,) or by slaying the latter for the slaughter of the former; (S, K;) and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- AqSR AlrRajulu minu nafosihi The man gave power, or authority, to retaliate upon himself, (K, TA,) by doing to him the like of that which he had done, whether it be slaughter or mutilation or beating or wounding. (TA.) [Whence the saying,] OaqoSaSotuka AljuroHapa (tropical:) I authorize thee to adduce anything whereby to invalidate the testimony. (A, * TA, art. jrH.) ＝ -A2- Darabahu HatRaI OaqaSRahu mina Almawoti, (S, K,) and EalaI Almawoti qaSRahu↓, (K,) He beat him until he made him to be near to death: (S, K:) and Fr used to say, Drbh HtRI OaqaSRahu Almawota [meaning as above]. (S.) You say [also], OaqoSaSotuhu EalaI Almawoti [I made him to be near to death]. (M.) And a poet says,
faqado OaqoSaSota OumRaka biAlohuzaAli
meaning, Thou hast made thy mother to be near to death. (TA.) ― -b2- Fr also said, (S,) Almawotu qaSRahu↓ and OaqaSRahu Almawotu [in the L and TA qaSRahu mina Almawoti and OaqaSRahu minohu, which seems to be a mistranscription,] both signifying Death became near to him: (S, K:) or he became at the point of death, and then escaped; (TA;) and so OaqaSRatohu XaEuwbu: (M:) and OaqaSRa ElI Almawoti he became at the point of death. (M.)

5 tqSRS c and taqaSRaI
5. tqSRS taqaSRaI: see 8. ＝ -A2- tqSRS Oavarahu: see qaSRa Avrh. ― -b2- tqSRS Alxabara: see qaSRa Ealayohi Alxabara. ― -b3- tqSRS kalaAmahu He preserved in his memory his speech, or discourse. (AZ, M, K.)

6 tqASRwA c
6. tqASRwA They made themselves quits, or even, one with another, by retaliation, (M, TA,) slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding. (M.) A poet says,
farumonaA AlqiSaASa wakaAna AltRaqaAS
Su HukomFA waEadolFA EalaI AlomusolimiynaA
[And we sought retaliation so as to make a party quit, or even, with us; for people's making themselves quits, or even, one with another, by retaliation, is a statute, and an act of justice, appointed to the Muslims]: in which AltRaqaASRu is an instance of a deviation from a general rule, as it presents two quiescent letters together in poetry; wherefore some relate it differently, saying, AlqiSaASu: and there is no other instance of the kind excepting one verse cited by Akh:
walawolaA xidaAXN Oaxadotu dawaAb
ba saEodK walamo OaEoTihi maA EalayohaA
but Aboo-Is-hák thinks, that, if this verse be genuine, the right reading is dawaAbiba saEodK, as the making the duplication of a letter distinct is allowable in poetry; or rawaAHila saEodK. (M, TA.) This is the primary signification of the verb. (TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (A, * Mgh, * TA,) [or, accord. to Fei, the reverse is the case, (see 3,)] (tropical:) They made themselves quits, or even, one with another, in a reckoning, (S, A, Mgh, K,) or other thing (S, A, K) one withholding from another the like of what the latter owed him. (Mgh.)

8 AqtSR c
8. AqtSR It (hair [or the like]) was, or became, cut, or clipped, or shorn, (M, TA,) with the miqaSR; (TA;) as also tqSRS↓ and taqaSRaI. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- AqtSR Oavarahu: see qaSRa Avrh. ― -b2- AqtSR AlHadiyva: see qaSRa Ealayohi Alxabara. ＝ -A3- He retaliated, slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding. (M.) You say, AqtSR lifulaAnK mino fulaAnK (S, A, K) He retaliated for such a one upon such a one, by wounding the latter like as he had wounded the former, or by slaying the latter for the slaughter of the former, (S, K, TA,) and the like; (TA;) as also minohu OaqaSRahu↓. (S, K.) [See the latter verb, first signification.] And OafaSRahu↓, inf. n. UiqoSaASN, signifies [also] He (the Sultán) slew him in retaliation. (Msb.) ― -b2- AiqotiSaASN, as a subst., [i. e., having no verb corresponding to the signification here following, though I do not see how this can be asserted, for one may certainly say AuqotuSRa minohu,] also signifies The being done to like as one has done, whether it be slaughter or mutilation or beating or wounding. (TA.) ― -b3- See also 10.

10 AstqSR c
10. AstqSR He sought, or demanded, retaliation, i. e., slaying for slaying, or wounding for wounding. (M.) ― -b2- AstqSRhu He asked of him to retaliate for him: (S, A, Msb, K:) and AqtSRhu↓ signifies the same accord. to the K; but the author has been misled into saying this by misunderstanding the following passage in the O; tqSRS Avrh mvl qaSRahu wAqtSRhu wAstqSRhu saOalahu Oano yuqiSRahu, in which wAqtSRh terminates a clause. (TA.)

qaSRN c
qaSRN (M, K) and qaSaSN↓ (M, TA) What is cut, or clipped, or shorn, of the wool of a sheep. (M, K, TA.) See also quSaASapN. ＝ -A2- Also, both words, (S, M, A, K,) and qaSoqaSN↓ (M, TA) The breast (M, A, K) of anything: (M:) or the head thereof, (S, K,) called in Persian sr synh [i. e. sarosiynaho, applied to the pit at the head of the breast]; and such is the qaSaS of the sheep or goat, &c.: (S:) or the middle thereof: (M, K:) or the bone thereof, (M, K,) of a man or other animal; (TA;) [i. e. the sternum;] the soft bone into which are set the cartilaginous ends of the [seven upper pairs of the] ribs, in the middle of the breast: (Lth, TA:) pl. qiSaASN [a reg. pl. of the first]. (K.) Hence the saying, huwa Oalozamu laka mino XuEayoraAti qaSRika, (S,) or huwa Oalozamu bika mino XaEaraAti qaSRika, and qaSaSika↓, (M, TA,) [He is more closely adherent to thee than the little hairs, or the hairs, of thy breast, &c.:] because as often as they are cut they grow [afresh]: (As, TA:) meaning, he will not separate himself from thee, nor canst thou cast him from thee: applied to him who denies his relation: and also to him who denies a due that is incumbent on him. (Sgh, TA.) ― -b2- Also, the same three words, (the first and ↓second accord. to the TA, and the ↓third accord. to the K) and qaSiySN↓, (K,) The place of growth of the hair of the breast. (K, TA.) ＝ -A3- qaSRN, (JK, and so in one place in a copy of the M, and in the TA,) or qiSRN↓, (so in one place in a copy of the M) and qaSRapN↓ and qiSRapN↓, (M,) i. q. jaSRN, (JK,) or jiSRN, (M,) [i. e. Gypsum;] qaSRapN is syn. with jSR (S, Msb) in the dial. of El-Hijáz: (S:) or qaSRapN↓ and qiSRapN↓, (K,) the latter on the authority of IDrd, (TA,) and said by Aboo-Bekr to be with kesr, but by others said to be with fet-h, (Seer, TA,) are syn. with jaSRapN [and jiSRapN, ns. un. of jaSRN and jiSRN]: (K:) or signify stones of jSR [or gypsum]: (TA:) pl. qiSaASN [reg. as pl. of qaSRapN]: (K:) and qaSRaASN↓ is a dial. form of qaSRN [app. as syn. with jaSRN and jiSRN], a subst., like jayRaArN [which is nearly, if not exactly, syn. with jiyrN and jiaSRN]. (M, L.) In a trad. of Zeyneb, occurs this expression: EalaI maloHuwdapK yaAqaSRapF↓ [O gypsum upon buried corpses!] by which she likens the bodies of the persons addressed to tombs made of jSR, and their souls to the corpses contained in the tombs. (TA.)

qiSRN c
qiSRN: see qaSRN, last signification; the latter in three places.

qaSRapN c
qaSRapN: see qaSRN, last signification; the latter in three places.

quSRapN c
quSRapN The hair over the forehead; syn. naASiyapN, (M, A,) or XaEaru AlnRaASiyapi; (S, K;) accord. to some, (TA,) of a horse: (M, TA:) or what comes forward, thereof, over the face: (M, TA:) and the nASyp of a woman: (M:) or the TurRap, i. e., the nASyp, [or front hair of the head,] which is cut over (lit. over against, HicaMCa,) the forehead: (Mgh, Msb:) or what a woman makes, in the fore part of her head, by cutting the hair of that part, excepting over her temples: (TA:) or it signifies, as some say, (Mgh,) or signifies also, (M, A,) any lock of hair: (M, A, Mgh:) pl. quSaSN (M, Msb, K) and qiSaASN. (M, K) See also quSaASN.

qiSRapN c
qiSRapN A story; a narrative: (S, M, TA:) and what is written: (S, K:) and an affair; or a case: (S, Msb, K:) and qaSaSN↓ is syn. therewith, in the first of the above senses; (S, * M, A, * Msb, * TA;) and signifies a story, or narrative, related: (M, TA:) and qaSiySapN↓ also is syn. with qiSRapN [in the first of the above senses], (A, K,) and so is qaSiySN↓: (A:) the pl. of qiSRapN is qiSaSN, (S, Msb, K,) and OaqaA SiySu is a pl. pl.: (A, * TA:) and the pl. of qaSiySapN↓ is qaSaAYiSu. (A, * TA.) You say, lahu qiSRapN EajiybapN and qaSaSN &c. [He has, or to him, or it, relates, a wonderful story]. (A.) And fiI raOosihi qiSRapN (tropical:) In his head is a speech; or the like. (TA.) And maA qiSRatuka What is thine affair? or thy case? (Msb.) And rafaEa qiSRapF UilaI AlsRuloTaAni [He referred an affair, or a case, to the Sultán]. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also qaSRN, last signification.

qaSaSN c
qaSaSN: see qaSRN, first signification. ＝ -A2- See also qiSRapN. ＝ -A3- See also qSRN, again, second and third significations.

qaSaASN c
qaSaASN: see quSaAS.

quSaASu AlXRaEari c
quSaASu AlXRaEari and qiSaASuhu↓ and qaSaASuhu↓, (S, M, A, Mgh, K,) of which three forms the first is the most common, (S,) The part where the growth of the hair terminates, (As, S, M, A, * Mgh, K,) in the fore part and the hind part (As, S, M) of the head; (M;) or in the fore part or the hind part; (K;) or in the fore part of the head and around it; (A;) or in the fore part of the head or around it; (Mgh;) or in the middle of the head: (TA:) or the extremity of the back of the neck: (M, TA:) or the whole circuit [of the hair], behind and before and around; and one says also AlXRaEari quSaASapu↓: (TA:) and AlXRaEari maqaSRu↓, of which the pl. is maqaASRu, signifies the same as quSaASuhu; (As, TA;) or the part where it is taken with the scissors: (TA:) AlquSaASu also signifies the place along which the scissors run in the middle of the head: (M, K:) or the extremity of the back of the neck: (K:) or the part where the growth of the hair terminates (K, TA) in the fore part of the head; or in the fore part and the hind part thereof; as before explained. (TA.) ― -b2- You say also, EaDRa biquSaASi kafRayhohi, meaning, (tropical:) He bit the extremities of his two hands, where they meet together. (A, TA.)

qiSaASN c
qiSaASN: see quSaAS. ＝ -A2- Also, (S, M, Msb, K,) and qaSaASaMCu↓, (so in a copy of the M, and in the CK, and in a MS copy of the K [in the TA quSaASaMCu↓, which I think a mistake,]) and qiSaASaMCu↓, (M, K,) [the first an inf. n. of 3, q. v.,] i. q. qawadN; (S, K;) Retaliation, by slaying for slaying, and wounding for wounding, (M, Msb, TA,) and mutilating for mutilating. (Msb.)

qaSiySN c
qaSiySN: see maqoSuwSN: ＝ -A2- and qiSRapN: ＝ -A3- and qaSRN, third signification.

quSaASapN c
quSaASapN Cuttings, or what is cut off (M, A) with the miqaSR, (A,) of hair, (Lh, M, A,) and of the unwoven end, or extremity, of a garment, or piece of cloth. (M.) ― -b2- See also quSaAS.

qaSiySapN c
qaSiySapN A camel, (M, K,) or horse, or the like, (M,) with which one follows, or follows after, (M, K,) footsteps, (M,) or the footsteps of travellingcamels: (K:) pl. qaSaAYiSu. (Ibn-'Abbád, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qiSRapN, in two places.

qaSaASaMCu c
qaSaASaMCu, or quSaASaMCu, and qiSaASaMCu: see qiSaASN.

qaSRaASN c
qaSRaASN: see qaSRN, last signification.

qaSoqaSN c
qaSoqaSN: see qaSRN, second and third significations.

qaASRN c
qaASRN A relater of a story or narrative (K, TA) in its proper course; as though he followed its meanings and expressions; or of stories, or narratives; as some say, because he pursues story after story: (TA:) pl. quSRaASN. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And One who recites, or delivers, the kind of discourse termed xuTobap. (TA.)

OaqaASiySu c
OaqaASiySu: see qiSRapu.

maqaSRu AlXRaEari c
maqaSRu AlXRaEari: see quSaAS.

miqaSRN c
miqaSRN A miqoraAD [or single blade of scissors or shears], (S, A, K,) with which one cuts, or clips, or shears; (TA;) one of the things whereof a pair is called miqaSRaAni: (S, K:) or miqaSRaAni signifies the thing with which one cuts hair [&c.]; and has no sing., accord. to the lexicologists, though Sb assigns to it a sing.: (M:) some say, that the use of the sing. is a mistake of the vulgar: (MF:) the pl. is maqaASRu. (A, TA.)

muqaSRaSN c
muqaSRaSN: see maqoSuwSN, in two places. ＝ -A2- A tomb plastered with qaSR [or gypsum]: and in like manner muqaSRaSapN applied to a city (madiynap). (M, TA.)

maqoSuwSN c
maqoSuwSN Cut, clipped, or shorn; applied to hair [&c.]; as also qaSiySN↓: (M, TA:) and to a wing; as also muqaSRaSN↓. (A.) maqoSuwSu AlxanaAHi A bird having the wing clipped. (S.) And muqaSRaSN↓ Having the forelocks clipped, or shorn. (Meyd, in Golius.)

1 qaSabahu c
1. qaSabahu, aor.
qaSiba
, (M, K,) inf. n. qaSobN, (S, M, O,) He cut it, (S, * M, O, * K,) namely, a thing; (M;) as also AqtSbhu↓. (M, K.) And qaSaba AlXRaApa, (S, M, O, Msb, K,) aor. as above, (M, Msb,) and so the inf. n., (S, M, O, Msb,) said of the butcher, (O,) He cut up the sheep, or goat, into joints, or separate limbs: (S, O, Msb:) or he separated the [bones called] qaSab of the sheep, or goat. (M, K.) ― -b2- fulaAnN lamo yuqoSabN meaning (tropical:) Such a one has not been circumcised, is from AlqaSobu signifying “ the act of cutting. ” (A.) ― -b3- And qaSabahu, (S, M, A, O, K,) aor.
qaSiba
, inf. n. qaSobF; (M;) and qSRbhu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoSibN, (K,) (tropical:) He attributed, or imputed, to him, or accused him of, a vice, or fault, or the like; (S, M, A, O, K;) and reviled, or vilified, him; (M, A, K;) meaning he cut him with censure. (A.) ＝ -A2- And qaSabahu, (S, M, O, K,) namely, a camel, and [any] other [animal], (S, O,) or a man, (M, K,) and a beast, (M,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He stopped, or cut short, (S, O,) or prevented, (M, K,) his drinking, before he had satisfied his thirst. (S, M, O, K.) ― -b2- And qaSaba Xurobahu He (a camel) abstained from his drinking before he had satisfied his thirst: (ISk, S, O:) or qaSaba [alone], said of a camel, (As, M, K, TA,) aor. as above, inf. n. qaSobN and quSuwbN, (M, K,) he refused to drink: (As, TA:) or he abstained from drinking the water, raising his head from it, (M, K, TA,) before he had satisfied his thirst: (TA:) or, as some say, quSuwbN signifies the satisfying of thirst by coming to the water &c. (M, TA.) ― -b3- And qaSaba AlmaMCa, aor.
qaSiba
, inf. n. qaSobN, He (a camel) sucked up, or sucked in, the water. (M, TA.) ＝ -A3- It seems to be applied in the S that qaSaba, aor. as above, also signifies He played upon a musical reed, or pipe. (MF.)

2 qaSRaba
2: see the preceding paragraph. ＝ -A2- qSRb AlzRaroEu, (S, M, O,) inf. n. taqoSiybN; (S;) and AqSb↓; (M;) The zrE [i. e. seed-produce, or wheat or the like,] produced its qaSab [or jointed stalks, or culms:] (M:) this is the case after the taforiyx. (S, O. [See 2 in art. frx.]) [Hence the saying,] UinRiI OaraI AlXRarRa qaSRaba (assumed tropical:) [Verily I see evil, or the evil, to have grown, like corn producing its culms]. (TA voce nabRaba.) ― -b2- And qSRb AlXRaEara, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoSiybN, (O, K,) (assumed tropical:) He twisted the locks of the hair [in a spiral form so that they became like hollow canes]: (M, K:) or qaSRabato XaEarahaA (tropical:) she (a woman) twisted the locks of her hair so that they became like qaSab [i. e. hollow canes]: (A:) and (K) (assumed tropical:) he curled the hair; syn. jaERadahu. (O, K.) ― -b3- And qSRbhu, (ISh, TA,) inf. n. as above, (O, K,) He bound his hands to his neck, (ISh, O, K, TA,) namely, a man's: (ISh, TA:) [and app., in like manner, his fore-legs, namely, a sheep's or a goat's: sea qaSRaAbN, last sentence.]

4 AqSbhu EiroDahu c
4. AqSbhu EiroDahu (assumed tropical:) He empowered him to revile, or vilify, him. (M.) [Agreeably with an explanation of qaSabahu in the A, mentioned above, it may rather be rendered (tropical:) He caused him to cut, with censure, or to wound, his honour, or reputation.] ＝ -A2- AqSb said of a pastor, (ISk, S, M, O, K,) [He performed his service ill, so that] his camels disliked, and refused to drink, the water; (ISk, M, K;) or, [so that] his camels abstained from drinking before they had satisfied their thirst. (S, O.) raEaI faOaqoSaba [He pastured, and performed his service ill, &c.,] is a prov., (S, M, O, K,) applied to a [bad] pastor; because, if he
pasture the camels ill, they will not drink; (S, O, K;) for they drink only when they are satiated with the herbage: (S, O:) or, as Meyd says, it is applied to him who will not act sincerely, or honestly, and with energy, or vigour, in an affair which he has undertaken, so that he mars, or vitiates, it. (TA.) ＝ -A3- AqSb said of a place, It produced reeds, or canes. (M, K.) ― -b2- See also 2.

8 UiqotaSaba
8: see 1, first sentence.

quSobN c
quSobN A gut; syn. miEFI: (S, M, Mgh, O, K:) or all the OamoEaMC [or guts]: or the guts [AmEMC] that are in the lower part of the belly: TA:) pl. OaqoSaAbN. (S. M, Mgh, O, K.) One says, huwa yajurRu quSobahu [expl. by what here follows]. (S, O.) The Prophet said, respecting 'Amr Ibn- 'Ámir El-Khurá'ee, who first set at liberty sawaAYib [pl. of saAYibapN, q. v.], (O,) or respecting 'Amr Ibn-Kamee-ah, who first changed the religion of Ishmael, (TA,) raOayotuhu yajurRu quSobahu fiI AlnRuAri [I saw him dragging his guts in the fire of Hell]. (O, TA.) ― -b2- El-Aashà in his saying
waXaAhidunaA AljulRa waAlyaAsamiI
nu waAlmusomiEaAtu biOaqoSaAbihaA
means [The rose being present with us, and the jasmine, and the songstresses] with their chords of gut: or, as some relate it, (and as it is cited in the M,) he said biquSRaAbihaA↓, meaning with their musical reeds, or pipes. (S, O.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The middle of the body; metaphorically applied thereto: so in the saying of Imra-el-Keys, (S, O, L,) or, accord. to the people of El-Koofeh and ElBasrah, it is falsely ascribed to him, (O,)
wAlquSobu muDoTamirN waAlmatonu maloHuwbu
[And the middle of the body slender and lean, and the portion next the back-bone, on either side, smooth, and sloping downwards]. (S, O, L.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The back. (O, K. [SM, not having found this in any lexicon but the K, supposed that AlZRahoru might be substituted in it for AlxaSoru, which is not therein mentioned as a meaning of AlquSobu.])

qaSabN c
qaSabN [a coll. gen. n., signifying Reeds, or canes; and the like, as the culms of corn, &c.; and sometimes signifying a reed, or cane, and the like, as meaning a species thereof;] any plant having (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) its stem composed of (Mgh, Msb) OanaAbiyb [or internodial portions] (M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and [their] kuEuwb [or connecting knots, or joints]; (Mgh, Msb;) [i. e. any kind, or species, of plant having a jointed stem;] i. q. OabaMCN [a word comparatively little known]; (S; [in the O AanAC, a mistranscription;]) and [it is said that] qaSobaMCu↓ signifies the same: (S, O: [but see what follows:]) the n. un. of the former is qaSabapN↓ (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and qaSobaApN↓ or qaSabaApN↓: (K accord. to different copies; the former accord. to the TA: [but each of these I believe to be a mistake for qaSuboMCapN↓, which is said to be a n. un. of qaSobaMCu, and therefore held by some to be syn. with qaSabapN:]) qaSobaMCu↓ [appears, however, to differ somewhat from qaSab, for it is said that it] signifies an assemblage of qaSab; (M, K;) and its n. un. is qaSabapN↓ and qaSobaMCapN↓ [like HalafapN and HalofaMCapN which are both said to be ns. un. of HalofaMCN; and TarafapN and TarofaMCapN, said to be ns. un. of TarofaMCN; the former in each case anomalous]: (M: [see also Ham p. 201:]) or, accord. to Sb, qaSobaMCu↓ is sing. and pl., (S, M, Mgh, O,) and so TarofaMCu, (S, M, O,) and HalofaMCu; (S, O;) as pl. and as sing. also having the sign of the fem. gender; therefore, when they mean to express the sing. signification, they add the epithet waAHidapN; thus, and thus only, distinguishing the sing. meaning from the pl., and making a difference between a word of this class and a noun that denotes a pl. meaning and has not the sign of the fem. gender such as tamorN and busorN, and such as OaroTFI and EaloqFI of which the ns. un. are OaroTaApN and EaloqaApN: (M:) or, as some say, qaSobaMCu↓ signifies many qaSab growing in a place: (Mgh:) and it signifies also a place in which qaSab grow: (M, K:) [or] maqoSabapN↓ has this last meaning; (Mgh, Msb;) or signifies, like OaroDN qaSibapN↓, a land having qaSab. (M, K. *) ― -b2- OaHoraza qaSaba AlsRaboqi, (Msb,) or AlsRaboqi qaSabapa↓, (TA,) [meaning (assumed tropical:) He won, or acquired, the canes, or cane, of victory in racing,] is said of the winner in horseracing: they used to set up, in the horse-course, a cane (qaSabap,) and he who outstripped plucked it up and took it, in order that he might be known to be the one who outstripped, without contention: this was the origin of the phrase: then, in consequence of frequency of usage, it was applied also to the expeditious, quick, and light, or active: (Msb, * TA:) [accord. to the TA, it is a tropical phrase, but perhaps it is so only when used in the latter way:] it is said in a trad. of Sa'eed Ibn-El-Ás, that he measured the horse-course with the cane, making it to be a hundred canes in length, and the cane was stuck upright in the ground at the goal, and he who was first in arriving at it took it, and was entitled to the stake. (O, TA. [See also muqaSRibN.]) ― -b3- [The qaSabap↓ here mentioned as A certain measure of length, used in measuring race-courses, was also used in other cases, in measuring land, and differed in different countries and in different times: accord. to some, it was ten cubits; thus nearly agreeing with our “ rod: ” (see jariybN:) accord. to others, six cubits and a third of a cubit: (see fadRaAnN:) the modern Egyptian qaSabap, until it was reduced some years ago, was about twelve English feet and a half; its twentyfourth part, called qaboDapN, being the measure of a man's fist with the thumb erect, or about six inches and a quarter.] ― -b4- AlqaSabu AlfaArisiIRu [The Persian reed] is a kind whereof writing-reeds are made: (Mgh, Msb:) and another kind thereof is hard and thick; and of this kind are made musical reeds, or pipes; and with it houses, or chambers, are roofed. (Msb) One says, qaSabu AlxTRi Oanofacu mino qaSabi AlxaTRi [meaning Writingreeds are more penetrating, or effective, than the canes of El-Khatt (which are spears); i. e., words wound more than spears]. (A, TA.) ― -b5- qaSabu AlsRukRari is well-known [as meaning The sugar-cane]: (Msb:) this is of three kinds; white and yellow and black: of the first and second, but not of the third, the juice [of which sugar is made] is expressed; and this expressed juice is called Easalu AlqaSabi. (Mgh.) ― -b6- qaSabu AlcRariyrapi [is Calamus aromaticus; also called qaSabu AlTRiybi]: a species thereof has the joints near together, and breaks into many fragments, or splinters, and the internodial portions thereof are filled with a substance like spiders' webs: when chewed, it has an acrid taste, and it is aromatic (Mgh, Msb) when brayed, or powdered; (Mgh;) and inclines to yellowness and whiteness. (Mgh, Msb. [See also cariyrapN, in art. cr.]) ― -b7- qaSabN also signifies (assumed tropical:) Any round and hollow bone [or rather bones]; (S, O;) it is pl. [or rather a coll. gen. n.] of which qaSabapN↓ is the sing. [or n. un,], this latter signifying any bone containing marrow; (M, K;) thus called by way of comparison [to the reed, or cane]. (M.) ― -b8- And (tropical:) The bones of the yadaAni and rijolaAni [i. e. arms and legs, or hands and feet, but here app. meaning the latter], (A, Msb,) and the like: (Msb:) [or] (assumed tropical:) the [phalanges, or] bones of the fingers and toes; (M, K, * TA;) (tropical:) the bones whereof there are three in each finger and two in the thumb [and the like in the feet]; (A, TA;) and Zj says, the bones of the OaSaAbiE [or fingers and toes] which are also called sulaAmaI: (Msb in art. slm:) or, as some say, the portions between every two joints of the OaSaAbiE: (M, TA:) and AlOaSaAbiEi qaSabapu↓ [or qaSabupu AlUiSobaEi] signifies the Oanomalap [here perhaps meaning the ungual phalanx] of the finger or toe. (Msb, TA.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) The bones and veins of a wing. (MF.) ― -b10- [And (assumed tropical:) Quills: thus in the phrase SaAra AlrRiyXu qaSabFA, in the K, voce OanuwqN, meaning The feathers became quills: n. un. qaSabapN↓: see SanamapN.] ― -b11- And (tropical:) [The bronchi;] the branches of the windpipe; (M, K;) and outlets of the breath; (K;) [i. e.] AlqaSabu, (S, M, O,) or faSabu AlrRiYapi, (A, Msb,) signifies the ducts (Euruwq) of the lungs; (S, A, O, Msb;) through which the breath passes forth. (S, M, A, O, Msb.) [See HaloqN.] ― -b12- And (assumed tropical:) Any things made of silver, and of other material, resembling [in form] the kind of round and hollow bone [or bones] thus called: n. un. qaSabapN↓. (S, O.) And (assumed tropical:) Jewels (S, M, K) having the form of tubes (OanaAbiyb), (S,) or oblong, (M, K,) and hollow. (M.) ― -b13- And (assumed tropical:) Brilliant pearls, and brilliant chrysolites, interset with jacinths. (IAar, O, K.) So in the saying, in a trad., (O, K,) related as uttered by Gabriel, (O,) [cited in the S app. as an ex. of the meaning next preceding
this last,] baXRiro xadiyjapa bibayoti fiI AljanRapi mino qaSabK (IAar, O, K) i. e. [Rejoice thou Khadeejeh by the announcement of] a pavilion [in Paradise] of brilliant pearls, &c.: (IAar, O:) or the meaning is, of hollow pearls [or pearl], spacious, like the lofty palace: (IAth, TA:) or of emerald: (TA voce bayotN:) and it is said by some to convey an allusion to Khadeejeh's acquiring what is termed qaSabu AlsRaboqi [expl. above], because she was the first person, or the first of women, who embraced El-Islám. (MF, TA.) ― -b14- And (tropical:) Fine, thin, or delicate, (S, O,) or soft, (M, Msb, K,) garments, or cloths, of linen: (S, M, O, Msb, K:) a single one thereof is called qaSabiIRN↓. (M, O, Msb, K.) One says, maEa fulaAnK qaSabu SanoEaMCa waqaSabu miSora (tropical:) [In the possession of such a one are] qaSab [meaning the cylindrical, or oblong, hollow pieces] of carnelian [of San'à], and qaSab [meaning the fine, or soft, garments, or cloths,] of linen [of Egypt]. (A.) ― -b15- Also (tropical:) The channels by which water flows from the springs, or sources: (S, M, A, O, K:) or the channels by which the water of a well flows from the springs, or sources: (As, T, TA:) n. un. qaSabapN↓. (M.) And qaSabu AlbaToHaMCi (assumed tropical:) The waters [of the kind of water-course called bTHMC (q. v.)] that run to the springs, or sources, of the wells. (As, S, O.) Aboo-Dhueyb says,
OaqaAmato bihi faQbotanato xayomapF
EalaI qaSabK wafuraAtK naharo
(As, S, M, O,) meaning She remained [in it, and constructed for herself a booth, or a tent,] amid wells and sweet water that flowed copiously. (As, S, O.) ― -b16- See also qaSabapN below, in the next paragraph. ＝ -A2- AlqaSabu is also a name for The ewe. (O.) ― -b2- And qaSabo qaSabo is A call to the ewe (O, K) to be milked. (O.)

qaSabapN c
qaSabapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in nine places. ― -b2- [It also, app., signifies The caneroll of a loom: see niyrN. ― -b3- And, app., (assumed tropical:) The mouth, which has the form of a short cylinder, in the middle of the upper part, of the kind of leathern water-bag called mazaAdap: see xurotapN.] ― -b4- (tropical:) The bone of the nose; qaSabapu AlOanofi signifying the nasal bone. (S, A.) ― -b5- [And (assumed tropical:) The shaft of a well.] You say biYorN musotaqiymapu AlqaSabapi (assumed tropical:) [A well of which the shaft is straight]. (TA.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) A well recently dug. (M, K, TA.) ― -b7- And (tropical:) The interior part of a country or town; (A;) and of a qaSor [i. e. pavilion, or palace]; (M, A, K;) and of a fortress; (A:) or of a fortress containing a building or buildings; or the middle of such a fortress, (TA,) and of a town or village: (S, L, Msb, TA: [Golius, reading qiroyap qaroyap, assigns to it also the signification of the “ middle of a water-skin: ”]) or a qaSor [i. e. pavilion, or palace,] itself; (M, K;) and [a fortress itself, or] a fortified castle such as is occupied by a commander and his forces: (TA in art. xwj:) and a town or village [itself]: (M, K:) and the Hariym [as meaning interior, or middle,] of a house. (T and TA in art. Hrm.) Also A city: (K:) or the [chief] city (S, M, Msb) of the Sawád, (S,) or, [by a general application,] of a country: (M, Msb:) or the chief, or main, part (M, K) of a city (M) or of cities. (K: but in the TA this last meaning is given as the explanation of AlOamoSaAri qaSabu↓.) ― -b8- See also qaSiybapN, in two places: ― -b9- and see qiSaAbN.

OaroDN qaSibapN c
OaroDN qaSibapN: see qaSabN, first quarter.

qaSobaMCu c
qaSobaMCu: see qaSabN, first quarter, in four places.

qaSobaApN c
qaSobaApN or qaSabaApN: see qaSabN, first sentence.

qaSobaMCapN c
qaSobaMCapN: see qaSabN, first sentence, in two places.

qaSabiIRN c
qaSabiIRN: see qaSabN, last quarter.

qiSaAbN c
qiSaAbN, (so in the K, there said to be like kitaAbN,) or qiSaAbapN↓, (so in the M and L,) A dam that is constructed in the place that has been eaten away by water, [for lajof in the CK, and liHof in other copies of the K, (in the place of which I find luhoj in a copy of the M, app. a mistranscription,) I read, and thus render lajaf, supposing it to mean such a place in the side of a rivulet for irrigation,] lest the torrent should collect itself together from every place, and consequently the border of the rivulet for irrigation of the garden of palm-trees [thus I render EiraAqu AlHaAYiTi (see art. Erq)] should become demolished. (M, K.) ― -b2- And qiSaAbN signifies dibaArN: (so accord. to a copy of the M:) or diyaArN: (so in copies of the K:) [the former I think to be the preferable reading; but its meaning is doubtful: accord. to the K it signifies Small channels for irrigation between tracts of seed-produce; and ISd says the like: accord. to AHn, patches of sown ground: see more voce daborN: it is a pl.,] and the sing. is qaSabapN↓. (M, K.)

qaSuwbN c
qaSuwbN A sheep or goat that one shears. (O, K.)

qaSiybN c
qaSiybN, applied to a he-camel, (M, TA,) and likewise to a she-camel, (TA, [but this I think doubtful, as it has the meaning of an act. (not pass.) part. n.,]) That sucks up, or sucks in, the water. (M, TA.) ― -b2- See also qaASibN.

qiSaAbapN c
qiSaAbapN The art of playing upon the musical reed, or pipe. (S, O.) ― -b2- [And] The craft, or occupation, of the butcher. (M, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also qiSaAbN.

qaSiybapN c
qaSiybapN: see quSRaAbapN. ― -b2- Also, and quSRaAbapN↓, (S, M, O, K,) and qaSabapN↓, (Lth, M, K,) and taqoSiybapN↓, (M, O, K,) and taqoSibapN↓, (M, K,) (tropical:) A lock of hair having a [spiral] twisted form [so as to be like a hollow cane]: (Lth, M, K:) or a pendent lock of hair that is twisted so as to curl [in a spiral form]; not plaited: (S, O:) or qaSiybapN signifies a lock of hair that curls naturally so as to be like a hollow cane; (A;) and its pl. is qaSaAYibN: (S, A:) [and,] accord. to Lth, such is termed qaSabapN↓ (TA) [and app. quSRaAbapN↓ also]: and taqoSiybapN↓, (Lth, A, TA,) of which the pl. is taqaASiybu, (Lth, A, O, TA,) signifies such as is twisted and made to curl by a woman; (Lth, * A, TA;) [and so, app., taqoSibapN↓;] i. e., such as, being [naturally] lank, is curled by means of canes and thread. (A.)

qaSRaAbN c
qaSRaAbN A blower in reeds or canes (naAfixN fiI AlqaSabi); as also qaASibN↓. (M, K. [In the former, this explanation is given in such a manner as plainly shows that it is meant to be understood as being distinct from that which next follows: but I incline to think that the two explanations are taken from different sources and have one and the same application.]) And (M, K) A player on the musical reed, or pipe; (AA, S, M, O, K;) and so qaASibN↓. (S, O.) Ru-beh says, (S, M, O, TA,) describing an ass, (S, O, TA,) braying, (TA,)
fiI jawofihi waHoIN kawaHoIi AlqaSRaAbo
[In his chest is, or was, a sound like the sound of the player on the musical reed]. (S, M, O, TA.) ― -b2- And A butcher; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also qaASibN↓: (M, K:) so called from qaSaba in the first of the senses expl. in this art.; (M, O, Msb, TA;) or because he takes the sheep or goat by its qaSabap, i. e. its shank-bone; (M, TA;) or because he cleanses the OafoSaAb, or guts, of the belly; or from qaSRabahu signifying as expl. in the last sentence of the second paragraph of this article. (O, TA.)

quSRaAbN c
quSRaAbN: see quSRaAbahN, in two places.

qaSRaAbapN c
qaSRaAbapN (O, K, accord. to my MS. copy of the K quSRaAbapN [which is wrong]) lilnRaAsi (O) (tropical:) One who reviles men, vilifies them, or defames them, much: (O, K:) [or, very much; for] the p is added to render the epithet [doubly] intensive. (O.) [See 1, third sentence.]

quSRaAbapN c
quSRaAbapN, (S, O, and so accord. to my MS copy of the K, accord. to other copies of the K qaSRaAbapN [which is wrong,]) with damm and teshdeed, (S,) An internodial portion of a reed or cane; such a portion thereof as intervenes between two joints, or knots; syn. OanobuwbapN; (S, O, K;) [a n. un. of the coll. gen. n. quSRaAbN↓;] and qaSiybapN↓, (O, K,) of which the pl. is qaSaAYibu, (TA,) signifies the same. (O, K.) ― -b2- And A musical reed, or pipe; syn. mizomaArN: (S, M, K:) pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] quSRaAbN↓. (S, M, O.) See an ex. of the latter in a verse of El-Aashà (accord. to one relation thereof) cited voce quSobN. (S, M, O.) ― -b3- See also qaSiybapN, in two places.

qaASbN c
qaASbN, applied to a he-camel and a she-camel,
(ISk, S, M, O, K,) Abstaining from drinking before having satisfied thirst: (ISk, S, O:) or abstaining from drinking the water, and raising the head from it; (M, K;) and so qaSybN↓, likewise applied to the he-camel and the she-camel: (K: [but this latter I think doubtful:]) or a camel (baEiyrN) refusing to drink: (As, TA:) and muqotaSibapN↓ is also said to be applied to a she-camel. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And A raiser, or grower, of qaSab [i. e. reeds, or canes]. (Mgh.) ― -b2- See also qaSRaAbN, in two places. ― -b3- Also (assumed tropical:) Sounding thunder: (M:) and a cloud in which is thunder and lightning: (As, TA:) or, accord. to As, a cloud in which is thunder; (O;) [and] so says Az; (TA;) likened to a player on a musical reed, or pipe. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And dirRapN qaASibapN (assumed tropical:) A stream of milk coming forth easily (M, O) from the teat of the udder (O) as though it were a rod of silver. (M, O.) ― -b5- See, again, qaSRaAbN, last sentence.

taqoSibapN c
taqoSibapN and taqoSiybapN: see qaSiybapN; each in two places.

maqoSabapN c
maqoSabapN: see qaSabN, first quarter.

muqaSRabN c
muqaSRabN (tropical:) Hair curled in the manner expl. above, voce qaSiybapN. (S, A, O.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A garment, or piece of cloth, folded. (Msb.)

muqaSRibN c
muqaSRibN (tropical:) One who wins, or acquires, the canes of the contest for victory (in racing yuHorizu qaSaba AlsRibaAqi, A, O, K, TA, in the CK qaSabaAti AlsRibAqi) [i. e. in horse-racing]: and (tropical:) a fleet horse, that outstrips others. (A.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Milk upon which the froth is thick. (O, K.)

miqoSaAbN c
miqoSaAbN may mean A place abounding with qaSab [i. e. reeds, or canes]; like as miEoXaAbN means “ a place abounding with [herbage of the kind termed] EuXob. ” (Ham p. 490.)

muqotaSibahN c
muqotaSibahN: see qaASibN.

1 qaSadahu c
1. qaSadahu, and qaSadalahu, and Ulayohi, (S, M, A, L, Msb, K,) and naHowahu, (A in art. smt, &c.,) aor.
qaSida
, (M, Msb, K, &c.,) inf. n. qaSodN, (S, M, Msb, K, &c.,) from which the pl. quSuwdN is formed by some of the professors of practical law; [and maqoSadN, q. v., is also an inf. n.;] (Msb;) He tended, repaired, or betook himself, or went, to, or towards, him, or it; (originally and properly, either in a direct course, in which sense it is in some places specially used, or indirectly; IJ, M, L;) he directed himself, or his course or aim, to, or towards, him, or it; he made for, or towards, him, or it; he made him, or it, his object; he aimed at him, or it: he sought, endeavoured after, pursued, or endeavoured to reach or attain, or obtain, him, or it: he desired it, or wished for it: he intended it; purposed it; or meant it: syn. tawajRaha wanahada wanahaDa naHowahu, (IJ, M, L,) and naHaAhu, (S, L,) and OataAhu, (S, A, L,) and Talabahu biEayonihi, (Msb,) and OamRahu, and AiEotamadahu, (M, L, K,) and AiEotazamahu. (IJ, M, L.) ― -b2- qaSadotu qaSodahu: see qaSodahu, below. ― -b3- qaSadotuhu bikacaA and qaSadotuhu lahu bihi [I brought to him such a thing: lit. I directed, or betook, myself to him with such a thing: see an ex. in the first para. of art. bI] (Ham. p. 41.) Uilayoka qaSodiI, and maqoSadiI↓, (the latter with fet-h to the S, Msb), To thee is my tending, or repairing, &c. (A.) ― -b4- qaSada fiI AlOamori, [aor.
qaSida
,] (A, Msb,) inf. n. qaSodN; (S. M, L, Msb, K) and fiyhi AqtSd↓; (M, L, K;) (tropical:) He pursued a right, or direct, course in the affair: (L:) or he followed the middle and most just way in the affair; and did not exceed the due bounds therein: (Msb:) or he acted in a moderate manner, in a manner between that of prodigality and that of parsimoniousness, in the affair: (S, L:) or he acted in a manner the contrary of that of extravagance in the affair: (M, L, K:) or he kept within the due bounds in the affair, and was content with a middle course: (A:) and in like manner, fI AlnRafaqapi in expense: (L:) and fiI maEiyXatihi with respect to his means of subsistence. (A, L.) See also 8. ― -b5- qaSada fiI maXoyihi He (a man) walked at an equable, or a moderate, pace; syn. maXaI musotuwiyFA. (L.) waQqoSido fiI maXoyika [in the Kur xxxi. 18,] (S) means And go thou at a moderate pace in thy walking; neither slowly nor quickly. (Beyd, Jel.) ― -b6- AiqoSido bicaroEika Deal thou gently with thyself; moderate thyself; restrain thyself; i. q. AirobaEo EalaI nafosika. (S.) ― -b7- AlqaSoda AlqaSoda taboluguwA Keep ye to the middle way: keep ye to the middle way in affairs; in sayings and actions: so shall ye attain [to that which ye should desire]: AlqSd being in the accus. case as a corroborative inf. n.; and it is repeated also for the sake of corroboration. (L, from a trad.) ― -b8- qaSada, aor.
qaSida
, (L,) inf. n. qaSodN, (M, L, K,) (tropical:) It (a road, or way,) was direct, or right; had a direct, or right, tendency. (M, L, K.) EalaI QllRehi qaSodu AlsRabiyli [Kur xvi. 9,] Upon God it rests to show the direct, or right way, (M, Beyd, L,) [or the right direction of the way] which leads to the truth, (Beyd,) and to invite to it by evident proofs: (M, L:) or upon God it rests to make the way direct, or right, in mercy and favour: or upon God depends one's directing his course to the [right] way. (Beyd.) ― -b9- qaSada, aor.
qaSida
, (S, L,) inf. n. qaSodN, (S, L, K,) (tropical:) He acted with justice, or equity. (S, L, K.) Abu-l-Lahhám Eth-Thaalebee says,
EalaI AlHakami AlmaOotiIRi yawomFA UicaA qaDaI
qaDiyRatahu Oan lRaA yajuwra wayaqoSidu
(S, L) meaning, It is encumbent on the judge who is come to, any day, when he decides his case, that he do not deviate from what is right, but (balo) act with justice, or equity. (IB, L.) Akh says, He means wayanobagiI Oano yaqoSida; but as he makes an ellipsis, and puts yqSd in the place, syntactically, of ynbgI, he makes it marfooa, because it has the place of that which is [virtually] marfooa: and Fr says, he makes it marfooa because of the disagreement; for as its meaning disagrees with that of the preceding verb, it is made to disagree therefore in desinential syntax. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- qaSada, (S, L,) aor.
qaSida
, (L,) inf. n. qaSodN, (S, L, K,) [and qaSida, see 7] He broke a stick: (S, L:) he broke in any way or manner: or he broke in halves: as also qSRd↓, inf. n. taqoSiydN: (L, K:) [or the latter signifies he broke many things; or broke in many pieces: see 7.] ＝ -A3- quSida lahu He was given a little. (S, O, K, art. qSd.) ＝ -A4- qaSuda, aor.
qaSuda
, inf. n. qaSaAdapN, He (a camel, TA) became fat. (K.) ＝ -A5- See also 4.

2 qaSRada
2: see 1 last sentence but one. ＝ -A2- And see 4.

4 OaqoSadaniI Uilayohi AlOamuro c
4. OaqoSadaniI Uilayohi AlOamuro The affair caused me to tend, repair, betake myself, or direct my course, to, or towards, him, or it; to aim at him, or it; to seek, endeavour after, pursue, or endeavour to reach, attain, or obtain, him, or it; to desire it, or wish for it; to intend it, or purpose it. (M, L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) It (an arrow) hit its object, and killed on the spot. (S, K.) ― -b3- He pierced a man with a spear, (K,) or shot him with an arrow, (TA,) and did not miss him: (K:) he struck, or shot, a thing so that it died on the spot: (As:) he killed on the spot: (Lth:) it (a serpent) killed a person (Lth, S) on the spot: (Lth:) or bit him so as to kill him. (K, * TA.) OaqoSadatohu AlmaniyRapu Destiny killed him on the spot. (A.) ＝ -A2- AqSd, (inf. n. UiqoSaAdN, TA,) He composed [odes, or] poems of the kind termed qaSiyd; a verb similar to Oaromala and Oahozaja and Oarojaza: (Ibn-Buzurj, L:) also, (L, TA,) or AqtSd↓, inf. n. UiqotiSaAdN, accord. to the K, but the former is the correct form, (TA,) [or the latter is probably correct, as being similar to Uirotajaza, as well as the former, of which the act. part. n. occurs in a verse,] and qaSada↓, inf. n. qaSodN; (K;) or qaSRada↓; (as in the M and L;) he continued uninterruptedly, (L, K,) and prolonged, (L,) the composition of [odes, or] poems of the kind termed qaSaAYid. (L, K.) See muqoSdN.

5 tqSRd c
5. tqSRd He (a dog &c.) died. (S.) ― -b2- And see 7, in three places.

7 AnqSd c
7. AnqSd and tqSRd↓; (L, K;) and qaSida↓, aor.
qaSada
, inf. n. qaSadN; but this form of the verb is seldom used; (L;) It broke, or became broken, in any way or manner: or it broke, or became broken, in halves: (L, K:) [but they are differently used: you say,] AnqSd AlrRumoHu [the spear broke: or] (S, L) the spear broke in halves: (L:) and AlrRimaAHu tqSRdti↓ the spears broke in many pieces. (S, A, L.) ＝ -A2- AnqSd and tqSRd↓ It (marrow) became detached, or came forth, from its place. (TA.)

8 AqtSd c
8. AqtSd: see 1. ― -b2- He aimed at that which was right and just. (A, art. Syd. See 1 in that art.) ＝ -A2- And see 4.

qaSodN c
qaSodN, [inf. n. of 1, q. v. ― -b2- Used as a subst., The tending, self-direction, aim, or course of a
person ― -b3- Hence, An object of aim, of endeavour or pursuit, of desire or wish, or of intention or purpose; one's intention, intent, or meaning; as also maqoSuwdN↓. See maqoSidN] ― -b4- A thing that is right, of what is said and of what is done; syn. sadaAdN and SawaAbN. (S, voce tasodiydN, &c.) huwa EaAaI qaSodK, He is following a right way, or course. (Msb.) See also qaASidN. ― -b5- Conforming, or conformable, to the just mean. (M in art. Am.) See also muqaSRadN. ＝ -A2- A little that is given. (S, O, K, art. qSd.) ＝ -A3- See also qaSiydN.

qaSodahu c
qaSodahu In the direction of, or towards, him, or it. Ex. qaSadotu qaSodahu I tended, repaired, betook myself, or directed my course, towards him, or it: (S, Msb:) [like Samadotu Samodahu, and Haradotu Harodahu, and XadaA Xadowahu, &c.:] also signifying, [I purposed his purpose, or] I pursued his (another's) way, or course, doing [and thinking] as he did. (L, in art. wkd.) Oaxaca qaSoda AlwaAdiI, and qaSiydahu↓, [He went towards the valley]. (A.) ― -b2- huwa qaSodaka, and qaSoduka, He is before thee, before thy face. It is more commonly used as a subst. (M, L.)

rumoHN qaSidN c
rumoHN qaSidN, and qaSiydN↓, (M, L, K,) and OaqoSaAdN↓, (S, L,) which is one of the words [used as a sing. epithet] having a pl. form, (Akh, S,) A spear broken: (M, L:) [or, broken in halves:] or broken in many pieces. (K.)

qiSodapN c
qiSodapN A fragment; a piece of a thing that is broken: (S, K:) and any piece [of a thing]: (TA:) pl. qiSadN. (S, K.) Ex. AlqanaA qiSadN [The spears are broken into fragments]. (S.) ― -b2- qiSodapN mino EaZomK A piece of a bone; meaning, a third, or a quarter, of the thigh, or arm, or skin, or shoulder; (M, L;) less than the half; as much as the third, or quarter. (IKtt.)

qaSuwdN c
qaSuwdN A camel having compact marrow. (ISh, L.) See also qaSiydN.

qaSiydN c
qaSiydN and maqoSuwdN↓ Aimed at, sought, desired, intended, or purposed. (L.) ＝ -A2- Fat marrow: (K:) or thick and fat marrow, that breaks in pieces (yataqaSRadu) by reason of its fatness: a piece thereof is termed qaSiydapN: (L:) or the former word and qaSuwdN↓ signify marrow inferior to that which is fat (A, O, K) but superior to that which is lean: (A, O:) and qaSiydapN, a piece of marrow that has come forth from the bone. (L.) ― -b2- And (L, K), or cuw qaSiydK, (L,) A bone containing marrow. (L, K.) ― -b3- Dry, or tough, (yaAsis,) fleshmeat; (Lth, S, L, K;) as also qaSodN↓; and, as some say, fat fleshmeat. (L.) ― -b4- A fat she-camel, (L, K,) plump and corpulent, (L,) and having marrow in her bones; as also qaSiydapN. (L, K.) ― -b5- A fat camel's hump. (K.) ＝ -A3- A staff; (L, K;) as also qaSiydap; (K;) or the latter has not been heard: (TA:) pl. qaSaAYidu. (L.) ＝ -A4- Poetry, or a poem, trimmed, pruned, or free from faults, well executed, (K,) and composed with premeditation; (TA;) as also qaSiydapN: (TA:) [but the latter is used as a subst.] ― -b2- qaSiydN, a gen. n., applied properly to poetry, and, by extension of the signification, to a single poem, for qaSiydapN; (IJ, L;). or it is pl. of qaSiydapN, like as safiynN is of safiynapN; (S, L;) and so is qaSaAYidu; (L;) [but properly, qaSiydN is a coll. gen. n., and qaSiydapN is its n. un., and qaSaAYidu is pl. of the latter;] Poetry, or a poem, [or an ode, (for it was always designed to be chanted or sung,)] of which the bipartition (XaTor) of the verses is complete; (M, L, K;) [i. e., of which the hemistichs are complete, not curtailed; (see AlrRamalu;)] consisting of three verses or more; (Akh, M, L, K;) or of sixteen or more; (M, L, K;) for it is usual to call that which consists of three verses, or ten, or fifteen, qiToEapN, and what consists of more than fifteen the Arabs call qSydp: (IJ, M, L:) or, as Akh has once said, what is of the metre called AlTRawiyl, and AlbasiyT that is complete, and AlkaAmil that is complete, and Almadiyd that is complete, by which he means the first species thereof, which is the most complete that is in use, and AlwaAfir that is complete, by which, in like manner, he means the first species thereof, and AlrRajaz that is complete, and Alxafiyf that is complete, and [any ode, or] any poem that is sung by persons riding; but, he adds, we have not heard them sing what is of the metre called Alxfyf: (M, L:) such poetry is thus termed because composed with purpose and consideration, and earnest endeavour to make it excellent; from qaSodN as syn. with OamRN: or because composed with care, and trimmed with excellent expressions and choice meanings, from qaSiydN signifying “ thick and fat marrow; ” for the Arabs tropically apply to chaste, or eloquent, or excellent, language the epithet samiyn, or “ fat: ” (L:) or because of its completeness, and the soundness of its measure. (M, L.) For the meanings of bayotu AlqaSiydapi, see bayotN; last sentence. ＝ -A5- See also qaSidN.

qaSiydapN c
qaSiydapN: see qaSiydN throughout.

Tryq qaASidN c
Tryq qaASidN, (M, L,) and qaASidapN, (A,) and qaSodN↓, (A, Msb,) (tropical:) A direct, or right road, or way; a road, or way, having a direct, or right, tendency: (A, L:) an even, and a direct, or right, road, or way: (M, L:) an even road, or way. (Msb.) ― -b2- sahomN qaASidN (tropical:) An arrow rightly directed towards the animal at which it is shot: pl. sihaAmN qawaASidu. (A.) ― -b3- qaASidN Near. (S, K.) ― -b4- safarN qaASidN An easy, short journey: (TA:) [a moderately easy and short journey:] a journey not difficult, nor extremely far. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) ― -b5- bayonanaA wabayona AlmaMCi layolapN qaASidapN (tropical:) Between us and the water is an easy night's journey (S, K) without fatigue or tardiness: (S:) pl. layaAlK qawaASidu. (TA.) ― -b6- maMCN qaASidN Water of which the herbage, or pasture, is near. (IAar, TA, voce muTolibN.)

OaqSadu c
OaqSadu [A more, or most, direct road]. (S, voce OaroXadu.) ― -b2- Ealayoka bimaA huwa OaqoSadu waOaqosaTu (tropical:) Keep thou to that which is most right and most just. (A.)

OaqoSaAdN c
OaqoSaAdN: see qaSidN.

maqoSadu AlkalaAmi c
[maqoSadu AlkalaAmi means the intended sense of the saying; the meaning thereof: (see maEonFI in art. EnI:) maqoSadN being an inf. n. used as in the sense of the pass. part. n. of its verb, i. e. in the sense of maqoSuwdN↓; like as is generally said of its syn. maEonFI, of which maqoSuwdN is one of the explanations: hence it has a pl. maqaASidu: in the CK in art. gzw it is erroneously written maqoSid, which is the n. of place and of time from qaSada. ― -b2- And in like manner maqoSadN signifies also A thing aimed at, intended, or purposed; an object of aim or pursuit: see 1: and maqoSidN↓, tropically used, has the same meaning.]

maqoSidN c
maqoSidN, with kesr to the S, A place to, or towards, which one tends, repairs, or betakes himself; to which one directs his course; at which one aims; which one seeks, pursues, endeavours to reach, desires, or wishes for; [pl. maqaASidu.] Ex. lahu maqoSidN maEayRanN He has a specified place to which, or towards which, he tends, or repairs, &c. (Msb.) baAbuka maqoSidiI Thy door, or gate, is the place to which, or towards which, I tend, or repair, &c. (A.) ― -b2- maqaASidu AlTRaruqi [The right places to which roads tend]; i. q. maraAXiduhaA. (S, L, K, art. rXd.) See also maqoSadN.

muqoSadN c
muqoSadN One who falls sick and quickly dies. (K.)

muqoSidN c
muqoSidN [One who composes poems of the kind termed qaSaAYid: see 4: also,] and muqaSRidN↓, one who continues uninterruptedly, and prolongs, the composition of poems of the kind termed qSAYd. (M, L.)

maqoSadapN c
maqoSadapN [lit., A thing that causes people to repair to, or seek, or endeavour after, or desire, it]. ― -b2- A woman great, and perfect, or complete, who pleases every one (K) that beholds her. (TA.) ― -b3- Also, (or, as some write it, muqaSRadapN↓, TA,) A woman inclining to shortness. (K.)

maqoSuwdN c
maqoSuwdN: see qaSodN, qaSiydN, and maqoSadN.

muqaSRadN c
muqaSRadN (tropical:) A man neither corpulent nor thin; as also muqotaSidN↓ and qaSodN↓: (L, K:) or a man of moderate, or middle, stature; (ISh, L;) neither tall nor short, nor corpulent; (IAth, L;) as also qaSodN: (ISh:) or a man &c. neither corpulent nor short. (Lth, L.) See maqoSadapN.

muqaSRidN c
muqaSRidN: see muqoSidN.

fulaAnN muqotaSidN fiI AlnRafaqapi c
fulaAnN muqotaSidN fiI AlnRafaqapi (tropical:) Such a one acts in a moderate manner, in a manner between that of prodigality and that of parsimoniousness, in expense. (S, L.) See 1. And see muqaSRadN.

1 qaSura c
1. qaSura, aor.
qaSura
, inf. n. qiSarN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and qaSorN (IAar, M, K) and qaSaArapN, (Lh, M, K,) It (a thing, S, Msb, i. e. anything, M) was, or became, short; contr. of TaAla. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- [And It was, or became, too short. And qaSura Eanohu It was, or became, too short for him, or
it. ― -b3- Hence, qaSurato yaduhu, and qaSura baAEuhu, (tropical:) He had little, or no, power: and he was, or became, niggardly.] ＝ -A2- And qaSara AlsRahomu Eani Alhadafi, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura
, (Msb,) inf. n. quSuwrN, (M, Msb,) The arrow fell short of the butt; did not reach it; (S, Msb;) fell upon the ground without reaching the butt: (M:) and qaSara Eano manozilihi [he fell short of his place of alighting or abode; did not reach it]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qaSara Eani AlOamori, (S, Msb, K,) [and qaSara duwnahu,] aor.
qaSura
, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. quSuwrN; (S, Msb, K;) and AqSr↓, (K,) inf. n.
