UiqaSaArN; (TA;) and qSRr↓, (K,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (TA;) and tqASr↓; (K;) [He fell, or stopped, or came, short of doing the thing, or affair; he failed of doing, or accomplishing, it;] he lacked power, or ability, to do, or accomplish, the thing, or affair; (S, Msb, K;) he could not attain to it: (S:) or the first has this signification; (ISk, S, Msb;) and [in like manner] Eanohu qSRr↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN, (TA,) he left or relinquished it, or abstained from it, being unable to do or accomplish it: (M, K:) but Eanohu AqSr↓, he desisted or abstained from it, being able to do or accomplish it: (ISk, S, M, Msb:) such, at least, is generally the case, though both sometimes occur in one and the same sense, that which AqSr Enh generally bears: (TA:) and fiI AlOamori qSRr↓ [he fell, or stopped, or came, short in the affair: it signifies nearly the same as AqSr Enh, i. e., he fell short of accomplishing the affair; he fell short of doing what was requisite, or due, or what he ought to have done, (EamRaA kaAna yanobagiI, or the like, being understood,) in, or with respect to, the affair: a meaning very common, and implied, though not expressed, in the M: and] he flagged, or was remiss, in the affair; syn. tawaAnaI: (S, TA:) or qSRr↓ signifies he left, desisted from, neglected, or left undone, a thing, or part thereof, from inability: but AqSr↓, he left it, &c., or part thereof, with ability to do it. (Kull p. 128.) [And qSRr↓ duwnahu He fell short of reaching, or attaining, it: see an ex. voce yaEoquwbN.] [Hence also,] qaSarato binaA AlnRafaqapu The money for expenses [fell short of what we required;] did not enable us to attain our object; (Msb;) meaning, that they were unable to pay the expenses: (Mgh:) and bihi qaSRara↓ Oamaluhu [his hope fell short of what he required]: 'Antarah says,
faQloyawoma qaSRara Eano tiloqaAYika AlOamalu
[but to-day, hope hath fallen short of extending to the meeting with thee]. (TA.) [And hence, app.,] bikacaA nafosuka qaSRarato↓ [Thy mind, or wish, fell short of what was requisite with respect to such a thing], said to him who has sought, or desired, little, and a mean share or lot. (TA.) And, bifulaAnK qaSRara↓ [He fell short of what was required by such a one, or due to him; or] he acted meanly, and sparingly, with such a one, in a gift. [&c.] (JK [see muqaSRirN: and see two exs. of qaSRara bihi voce OazoraI in art. zrI.] ― -b3- [Also, qaSara Eani AlOamori, (M, K,) aor.
qaSura
, (M,) inf. n. quSuwrN; and AqSr↓; and qSRr↓ and tqASr↓; (M, K;) He refrained, abstained, or desisted, from the thing, or affair. (M, K.) A poet says,
UicaA gamRa xiroXaMCu AlvRumaAlapi Oanofahu
minohaA lilSRariyHi faOaqonaEaA taqaASara↓
[When the froth of the water remaining in the drinking-trough covers his nose, he refrains from it, turning to the clear, and raises his head]: or mnhA tqASr↓ here signifies he contracts his neck from it: and it is said that Enh qSRr↓ signifies as explained above, he left or relinquished it, &c. (M.) qaSara EanRiI AlwajaEu, and AlgaDabu, (M, K,) aor.
qaSura
, inf. n. quSuwrN, (M,) The pain, and anger, ceased from me; quitted me; (M, K;) as also qaSira; (M, TA;) which latter is erroneously written in the copies of the K, qaSRara: (TA:) and qaSarotu OanaA Eanohu [I ceased from it]. (M.) And QlomaTaru OaqoSara↓ The rain left off. (TA.) ＝ -A3- qado qaSara AlEaXiIRu, aor.
qaSura
, inf. n. quSuwrN, [The afternoon, or evening, has come,] is said when you enter upon the masaMC [i. e. afternoon, or evening]: (S:) or it means has almost drawn near to night. (TA.) [See also qaSorN, below.] ― -b2- Hence, (S,) qaSaronaA and OaqoSaronaA↓ We entered upon the EaXiIR [i. e. afternoon, or evening]; (M, K;) the former signifies OamosayonaA; and the latter, daxalonaA fiI qaSori AlEaXiIRi, like as you say OamosayonaA from AlmasaMCu: (S:) or the former, we came to be in the last part of the day; and the latter, we entered upon the last part of the day. (IKtt.) ＝ -A4- qaSarahu, (Msb, K,) aor.
qaSura
, (Msb,) or
qaSira
, (K,) inf. n. qaSorN; (TA;) and qSRrhu↓, (M, Msb, TA;) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (TA;) and AqSrhu↓; (Msb;) He made it short; (M, K, TA;) he shortened it; took from its length. (Msb.) You say qaSara AlXRaEara, (M, Msb, K,) and qaSara mina AlXRaEari, (S,) aor.
qaSura
, (Msb,) or
qaSira
; (K;) and qSRrh↓, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) and minohu qSRr↓; (S;) and AqSrhu↓; (Msb;) He shortened the hair; (M, K, * TA;) took from its length; (Msb;) cut its ends; (Mgh;) clipped, or shore, it. (TA.) And qaSara AlSRalaApa, (M, Msb, TA,) and qaSara mina AlSRalaApi, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura
, inf. n. qaSorN; (S, M, Msb, TA;) and qSRrhA↓, (M, Msb, TA,) and qSRr mnhA↓, (S, M,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (S;) and AqSrhA↓, (Msb, TA,) and AqSr mnhA↓; (S;) but AqSrhA is extr.; (TA;) He curtailed [or contracted] the prayer; (M;) he performed a prayer of four rek'ahs (rakaEaAt) making it of two; (Mgh;) in a journey. (Mgh, TA.) And AlxuTobapa AqSr↓ He made the [form of words called] xTbp [delivered from the pulpit] short, or concise: (Mgh, TA: *) the doing so being commanded. (Mgh.) qaSorN also signifies the contr. of madRN; (M, K;) and the verb is qaSara [He contracted, or straitened]. (M.) You say qaSarotu qayoda AlbaEiyri; (Msb;) and qaSarotu lahu mino qayodihi; (M;) aor.
qaSura
, inf. n. qaSorN; (M, Msb;) I contracted the shackles of the camel; syn. SayRaqutuhu; (Msb;) and I contracted his shackles; syn. qaArabotu. (M.) [And in like manner, AlEaTiyRapa qaSRara↓, inf. n. taqoSiyrN, He made the gift scanty, or mean: or, accord. to the TK, qSRr fiI AlEaTiyRapi, which properly signifies he fell short of what he ought to have done with respect to the gift: but, though each of these phrases is doubtless correct, the former expression I hold to be that which is indicated when it is said that] AltRaqoSiyru signifies UixosaAsu AlEaTiyRapi. (M, K.) ＝ -A5- qaSarahu, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura
, (S, M,) inf. n. qaSorN, (S, M, Msb, K,) He confined, restricted, limited, kept within certain bounds or limits, restrained, withheld, hindered or prevented, him, or it; syn. Habasahu. (S, M, Msb, K. *) It is said in a trad. of Mo'ádh, lahu maA qaSara fiI bayotihi To him belongeth what he hath held confined in, or kept within, his house or tent: (TA:) or what he hath held in possession &c. (Az, TA in art. xmr: see 10 in that art.) You say also qaSarotu AldRaAra, inf. n. as above, I [confined and so] defended the house by walls. (TA.) And qaSara AljaAriyapa biQloHijaAbi He [confined and so] kept safe the girl by means of the veil, or covering, or the like: and in like manner you say of a horse. (TA.) And in a trad. of 'Omar it is said, qaSara bihimu AllRayolu, (TA,) or qaSRara↓, (L,) The night withheld them; namely a company of riders upon camels on other beasts. (L, TA.) You also say qaSara AlrRajula Eani AlOamori [and qaSara bihi and bh qSRr↓] He withheld the man from the thing, or affair, that he desired to do. (TA.) [See an ex. in a verse cited voce TalRaAE.] And qaSarotu nafasiI Eano XaIoCK I withheld, or restrained, myself from a thing: (JK, TA: *) and I restrained myself from inordinate desire of a thing. (TA.) Lebeed says
falasotu waUino OaqoSarotu Eanohu bimuqoSiri
meaning, But although thou blame in order that I may be restrained, I do not refrain from that which I desire to do. (El-Mázinee, L.) Also, qaSarotu TarofiI [I restrained my eye, or eyes;] I did not raise my eye, or eyes, towards that at which I ought not to look. (TA.) And qaSara AlbaSara He turned away the eye. (TA.) It is also said in a trad. of I'Ab, quSira AlrRijaAlu EalaI OarobaEK mino Oajoli OamowaAli AlyataAmaI Men were restricted to marrying no more than four [because of the property of the orphans which they might leave]. (TA.) And one says qaSarotu nafosiI EalaI AlXRaIoCi I confined, or restricted, myself to the thing, and obliged myself to do it. (TA.) [See also 8.] Hence what is said of Thumámeh, in a trad., fOabaI Oano yusolima qaSorFA But he refused to become a Muslim by constraint and compulsion: or by force, as some say, from Alqasuru; the s being changed into S, as is done in many other cases. (TA.) You say also
qaSarotu AlXRaIoCa EalaI kacaA I restricted the thing to such a thing. (S, TA.) And qaSarahu EalaI AlOamori, meaning, radRahu Uilayohi, (M, K,) i. e., [He reduced him, to the thing, or affair; or] he appropriated him [or it, restrictively,] to the thing, or affair. (TK.) [Hence,] qaSarotu AllRiqoHapa EalaI farasiI I appropriated the milk of the milch-camel [restrictively] to my horse. (S, TA.) [And hence,] qaSarotu EalaI nafosiI naAqapF I retained for myself [restrictively] a she-camel, that I might drink her milk. (Msb.) Aboo-Du-ád says, describing a horse,
faquSirona AlXRitaMCa baEodu Ealayohi
wahuwa lilcRawodi Oano yuqasRamona jaArN
meaning, So they were restricted to him, that he might drink their milk, during the severity of the winter, afterwards; and he is a protector to the few she-camels from their being suddenly attacked and divided in shares; mino being understood before Oano. (M.) ＝ -A6- qaSara AlvRawoba, (S, M, Msb,) aor.
qaSura
, (S,) inf. n. qaSorN (S, Mgh, Msb) and qiSaArapN; (Sb, M, TA;) and qSRrhu↓, (S, M,) inf. n. taqoSiyrN; (S;) He beat, (S, TA,) washed, (Mgh,) and whitened, (M, Msb, TA,) the cloth, or garment. (S, M, &c.)

2 qaSRara
2: see 1, throughout.

4 OaqoSara
4: see 1, throughout. ＝ -A2- OaqoSarato She brought forth short children: hence the saying, UinRa AlTRawiylapa qado tuqoSiru waUinRa AlqaSiyrapa qado tuTiylu [Verily the tall woman sometimes brings forth short children, and verily the short woman sometimes brings forth tall children]. (S, K. *) J is in error in saying that this is in a trad. (Sgh, K.) But IAth also asserts it to be a trad. (MF in art. Twl.)

6 tqASr c
6. tqASr He feigned, or pretended, (OaZohara,) shortness; (M, Sgh, K;) as also taqawoSara↓: (Sgh, K:) or, accord. to some, these two verbs have different significations: see the latter below. (TA.) ― -b2- [And He contracted himself, or drew himself together. (See R. Q. 1 in art. fc.)] ― -b3- tqASrt nafosuhu (assumed tropical:) He (lit. his spirit, or soul,) became abject, mean, contemptible, or despicable; syn. taDaMCalato. (M.) ― -b4- tqASr AlZRilRu (tropical:) The shade became contracted. (M, TA.) ― -b5- See also 1, in two places.

8 AqtSr EalaI AlOamori c
8. AqtSr EalaI AlOamori He confined, restricted, or limited, himself to the thing, or affair; did not exceed it. (M, K. *) ― -b2- AqtSr EalaI AlXRaIoCi, (S,) or ElI kacaA, (Msb,) [and bikacaA,] He was satisfied, or content, (S, Msb,) with the thing, (S,) or with such a thing. (Msb.) ― -b3- AqtSr EalaI OamoriI He obeyed my command. (JK.)

10 AstqSrhu c
10. AstqSrhu He reckoned, or held, him, or it, to be short. (S.) ― -b2- He reckoned him, or held him, to fall short of doing what he ought to do: or to flagg, or be remiss: EadRahu muqaSRirFA. (S.)

Q. Q. 2 taqawoSara c
Q. Q. 2. taqawoSara, said of a man, (M,) He became contracted; lit., one part of him entered into another part; (M, K;) as though he became like a qawoSarRap, from which word the verb is derived. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- See also 6.

qaSorN c
qaSorN and qaSarN↓ and quSorapN↓ [like the inf. n. quSuwrN] The falling, or stopping, or coming, short of accomplishing an affair; or of doing what one ought, or is commanded, to do; or flagging, or remissness: you say to a man whom you have sent to accomplish some needful affair, and who has fallen short of doing what you commanded him to do, on account of heat or some other cause, maA manaEaka Oano taboluga AlmakaAna AlRaciI Oamarotuka bihi UilRaA OanRaka OaHobabota AlqaSora, and AlqaSara, and AlquSorapa, i. e. Oano tuqaSRira [Nothing prevented thy reaching the place to which I commanded thee to go but thy loving to fall short &c.; or to flag, or be remiss]. (M, K *.) And qaSarapN↓, (K,) or qaSarN↓, without p, accord. to the Nawádir of IAar, as cited in the L, and so in the handwriting of Sgh, (TA,) and qaSaArN↓, (K,) signify Laziness; slothfulness. (IAar, Sgh, K.) An Arab of the desert is related to have said Oaradotu Oano Mtiyaka famanaEaniI AlqaSaAru↓ [I desired to come to thee, but laziness prevented me]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qaSoruka Oano tafoEala kacaA and qaSaAruka↓, (S, M, K,) and quSaAruka↓, (M, K,) and quSaAraAka↓, (S, M, K,) and quSayoraAka↓, (M, K,) Thine utmost, or the utmost of thy power or of thine ability or of thy deed, (juhoduka, M, K, [or app., jahoduka, (see art. jhd,)] and gaAyatuka, S, M, K,) and the end of thy case, and that to which thou hast confined or restricted or limited thyself, (S, TA,) [or that to which thou art confined or restricted or limited,] is, or will be, thy doing such a thing. (S, M, K.) It is from qaSorN signifying the “ act of confining, restricting, limiting, ” &c. (TA.) And quSoraI↓ also signifies the end of an affair. (Sgh, TA.) A poet says
UinRamaA OanofusunaA EaAriyRapN
waQloEawaAriIRu qaSaArN Oano turado
[Our souls are only a loan: and the end of loans is their being given back; turado being for turadRa]. (S, TA.) You also say, kulRi balaMCK waXidRapK Almawotu quSaAriI↓ [Death is the end of every trial and distress]. (TA, art. HmO.) ＝ -A3- qaSorN (S, M) and maqoSarN↓ (K) and maqoSarapN↓ and maqoSirN↓ (M, K) The afternoon: or evening: syn. EaXiIRN: (S, M, K:) or the first signifies the last part of the day: (IKtt:) or the time before the sun becomes yellow: (JK:) or the first and second signify the time of the approach of the EaXiIR, a little before the EaSor: (A, TA:) and the first (S, K) and second (A'Obeyd, TA) and third, (A'Obeyd, S, TA,) [the time of] the mixing of the darkness: (A'Obeyd, S, K, TA:) pl. of the second (TA) and third (S, M) and fourth, (M,) maqaASiru (S, M) and maqaASiyru, which latter is extr.; (M;) in the first sense, as signifying EaXaAyaA; (M;) or in the last sense; (S;) not signifying, as it is said to do in the K, AlEiXaMCu AlMxirapu; for this is a great mistake, app. occasioned by F's seeing the passage [in the T] of Az, [or in the M, in which I find it,] waAlmaqaASiru waAlmaqaASiyru AlEaXaAyaA AlOaxiyrapu naAdirapN, and not properly considering it. (TA.) Sb says, that qaSorN has no dim.; the Arabs being content to use in its stead the dim. of masaMCN. (M.) You say Oatayotuhu qaSorFA I came to him in the afternoon, or evening; syn. EaXiyRFA. (S.) And jiYotu qaSorFA, and maqoSarFA↓, I came at the approach of the EaXiIR, a little before the EaSor. (A, TA.) And AlEiXaMCi Oaqobalato maqaASiyru↓ [The times of the mixing of the darkness of nightfall came, or advanced]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A4- qaSorN [A palace: a pavilion, or kind of building wholly or for the most part isolated, sometimes on the top of a larger building, i. e., a belvedere, and sometimes projecting from a larger building, and generally consisting of one room if forming a part of a larger building or connected with another building; the same as the Turkish kwXk: to such buildings we find the appellation to have been applied from very early times to the present day:] a well-known kind of edifice: (M:) a mansion, or house; syn. manozilN: (Lh, M, K:) or any house or chamber (bayot) of stone; (M, K;) of the dial. of Kureysh: (M:) so called because a man's wives and the like are confined in it: (M:) pl. quSuwrN. (S, M, Msb.) qaSoru Qlomaliki [The palace, or pavilion, of the king]. (Msb.) ＝ -A5- Also qaSorN Large and dry, or large and thick, or dry, fire-wood; HaTabN jazolN. (M, K.) So in the Kur, lxxvii. 32, accord. to El-Hasan, as related by Lh. (M.)

qaSarN c
qaSarN: see qaSorN, in two places. ＝ -A2- The necks of men, and of camels: (M, K:) a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.], of which the sing. [or n. un.] is qaSarapN: (M:) [see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. sndr:] or [so accord. to the M, but in the K and] qaSarapN↓ signifies the base of the neck; (S, M, K;) the base of the neck at the place where it is set upon the upper part of the back: (Nuseyr, TA:) or the base of the neck when thick; not otherwise: (Lh, M:) pl. [or coll. gen. n.] qaSarN, and pl. pl. [or pl. of qaSarN] OaqoSaArN: (M:) or this latter is pl. of qaSarapN, (M, K,) accord. to Kr, but this is extr., unless the augmentative letter in the sing. be disregarded in its formation. (M.) I'Ab reads kaQloqaSari, in the Kur, lxxvii. 32, (S, M, * TA,) and explains it as meaning Like the thick bases of necks, (M, * TA,) or as meaning kaqaSari AlnRaxoli, i. e. AlOaEonaAq. (S.) [See the next signification.] You say calRato qaSaratuhu [His neck or] the base of his neck became in a state of subjection. (TA.) And UinRahu lanaAmRu AlqaSarapi Verily he has a large, or thick, neck. (Aboo-Mo'ádh the Grammarian.) ― -b2- And hence, (Aboo-Mo'ádh,) (tropical:) The trunks, or lower-parts, (OuSuwl, M, K, or OaEonaAq,
I'Ab, S,) of palm-trees: (S, M, K:) so explained in the Kur, ubi supra, (S, M,) by I'Ab: (S:) sing. [or n. un.] qaSarapN↓: the palm-tree is cut into pieces of the length of a cubit, to make fires therewith in the winter: (Aboo-Mo'ádh:) and [in the TA or] so of other trees: (M, K:) or of large trees: (Ed-Dahhák:) or [accord. to the M, but in the K and] the remains of trees. (M, K.)

qaSorapN c
qaSorapN: see quSorapN.

quSorapN c
quSorapN: see qaSorN. ＝ -A2- huwa Qbonu EamRihi quSorapF, (S, M, K,) and qaSorapF↓, (K,) and maqoSuwrapF↓, (S, M, K,) and qaSiyrapF↓, (K,) [He is his cousin on the father's side,] nearly related; (S, M, K;) i. q. dinoyFA (S, TA) and dunoyFA: (TA:) and in like manner you say of the Abn AlEamRap and Abn AlxaAlap and Abn AlxaAl. (Lh, M.)

quSoraI c
quSoraI: see qaSorN. ＝ -A2- AlquSoraI (Az, S) and AlquSayoraI↓ (A'Obeyd, Az, S) The rib that is next to the XaAkilap [or flank], (A'Obeyd, Az, S,) also called AlwaAhinapu, (S,) and DilaEu Alxilofi, (A'Obeyd,) at the bottom of the ribs, (S,) between the side and the belly: (Az:) or the former is the lowest of the ribs, and the latter is the highest of the ribs: (AHeyth:) or the latter is the lowest of the ribs: or the last rib in the side: or the quSorayaAni and quSayorayaAni↓ are the two ribs that are next to the TafoTafap [or flank]: or that are next to the two collar-bones. (M, K.)

qaSarapN c
qaSarapN: see qaSorN: ＝ -A2- and qaSarN, in two places: ＝ -A3- and miqoSarapN.

qaSaArN c
qaSaArN: and qaSaAruka and quSaAruka: see qaSorN.

qiSaArN c
qiSaArN, a subst., The shortening [or clipping] of the hair. (Th, M, K. *) Fr says, An Arab of the desert said to me in Minè, AlqiSaAru OaHabRu Uilayoka Oami AlHaloqu, meaning, Is the shortening [or clipping] more pleasing to thee, or the shaving of the head? (M.)

qaSiyrN c
qaSiyrN Short; and low, i. e. having little height; contr. of TawiylN; (S, M, Msb, K;) and so qaASirN↓, app. a kind of rel. or possessive n., not a verbal epithet: (M:) fem. of the former [and of the latter] with p: (M, K:) pl. of the former, masc., (S, M, Msb, K,) and fem., (M, K,) qiSaArN, (S, M, &c.,) and pl. masc. [applied to rational beings,] quSaraMCu, (M, K,) and pl. fem. qiSaArapN; (K;) p being added by the Arabs to any pl. of the measure fiEaAlN, as in jimaAlapN and HibaAlapN and cikaArapN and HijaArapN; (Fr;) or qiSaArapN is syn. with qaSiyrapN, and is extr. (Sgh, K.) ― -b2- qaSiyrapN mino TawiylapK [lit. A short thing from a tall thing; meaning,] a date from a palm-tree: a proverb; alluding to the abridgment of speech or language. (K.) ― -b3- huwa qaSiyru Alyadi, [and AlbaAEK, (tropical:) He has little, or no, power: or is niggardly:] and lahumo OayodK qiSaArN [they have little, or no, power: or are niggardly]. (TA.) ― -b4- qaSiyru AlhimRapi [Having little ambition]. (O in art. bjl.) ― -b5- UinRahu laqaSiyru AlEilomi (tropical:) [Verily he has little knowledge]. (M.) ― -b6- qaSiyru AlnRasabi [Having a short pedigree;] whose father is well known, so that when the son mentions him it is sufficient for him, without his extending his lineage to his grandfather. (K.) [See also a verse below, in this paragraph.] ― -b7- HadiyvN qaSiyrN, and muqotaSarN↓, A [concise, or] comprehensive, and profitable, story, or narration. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [I. q. maqoSuwrN↓ and maqoSuwrapN↓, Shortened; contracted: and confined; restricted; limited; &c.] ― -b2- UimoraOapN qaSiyru AlxuTaI, and AlxaTowi maqoSuwrapu↓, [A woman whose steps are shortened, or contracted;] likened to one who is shackled, whose steps are shortened, or contracted, by the shackles. (Fr.) ― -b3- farasN qaSiyrN A mare that is brought near [to the tent or dwelling], and treated generously, and not left to seek for pasture, because she is precious: (S, K:) and a mare that is kept confined. (TA.) ― -b4- qaSiyrapN, [which is extr., for by rule it should be without p,] and qaSuwrapN↓, (Az, S, M, K,) and maqoSuwrapN↓, (K,) A woman confined in the house, or tent, not suffered to go forth: (S, M, K:) a woman kept behind, or within, the curtain: (TA, in explanation of the last of these three epithets:) a girl kept with care, that does not go out: (Az:) the pl. of qSwrp is qaSaAYiru:] [and so, app., of qSyrp:] when you mean short in stature, you say qaSiyrapN [only], and the pl. is qiSaArN. (TA.) Kutheiyir says
waOanoti AlRatiI HabRaboti kulRa qaSiyrapK
UilaIRa wamaA tadoriI bicaAka AlqaSaAYiru
Eanayotu qaSiyraAti AlHijaAli walamo Ourido
qiSaAra AlxuTaI XarRu AlnRisaMCi AlbaHaAtiru
(S, M) or, as Fr relates it, kulRa qaSuwrapF (S) [And thou art the person who hath made every female confined within the house to be an object of love to me, while the females confined within the house know not that: I mean those confined within the curtained canopies: I do not mean the short in step: the worst of women are the short and compressed]. And a poet says
waOahowaI mina AlnRiswaAni kulRa qaSiyrapK
lahaA nasabN fiI AlSRaAliHiyna qaSiyru
[And I love, of women, every one that is confined within the house, that has a short pedigree, among the good]; i. e., every maqoSuwrap↓, of whom it suffices to mention her descent from her father, because of his being well known. (M.) Hence, in the Kur, [lv. 72,] HuwrN maqoSuwraAtN fiI AlxiyaAmi [Damsels having eyes whereof the white is intensely white and the black intensely black,] confined in the pavilions, (Az, Msb,) which are of pearls, for their husbands; (Az;) concealed by curtains: (Az, Bd:) or confined to their husbands, and not raising their eyes to others: (Fr:) or having their eyes restricted to their husbands. (Bd.) And naAqapN maqoSuwrapN↓, (TA,) or maqoSuwrapN EalaI AlEiyaAli, (Msb,) A she-camel retained [restrictively] for the household, that they [alone] may drink her milk. (Msb, TA. *) ― -b5- See also quSorapN.

quSaArapN c
quSaArapN: see maqoSuwrapN.

qiSaArapN c
qiSaArapN The art of [beating and] washing (Mgh) and whitening (M, Msb) clothes. (M, Mgh, Msb.)

qaSuwrapN c
qaSuwrapN: see maqoSuwrapN: and qaSiyrN.

quSaAraI c
quSaAraI. ― -b2- quSaAraAka: see qaSorN.

quSayoraI c
quSayoraI. ― -b2- quSayoraAka: see qaSorN. ＝ -A2- See also quSoraI.

qaSRaArN c
qaSRaArN One who beats (S) and washes (Mgh) and whitens (M, Msb, K) clothes; (S, M, &c.;) as also muqaSRirN↓. (M, K.)

qaASirN c
qaASirN: see qaSiyrN, first signification. ＝ -A2- UimorOapN qaASirapu AlTRarofi A woman restraining her eyes from looking at any but her husband. (S, K.) ― -b2- ZilRN qaASirN (tropical:) Contracting shade. (TA.)

qawoSarRapN c
qawoSarRapN, and (sometimes, S,) qawoSarapN, without teshdeed, A receptacle for dates, or for dried dates, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) in which they are stored, made of mats, (S,) of reeds: (M, Mgh, Msb, K:) in common conventional language only so called as long as it contains dates: otherwise it is called zabiylN: (Mgh:) thought by IDrd to be not Arabic; (M;) and he doubts respecting the authenticity of a verse in which it is mentioned, ascribed to 'Alee: (TA:) pl. qawaASiru: (K, art. knz; &c.:) the dim. is quwayoSirRapN and quwayoSirapN. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A woman, or wife; (IAar, K;) as also qaAruwrapN [q. v.]. (IAar, TA.)

OaqoSuru c
OaqoSuru More, and most, short: fem. quSoraI: (Mgh:) the pl. of OaqoSaru is OaqaASiru. (S, K.)

tiqoSaArN c
tiqoSaArN (S, M, K) and tiqoSaArapN (S, K) A necklace, or collar, or the like, syn. qilaAdapN, (S, M, K,) resembling a mixonaqap: (S:) so called because it cleaves to the qaSarap [or base] of the neck: (M:) or a mixonaqap proportioned to the qaSarap [or base of the neck]: (A, TA:) pl. taqaASiyru. (S, K.)

raDiIa bimaqoSarK mina AlOamori c
raDiIa bimaqoSarK mina AlOamori, and minohu bimaqoSirK↓, He was content with less than he was seeking, of the thing. (TA.) And mimRaA kaAna yuHaAwilu raDiIa bimuqoSirK↓ with kesr to the S, (S,) or bimaqoSarK minohu, (as in a copy of the M,) He was content with less than he was seeking. (S, M.) And raDiytu mino fulaAnK bimaqoSarK, and bimaqoSirK↓, I was content with an inferior thing from such a one. (M.) ＝ -A2- See also qaSorN.

maqoSirN c
maqoSirN: see maqoSarN: ＝ -A2- and qaSorN.

jaMCa fulaAnN muqoSirFA c
jaMCa fulaAnN muqoSirFA Such a one came when the
afternoon, or evening, was almost drawing near to night. (TA.)

maqoSarapN c
maqoSarapN: see qaSorN.

miqoSarapN c
miqoSarapN (M, K) and qaSarapN↓ (M, TA) The wooden implement of the qaSRaAr, (M, K,) with which he beats clothes: (M:) and the ↓latter, a piece of wood, (M, K,) of any kind; or of the jujube-tree, specially. (TA.)

muqaSRirN c
muqaSRirN act. part. n. of 2, q. v. and see qaSRaArN. ― -b2- [Deficient in liberality or bounty:] one who makes a gift scanty, or mean. (TA.) A poet says
faqulotu lahu qado kunota fiyhaA muqaSRirFA
[And I said to him Thou hast been deficient in liberality with respect to them; app. meaning she-camels or the like;] i. e., thou hast not given of them nor given to drink from them [of their milk]. (M.)

maqoSuwrN c
maqoSuwrN and maqoSuwrapN: see qaSiyrN, in five places. ― -b2- See also quSorapN. ― -b3- maqoSuwrapN An ample or a spacious [house or mansion such as is called a] dAr, which is defended by walls: (M, * K, * TA:) or it is less than a dAr; (M, K;) as also quSaArapN↓; and is not entered by any but the owner: (K:) such a part of a house is called the mqSwrp of a dAr, and the qSArp thereof: (Useyd, TA:) any apartment (naAHiyapN), by itself, of a dAr, when the latter is ample, or spacious, and defended by walls: (Lth, TA:) a [chamber such as is called a] Hujorap, of a house: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. maqaASiyru and maqaASiru. See an ex. voce muSomatN. (Lth, TA.) And AlmaqoSuwrapN, (Lth,) and maqoSuwrapu masojidK, (Mgh, Msb,) and maqoSuwrapu jAmiEK, (S,) The part which is the station of the Imám [or Khaleefeh] in a mosque: (Lth, Mgh:) so called because confined [by a railing or screen]: (S:) or, accord. to some, mqSwrp, thus applied, is changed from its original form, which is qaASirapN, an act. part. n.: (Msb:) [and, as used in the present day, that part of a mosque which is the principal place of prayer, when it is partitioned off from the rest of the building: and the railing, or screen, which surrounds the oblong monument of stone or brick or wood over a grave in a mosque; sometimes enclosing a kind of baldachin over the monument. maqoSuwrapN also signifies The chancel of a church: see macobaHN.] And maqoSuwrapN and qaSuwrapN↓ A Hajalap [or kind of curtained canopy or baldachin, such as is prepared for a bride]. (Lh, M, K.) And the former word, A piece of ground which none but the owner thereof is allowed to tread. (TA.)

maqoSuwrapN c
maqoSuwrapN: see maqoSuwrN.

HadiyvN muqotaSarN c
HadiyvN muqotaSarN: see qaSiyrN.

quSoTaAsN c
quSoTaAsN and qiSoTaAsN dial. forms of qusoTaAsN and qsoTaAsN. [q. v.] (K.)

dictScrap.label: qSE qSf qSl qSm qSw : See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qaeDRa c
1. qaeDRa, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor. yaquDRu, (S, M, Msb,) inf. n. qaDRN, (M, Msb,) He bored, or perforated, a pearl, (S, M, A, K,) or a piece of wood. (Msb.) qaDRa durRapF is also used as signifying qaDRa EanohaA SadafahaA faQsotaxorajahaA [app. meaning He broke through the shell of the pearl so as to disclose it, and extracted it.] (TA.) ― -b2- Also, (M, A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (M,) He broke a thing: (M:) or he broke a stone with the miqaDR, q. v.: (A:) or he broke, brayed, crushed, or broke in pieces by beating, a thing; syn. daqR; (K;) as also qaDoqaDa↓: (TA:) which latter also signifies he broke a thing in pieces [in any manner]. (M, TA.) You say also, qaDRa AlHaAYiTa, (A,) or AljidaAra, (TA,) meaning He threw down, pulled down, pulled to pieces, demolished, or destroyed, with violence, the wall. (A, TA.) And AlOasadu yuqaDoqiDu↓ fariysatahu (S, A) The lion breaks the limbs and bones of his prey. (A.) And janobahu mino Sulobihi qaDoqaDotu↓ I severed his side from his back-bone. (Sh.) ― -b3- [Hence,] qaDRa Ealayohimu Alxayola, (S, M, A [in the first and last qaDaDonaA]) aor. as above, (M, A,) and so the inf. n., (M,) (tropical:) He sent, or sent forth, (M, TA,) or impelled, (TA,) [or dispersed, (see 7,)] the horses, or horsemen, against them, or upon them. (M, TA.) ― -b4- qaDRa Alwatida, (JK, O, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) He pulled out (qalaEa, in some copies of the K qaTaEa,) the wooden pin or peg or stake. (JK, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- qaDRa AlsRawiyqa, (Zj, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (Zj,) (tropical:) He put into the swyq [i. e. meal of parched barley, or gruel made thereof,] something dry, or hard, such as sugar, or qanod [i. e. sugar-candy]; (Zj, K;) as also OaqaDRahu↓: (A, Sgh, K:) and qaDoqaDa↓ signifies (tropical:) he put much sugar into his swyq. (IAar.) ＝ -A3- qaDiDotu AlTRaEaAma, (TA,) and qaDiDotu minohu, (S, M, K,) [aor. OaqaDRu,] inf. n. qaDaDN, (M, TA,) I found pebbles, (S, M, K,) or dust, (M, K,) between my teeth in eating the food. (S, M, K.) ― -b2- qaDR AlTRaEaAmu, aor. yaqaDRu, (S, A, K,) inf. n. qaDaDN, (A, TA,) The food had in it pebbles, (S, * A, * K, * TA,) or dust, (K, * TA,) which got between the teeth of the eater: (S, * K, * TA:) from qaDaDN [q. v.]: (S:) the verb is like Ealima, in this sense as well as in that next preceding; intrans. as well as trans.: (TA:) and OaqaDRa↓ signifies [in like manner] it (food) had in it pebbles and dust. (TA.) And qaDRa AllRaHomu, (IAar, M,) second pers. qaDiDota, [aor. yaqaDRu,] inf. n. qaDaDN, (M,) The flesh-meat had in it qaDaD [q. v.], which got between the teeth of its eater, like small pebbles: (IAar:) or fell upon pebbles, or dust, which one consequently found in the eating of it. (M.) And qaDRati AlbaDoEapu biAltRuraAbi The piece of flesh-meat had some dust upon it; as also OaqaDRat↓. (M, K.) An Arab of the desert, describing the effect of rains, said, lawo Oaloqayota baDoEapF maA qaDRato, i. e. [If thou wert to throw down a piece of flesh-meat,] it would not become dusty; meaning, by reason of the abundance of the herbage. (M.) You say also, qaDRa AlmakaAnu, aor. yaqaDRu, inf. n. qaDaDN, The place had in it, or upon it, qaDaD [or small pebbles, or dust]; as also OaqaDRa↓; (M, K;) and AstqDR↓. (K.) And qaDRa AlfiraAXu, aor. and inf. n. as in the next preceding instance, The bed became overspread with dust. (M.) And Ealayohi AlmaDojaEu OaqaDRa↓ (S, M, A, K *) The bed, or place where he lay upon his side, was, or became, rough to him, and dusty: (S, K: *) or had qaDaD, or small pebbles, upon it: (TA:) or was, or became, uneasy to him; as also qaDRa Elyh: (M, TA:) or both signify he did not sleep: or his sleep was uneasy. (TA.) And [hence] Ealayohi AlhamRu OaqaDRa↓ (assumed tropical:) [Grief, or anxiety, disquieted him]. (A, TA.)

4 OaqoDaDa
4: see 1, in six places; from qaDRa AlsRawiyqa to the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- AqDR QllRehu Ealayohi AlmaDojaEa God rendered the bed, or the place where he lay upon his side, rough to him, and dusty: thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (S, K. *) And AqDR AlXRaIoCa He left the thing [consisting of, or overspread with,] small pebbles. (K, * TA.)

5 taqaDRaDa c and taqaDRaI
5. taqaDRaDa taqaDRaI: see 7.

8 AqtDRhA c
8. AqtDRhA (tropical:) He devirginated her; (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K;) namely a girl, (S, A, Mgh,) or a woman; (M;) or either, i. e. before and after puberty; whereas AbtkrhA and AbtsrhA and AxtDrhA are only used as meaning before puberty: (Msb:) and AftDRhA, with f, signifies the same as AqtDRhA. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AqtDR AlUidaAwapa (assumed tropical:) He opened the head [or mouth] of the AdAwp [or water-skin]. (TA.)

10 UisotaqoDaDa
10: see 1, near the end. ＝ -A2- AstqDR maDojaEahu He found his bed, or the place where he lay upon his side, to be rough. (S, K.) ― -b2- [And hence,] AstqDR AlhamRa (assumed tropical:) [He found grief, or anxiety, to be disquieting to him]. (A, TA.)

R. Q. 1 qaDoqaDa c
R. Q. 1. qaDoqaDa: see 1, first half, in four places: and see qaDoqaDapN, below.

R. Q. 2 taqaDoqaDa c
R. Q. 2. taqaDoqaDa It broke, or became broken, into pieces: (M:) it separated, or dispersed; or became separated, or dispersed; (K, TA;) said of a company of men, in a trad. (TA.)

qaDRN c
qaDRN A place in which are qaDaD, (M, K,) meaning small pebbles, or dust; (M;) as also qaDiDN↓. (M, K.) And OaroDN qaDRapN, (M,) or qaDRapN↓ [alone, as though a subst.], (K,) and qiDRapN↓, (S, K,) Land in which are pebbles: (S, M, K:) and land abounding with stones: (M:) or low, or depressed, land, the ground of which is sand, and by the side of which is plain, or hard, and elevated land: (Lth in explanation of the last of these words, and K:) pl. of the last, qiDaDN. (Lth.) Also, Food in which are pebbles and dust: (TA:) and flesh-meat that has fallen upon pebbles, or dust, (M,) or upon stones, or pebbles, (TA,) which one consequently finds in eating it: (M, TA:) and anything having dust in it, or upon it; as food, or a garment, &c.: (M, TA:) and [in like manner] qaDiDN↓, (S,) or qaDaDN↓, (K,) but when applied to a place, the author of the K writes it qaDiDN, (TA,) food containing pebbles, (S, K,) or dust, (K,) getting between the teeth of the eater. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- See also qaDaDN, in two places.

qaDRapN c
qaDRapN: see qiDRapN, in four places. ＝ -A2- Also, of a star, or an asterism, (tropical:) i. q. nawoCN [here signifying The dawn-setting thereof; for it is] from UinoqaDRa said of a star, or asterism. (TA.) So in the saying (TA) OatayonaA Einoda qaDRapi AlnRajomi (tropical:) [We came at the dawnsetting of the asterism, meaning the Pleiades]. (A, * TA.) And muTironaA biqaDRapi AlOasadi (tropical:) [We were rained upon, or we had rain at, lit. by means of, the dawn-setting of the Lion]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also qaDaDN, in three places. ＝ -A4- And see qaDRN.

qiDRapN c
qiDRapN, (M, K,) or qaDRapN↓, (A,) (tropical:) [Devirgination]; a subst. from UiqotaDR in the former of the two senses assigned to it above. (M, K.) You say, layolapa EurosihaA kaAna celika Einoda qaDRatihaA↓ (tropical:) [That was on the occasion of her devirgination, on the night of her being conducted to her husband]. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also the former, (S, M, Msb,) or ↓latter, (A, Mgh,) or both, (K,) (tropical:) The virginity, or maidenhead, (S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) of a girl, (S, Mgh, K,) or of a woman, (M,) or of both. (Msb.) You say, Oaxaca qiDRatahaA, (Lh, M,) and cahaba biqaDRatihaA↓, (A, Mgh,) (tropical:) He took her virginity. (Lh, M, Mgh.) ＝ -A3- See also qaDaDN. ＝ -A4- And see qaDRu.

qaDaDN c
qaDaDN A thing broken, brayed, crushed, or broken in pieces by beating: (TA:) pebbles broken in pieces and crushed: (TA:) or, as also qaDRapN↓, pebbles broken into small pieces: (K:) or small pebbles broken in pieces: (A:) or, accord. to some, the former is pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] of the latter: (TA:) or both signify pebbles, and dust: (TA:) or the former signifies small pebbles; (S, M;) as also qiDRapN↓, (S, K,) and qaDRapN↓, (K,) and qaDiyDN↓, accord. to IAar, as is said by IAth and Sgh and the author of the L, not qaDRN↓, as is said in the K, for this signifies large pebbles, accord. to IAar, as is said by the three authors mentioned above as citing him, and the author of the K has erred in assigning this last meaning to qaDiyDN↓: (TA:) or qaDRN↓ signifies pebbles; and qaDiyDN↓ is a pl. [or rather a quasi-pl. n.] thereof: (AHeyth, L:) and qaDaDN also signifies dust that overspreads a bed. (M, K.) You say, UitRaqi AlqaDaDa fiI TaEaAmika, and AlqaDRapa↓, Beware thou of the pebbles and dust in thy food. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qaDRN.

qaDiDN c
qaDiDN: see qaDRN, in two places.

qaDiyDN c
qaDiyDN: see qaDaDN, in three places. ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) Small pieces of food; as being likened to small pebbles. (Kt.)

qaDoqaDapN c
qaDoqaDapN The sound of the breaking of bones. (S.) ― -b2- [See also R. Q. 1., of which it is the inf. n.]

miqaDRN c
miqaDRN An instrument with which stones are broken, (JK, A, TA,) resembling a qaduwm, q. v. (JK.)

1 qaDiYa AlsRiqaMCu c
1. qaDiYa AlsRiqaMCu, (K,) or qaDiYati Alqirobapu, aor.
qaDaAa
, inf. n. qaDaON, (AZ, S, O, K,) The water-skin became rotten, and fell in pieces, (AZ, S, O, K, TA,) as is the case when it has been folded while damp. (TA.) You say siqaMCN qaDiYN↓ (TA) and qirobapN qaDiYapN↓. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- And qaDiYa said of a garment, (S, O, TA,) or of a rope, (K, TA,) It became old and worn out, and dissundered, (K, TA,) and rotten, (S, * O, * TA,) when said of a garment, (S, O,) from being long moist and folded: (S, O, TA:) or, said of a rope, it broke in pieces in consequence of its having been long buried in the earth. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And qaDiYati AlEayonu, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) The eye became red, and flaccid in its inner angle, and in an unsound, or a corrupt, state, (K, TA,) ulcerated, or sore. (TA.) You say EayonN qaDiYapN↓. (TA.) And fiI Eayonihi quDoOapN↓ (S, O, TA) meaning In his eye is unsoundness, or corruptness [&c.]. (S, O.) ― -b4- And qaDiYa Hasabuhu, inf. n. qaDaON (K, TA) and qaDaOapN or qaDaMCapN, (accord. to different copies of the K,) in the L the latter of these, and quDuwoCN also, (TA,) His Hasab [or grounds of pretension to respect or honour] were unsound, (K, TA,) and faulty. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qaDiYa, (El-Umawee, S, O, K,) aor.
qaDaAa
, inf. n. qaDoCN, (El-Umawee, S, O, [and the same is indicated in the K,]) He ate (El-Umawee, S, O, K) a thing; said of a man. (El-Umawee, S, O.)

4 AqDOhu c
4. AqDOhu He gave him to eat; (S, O, K;) namely, a man: (S, O:) some say that it is with f: (TA in this art.:) but Sh says that it is with q, after mentioning AfDMh as transmitted from A 'Obeyd from As (TA in art. fDA.)

5 taqaDRaWuwA minohu Oano yuzawRijuwhu c
5. taqaDRaWuwA minohu Oano yuzawRijuwhu They accounted his grounds of pretension to respect or honour [too] low [for them to marry him], or [too] mean, (Ibn-Buzurj, K, TA,) and [too] faulty. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA.) ― -b2- See also tafasRaOa.

qaDiYN c
qaDiYN part. n. of qaDiYa; and its fem, with p: see 1, in three places.

qaDoOapN c
qaDoOapN: see the following paragraph.

fiI Eayonihi quDoOapN c
fiI Eayonihi quDoOapN: see 1. ― -b2- One says also, maA Ealayoka fiI hecaA AlOamori quDoOapN i. e. [There is not] any disgrace [to be imputed to thee in, or in respect of, this affair]. (S, O.) And fiI Hasabihi quDoOapN (S, O, K) and qaDoOapN↓ (K) [In his grounds of pretension to respect or honour is] faultiness, (S, O, K,) and unsoundness. (K.) And nakaHa fiI quDoOapK (S, O, TA) He married in a disparaging manner. (TA.)

1 qaDabahu c
1. qaDabahu, (S, M, A, &c.,) aor.
qaDiba
, (M, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. qaDobN, (M, Mgh, O, Msb,) He cut it, or cut it off; (S, M, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also AqtDbhu↓; (M, Msb, K;) and qDRbhu↓; (M, K;) [or this last is used in an intensive sense, or in relation to a number of objects:] you say, qaDaba AlguSona [He cut off the branch]; and guSonFA mino XajarapK AqtDb↓ [He cut off a branch from a tree]; and fuDuwla OagoSaAni AlXRajari qDRb↓ [He cut off the redundant portions of the branches of the trees], inf. n. taqoDiybN. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also 8, in
two places. ＝ -A3- And qDabahu, (S, O, K, JM,) aor. in this case
qaDuba
, (JM,) inf. n. qaDobN, (S, TA,) He struck him, or beat him, (i. e. a man, K,) with a qDyb, (S, O, K, JM,) i. e. a rod, or stick, or the like. (TA.)

2 qaDRaba
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places. ― -b2- [Hence,] qDRb Alkaroma, (S, M,) inf. n. taqoDiybN, (S,) He cut (S, M) the branches, (S,) or some of the branches, (M,) of the grape-vine, [i. e. he pruned it,] in the days of the rabiyE [or spring]. (S, M.) ＝ -A2- And qDRbt AlXRamosu, (M, O, K,) inf. n. as above; (O, K;) The sun extended its rays, or beams, (M, O, K,) like quDobaAn [or rods]; (M;) as also tqDRbt↓: (M, O, K:) used by a rájiz in describing the sun when it had risen appearing like a shield, without rays, or beams. (IAar, M.)

4 AqDbt AlOaroDu c
4. AqDbt AlOaroDu (M, K, * TA) The land produced, (M, TA,) or produced abundantly, (K, [but SM states that he had not found it thus expl. in any lexicon except the K,]) the plant called qaDob which is eaten when freshly cut. (M, K, TA.)

5 taqaDRaba
5: see 7: ― -b2- and see also 2.

7 AnqDb c
7. AnqDb It was, or became, cut, or cut off; (S, M, O, Msb, K;) and so tqDRb↓ [but app. in an intensive sense or said of a number of things]. (M, K.) ― -b2- And [hence] (tropical:) He became cut off, or separated, from his companions. (A.) ― -b3- And, said of a star, (tropical:) It darted down (TA) from its place. (S, A, O.) Dhu-r-Rummeh says, (S, A, O,) describing a wild bull [i. e. a bovine antelope], (O,)
kaOanRahu kawokabN fiI Uivori EiforiyapK
musawRamN fiI sawaAdi AllRayoli munoqaDibu↓
[As though he were a star launched forth in the darkness of night, darting down after an evil demon]. (S, A, O.)

8 UiqotaDaba
8: see 1, in two places. You say, AiqotaDabotuhu, meaning I cut it off from the thing. (S, O.) ― -b2- And [hence] one says, kaAna yuHadRivunaA fulaAnN fajaMCa zayodN faQqotaDaba Hadiyvahu, meaning AiqotaTaEahu and AinotazaEahu [i. e. Such a one was talking to us, and Zeyd came, and broke off his talk, and turned it to what was wholly different in subject, or to what had but little connection with the subject of the former discourse: an ex. of a common conventional usage of AqtDb, mentioned in rhetorical treatises &c.; as when a poet breaks off his nasiyb to enter upon the main subject of his ode]. (A.) ― -b3- And AqtDb (tropical:) He extemporized, or uttered without having prepared it, (S, M, A, O,) speech, (S, A, O,) or a narrative, and poetry, or verses. (M.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) He rode (S, A, K) a beast, (S,) or a she-camel, (A,) before it, or she, was trained, or broken-in; (S, A, K;) and (S, K) so qaDaba↓, (S, O, K,) aor. qaDaba. (K.) And (TA) (assumed tropical:) He took from the camels, and trained, one in an untrained state; (M, K;) as also AqtDbhu↓. (TA.) And (assumed tropical:) He rode a young camel for a night, before it was trained. (TA.) ― -b5- And qaDobN (assumed tropical:) He tasked him to do a deed, or work, before he was able to do it well. (M.) ― -b6- And (tropical:) He slaughtered him, namely, a camel, in a state of freedom from disease and in a fat and youthful condition. (A.)

qaDobapN c
qaDobapN Such as are cut, and eaten in their fresh state, of plants, (M, Msb, K,) of any kind; as is said in the Bári'; (Msb;) a pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of which the sing. [or n. un.] is qaDobapN↓: (K:) or it signifies, (S, O, Msb,) or signifies also, (K,) [a species of trefoil, or clover; i. e.] i. q. raTobapN, (S, O, Msb,) which is the same as fiSofiSap, (Msb,) or qatRN, [which is also the same,] (K,) the name by which the people of Mekkeh call qatR, (Fr, TA,) and (K) called in Pers. (S, O) Uisofisot, (S, Mgh, K,) or Uisobisot; (O;) as also qaDobapN↓; (S;) or this is the sing. [or rather n. un.] of qaDobN, which signifies faSaAfiSu [pl. of fiSofiSapN]; (M;) called qaDobN because it is cut. (Mgh.) ― -b2- And Any tree of which the branches grow long and lank: (K, * TA:) basaTato in the K is a mistranscription for sabiTato. (TA.) ― -b3- And Certain trees from which bows are made; (En-Nadr, O, K;) said to be of the kind called naboEN. (O.) AHn says that qDb [accord. to the L and TA app. qaDobN, but accord. to a copy of the M qaDabN↓, which I think a mistranscription,] is the name of Certain trees of the plains, or soft tracts, growing among collections of [other] trees; having leaves like those of the pear-tree, except that they are thinner, and more soft; and as trees [in general] resembling pear-trees: the camels feed upon its leaves and the extremities of its branches; but when the camel has become satiated therewith, he forsakes it for a time, for it sets his teeth on edge, and irritates his chest, and occasions him cough. (M, L, TA.) And qaDobapN↓ [as n. un. of qaDobN] signifies A tree from which arrows are made: one says sahomu qaDobK [An arrow made from the species of tree called qDb]; like as one says sahomu naboEK &c. (ISh, TA. [See also qaDobapN below.]) ― -b4- It is also a name applied to Portions that one has cut from branches to make thereof arrows or bows. (O, K. *) ― -b5- See also qaDiybN.

qaDabN c
qaDabN: see the next preceding paragraph.

qaDobapN c
qaDobapN: see qaDobN, in three places. ― -b2- Also i. q. qaDiybN (K, TA) as meaning The bow thus called: (TA:) see the latter word: or an arrow-shaft from a tree of the species called naboE, whereof (minohu [for which the CK has fyhi]) an arrow [in the complete state] is made: pl. qaDabaAtu. (M, K. [In the TA, the pl. is said to be qaDobaAtN, with fet-h and sukoon; but this, as pl. of a subst. of the class of qaboDapN, is anomalous.])

qiDobapN c
qiDobapN A portion of a herd of camels; and of a flock, or herd, of sheep or goats. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- And Such as is slender, and light, or active; as an epithet applied to a she-camel, and in like manner to a man. (O, K. *)

qaDiybN c
qaDiybN, as an epithet applied to a branch, i. q. maqoDuwbN [i. e. Cut off]. (M voce fananN, and Msb. *) ― -b2- And [as a subst., A rod, stick, wand, branch, twig, switch, shoot, or stalk;] a guSon [i. e. branch from the stem or from another branch, of a tree], (S, M, O, Msb, K,) [and particularly] that is cut off: (M, Msb:) pl. quDobaAnN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and qiDobaAnN (M, O, Msb, K, but this is less approved, TA) and quDubN, and qaDobN↓ is a quasi-pl. n. (M, TA.) [Hence] one says, malaka Alburodapa waAlqaDiyba (tropical:) [lit. He became possessor of the burdeh and the rod], meaning Ausotuxolifa [i. e. he became a successor]. (A.) ― -b3- And A bow made of a rod, or branch, (AHn, M, K) in its complete state: (AHn, M:) or one made of a rod, or branch, not split: (M, K:) also called qaDobapN↓. (TA.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The quill of a feather. (TA voce baTonN.) ― -b5- And (tropical:) The virga, nervus, or yard, (AHát, T, K, TA,) of a bull, (AHát, TA,) or of a man, and of an animal other than man, (T, TA,) or of an ass, &c. (S, * TA.) ― -b6- And (assumed tropical:) A slender arrow: pl. quDubN. (As, TA.) ― -b7- And (assumed tropical:) A slender sword; contr. of SafiyHapN: pl. qawaADibu and quDubN: (IAth, TA:) or (tropical:) slender as an epithet applied to a sword; (M, A, K; *) likened to the qaDiyb of the tree. (A.) ― -b8- See also qaADibN. ＝ -A2- Also (tropical:) A she-camel that has not been trained, or broken-in: (S, K:) or that has been ridden (A, M) before she has been trained, (A,) or before she has been rendered gentle: (M:) or that has not acquired expertness in being trained: and applied also to the male. (M.)

qaDaAbapu XajarK c
qaDaAbapu XajarK, (S, M, * A, O,) and karomK, (A,) What falls in consecutive portions, of the extremities of the branches of trees, when they are lopped, or pruned, (S, M, * A, * O,) and of a grape-vine: (A:) or you say quDaAbapu XaIoCK, meaning what is [or are] cut off, of a thing. (M, K.)

qaDRaAbN c
qaDRaAbN: see qaADibN. ― -b2- Also One whose habitual work or occupation is that of cutting [app. in a general sense]. (Ham p. 490.)

quDRaAbN c
quDRaAbN A certain plant. (Kr, M.)

qaDRaAbapN c
qaDRaAbapN: see qaADibN. ― -b2- One says also, maA fiI famiI qaDRaAbapN There is not in my mouth a tooth that will cut a thing so as to separate one half of it from the other half. (TA.) ― -b3- And rajulN qaDRaAbapN (tropical:) A man who often exercises the faculty of deciding affairs; (qaTRaAEN liloOamuwri; S, M, A, K;) possessing ability to execute, or perform, them. (S, A.)

qaADibN c
qaADibN and qaDiybN↓ (S, M, Msb, K) and qaDRaAbN↓ and qaDRaAbapN↓ and miqoDabN↓, (M, K,) as epithets applied to a sword, Very sharp, or sharply-cutting: (S, M, Msb, K:) or the first signifies [simply] cutting, or sharp: (O:) [and the last but one is doubly intensive, signifying very sharply-cutting:] the pl. (of the first, O) is qawaADibu (S, O) and [of the second] quDubN. (S.)

miqoDabN c
miqoDabN and miqoDaAbN↓ i. q. minojalN [as meaning A reaping-hook and also a pruning-hook]. (O, K.) ― -b2- For the former, see also qaADibN.

maqoDabapN c
maqoDabapN A place in which grows [the species of trefoil, or clover, called] qaDob, (T, S, M, * O, * K, *) i. e. (S, K) raTobap, which is called in Pers. (S) Uisofisot: (S, K; and the like is said in the M:) pl. maqaADibu, and by poetic license maqaADiybu. (O.) And A place in which grow the trees called qaDob from which bows are made. (K.)

miqoDaAbN c
miqoDaAbN One whose craft, or occupation, is that of cutting [app. herbage &c.]. (Ham p. 490.) ― -b2- See also miqoDabN. ＝ -A2- And Land that produces (M, K) abundantly (K) the herbage called qaDob which is eaten when freshly cut, (M, * K, TA,) i. e. [the species of trefoil, or clover, called] fiSofiSap. (TA.)

maqoDuwbN c
maqoDuwbN [pass. part. n. of 1, q. v.; and see qaDiybN].

AlmuqotaDabu c
AlmuqotaDabu A certain metre of verse, (M, O,) the thirteenth, (O,) consisting of faAEilaAtu mufotaEiluno, (M, O,) twice; (M;) originally mafoEuwlaAtu musotafoEiluno: so called as though it were the munosariH with a foot, namely, mstfEln, cut off. (O.) ― -b2- muqotaDabN applied to verse, or poetry, and a writing, means (tropical:) Extemporized. (S, O.) ― -b3- And muqotaDabN fiI EamalK means (tropical:) Untrained in a work; (A;) or tasked to do it before he can do it well. (IDrd, S.)

munoqaDibN c
munoqaDibN: see its verb, 7.

dictScrap.label: qDE qDf qSm qSI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qaTRahu c
1. qaTRahu, aor.
qaTuTa
, (S, M,) inf. n. qaTRN, (M, K,) He cut it, in a general sense: (M, K:) or he cut it, meaning a hard thing, such as a HuqRp [or box], (Lth, M, K,) and the like, (M,) in a good form, or fashion, like as a man cuts a reed upon a bone; (Lth;) and taqoTiyTN↓, also, [inf. n. of qTRThu,] signifies the cutting a HuqRap, (K, TA,) and making it even: (TA:) or qaTRahu signifies he cut it breadthwise, across, or crosswise; (S, M, O, K;) he so separated it; (Kh, S;) opposed to qadRahu, (S, TA,) which signifies he cut it in halves lengthwise, like as one cuts a strap or thong: (TA:) and AqtTRhu↓ signifies the same. (M, K. *) You say, qaTRa Alqalama, (S, Msb,) aor. as above, (K,) and so the inf. n., (Msb,) He nibbed the reed for writing; cut off its head breadthwise, across, or crosswise. (S, * Msb.) And qaTRa AlbayoTaAru HaAfira AldRaAbRapi The farrier pared, and made even, the hoof of the beast of carriage. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qaTTa AlXRaEaru, (S, M, K,) with the reduplication made manifest, (S, M,) and qaTRa, aor. yaqaTRu, (M, Msb, K,) and, of the latter, yaquTRu also, [contr. to the general rule,] (Msb,) inf. n., of the former, qaTRN, (M, TA,) which is extr., (M,) and of the latter, (M, TA,) qaTaTN and qaTaATapN, (M, K,) The hair was, or became, [frizzled, or] very crisp, very curly, or much twisted, and contracted: (S, * Msb:) or like that of the zanojiIR: (Msb:) or crisp, curly, or twisted, and contracted, and short. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- qaTRa AlsRiEoru, (S, M, Msb, K,) aor. yaqiTRu, (S, K,) with kesr, (S, TA,) or yaquTRu, (M, Msb,) the verb being co-ordinate to qatala, [contr. to the general rule,] (Msb) inf. n. qaTRN (S, M, Msb, K) and quTuwTN; (M, K;) as also quTRa, with damm; (Fr, K;) The price was, or became, dear, (S, M, Msb, K,) and high: (Msb:) Sh thought this explanation to be wrong, and the meaning to be the price flagged; but Az says, that in this he was mistaken. (TA.) ― -b2- qaTRa QllRehu AlsRiEora God made the price to be, or become, dear. (Fr. TA.)

2 qaTRaRa
2: see 1, first sentence.

7 AnqTR c
7. AnqTR quasi-pass. of qaTRahu as explained in the first sentence of this art.; It was, or became, cut; &c.; and so AqtTR↓. (M, TA.)

8 UiqotaTaTa
8: see 1, first sentence: and see also 7.

R. Q. 1 qaToqaTati AlsRamaMCu c
R. Q. 1. qaToqaTati AlsRamaMCu The sky let fall rain, (AZ, S, M,) or hail, (M,) such as is termed qiToqiTN: (AZ, S, M:) or the sky rained. (K.)

qaTo c
qaTo, signifying Hasobu, [explained in exs. here following,] (Lth, S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K,) i. e., (S,) denoting the being satisfied, or content, (Sb, S, M, Msb,) with a thing, (Msb,) is thus written, with fet-h to the q, and with the T quiescent, (Sb, S, M, Msb, * Mughnee,) like Eano; (K;) and also, (Sb, M, K,) sometimes, (Sb, M,) qaTK↓, (Sb, M, K,) with tenween, mejroor; (K;) and qaTiI↓ [distinguished from qaTiI in the next sentence]; (Sb, M, K;) but the term “ mejroor ” is here used contr. to the rules of grammar, as it denotes that qT is decl., whereas it is not. (MF.) It is used as a prefixed noun: you say, qaToka hecaA AlXRaIoCu Thy sufficiency [meaning sufficient for thee] is this thing; syn. Hasobuka; (Lth, S, Mughnee; *) and like it is qado: (Lth:) and you also say, using it as a prefixed n., qaToniI My sufficiency; syn. HasobiI; (Lth, S, * Mughnee;) like qadoniI; introducing n, (Lth, S, TA,) as in EanRiI and minRiI and ladunRiI, contr. to rule, for the reason which has been explained in treating of qado, (S, TA,) to preserve the original quiescence of the T; (Mughnee;) and qaTiI; (S, Msb, Mughnee;) and qaTi↓; (S;) and qaTaATi↓, (S, M, K,) like qaTaAmi, (S, K,) indecl.; (M;) as signifying HasobiI: (S, M, Msb, Mughnee, K:) and, as is said in the Moo'ab, qaTo Eabodi AllRehi dirohamN The sufficiency of 'Abd-Allah is a dirhem; [and the like is said by Lth and in the Mughnee;] pausing upon the T, and making qT to govern a gen. case [as it does virtually in the preceding instances]; and the Basrees say, that this is the right mode, as meaning the like of Hasobu zayodK dirohamN and kafoIa zayodK dirohamN: (K:) or some say qaTo, with jezm; and some say qaTu↓, making it inded. with damm for its termination; each governing what follows it in the gen. case. (M.) ― -b2- It is also a verbal noun, signifying yakofiI [It suffices, or will suffice; or it is, or will be, sufficient]; and when this is the case, you say, qaToniI, (Mughnee, K,) like as you say, yakofiyniI [It suffices me, or will suffice me]; (Mughnee;) or kafaAniI [which means, emphatically, it suffices me], accord. to the Koofees; (Lth;) which is also allowable when qaTo is equivalent to Hasobu [as we have observed above]: (Mughnee:) and you say also, qaToka, meaning kafaAka [emphatically It suffices thee]: and qaTiI, meaning kafaAniI [emphatically It suffices me]: (K:) so in the copies of the K; [in the CK, erroneously, qaTRaniI;] but [it seems that it should be qaToniI; for] it is said in the Mughnee and its Expositions, that in this last case the addition of the n is indispensable: (MF:) and some say, qaTo Eaboda AllRehi dirohamN [A dirhem suffices, or will suffice, 'Abd-Allah (in the CK, erroneously, qaTRu)]; making it to govern the accus. case [as it does virtually in preceding instances]: and some add n, saying, Eaboda AllRehi dirohamN qaTonu↓ [meaning the same]: (Lth, K:) [hence,] some say, that [qaTon in] qaToniI is a word originally thus formed without any augmentation, like [Hasob in] HasobiI; (M;) [but J says,] if the n in qaToniI belonged to the root of the word, they had said qaTonuka, which is not known. (S.) ― -b3- It is also syn. with Hasobu in the phrase maA raOayotuhu UilRaA marRapF waAHidapF faqaTN [I have not seen him, or it, save once, and that was a thing sufficient or that was enough]: (S, Msb: *) or, as is said in the Mutowwel, qaTo in faqaTo is a verbal noun, meaning abstain thou [from further questioning, or the like], as though it were the complement of a condition suppressed [such as “ the case being so ”]: or, as is said in the Mesáïl of Ibn-Es-Seed, the f is properly prefixed because the meaning is and I was satisfied, or content, therewith; so that the f is a conjunction: (from a marginal note in a copy of the Mughnee:) [it therefore virtually signifies and no more; or only; and thus it may often be rendered: and this explains what here follows:] when qaT is used to denote paucity, (M, K,) which is said by El-Hareeree, in the Durrah, to be only in negative phrases, (MF,) it is [written qaTo,] with jezm, (M, K,) and without teshdeed: (M:) you say, maA Einodaka UilRaA hecaA qaTo [which may be rendered Thou hast not save this only]: but when it is followed by a conjunctive A, it is with kesr; [as in the saying,] maA Ealimotu UilRaA hecaA qaTi Alyawoma [virtually mean-
ing I knew not, or, emphatically, know not, save this only, to-day]: (K:) and also, (K,) when thus using it, (M,) you say, maA lahu UilRaA EaXarapN qaTo yaAfataI [likewise virtually meaning He has not save ten only, O young man], without teshdeed, and with jezm; and qaTRi↓, with teshdeed and khafd; (Lh, M, K;) the kesreh of the latter, in a case of this kind, being to distinguish the qaTR which denotes [paucity of] number from qaTRu, which denotes time. (Lth.) ＝ -A2- See also qaTRu, first sentence.

quTo c
quTo: see qaTRu.

qaTu c
qaTu: see qaTo: ＝ -A2- and see also qaTRu.

qaTi c
qaTi: see qaTo.

quTu c
quTu: see qaTRu.

qaTK c
qaTK: see qaTo.

qaTRa c
qaTRa: see qaTRu.

qaTRu c
qaTRu is an adv. noun, (Mughnee,) [generally] denoting time, (S, M, Mughnee,) or past time, (Msb, K,) used to include all past time; (Lth, Mughnee;) as also quTRu↓, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) the former vowel being assimilated to the latter; (S, Mughnee;) and qaTu↓, (S, M, Mughnee, K,) and quTu↓; (S, Mughnee, * K;) and some say qaTo↓, (S, Mughnee,) whence qaTu is formed, by making its termination similar to that of the primary form qaTRu, to show its origin; (S, M;) or this would be better than qaTu; (M;) and quTo↓, (S, M, Mughnee, *) like muco, which is rare: (S, M:) of all these, the first is the most chaste: (Mughnee:) when time is meant by it, it is always with refa, without tenween: (K:) or one says also qaTRi↓, (M, Mughnee, K,) with kesr and teshdeed to the T, (M, K,) accord. to IAar; (M;) and qaTRa↓, with fet-h and teshdeed to the T; (M, * K;) as well as with damm to the T without teshdeed. (K [in some copies of which is here added, “ and with refa to the T; ” to which is further added in the CK, “ without teshdeed: ” but I find two copies without any addition of this redundant kind: for by “ refa ” is here meant, as in a former instance, “ damm; ” though improperly, as the word is indecl.]) You say, maA raOayotuhu qaTRu &c. [I have not seen him, or it, ever, or hitherto]; (S, M, K;) and maA faEalotuhu qaTRa [I have not done it ever, or hitherto]; (Msb, Mughnee;) i. e., in the time that is past; (Msb, K;) or in what has been cut off of my life; (Mughnee, K;) its derivation being from qaTaTotu meaning “ I cut; ” for the past is cut off from the present and the future; and it is indecl. because it implies the meaning of muco and UilaI; its meaning being muco Oano xuliqotu UilaI AlMna [since my being created until now]; and with a vowel for its termination to prevent the occurrence of two quiescent letters together; (Mughnee;) and it is with refa [meaning damm for its termination] because it is like qabolu and baEodu: (Lth:) accord. to Ks, (S,) qaTRu is a contraction of qaTaTu: (S, M:) Sb says, that it denotes AlUinotihaMC; [app. meaning that it signifies abstain thou from further questioning, or the like; for El-Hareeree says, in the Durrah, that qaTRu and qaTo both signify the same as Hasobu;] and that it is indecl., with damm for its termination, like Hasobu. (M.) You say also, maA faEalotu hecaA qaTo walaA qaTRu [app. meaning I have not done this alone, nor ever]: (K, TA: [in the CK qaTRu wlA quTu, but]) the former qT is with jezm to the T, and the latter is with teshdeed and damm to the T. (TA.) And yaA fataI maA zaAla EalaI hecaA muco quTRa↓ [He, or it, has not ceased to be after this manner during all past time, O young man]; with damm to the q, and with teshdeed. (Lh, M.) It is used only in negative phrases relating to past time; the saying of the vulgar laA OafoEaluhu qaTRu [meaning I will not do it ever] being incorrect; (Mughnee, K; [in the CK qaTu]) for with respect to the future you say EawoDu (TA) [or OabadFA]: or it is mostly so used, accord. to Ibn-Málik: (MF:) but it occurs after an affirmative phrase in places in El-Bukháree, (K,) in his Saheeh; (TA;) for ex., OaTowalu SalaApK SalRayotuhaA qaTRu [The longest prayer which I have prayed ever]: and in the Sunan of Aboo-Dawood; tawaDRaOa valaAvFA qaTRu [He performed the wuDuwoC three times ever]: and Ibn-Málik asserts it to be right, and says that it is one of the things which have been unperceived by many of the grammarians: (K:) El-Karmánee, however, interprets these instances as though they were negative. (TA.)

qaTRi c
qaTRi: see qaTo, near the end of the paragraph: ＝ -A2- and see also qaTRu, in the first sentence.

quTRu c
quTRu: see qaTRu, in two places.

XaEarN qaTRN c
XaEarN qaTRN, and qaTaTN↓, (M, Msb, K,) and qaTiTN↓, (TA,) Crisp, curly, or twisted and contracted, and short, hair: (M, K:) or hair that is very crisp, very curly, or much twisted and contracted: or, accord. to the T, qaTaTN↓ means hair of the zanojiIR: (Msb:) or you say, jaEodN qaTaTN↓, meaning very crisp, very curly, or much twisted and contracted. (S.) ― -b2- rajulN qaTRN, and qaTaTN↓, (Msb,) or rajulN qaTRu AlXRaEari, and qaTaTu↓ AlXRaEari, (S, M, K,) A man whose hair is crisp, curly, or twisted and contracted, and short: (M, K:) or whose hair is very crisp, very curly, or much twisted and contracted; (S, * Msb;) as also qiTaATN↓: (K: accord. to some copies; but accord. to other copies, as a pl. in this sense: [the reading of the latter is more probably correct, and is that of the TA:]) or beautifully crisp or curly or twisted and contracted: (TA:) the pl. [of qaTRN] is OaqoTaATN [a pl. of pauc.] and qaTRuwna and qiTaATN; and [of qaTaTN↓] qaTaTuwna: (M, K:) the epithet applied to a woman is qaTRapN, and qaTaTN↓ without p. (M, Msb.) ＝ -A2- See also qaATRN↓.

qiTRN c
qiTRN A slice cut off (XaqiyqapN), of a melon or other thing. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A portion, share, or lot, (M, A, Msb, K,) of gifts, (A, TA,) &c. (TA.) Hence the saying in the Kur, [xxxviii. 15,] rabRanaA EajRilo lanaA qiTRanaA qabola yawomi AlHisaAbi (tropical:) [O our Lord, hasten to us our portion before the day of reckoning]: accord. to some, our portion of punishment: but accord. to Sa'eed Ibn-Jubeyr, it means, of Paradise. (TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A writing; (Fr, S, Msb;) [such as that of a man's works;] and hence, accord. to Fr, the words of the Kur cited above; those words being said in derision: (TA:) or a writing of reckoning: (M, K:) or a written obligation: (M:) or it signifies also a written obligation binding one to give a gift or present; (S, K, TA;) and hence the saying in the Kur cited above: (S:) pl. quTuwTN: (S, M, Msb, K:) which Az explains as meaning gifts, and stipends; so called because they were issued written in the form of notes and statements of obligation upon cut pieces of paper or the like. (TA.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) An hour, or a portion, (saAEap,) of the night. (M, K.) You say maDaI qiTRN mina AllRayoli (assumed tropical:) [An hour, or a portion, of the night passed]. (Th, M.) ＝ -A2- A male cat: (S, M, Msb, K:) the female is called qiTRapN: (Lth, S, M, Msb:) Kr disallowed this latter; and IDrd says, I do not think it to be genuine Arabic; (M;) but to this it is objected that it occurs in traditions: (MF:) the pl. is qiTaATN (S, M, Msb, K) and qiTaTapN, (M, K,) or qiTaTN. (Msb.)

qaTaTN c
qaTaTN: see qaTRN, throughout.

qaTiTN c
qaTiTN: see qaTRN.

qiTRapN c
qiTRapN [A mode, or manner, of cutting a thing, such as the extremity of the nib of a writingreed]: see an ex. voce sinRN (near the end of the paragraph).

qaTonu c
qaTonu: see qaTo.

qaTiI c
qaTiI: see qaTo.

qaTaATi c
qaTaATi: see qaTo.

qiTaATN c
qiTaATN: see qaTRN.

qaTRaATN c
qaTRaATN A xarRaAT [q. v.] who makes [the small boxes of wood or the like called] Huqaq [pl. of HuqRap]. (S, O, K.) [See 1, first sentence.]

qiToqiTN c
qiToqiTN Small rain; (M, K;) resembling Xacor [q. v.]: (M:) or the smallest of rain; the next above which is termed racaAdN; the next above this, TaXRN; [but see this last term;] the next above this, bagoXN; and the next above this, gaboyapN: (AZ, S:) or rain falling continuously, in large drops: (Lth, K:) or hail: (K:) or small hail, (M, O, K,) which is imagined to be hail or rain. (O.)

sEorN qaATRN c
sEorN qaATRN A dear price; as also maqoTuwTN↓, (M, K,) and qaTRN↓, (K,) and qaATiTN↓. (IAar, K.)
You say, waradonaA OaroDFA qaATRFA siEoruhaA We arrived at a land of dear prices. (S, TA.)

qaATiTN c
qaATiTN: see qaATRN.

maqaTRN c
maqaTRN [in the CK erroneously miqaTR] The place of ending of the extremities of the ribs of a horse: (M, K:) or the extremity of the rib, projecting over the belly: (K in art. Xrsf:) or the place of ending of the ribs of a horse: (TA:) maqaATRu [is the pl., signifying, as explained in the S, in art. Xrsf, the extremities of the ribs, projecting over the belly: or it] signifies the two extremities of the belly of a horse, whereof one is at the sternum (AlqaSR), and the other at the pubes. (En-Nadr.)

miqaTRapN c
miqaTRapN The thing upon which the reed for writing is nibbed; (S;) [generally made of bone or ivory;] a small bone upon which the writer nibs his reeds for writing; (K;) a small bone which is found with the sellers of paper, upon which they cut the extremities of the reeds for writing. (Lth.)

maqoTuwTN c
maqoTuwTN: see qaATR.

samaMCN muqaToqiTapN c
samaMCN muqaToqiTapN A sky letting fall rain such as is called qiToqiTN. (AZ, S.)

1 qaTaba c
1. qaTaba, (K, TA,) aor.
qaTiba
, inf. n. qaTobN, (TA,) He collected a thing, brought it, gathered it, or drew it, together: (K, TA:) this is the primary signification. (O.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, qaTaba AlHimaAru EaAnatahu i. e. (tropical:) [The wild ass] collected [his herd of wild she-asses]. (A: there distinguished as tropical.) ― -b3- And qaTaba Alqawomu, [Oanofusahumo being app. understood,] and AqTb↓, (assumed tropical:) The people, or party, assembled themselves together, or congregated, (O, K, TA,) and were guests, and mixed together. (TA.) ― -b4- And qaTaba, (A, K,) aor.
qaTiba
, inf. n. qaTobN and quTuwbN; (K, TA;) and qTRb↓, (K,) inf. n. taqoTiybN; (TA;) He contracted the part between his eyes; (A, K;) and grinned, or displayed his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; (K, TA;) by reason of drink, &c.: (TA:) or qaTaba bayona Eayonayohi, (S, O, Msb,) aor.
qaTiba
, inf. n. qaTobN, (Msb,) he contracted the part between his eyes: (S, O, Msb:) and wajohahu qTRb↓, inf. n. taqoTiybN, he contracted his face; (S, O;) or did so much. (So accord. to a copy of the S.) ― -b5- And qaTaba AlXRaraAba, (S, A, O, Msb, K,) aor.
qaTiba
, inf. n. qaTobN, (Msb,) He mixed the wine, or beverage; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) as also AqTbhu↓; (S, O, K;) and qTRbhu↓, (O, K, TA,) inf. n. taqoTiybN. (TA.) ― -b6- And qaTaba AlUinaMCa He filled the vessel. (K.) ― -b7- qaTaba AljuwaAliqa, (K, TA,) inf. n. qaTobN, (S, O,) He inserted one of the two loops of the [sack called] jwAlq into the other, (S, O, K, TA,) on the occasion of making up a load, (TA,) then bent it (S, O, K *) again, (S, O,) [this time, app., back and down,] and put them together [in order, it seems, to insert a stick, so that the middle of one loop should be above the stick and the middle of the other should be beneath it]: (K, TA:) when he does not bend the loop, [app. meaning through the other and then a second time as described above,] the action is termed saloqN. (S, O, [See salaqa AljuwaAliqa, in art. slq.]) ＝ -A2- qaTabahu signifies also He angered him; (O, K;) aor. as above [and so, app., the inf. n.]. (O.) ＝ -A3- And also, (K, TA,) aor.
qaTiba
, (TA,) inf. n. qaTobN, (S, O,) He cut it, or cut it off: (S, O, K:) but in this instance the T is substituted for D. (O.)

2 qaTRaba
2: see above, in three places.

4 OaqoTaba
4: see the first paragraph, in two places.

qaTobN c
qaTobN: see the next paragraph, in two places.

quTobN c
quTobN (S, A, O, Msb, K) and qaTobN↓ and qiTobN↓ (S, A, O, K, but some reject the second and third of these, TA) and quTubN↓ (A, K) and quTobapN↓, (so in some copies of the K,) or qaTobapN↓, (so in other copies of the K, and thus accord. to the TA, as on the authority of Th,) The axis, or pivot, (T, A, Msb, K,) of iron, (A, K,) of a mill; (T, S, A, O, Msb, K;) the iron thing that is fixed in the middle of the nether stone of a mill; (IAth, TA;) the iron in the nether stone, around which revolves the upper stone, of a mill: (Ham p. 54:) pl. OaqoTaAbN (A, IAth, O, TA) and quTuwbN (IAth, TA) and qiTabapN. (O.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlquTobu, (S, O, Msb, K,) and accord. to some AlqaTobu↓ and AlqiTobu↓, (MF,) (tropical:) [The pole-star: or the pole of the celestial sphere:] a certain star, (K,) a small star, (ISd, TA,) according to which the kibleh is constructed: (ISd, K, TA:) a star between the jadoI and the faroqadaAni, around which the celestial sphere, or firmament, revolves, (S, O, TA,) small and white, and never moving from its place: [but it seems that nebula should be here substituted for star:] Aboo-'Adnán says that the qZb is a small star always in the midst of the four [stars] of banaAtu naEoXK, [which is evidently a mistake,] never quitting its place, around which revolve the jdI and the frqdAn: but accord. to Ibn-Es-Saláh El-Mohaddith, it is not a star, but a buqoEap [meaning a spot, or a nebula,] in the sky, near the jdI, which latter is the [pole-] star whereby the kibleh is known in the northern countries. (TA.) ― -b3- And [hence likewise,] AlquTobu signifies also (tropical:) The cause, or means, of the subsistence of a thing: and (tropical:) the thing, or point, [or person,] upon which [or upon whom] a thing [such as an affair, and a question,] turns: pl. [as above, i. e.] OaqoTaAbN and quTuwbN and qiTabapN. (K, TA.) ― -b4- And (tropical:) The chief, or lord, of a people or tribe; (S, A, O, K;) quTobu baniI fulaAnK meaning (tropical:) the chief, or lord, of the sons of such a one, upon whom their state of affairs turns [i. e. depends, and by whose government their affairs are regulated]. (S, O, TA.) And quTobu raHaI AlHarobi [lit. The axis, or pivot, of the mill of war, or of the mill of the war,] means (tropical:) the commander of the army. (S, O, TA.) ― -b5- [In the conventional language of the mystics, it is applied to (assumed tropical:) The hierarch of the saints of his generation, who is also called Algawovu, and is supposed to be pre-eminently endued with sanctity, and with thaumaturgic faculties, and to be known as the quTob to none but his agents unless he make himself known: at his death, his place is believed to be filled by another.] ＝ -A2- [quTobN also signifies A species of plant:] accord. to AHn, the quTob [is a species of plant that] extends upon the ground like ropes, and has a yellow, thorny, or prickly, blossom; when fit to be reaped, and dry, it hurts men to tread upon it; and is round like a pebble: n. un. quTobapN↓: (O:) [it is said in the K that AlquTobapu↓ is said to signify a certain plant: and the pl. is quTobN or quTabN: (thus accord. to different copies: in my MS. copy, the former; and in the CK, the latter, and there said to be like SuradN: if the former be right, it is a coll. gen. n.:)] or quTobN and quTobapN↓ signify two species of plants: and the latter is said to be a certain herb, having a fruit, or produce, and berries (HabR) like those of the haraAs [a tree that bears a kind of drupe]: Lh says that it [app. the quTob, the pronoun being masc.,] is a species of thorn, from which diverge three thorns, resembling a Hasak [here meaning caltrop: the leaves of its stem resemble those of the [species of trefoil called] nafal and curq, and qTb is the name of the fruit: and OaroDN qTbp [i. e., accord. to general analogy, qaTibapN↓, like qaSibapN &c.,] signifies Land in which this kind of plant grows. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also quTobapN.

qiTobN c
qiTobN: see quTobN, first and second sentences.

qaTabN c
qaTabN, [app. an inf. n. of which the verb is not mentioned, (in the CK qaTob, but, as is said in the TA, it is muHarRakap,)] which is forbidden, is One's taking a thing [by measure or weight], and then taking the rest of the commodity by comparing it with the former portion, without measure or weight. (Kr, K, * TA.)

qaTibN c
qaTibN: see qaTuwbN: ＝ -A2- and OaroDN qaTibapN: see quTobN, last sentence but one.

quTubN c
quTubN: see quTobN, first sentence.

qaTobapN c
qaTobapN: see quTobN, first sentence.

quTobapN c
quTobapN: see quTobN, first sentence: ＝ -A2- and again, in the last quarter of the paragraph, in three places. ＝ -A3- Also An arrow-head (S, O, K) of small size (O) with which one shoots at a butt: (S, O, K:) accord. to ISd, a small, short, foursided head at the end of an arrow with which one shoots, to the utmost possible distance, at the butts: accord. to Th, the end of an arrow with which one shoots at the butt: accord. to AHn, it is of what are called AlmaraAmiI [pl. of miromaApN, q. v.]: (TA:) or an arrow with which one contends for superiority in shooting: (A:) [but] accord. to En-Nadr, it is not accounted an arrow: and quTobN↓ signifies an arrow-head; occurring in a trad. in this sense. (TA.)

quTobaAnN c
quTobaAnN A certain plant. (K.)

qiTibRaI c
qiTibRaI A certain plant, of which is made rope of twisted strands, or well-twisted rope, (K, TA,) resembling that of the cocoa-nut, the price of which mounts to a hundred deenárs of ready money, (TA,) and which is better than that made of the fibres of the cocoa-nut. (K, TA.)

qiTaAbN c
qiTaAbN An admixture (Lth, S, * O, K, TA) in what is drunk and what is not drunk. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- And qiTaAbu Aljayobi, (S, A, O, K, *) from AlqaTobu meaning “ the act of cutting, ” (S, TA,) or from the same as meaning “ the act of bringing, or drawing, together ” two things, (TA,) The opening that is cut out at the neck and bosom of a shirt or the like, for the head to enter into it: (O:) or (tropical:) the part where the two sides of that opening unite: (A, * K, * TA:) or, as AAF says, the lower, or lowest, part of that opening. (TA.)

qaTuwbN c
qaTuwbN (S, O, K) and qaATibN↓ (K) [and qaTibN↓ (occurring in the A in art. dEb, as opposed to daEibN and laEibN, to which it seems to be therefore assimilated in form,)] Who contracts the part between his eyes; (S, O, K;) and grins, or displays his teeth, frowning, or contracting his face, and looking sternly, austerely, or morosely; (K;) [or rather the first signifies one who does so much;] applied to a man. (S.) ― -b2- Hence, (TA,) AlqaTuwbu and AlqaATibu↓ signify The lion. (O, K, TA.)

qaTiybN c
qaTiybN Mixed wine or beverage [&c.]; as also maqoTuwbN↓. (K.)

quTaAbapN c
quTaAbapN A piece of flesh: (Kr, K:) from qaTaba signifying “ he cut ” a thing. (TA.)

qaTiybapN c
qaTiybapN Anything mixed. (TA.) And [particularly] (TA) Camels' milk and sheeps' or goats' milk mixed together: (IAar, S, O, K:) or goats' milk and sheeps' milk mixed together; (K;) which is also called naxiysapN: (TA:) or fresh milk, or milk such as is termed Haqiyn [q. v.], mixed with UihaAlap [or melted fat, &c.]: and i. q. raviyYapN [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- See also qaATibap.

qaATibN c
qaATibN: see qaTuwbN, in two places.

jaAWuwA qaATibapF c
jaAWuwA qaATibapF (tropical:) They came all together: (S, A, * O, Msb, K:) qATbp being a noun denoting generality, (Sb, S, O,) not used but as a word descriptive of state, in the accus. case: (Sb, S, O, K:) its use otherwise is a vulgar corruption, though allowed by El-Khafájee: (MF:) or it may be regarded in a phrase such as that above as being in the accus. case as an inf. n.: (IAth, TA:) it is expl. in the T as meaning all together; mixed, one with another. (TA.) And jaAWuwA biqaTiybatihim↓ means (assumed tropical:) They came with their [whole] company. (K.)

AlmuqaTRabu c
AlmuqaTRabu and AlmuqaTRibu and AlmaqoTibu The part between the eyebrows. (TA.)

maqoTuweebN c
maqoTuweebN: see qaTiybN. ― -b2- qirobapN maqoTuwbapN A water-skin filled. (Lh, O, TA.)

wajohN mutaqaTRibN c
wajohN mutaqaTRibN [A contracted face]. (K in art. bsr.)

1 qaTara c
1. qaTara, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) aor.
qaTura
, (S, Msb,) inf. n. qaTorN and qaTaraAnN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and quTuwrN; (K;) [and in an intensive sense, taqoTaArN (see a verse cited voce gusolN);] and AqTr↓; (AHn, TA;) and tqATr↓; (Msb, TA;) said of water, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) and of tears, (K,) or other fluid, (S, * TA,) [It dropped, dripped, or fell in drops;] it flowed (Mgh, Msb, TA) drop by drop. (Msb.) ― -b2- It occurs in a trad. as signifying qaTara EaraqFA, or bawolFA, [He let fall sweat, or urine, in drops,] in which each subst, is in the accus. case as a specificative: said of a person in intense awe or fear. (Mgh.) ― -b3- qaTara AlSRamogu minaI AlXRajarapi The gum [exuded in drops or] came forth from the tree. (TA.) ― -b4- qaTarati Qsotuhu i. q. maSalat [His anus voided excrement in drops]. (K.) ＝ -A2- qaTara fiI AlOaroDi inf. n. quTuwrN, (tropical:) He went away into the country, or in the land; (S, K; *) and hastened; (K, * TA;) as also maTara, inf. n. muTuwrN. (TA.) ＝ -A3- qaTarahu, (As, S, Mgh, Msb, K,) [aor.
qaTura
,] inf. n. qaTorN; (Mgh;) and AqTrhu↓, (Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiqoTaArN; (Msb;) or the latter but not the former accord. to AZ; (Msb;) and qTRrhu↓, (S, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoTiyrN; (S, Mgh, Msb;) He (God, K, or a man, S, Msb) made it (namely water &c.) [to drop, drip, dribble, or fall in drops;] to flow (S, Msb, TA) drop by drop: (S, Msb:) he poured it out, or forth. (Mgh.) You say qaTarotu AlmaMCa fiI AlHaloqi, and OaqoTarotuhu, and qaTRarotuhu, [He made the water to fall drop by drop into the throat.] (Msb.) ― -b2- maA qaTaraka EalayonaA (tropical:) What hath poured thee (maA SabRaka) upon us? (TA.) ― -b3- qaTara fulaAnFA, (Lth, K,) inf. n. qaTorN, (Lth,) (assumed tropical:) He prostrated such a one with vehemence. (Lth, K.) [Perhaps this is from quTorN, signifying the “ side; ” and if so it is not tropical. See also 2.] ― -b4- qaTara AlvRawoba (tropical:) He sewed the garment, or piece of cloth. (IAar, K.) ＝ -A4- qaTara AlUibila, (Msb, K,) aor.
qaTura
, (Msb,) inf. n. qaTorN; (Msb, K;) and qTRrhA↓, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoTiyrN; (S;) but this has an intensive signification; (Msb;) and AqTrhA↓; (K;) but this [says SM] I do not find in the [other] lexicons; Az and ISd mention only the first and second; (TA;) He disposed the camels in a file, string, or series; (S, * Msb;) he placed the camels near, one to another, in a file, string, or series; (K;) [and tied the halter of each, except the first, to the tail of the next before it.] It is said in a proverb, Aljalaba AlnRufaADu yaqaTRiru↓ The failure of provisions causes the camels, driven or brought from one place to another, to be disposed in files for sale. (S.) ＝ -A5- qaTara AlbaEiyra He smeared the camel with qaTiraAn [or tar]. (S, Msb.)

2 qTRrhu c
2. qTRrhu: see 1. ― -b2- bihi taqoTiyrN [He has a dribbling of his urine] is said of a man who cannot retain his urine, (Mgh, K, *) by reason of cold affecting the bladder. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qTRr AlUibila: see 1. ＝ -A3- TaEanahu faqaTRarahu (inf. n. taqoTiyrN, S) He pierced him [with his spear] and threw him down on one of his sides. (S, Msb.) And qTRrhu farasuhu; in the copies of the K qTRrhu EalaI farasihi, but this is a mistake; (TA;) and AqTrhu↓; and bih tqTRr↓; (K;) vulgarly taqanoTara bihi; (TA;) His horse threw him down on one of his sides. (K, * TA.) See quTorN: see also 1. ＝ -A4- qTRr vawobahu, inf. n. as above, He fumigated his garment with quTor, i. e., aloes-wood. (K.)

4 AqTr c
