4. AqTr: see 1. ― -b2- It was time for it to drop, drip, or fall in drops; it was ready, or near, to drop, &c.; expl. by HaAna lahu Oano yaqoTura, (S,) and HaAna Oano yaqoTura. (K.) ＝ -A2- AqTrhu: see 1. ＝ -A3- AqTr AlUibila: see 1. ＝ -A4- AqTrhu farasuhu: see 2.

5 tqTRr c
5. tqTRr, quasi-pass. of 2, [It was made to drop, drip, or fall in drops; &c. See an ex. in a verse cited voce tasaqRaI. ― -b2- ] He fell [upon his side]. (S.) ― -b3- tqTRr bihi farasuhu: see 2. ＝ -A2- tqTRrt She fumigated herself with quTor, i. e., aloes-wood. (K.)

6 taqaAoTara
6: see 1. ＝ -A2- tqATr Alqawomu (tropical:) The people came in consecutive companies; from qiTaAru AlUibili. (S, TA.) And hence also, tqATrt kutubu fulaAnK (tropical:) [The books, or letters, of such a one followed one another in a regular series]. (TA.)

10 AstqTrhu c
10. AstqTrhu He sought, or desired, its dropping, or dripping, or flowing; [endeavoured to make it drop, or drip;] expl. by raAma qaTaraAnahu, (K, TA,) i. e., sayalaAnahu. (TA.) ― -b2- AstqTr maEoruwfFA [He sought, or demanded, bounty, as it were drop by drop]. (K in art. nD.)

Q. Q. 1 qanoTara c
Q. Q. 1. qanoTara: see art. qnTr.

Q. Q. 2 taqanoTara c
Q. Q. 2. taqanoTara: see art. qnTr.

qaTorN c
qaTorN [Drops;] pl. of qaTorapN: (S:) [or rather a coll. gen. n., having this signification; or] what drops, (K,) of water &c.: (TA:) n. un. qaTorapN; (K;) which signifies a drop: (Msb:) pl. of the former, qiTaArN: (K:) and of the latter, qaTaraAtN. (Msb.) [See also quTaArapN.] You say saAla qaTorapF qaTorapF It flowed drop by drop. (Msb.) ― -b2- Rain: (S, Msb:) n. un. qaTorapN [signifying a rain; a shower of rain]: (Msb:) pl. of the former, qiTaArN. (S.)

quTorN c
quTorN A side, part, portion, quarter, tract, or region, (S, Msb, K,) of the heavens, and of the earth; (TA;) as also qutorN (S, K, art. qtr,) and quturN: (K, ibid.) either side of a man: pl. OaqoTaArN. (S, Msb, K.) You say OaloqaAhu ElI AHd quTorayohi He threw him down on one of his sides. (S, * Msb, * K, * TA.) And laA OadoriI EalaI OaIRi quTorayohi yaqaEu [I know not on which of his two sides he will fall; i. e., what will be his final state]. (JK.) And the pl. signifies The outer parts or regions (nawaAHK)
of a horse, and of a camel: the prominent parts of a horse, such as the withers (AlkaAvibap) and the rump: the prominent parts of the upper portions of a camel, and of a mountain. (TA.) ― -b2- fuToru daAYirapK [The diameter of a circle;] a straight line extending from one side of a circle to the other side so that its middle falls upon the centre (KT.) [But this is app. post-classical.] ＝ -A2- quTorN (S, K) and quTurN↓ (S) Aloes-wood with which one fumigates. (S, K.)

qiTorN c
qiTorN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and qaTirN↓ (ISk, TA) Copper, or brass: (S, Mgh, Msb:) so in the Kur [xiv. 51, accord. to one reading,] mino qiTorK MnK (S,) or mino qaTirK MnK, accord. to the reading of I'Ab, meaning, of copper, or brass, in the utmost state of heat: (TA:) [but the common reading is mino qaTiraAnK:] or copper, or brass, in a state of fusion: (K:) so in the Kur, xxxiv. 11 (TA) [and xviii. 95]: or a certain kind thereof: (K:) or molten iron: (Mgh, Msb:) and anything that drops or flows (yaqoTuru) by fusion or melting, like water. (Mgh.)

qaTirN c
qaTirN: see qiTorN.

quTurN c
quTurN: see quTorN.

qaTorapN c
qaTorapN: see qaTorN, in two places.

qaTiraAnN c
qaTiraAnN (S, Msb, K) and qiToraAnN (Msb, K) and qaToraAnN (K) [Tar, or liquid pitch;] what exudes from the tree called Oabohal, [or juniper, or the species of juniper called savin, both of which have this name in the present day,] (Msb, K, * TA,) and from the Oaroz [or pine-tree], and the like, (K, TA,) when subjected to the action of fire; (lit. when cooked;) used for smearing [mangy] camels, (Msb, TA,) &c.; (Msb;) i. q. hinaMCN. (S.) [See also zifotN.]

quTaArN c
quTaArN A cloud, (K,) or rain, (TA,) having large drops. (K, TA.)

qiTaArN c
qiTaArN A file, string, or series, of camels; a number of camels disposed in one series; (JK, Msb, K; *) one behind another; (JK;) [the halter of each, except the first, being tied to the tail of the next before it:] and the poet Abu-n-Nejm speaks of a qiTaAr of ants: (S:) of the measure fiEaAlN in the sense of the measure mafoEuwlN: (Msb:) pl. quTurN (S, Msb) and, (S,) or pl. pl., (Msb,) quTuraAtN; (S, Msb;) vulg. qiTaAraAtN. (TA.)

qaTuwrN c
qaTuwrN and miqoTaArN A cloud having many drops, or much rain. (Th, AAF, K.)

quTaArapN c
quTaArapN What drops, or drips, (maA qaTara,) from a jar (HubR) and the like: (Lh, S:) or from a thing. (K.) See also qaTorN. ― -b2- A small quantity of water. (Lh, K. *) Ex. fiI AlUinaMCi quTaArapN mino maMCK In the vessel is a little water. (Lh.)

qaATirN c
qaATirN Any gum that exudes in drops, or comes forth, (yaqoTuru,) from trees. (IDrd, K. *) ― -b2- AlqRATiru AlmakRiIRu: see damN in art. dmw. ― -b3- A camel whose urine continually dribbles. (S, K.)

qanoTarapN c
qanoTarapN and qinoTaArN &c.: see art. qnTr.

miqoTarapN c
miqoTarapN [A kind of stocks]: see EilobapN and falaqN.

maqoTuwrN c
maqoTuwrN. ― -b2- OaroDN maqoTuwrapN Land rained upon. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- baEiyrN maqoTuwrN, and muqaToranN↓, (S, K,) the latter after the form of the original [qaTiraAnN], (S, TA.) A camel smeared with qaTiraAn [or tar]. (S, K.)

muqaToranN c
muqaToranN: see maqoTuwrN.

Q. 1 qaToraba c
Q. 1. qaToraba, (K,) inf. n. qaTorabapN, (O,) He hastened, sped, or went quickly. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- And qaTorabahu He threw him down, or prostrated him, on the ground: (O, K: *) and so qaroTabahu. (O.)

Q. 2 taqaToraba c
Q. 2. taqaToraba He (a man, TA) moved about his head: and made himself to resemble the quTorub: (K:) or became like the quTorub in some one of the senses assigned to it in what follows. (TA.)

quTorubN c
quTorubN A certain bird; (S, O, K;) [app. a species of owl; accord. to Dmr, as cited by Freytag, a bird that roves about by night and does not sleep; and hence rendered by him, and by Golius, strix. No other meaning of the word, as an appellative, is mentioned in the S.] ― -b2- And A certain insect that rests not all the day, going about, or going about quickly, (O, K, TA,) or, as they used to assert in the Time of Ignorance, that never rests, (TA,) moving about on the surface of water. (KL.) Mohammad Ibn-El-Mustaneer, (K, TA,) the grammarian, (TA,) was surnamed quTorub because he used to go early in the morning to Seebaweyh; so that the latter, whenever he opened his door, found him there; wherefore he said to him, maA Oanota UilRaA quTorubu layolK [Thou art none other than a kutrub of night]. (K, * TA.) It is also expl. in the K as meaning Light, or active; and Th mentions that it signifies thus; and adds that one says, UinRahu laquTorubu layolK [Verily he is a kutrub of night]; but this shows that it means an insect [described above], and is not [properly speaking] an epithet. (TA.) To this insect is likened a man who labours during the day in accomplishing worldly wants and in the evening is fatigued so that he sleeps during the night until he enters upon the time of morning to betake himself to the like thereof, hecaA jiyfapu layoli quTorubu nahaArK [lit. This is a corpse of the night, a kutrub of the day]. (O, from an explanation of a trad.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 329 and 643.] ― -b3- And [hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) A thief who is skilful, or active, in thievishness: (O, M, TA:) for AllRiSRu AlfaArihu fiI AllRuSuwSiyRapi, an explanation of AlquTorubu given [in the O and] by IM and others, the copies of the K erroneously substitute AllRiSu waAlfaOorapu [as though quTorubN had the significations of a thief and a rat or mouse]. (TA.) ― -b4- And The male (Lth, O, K, TA) of the [kind of demon called] siEolaAp (Lth, TA) or of the guwl [which is said to signify the same as sElAp]; as also quToruwbN↓. (O, K, TA.) ― -b5- And [app. A young, or little, jinnee: thus quroTubN is expl. in the L: or] the young ones, or little ones, of the jinn. (K.) ― -b6- And A young, or little, dog: (O:) or the young ones, or little ones, of dogs. (K.) ― -b7- And A wolf such as is termed OamoEaT [i. e. whose hair has fallen off, part after part, or has become scanty; or mischievous, or malignant]. (O, K.) ― -b8- And An ignorant person, (O, K, TA,) who boasts by reason of his ignorance (yaZoharu bijaholihi). (O, TA.) ― -b9- And Cowardly, or a coward, (O, K, TA,) even if intelligent. (O, TA.) ― -b10- And Lightwitted; syn. safiyhN; (O, K, TA;) as also quToruwbN↓: and IAar has mentioned as a pl. in this sense, used by a poet, qaTaAriybu, which, ISd says, may be pl. of quToruwbN or of a sing. of some other form requiring such a form of pl., or it may be used as a pl. of quTorubN by poetic license. (TA.) ― -b11- And Thrown down, or prostrated, on the ground, syn. maSoruwEN, (O, K, TA,) by reason of diabolical possession or wrestling. (O, * TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A species of melancholia; (O, K, TA;) a well-known disease, arising from the black bile; (TA;) mostly originating in the month of XubaAT [February, O. S.]; vitiating, or disordering, the intellect, contracting the face, occasioning continual unhappiness, causing to wander about in the night, and rendering the face OaxoDar [here app. meaning of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour], the eyes sunken, and the body emaciated. (O.) [A more ample discription is given by Avicenna (Ibn-Seenà). in book iii. pp. 315, et seq. SM states that he had not found this in any other lexicon than the K. Golius explains the word as signifying Lycanthropia, on the authority of Rhazes (Er-Rázee).]

quToruwbN c
quToruwbN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

dictScrap.label: qTE qTf qTl qTm: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
qiTomiyrN c
qiTomiyrN (S, K) and qiTomaArN (K) The cleft (XaqR) of a date-stone: (M, K:) or the integument (qiXorap) that is upon it (fiyhaA): (K:) the thin skin (S, K) called fuwfap, which is upon a date-stone, (S,) between the stone and the date itself: (K:) or the white point [i. e. the embryo] in the back of the date-stone, (S, K,) from which [when it is sown] the palm-tree grows forth. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] (assumed tropical:) A small, mean, paltry, contemptible, thing. So the former signifies in the Kur, xxxv. 14. One says also maA OaSabotu minohu qiTomiyrFA, meaning, (assumed tropical:) I obtained not of him, or it, anything. (TA.)

dictScrap.label: qTn qTw: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
2 taqoEiybN c
2. taqoEiybN [as inf. n. of the pass. v. quERiba], used in relation to a solid hoof, means (tropical:) The being muqabRab [i. e. round, or hemispherical,] like the [drinking-cup, or bowl, called] qaEob. (K, TA. [See also muqaERabN.]) ― -b2- And AltRaqoEiybu signifies taqoEiyru AlkalaAmi; (K;) or taqoEiybu AlkalaAmi signifies taqoEiyruhu; (S, O;) [or AltRaqoEiybu fiI AlkalaAmi signifies AltRaqoEiyru fiyhi, i. e. (tropical:) The speaking with a guttural voice, or from the furthest part of the fauces; or the doing thus, with a twisting of the sides of the mouth; and opening the mouth so that it becomes as though it were a cup such as is called qaEob: (see muqaERibN:)] you say, qaERaba fiI kalaAmihi and qaERara; both meaning the same. (L, TA.)

Q. Q. 3 AiqoEanobaI c
Q. Q. 3. AiqoEanobaI He put his hands upon the ground, and sat in such a posture as to be ready to rise. (TA in art. qEnb, from a trad.)

qaEobN c
qaEobN A deep wooden drinking-cup or bowl: (S, O:) or a large vessel like the [bowl called] qaSoEap: (Msb:) or a large, rude, drinking-cup or bowl: (A, K:) or one inclining more nearly to be small: (A, K: *) to which a solid hoof is likened: (TA:) or such as satisfies the thirst of a man: (A, K:) accord. to IAar, the first [or smallest] of drinkingcups or bowls is that called the gumar, which does not hold enough to satisfy [a man's] thirst: next is the qaEob, which is [a cup] large enough to satisfy the thirst of a man; and sometimes it satisfies the thirst of two men, and three: and then, the EusR: (TA:) the pl. is qiEabapN (S, O, K) and (K) qiEaAbN and OaqoEubN, (Msb, K,) the last a pl. of paucity. (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Depth of speech, or language. (O, K, TA.) One says, hecaA kalaAmN lahu qaEobN (assumed tropical:) This is speech, or language, having depth. (TA.) ― -b3- And in the T, in art. qnE, the phrase qiEaAbu AlOaworaAqi is expl. as meaning OaqotaMCN biyDu AlOasonaAni [app. for AlbiyDu AlOasonaAni mina AlOafotaMCi i. e. The white in respect of the teeth, of the young; for AlAwrAq seems to be here used in a sense assigned to its sing., Alwaraqu, namely, AlOaHodaAvu, pl. of AlHadavu, which is syn. with AlfatiIRu, of which AlOafotaMCu is pl.: but for this usage of qiEaAb I am unable to account: I incline to think it a mistranscription, though I do not know any word resembling it for which it may have been substituted]. (TA.)

qaEobapN c
qaEobapN (assumed tropical:) A thing resembling [the kind of receptacle called] a HuqRap, pertaining to a woman: or a covered HuqRap for sawiyq [i. e. meal of parched barley or the like]: (K:) or a thing resembling a covered HuqRap in which is a woman's swyq. (O.)

quEobapN c
quEobapN (assumed tropical:) A [hollow, or cavity, such as is termed] nuqorap, in a mountain. (O, K.)

qaEiybN c
qaEiybN A large number: (K:) or a number: and a large number or quantity. (O.)

qaAEibN c
qaAEibN A wolf that howls much. (O, K.)

EuqaAbN qaEonabaApN c
EuqaAbN qaEonabaApN i. q. EqAb EaqanobaApN, (O, K,) formed by transposition, meaning [An eagle] having sharp talons. (O. [See more in art. Eqb.])

HaAfirN muqaERabN c
HaAfirN muqaERabN (tropical:) A solid hoof likened to a qaEob; (S, O;) round like the qaEob. (A.) ― -b2- And surRapN muqaERabapN (tropical:) A navel resembling a qaEob, (A, O, K,) sunk in the belly, and elevated in the part around it. (O.) ― -b3- And HajarN muqaERabN (tropical:) A stone in which is a hollow, or cavity, resembling the qaEob. (A.)

fulaAnN muqaERibo muqaERirN c
fulaAnN muqaERibo muqaERirN (tropical:) Such a one is a person who twists the sides of his mouth, and who speaks [with a guttural voice, or] with [or from] the furthest part of his fauces, and opens his mouth [making it to be] as though it were a [cup such as is called] qaEob. (A, TA.)

1 qaEavotu lahu qaEovapF c
1. qaEavotu lahu qaEovapF, (S, O, K, * TA, *) [accord. to which last, qaEovapN↓ is an inf. n., as also qaEovN, but, if an inf. n., it is app. an inf. n. un.,] aor.
qaEuva
, (accord. to the TK, [but I think it is more probably
qaEava
, agreeably with a general rule, like the aor. of the same verb in the next sentence,]) means Hafanotu lahu HafunapN, (S, O,) i. e. I gave to him a small quantity, (S, O, K, *) mina AlXRaIoCi [of the thing]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qaEava AlXRaIoCa, aor.
qaEava
, inf. n. qaEovN, He (a man) eradicated, or uprooted, the thing; (IDrd, O, L;) and (O) so qERvhu↓, inf. n. taqoEiyvN. (O, K.)

2 qaERava
2: see what immediately precedes.

4 AqEv fiI maAlihi c
4. AqEv fiI maAlihi He acted extravagantly in respect of his property. (ISk, S, O, K. *) ― -b2- And AqEv lahu AlEaTiyRapa He made the gift to him large; (S, O, K, TA;) and so AiqotaEavahaA↓, and AqEvhu [i. e. AqEvhu AlEaTiyRapa]. (TA. See the verse cited voce muqoEavN; and the remark of As respecting it.)

7 AnqEv c
7. AnqEv It was, or became, pulled out, or up, (As, S, O, TA,) from the foundation, or utterly; (As, S, TA;) it was, or became, eradicated, or uprooted. (K.) One says, Darabahu faQnoqaEava He struck it, and it became pulled out, or up, (As, S, O, TA,) from the foundation, or utterly. (As, S, TA.) ― -b2- And It (a wall) fell down from its foundation: like AnqEf. (As, S, O.)

8 AqtEv c
8. AqtEv He (a digger) took forth much earth from a well. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also 4.

qaEavN c
qaEavN Muchness, or abundance. (TA. [See qaEiyvN.])

qaEovapN c
qaEovapN: see the first sentence of this art.

quEaAvN c
quEaAvN A certain disorder in the noses of sheep, or goats: (O, K:) thus expl. by Aboo-Turáb. (O.)

qaEiyvN c
qaEiyvN, (O, K,) as expl. by As, (O,) Paltry, or little in quantity; syn. hayRinN and yasiyrN. (O, K. [See also muqoEavN.]) ― -b2- And Abundant, or copious; applied to rain: (S, O, K:) and to a benefit, or benefaction, &c.: (TA:) and to a gift (sayob): (O, TA:) and, (S, K, TA,) or as some say, (O,) to a torrent (sayol), (S, O, K,) as meaning thus, (S, O,) or as meaning great: (K:) whence, in a verse of Ru-beh,
maA XaMCa mino OabowaAbi kasobK miqoEavi↓
[What he will of the means of the attainment of abundant gain]; miqoEavN being of the measure mifoEalN from qaEiyvN as applied to rain &c. (O. [The word ksb, of which the right reading is certainly as above, is there imperfectly written, more like kusob than kasob.])

muqoEavN c
muqoEavN [pass. part. n. of 4]. Ru-beh says,
OaqoEavaniI minohu bisayobK muqoEavi
layosa bimanozuwrK walaA birayRivi
[He gave me liberally thereof, or from him, a large gift, (lit., accord. to the explanation of the verb, a gift made large,) not such as was small, or not such as was obtained by importunity, nor such as was slow in coming]: (S, * TA:) but As says that Ru-beh has done ill in using the phrase bsyb mqEv; for muqoEav, he says, means paltry, or little in quantity; syn. hayRinN and yasiyrN [like qaEiyvN, which is said to have this meaning and also the contr. thereof]. (TA. [Perhaps the right reading in the verse cited above is miqoEav↓.]

miqoEavN c
miqoEavN: see qaEiyvN. [See also what here immediately precedes.]

1 qaEada c
1. qaEada, (S, K, &c.,) aor.
qaEuda
, (A, L,) inf. n. quEuwdN and maqoEadN (S, L, K) and qaEodN, (L,) He sat; i. q. jalasa [when the latter is used in its largest sense]; (S, A, L, K;) so accord. to 'Orweh Ibn-Zubeyr, a high authority; contr. of qaAma: (L:) or it signifies he sat down; or sat after standing: and jls, he sat after lying on his side or prostrating himself: (Kh, IKh, El-Hareeree, K:) or, as some say, qEd signifies he sat for some length of time. (MF.) See also jalasa. ― -b2- [And hence, He remained.] ― -b3- qaAma waqaEada (tropical:) He experienced griefs which disquieted him so that he could not remain at rest, but stood up and sat down. (Mgh, art. qdm.) [See an ex. voce sudRapN.] hecaA XaIoCN yaqoEudu bihi Ealayoka AlEaduwRu wayaquwmu (tropical:) [This is a thing for which the enemy will be restless in his attempts against thee]. (A.) Darabahu Darobapa Qbonapi QqoEudiI waquwmiI He beat him with a beating of a female slave: (IAar, L, K: *) who is thus called because she sits and stands in the service of her masters, being ordered to do so. (IAar, L.) ― -b4- [qaEada lahu, properly, He sat for him, often means He lay in wait for him, in the road, or way: see an ex. in a verse cited voce sadRN.] ― -b5- qaEadati AlrRaxamapu (tropical:) The
aquiline vulture lay upon its breast on the ground; syn. javamat. (S, A, K.) See also jalasa. ― -b6- [Hence, from the notion of sitting down over against any one,] qaEada biqironihi (assumed tropical:) He was able to contend with his adversary. (L, K.) ― -b7- banuw fulaAnK libaniI fulaAnK yaqoEuduwna (assumed tropical:) The sons of such a one are able to contend with the sons of such a one, and come to them with their numbers. (L.) ― -b8- qaEaduwA EanRaA (assumed tropical:) They were able to contend for us, with their warriors, and to suffice us in war. (L.) ― -b9- qaEada liloHarobi (tropical:) He prepared for war those who should contend therein. (L, K.) ― -b10- qaEada liloOamori He performed the affair; syn. UihotamRa bihi. (Msb.) ― -b11- qaEada yaXotimuniI (tropical:) He set about, fell to, or commenced, reviling me. (Fr, A, L.) ― -b12- [And from the notion of sitting down in refusal or unwillingness,] qaEada Eani AlOamori (tropical:) He abstained from, omitted, neglected, left, relinquished, or forsook, the thing or affair; (A, Mgh;) he hung back, or held back, from it. (IKtt.) qaEada Eano HaAjatihi (tropical:) He hung, back, or held back, from accomplishing his want. (Msb.) qaEada Eani Alqawomi (assumed tropical:) He remained behind, or after, the people, or party, not going with them. (Msb, art. xlf.) And qaEadotu baEodahu [(assumed tropical:) I remained behind, or after, him;] as also qEdt xilaAfahu: (Msb, ibid.:) and qaEada xilaAfa OaSoHaAbihi, He remained behind, or after, his companions; he did not go forth with them (TA, in art. xlf) ― -b13- [qaEada maEahu and qaEada Uilayohi are like jalasa maEahu and jalasa Uilayohi, q. v.] ― -b14- qaEada bihi, see 4 in three places, and 5. ― -b15- qaEadato, inf. n. quEuwdN; (K;) or qaEadato Eani Alwaladi, (Mgh, K,) and AlHayoDi, (A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and AlzRawoji; (A, Msb, K;) (tropical:) She (a woman) ceased from bearing children, (A, Mgh, K,) and from having the menstrual discharge, and from having a husband. (A, K.) [And hence,] (tropical:) She (a woman) had no husband: (K, * TA:) said of her who is, and of her who is not, a virgin. (TA.) ― -b16- qaEadati AlnRaxolapu (tropical:) The palm-tree bore fruit one year and not another. (L, K.) ― -b17- qaEada maqaAEida riqaAqFA (assumed tropical:) [He had thin evacuations of the bowels: see sadRa] (TA, in art. sk.) ― -b18- qaEadN Laxness (S, K) and depression (S) in the shank (waZiyf) of a camel. (S, K.) [App. an inf. n., of which the verb is qaEida. But see 1 in art. Sdf.] ＝ -A2- qaEada It [or he] became; syn. SaAra. Ex. HadRada Xaforatahu HatRaI qaEadato kaOanRahaA HarobapN He sharpened his large knife so that it became as though it were a javelin. And vawobaka laA taqoEudu taTiyru bihi AlrRiyHu [in the CK, vawobuka and yaqoEudu] Take care of thy garment, that the wind do not become flying away with it. (IAar, L, K. *) vwbk is here in the acc. case because the verb AiHofaZo is understood before it. (L.) ― -b2- qaEadati Mlfasiylapu (tropical:) The young palm-tree came to have a trunk. (S, A, K.) ＝ -A3- qaEada He (a man, AZ) stood. Thus it bears two contr. significations. (AZ, L, K.)

2 qaERadotuka QllReha c
2. qaERadotuka QllReha I beg God to perserve, keep, guard, or watch, thee. See qaEiydaka QllReha. (Aboo- 'Alee, IB, L.) See also 4 in two places, and 5.

3 qAEdhu c
3. qAEdhu He sat with him. (L.) [See also an ex. in art. sfh, conj. 3.]

4 AqEdhu c
4. AqEdhu, (S, L, K,) and bihi qaEada↓, (L, K,) He caused him to sit, or sit down; he seated him. (S, L.) ― -b2- OuqoEida (tropical:) He was affected by a disease in his body which deprived him of the power to walk: (Msb:) he was unable to rise: (L:) [as though constrained to remain sitting: see muqoEadN, and quEaAdN.] ― -b3- OaqoEadahu Alharamu (tropical:) [Decrepitude crippled him, or deprived him of the power of motion]. (A.) ― -b4- OuqoEida He (a man) was, or became, lame. (S, L.) ― -b5- UiqoEaAdN in the hind leg of a horse is Its being much expanded (An tuforaXa jidRFA), so that it is not erect. (S, L.) ― -b6- OuqoEida He (a camel) had the disease called quEaAd. (IKtt, L.) ― -b7- OaqaAmahu waOaqoEadahu, and qaAma bihi waqaEada↓, (tropical:) He, or it, caused him to experience griefs which disquieted him so that he could not remain at rest, making him to stand up and sit down. (See 1, and muqoEidN. And see an ex. in a verse cited in art. fnI, conj. 3.] ― -b8- AqEd AlbiYora He dug the well to the depth of a man sitting: or he left it upon the surface of the ground, and did not dig it so as to reach water. (L, K.) See also muqoEadapN. ― -b9- AqEd (Ibn-Buzurj, L) and UiqoEanodada↓ (K) He remained, stayed, abode, or dwelt, in a place. (Ibn-Buzurj, L, K.) ＝ -A2- AqEdhu and qERdhu↓ (inf. n. of the latter taqoEiydN) He sufficed him (namely his father [but in the CK, instead of OabaAhu, we read UiyRaAhu,]) for gaining, or earning; (K, TA;) and aided, or assisted, him. (TA.) ― -b2- AqEdhu and qERdhu↓ (inf. n. of the latter taqoEiydN, K) He served him. (IAar, L, K.) [Ex.] maA lifulaAnK QmoraOapN tuqoEiduhu, and tuqaERiduhu, [Such a one has no wife to serve him]. (A.) ＝ -A3- AqEdhu MbaAWuhu, and tqERdhu↓, (tropical:) His ancestors withheld him from eminence, or nobility; (L;) [as also bihi qaEada↓, and AqtEdhu↓. You say also,] bihi Eano nayoli maA qaEada↓ AlmasaAEiI UilRaA luWomu EunoSurihi, and mA tqERdhu↓, and mA AqtEdhu↓, (tropical:) [Nothing withheld him from attaining to the means of honour and elevation but the baseness of his origin]. (A.) See also 5. ― -b2- wirovuhu biAlUiqoEaAdi (assumed tropical:) [His inheritance is by reason of nearness of relationship]. You do not say biAlquEuwdi (L.) ― -b3- UiqoEaAdN (tropical:) The having few ancestors. (IAar, L.)

5 tqERdhu c
5. tqERdhu (tropical:) He, or it, withheld, restrained, debarred, or prevented, him from attaining the thing that he wanted. (S, L, K.) Ex. maA taqaERadaniI Eanoka UilRaA XugolN Nothing but business withheld me from thee. (ISk, S.) See also 4. You say also biI Eanoka XugolN qaEada↓ Business withheld me from thee. (TA.) [And so,] maA qaERadaka↓, and maA QqotaEadaka↓, what hath withheld, restrained, debarred, or prevented, thee? (L.) ― -b2- tqERd Eani AlOamori, (S, A, L, K,) and tqAEd↓, (A,) (tropical:) He did not seek, seek for or after, or desire, the thing. (S, A, L, K.) See also 1. ― -b3- tqERd signifies He held back, or refrained. (KL.) ― -b4- And also He held back, or restrained. (KL.) ― -b5- tqERdhu He performed his affair. (IAar, Th, L, K.)

6 tqAEd bihi fulaAnN c
6. tqAEd bihi fulaAnN (assumed tropical:) Such a one did not pay him his due. (S, L.) ＝ -A2- See also 5.

8 AqtEd c
8. AqtEd He rode a camel: (L, Msb:) he took, or used, a camel as a quEodap q. v. (L, K.) ― -b2- AqtEd qaEiydapF [He took a seat of the kind called qEydp to sit upon]. (L.)

R. Q. 3 UiqoEanodada c
R. Q. 3. UiqoEanodada: see 4.

qaEodaka MllReha c
qaEodaka MllReha and qiEodaka, see qaEiydaka MllReha throughout.

qaEadN c
qaEadN Human dung. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- See also qaAEidN in two places.

qaEodapN c
qaEodapN A single sitting. (S, L, Msb.) Ex. qaEada qaEodapF waAHidapF He sat a single sitting. (L.) ― -b2- qaEodapu rajulK, see qiEodapN in three places. ＝ -A2- And see qaAEidN. ＝ -A3- cuw AlqaEodapi, and cuw AlqiEodapi, A certain month; (S, L, K;) [the eleventh month of the Arabian year;] next after XawRaAl: (L:) so called because the Arabs [when their year was solar] used to abstain (yaqoEuduwna) therein from journeys (L, K, * TA) and warring and plundering expeditions and laying in stores of corn and seeking pasturage, before performing the pilgrimage in the next month; (L, TA;) or because in that month they broke in the young camels (AlqiEodaAn) for riding: (Msb, voce jumaAdaI:) pl. cawaAtu AlqaEodapi (S, L, Msb, K) and cawaAtu AlqaEadaAti; (Yoo, Msb;) but the former is the regular pl., (Yoo,) because the two words are considered as one, (Msb,) and it is the more common: (TA:) dual cawaAtaA AlqaEodapi and cawaAtaA AlqaEodatayoni. (Msb.)

quEodapN c
quEodapN, (K,) or quEadapN↓, (L,) An ass: (L, K:) pl. quEodaAtN, (K,) with the E quiescent, (TA,) [in the CK, quEodaAnN,] or quEadaAtN. (L.) ＝ -A2- [The former,] A horse's, and a camel's saddle: (L, K:) pl. quEudaAtN, (IDrd, L,) with which is syn. quEayodaAtN [the dim.]. (S, L.) ― -b2- See qaEuwdN.

qiEodapN c
qiEodapN A mode, or manner, of sitting. (S, L, Msb, K.) Ex. huwa Hasanu AlqiEodapi He has a good manner of sitting: (A, L:) and qaEada qiEodapa AldRubRi He sat in the manner of sitting of the bear. (A, * TA.) ― -b2- qiEodapu rajulK, and rajulK qaEodapu↓, (L, K, *) The space occupied by a man sitting: (L, K:) and the height, or depth, of a man sitting. (L.) Ex. XajarapN qiEodapu rajulK A tree of the height of a man sitting: (AHn, in L and TA, passim:) and biYorN qiEodapN A well of the depth of a man sitting: (As:) and Eumoqu biYorinaA qiEodapN, and qaEodapN↓, The depth of our well is that of a man sitting: (L:) and
maA Hafarotu fiI AlOaroDi UilRaA qiEodapF, and qaEodapF↓, I dug not in the ground save to the depth of a man sitting: (Lh, L:) and mararotu bimaMCK qiEodapi rajulK I passed by water of the depth of a man sitting. (Sb, L.) ＝ -A2- qiEodapN One's last child, male or female; and one's last children. (K.)

qaEadapN c
qaEadapN A vehicle, or beast of carriage, (marokabN,) for women: so in the copies of the K in our hands; (S, M;) but accord. to the L, &c., of a man: and it is qaEiydapN↓ that bears the former signification. (TA.) ― -b2- The [kind of carpet called] Tanofasap [q. v.] (L, K) upon which a man sits; and the like. (L.)

quEadapN c
quEadapN see quEodapN and quEodiIRN.

quEodadN c
quEodadN: see the next paragraph.

quEodudN c
quEodudN (tropical:) Nearness of relationship. (L.) ― -b2- cuw quEodudK A man nearly related to [the father of] the tribe. (Lh.) [And] quEodudN and quEodadN↓ (S, K) and quEoduwdN↓ and OaqoEadu↓ and AlnRasabi qaEiydu↓, (L, K,) (tropical:) A man near in lineage to the chief, or oldest, ancestor [of his family or tribe]; (S, L, K;) contr. of TarifN and TariyfN: (S, M, K in art. Trf:) and the first, The next of kin to the chief, or oldest, ancestor [of his family]; (Msb;) and contr., remote in lineage therefrom: (L, K:) [in the former sense, an epithet of praise:] in the latter sense, an epithet of dispraise: or, as some say, of praise: (TA:) or, in the first sense, it is an epithet of praise in one point of view, because dominion, or power, or authority, belong to the elder; and of dispraise in another point of view, because the person so termed is of the sons of the very old, and weakness is attributed to him. (S.) ― -b3- AlmiyraAvu AlquEodudu (tropical:) The inheritance of him who is nearest of kin to the deceased. (L.) ― -b4- quEodudN (assumed tropical:) A cowardly and ignoble man, who holds back, or abstains, from war and from generous actions; (L, K; *) as also quEodadN↓. (L.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) A man withheld from eminence, or nobility, by his lineage; as also muqoEadN↓. (Az, L.) ― -b6- (assumed tropical:) An obscure man; (L, K;) ignoble; of low rank; as also quEodadN↓. (Az, L.)

quEodaI c
quEodaI [A nearer degree in lineage to the chief, or oldest, ancestor, than TurofaI, q. v.]

quEodiIRN c
quEodiIRN and qiEodiIRN, and both with p, and DujoEiIRN and DijoEiIRN, (K,) and DujaEapN quEadapN↓, (S, K,) A man (S) who sits much and lies much upon his side: (S, K:) or the last, an impotent man, who does not earn that whereby he may subsist; (A;) [and the first two] (assumed tropical:) A man impotent; or lacking power, or ability; (L, K;) as though preferring sitting: (L:) or loving to sit in his house. (A.)

qaEadiIRN c
qaEadiIRN (tropical:) A man belonging to the sect called AlqaEadu, (L,) or AlqaEadapu; (A [see qaAEidN];) who holds the opinions of that sect. (L, K.) ― -b2- Also applied by a post-classical poet to (tropical:) A man who refuses to drink wine while he approves of others' drinking it. (L.)

quEaAdN c
quEaAdN Lameness in a man. You say mataI OaSaAbaka hecaA AlquEaAdu When did this lameness befall thee? (S, L;) [and] bihi quEaAdN, (L, K,) and UiqEAd↓, (K,) and OaqoEaAdN↓, (CK,) (tropical:) He has a disease which constrains him to remain sitting. (L, K.) See OuqoEida, and muqoEadN. ― -b2- quEaAdN also signifies, (S, L, K,) and so UiqoEaAdN↓, (S, L,) or OaqoEaAdN↓, with fet-h, (accord. to the K,) A certain disease which affects camels in their haunches, and makes them to incline (or as though their rumps inclined, IAar) towards the ground: (S, K:) or a laxness of the haunches. (IKtt.)

qiEaAdN c
qiEaAdN: see qaEiydN.

qaEuwdN c
qaEuwdN A young weaned camel: (L, K:) and a young she-camel; i. q. qaluwSN: (K:) or this latter epithet is applied to a female and the former to a male young camel: (ISh, L, Msb:) so called because he is ridden: (Msb:) and a young male camel, until he enters his-sixth year: (K:) or a young male camel when it may be ridden, which is at the earliest when he is two years old, after which he is thus called until he enters his sixth year, when he is called jamalN: the young she-camel is not called thus, but is termed qaluwSN: (S, L:) Ks heard the term qaEuwdapN applied to the female; but this is rare. (Az, L.) ― -b2- A camel which the pastor rides, or uses, in every case of need; (A'Obeyd, S, L, K;) called in Persian raxoto; (A'Obeyd, S, L;) as also qaEuwdapN↓, (K,) accord. to Lth, the only authority for it known to Az; but Kh says that this signifies a camel which the pastor uses for carrying his utensils &c., and that the p is added to give intensiveness to the epithet; (TA;) or the former is masc. and the latter fem.; (Ks, L;) and quEodapN↓: (S, K:) you say niEoma AlquEodapu hecaA, i. e. AlmuqotaEadu, [an excellent camel for the pastor's ordinary riding, or use, is this]: (S, L:) or each of these words signifies a camel which the pastor uses for riding and for carrying his provisions and utensils &c.: and quEodapN, a camel which a man rides whenever and wherever he will: (L:) the pl. of qaEuwdN is OaqoEidapN [a pl. of pauc.] and quEudN and qiEodaAnN and qaEaAYidu; (L, K;) and pl. pl. [i. e. pl. of qiEodaAnN] qaEaAdiynu. (TA.) The dim of qaEuwdN is quEayRidN. It is said in a proverb, UitRaxacuwhu quEayRida AlHaAjaAti They made him an ordinary servant for the performance of needful affairs. (S, L.)

qaEiydN c
qaEiydN A companion in sitting: (S, AHeyth, L, K:) of the measure faEiylN in the sense of the measure mufaAEilN. (L.) ― -b2- A preserver; a keeper; a guardian; a watcher. (L, K.) [In some copies of the K, by the omission of wa, this meaning is assigned to muqaAEidN.] It is used alike as sing. and pl. and masc. and fem. (L, K) and dual also. (L.) It is said in the Kur, [l. 16,] Eani Alyamiyni waEani AlXimaAli qaEiydN [On the right and on the left a sitter, or guardian, or watcher]: respecting which it is observed, that faEiylN and faEuwlN are of the measures used alike as sing. and dual and pl.; as in UinRaA rasuwlu rabRika, [Kur xi. 83, accord. to one reading,] and waAlmalaAYikapu baEoda celika ZahiyrN, [Kur lxvi. 4:] (S, L:) or, as the grammarians say, qaEiydN is understood after Alymyn. (L.) ― -b3- [Hence,] A father; (A'Obeyd, K;) and qaEiydapN↓ A man's wife; (S, L, K; *) as also qiEaAdN↓: (S, L:) and qaEiydapu bayoti rajulK a man's wife: pl. qaEaAYidu. (L.) ― -b4- qaEiydaka QllReha, and QllReha qaEodaka↓, and QllReha qiEodaka↓, (K,) but the last was unknown to AHeyth, (L,) [By thy Watcher, or Keeper, God: qEyd and qEd↓ being epithets, put in the acc. case because of the prep. bi understood: or] I conjure thee by God; syn. naXadotuka QllReha: some say, the meaning is, as though God were sitting with thee, watching over thee, or keeping thee: [in some copies of the K, for biHifoZihi Ealayoka, the reading in the TA, we find yaHofaZuhu Ealayoka:] or by thy Companion, who is the Companion of every secret, [namely God]! qaEiydaka laA Mtiyka, and lA Atyk qiEodaka↓; and qaEiydaka QllReha lA Atyk, and QllReha lA Atyk qiEodaka↓; are forms of swearing used by the Arabs, in which qEyd and qEd↓ are inf. us. put in the acc. case because of a verb understood; [or rather, as it appears to me, and as I have said above, they are epithets, put in the acc. case because of the prep. bi understood;] and the meaning is, By thy Companion, who is the Companion of every secret, [I will not come to thee; and by thy Companion, &c., or by thy Watcher, or Keeper, God, I will not come to thee;] like as one says naXadotuka QllReha: (S, L:) some say, that qEyd and qEd↓ signify here a watcher, or an observer, and a preserver, a keeper, or a guardian, that God is meant by them, and that they are in the acc. case because Ouqosimu followed by the prep. bi is understood; [the meaning being I swear by thy Watcher, or Keeper, &c., God, &c.; and this opinion is the more agreeable with the explanation given above, “ By thy Companion &c. ”:] others say, that they are inf. ns., and that the meaning is, I swear by thy regard, or fear, of God, bimuraAqabatika QllReha: El-Mázinee and others, however, assert that qEyd has no verb. (MF.) ― -b5- Ks says that QllRehu qiEodaka↓ [AllReh being in the nom. case] signifies God be with thee! (L.) [or God be thy Companion, or Watcher, or Keeper!]; and so does qaEiydaka AllRehu. (AHeyth, L.) [Or] qaEiydaka QllReha, (IB, L, K,) and qiEodaka QllReha, (K,) and qaEodaka QllReha, (IB, L, TA,) [are] expressions of conciliation, not oaths, as they have not the complement of an oath: the former word in each is an inf. n. occupying the place of a verb, and therefore is put in the acc. case, as in Eamoraka QllReha, which means EamRarotuka QllReha, i. e., I beg God to prolong thy life: in like manner, qaERadotuka QllReha [in the K, qiEodaka,] signifies, [and so the three first phrases above, of which it is the original form,] I beg God to preserve, keep, guard, or watch, thee; from the saying in the Kur, [l. 16,] Eani Alyamiyni waEani AlXRimaAli qaEiydN, i. e. HafiyZN. (Aboo-'Alee, IB, L, K. *) qaEiyda kumaA QllReha is used in interrogative phrases and in phrases conveying an oath, [and so is
qaEiydaka QllReha]. You say, interrogatively, qaEibdakumaA QllReha Oalamo yakuno kacaA wakacaA [I beg God to preserve, keep, guard, or watch, thee. Was it not so and so?]: and in the other case, qaEiydaka QllReha laOukorimanRaka [By thy Watcher, or Keeper, God, I will assuredly pay thee honour!] (Th, L.) ― -b6- [And from the signification of ' father ' is derived] the phrase qaEiydaka latafoEalanRa, By thy father, thou shalt assuredly do such a thing. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- What comes to thee from behind thee, (S, L, K,) of gazelles or birds (L, K) or wild animals: contr. of naTyHN: (S, L:) of evil omen. (L.) ＝ -A3- The locust of which the wings are not yet perfectly formed. (S, K.)

qaEiydapN c
qaEiydapN A thing like the [kind of receptacle called] Eayobap, (L, K,) woven by women, (L,) upon which one sits: (L, K:) pl. qaEaAYidu. (L.) ― -b2- See qaEadapN ＝ -A2- A [sack of the kind called] giraArap: (S, K:) or the like thereof, in which are put qadiyd [or pieces of flesh-meat, q. v.] and kaEok: (L, K:) pl. qaEaAYidu. (S, L.) ＝ -A3- A sand that is not of an oblong form: (S, L, K:) or a long tract of sand like a rope, cleaving to the ground: (L, K:) or a heap of sand collected together. (L.) ＝ -A4- See also qaEiydN.

qaERaAdapN c
qaERaAdapN A [seat, or couch, of the kind called] sariyr: of the dial. of El-Yemen. (TA.)

qaAEidN c
qaAEidN [act. part. n. of qaEada] Sitting; sitting down; pl. quEuwdN (Msb) and quERaAdN and qaAEiduwna: (TA:) fem. qaAEidapN; pl. qawaAEidu and qaAEidaAtN. (Msb.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) A sack full of grain; (IAar, K;) as though by reason of its fulness it were sitting. (IAar.) ― -b3- [And from qaEada in the third meaning,] qaAEidN Eani Algazowi (tropical:) A man holding back, or abstaining, from warring and plundering: pl. quERaAdN and qaAEiduwna; and quasi-pl. n. qaEadN: (L:) which last is also explained as signifying those who have no diywaAn [or register in which they are enrolled as soldiers and stipendiaries], (S, A, L, K,) and (as some say, L) who do not go forth to fight. (L, K.) ― -b4- [And hence, the pl.] qaEadN, [which is, properly speaking, a quasi-pl. n.,] like HaArisN and HarasN, (S,) and xaAdimN and xadamN: (TA:) [The Abstainers, or Separatists:] the qaEad (so in the S, L, K: in the A, and some copies of the K, qaEadap↓:) are (tropical:) The [schismatics called] xawaArij: (K:) or certain of the xwArj; (S;) a people of the xwArj who held back (qaEaduwA) from aiding 'Alee, and from fighting against him; (A;) certain of the HaruwriyRap; (L;) the [schismatics called] XuraAp, who hold the doctrine that government belongs only to God, but do not war; (IAar, L;) who hold the doctrine that government belongs only to God, but do not go forth to war against a people. (L.) ― -b5- [And the sing.,] qaAEidN (tropical:) A woman who has ceased to bear children, (S, K,) and to have the menstrual discharge, (ISk, S, K,) and to have a husband: (Zj, K:) or an old woman, advanced in years: (IAth:) pl. qawaAEidu: (ISk, S:) when you mean “ sitting, ” you say qaAEidapN. (ISk, IAth.) ― -b6- naxolapN qaAEidapN (tropical:) A palm-tree bearing fruit one year and not another: (A, TA:) or, that has not borne fruit in its year. (IKtt.) ― -b7- Also, qaAEidN, A palm-tree: or a young palm-tree: pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] qaEadN, like as xadamN is of xaAdimN. (L.) ― -b8- qaAEidN (tropical:) A young palm-tree having a trunk: (A, K:) or, [of] which [the branches] may be reached by the hand. (S, K.) Ex. fiI OaroDihimo kacaA mina AlqaAEidi In their land are so many young palm-trees having trunks. (A.) Thus it is used us a gen. n. (TA.) ＝ -A2- raHFI qaAEidapN A mill which one turns by the handle with the hand. (L.) ＝ -A3- Halabota qaAEidFA: see art. Hlb.

qaAEidapN c
qaAEidapN A foundation, or basis, of a house: (Msb:) pl. qawaAEidu: (S, Msb:) which signifies, accord. to Zj, the columns, or poles, (OasaATiyn) of a structure, which support it. (L.) [Hence,] qaAEidataA AlbaAbi [The two side-posts of the door]. (K, in art. swm.) ― -b2- banaI Oamorahu EalaI qaAEidapK, and ElI qawaAEida, (tropical:) [He built his affair upon a firm foundation, and, upon firm foundations]. And qaAEidapu Oamorika waAhiyapN (tropical:) [The foundation of thine affair is unsound]. (A.) ― -b3- qawaAEidu AlsRaHaAbi (tropical:) The lower parts of clouds extending across the view in the horizon, likened to the foundations of a building: (A'Obeyd, L:) or clouds extending across the view, and lying low. (IAth, L.) ― -b4- [Hence] qawaAEidu Alhawodaji The four pieces of wood, (S, K,) placed transversely, [two across the other two, so as to form a square frame,] beneath the hwdj (S, K,) which is fixed upon them. (K.) [See 1 in art. fXl.] ＝ -A2- As a conventional term, i. q. DaAbiTN, i. e. (assumed tropical:) A universal, or general, rule, or canon. (Msb.) [See DaAbiT.]

OaqoEadu c
OaqoEadu A camel having a laxness and depression in the shank. See qaEadN. (TA.) But see OaSodafa ＝ -A2- fulaAnN OaqoEadu mino fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one is more nearly related to his chief, or oldest, ancestor than such a one. (IAar, IAth, L.) See also quEodudN.

maqoEadN c
maqoEadN A place of sitting; a sitting-place; (L, Msb, K;) as also maqoEadapN↓: (L, K:) pl. of the former maqaAEidu, (Msb,) signifying sittingplaces of people in the markets &c. (S.) huwa minRiI maqoEada AlqaAbilapi [He is, with respect to me, as though in the sitting-place of the midwife;] i. e., in nearness; meaning he is sticking close to me, before me: (Sb, S:) denoting nearness of station. (Sb, L.) See also maEoqidN. ― -b2- [Hence, (tropical:) a place of abode,] tarakuwA maqaAEidahumo, (tropical:) They left their places of abode. (A.) ― -b3- A time of sitting. (MF.) ― -b4- AlmaqoEadapu↓ The anus [as is shown in the S and Msb, voce baAsuwr &c., and so in modern Arabic; and app. also the posteriors, upon which one sits]: syn. AlsRaAflapu. (S, Msb.)

muqoEadN c
muqoEadN (tropical:) Having a disease which constrains him to remain sitting: (K:) or crippled, or deprived of the power of motion, by a disease in his body; (Mgh, L;) as though the disease constrained him to remain sitting: (Mgh:) or deprived of the power to stand, by protracted disease; as though constrained to remain sitting: (L:) or affected by a disease in his body depriving him of the power to walk: (Msb:) a lame man (S, L:) also, i. q. zaminN: (Msb:) accord. to the physicians, muqoEadN and zaminN are syn.; [see the second explanation above, which is that here indicated;] but some make a distinction, and say that the former signifies having the limbs contracted, and the latter, having a protracted disease; (Mgh;) [which is app. one of the two significations assigned to the former word in the Msb:] accord. to some, it is from quEaAdN signifying a disease which affects camels in their haunches: (L:) [and] muqoEadN [is applied to] a camel having this disease. (L.) ― -b2- muqoEadu AlnRasabi, and mqEd AlOasobaAbi, (assumed tropical:) A man of short lineage. (L.) ― -b3- muqoEadu AlHasabi (assumed tropical:) A man without eminence, or nobility. (L.) See also quEodudN. ＝ -A2- muqoEadu AlOanofi (tropical:) A man having wide nostrils: (K:) or having wide and short nostrils. (A, L.) vadoIN muqoEadN (tropical:) A breast that is swelling, prominent, or protuberant, (S, A, L, K,) that fills the hand, (A,) and has not yet become folding. (S, L, K.) ＝ -A3- biYorN muqoEadapN A well that is partly dug, and then left before the water has come into it; (K;) i. q. musohabapN. (TA.) ＝ -A4- muqoEadaAtN (tropical:) Young birds of the kind called qaTFA, before they rise (L, K) to fly. (L.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Frogs. (A, L, K.)

Oaxacahu Almuqiymu AlmuqoEidu c
Oaxacahu Almuqiymu AlmuqoEidu (tropical:) (A) Griefs took hold upon him, disquieting him so that he could not remain at rest, and making him to stand up and sit down: a phrase similar to Oaxacahu maA qaduma wamaA Haduva, and maA qaruba wamaA baEuda. (Mgh, art. qdm.) ＝ -A2- muqoEidN and muqaERidN↓ A servant. (IAar, L.)

maqoEadahN c
maqoEadahN and AlmaqoEadapu: see maqoEadu.

muqoEadapu c
muqoEadapu and muqoEadaAtN: see muqoEadN.

muqaERidN c
muqaERidN: see muqoEidN.

1 qaEurati AlbiYoru c
1. qaEurati AlbiYoru, aor.
qaEura
, inf. n. qaEaArapN, The well was deep; had a deep bottom. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- qaEara AlbiYora, (S, K,) aor.
qaEara
, inf. n. qaEorN, (TA,) He reached the bottom of the well; (K;) he descended the well until he reached the bottom of it: (S:) or the same verb; (IAar, K;) or qaERarahaA↓, (A,) inf. n.
taqoEiyrN; (S;) and OaqoEarahaA↓; (A;) he made the well deep. (IAar, S, * A, K.) ― -b2- qaEara AlUinaMCa, (S, K,) or tqERrhu↓, (A,) (tropical:) He drank what was in the vessel, (S, A. K,) or all that was in the vessel, (TA,) until he came to the bottom of it. (S, A, TA.) And in like manner, qaEara AlvRariydapa (tropical:) He ate the vrydp [or mess of crumbled bread moistened with broth] from the bottom of it. (K.) ― -b3- qaEara AlXRajarapa, (S, A,) inf. n. qaEorN, (S,) (tropical:) He pulled out the tree from its root; uprooted it. (S, A.) And qaEara AlnRaxolapa, aor.
qaEara
, (tropical:) He cut down the palm-tree from its root. (K.) And qaEarahu (assumed tropical:) He threw him down prostrate. (K.)

2 qaERara
2: see 1. ― -b2- qaERara fiI kalaAmihi He twisted the sides of his mouth in his speaking, and spoke with the furthest part of his mouth; as also tqERr↓: (K:) or both signify, he spoke [gutturally, or] with the furthest part of his fauces: (TA:) [he was guttural in his speech, or spoke with a guttural voice.] See qERb.

4 AqEr AlbiYora c
4. AqEr AlbiYora He made a bottom to the well. (S, K.) ― -b2- See also 1.

5 tqERr c
5. tqERr He went deep; syn. taEamRaqa. (S.) See EajorafiyRap. ― -b2- (tropical:) He, or it, became prostrated, and overturned. (TA.) [See also 7.] ＝ -A2- tqERr AlUinaMCa: see 1.

7 AnqErt AlXRajarapu c
7. AnqErt AlXRajarapu, (S, A,) or AlnRaxolapu, (K,) (tropical:) The tree, (S, A,) or palm-tree, (K,) became uprooted, (S, A, K,) and fell prostrate; (TA;) it fell down: (K:) or, as some say, it went into the bottom [or depth] of the earth [and disappeared, leaving no mark nor trace: see the part. n., below]: (TA:) and, accord. to some, AnqEr, said of anything, signifies it became prostrated. (TA.) [See also 5.] ― -b2- AnqEr Eano maAlK lahu (assumed tropical:) He died, leaving property that belonged to him: (TA, from a trad.:) and AnqEr [simply] he died. (TA.)

qaEorN c
qaEorN The bottom, lowest depth, or extremity of the lower part, [of the interior,] of a thing; (Msb;) i. q. EumoqN, of a well &c.; (S;) the remotest part of anything; (A, K;) [as, for instance,] of a river, (TA,) and of a vessel; (S, A;) pl. quEuwrN. (Msb, K.) You say jalasa fiI qaEori bayotihi, [lit., He sat in the innermost part of his house,] meaning (assumed tropical:) he kept in his house. (Msb.) And laA Oadoxulu Ealayohi qaEora Albayoti, and qaEiyratahu↓, and qaEoratahu↓, all signify the same [I will not go in to him in the innermost part of the house; or (assumed tropical:) I will not be an intimate in his house]. (TA.) ― -b2- [Depth, properly and tropically. You say] cahaba fI qaEori AlOaroDi [It (a tree or the like) went into the depth of the earth]. (TA.) And fulaAnN baEiydu AlqaEori (A, TA) (tropical:) Such a one is deep and excellent in judgment; one who examines deeply. (TA.) And layosa likalaAmihi qaEorN (tropical:) [His speech, or language, has not depth]. (A, TA.) ― -b3- The root, or lower or lowest part, of a palm-tree [or the like]. (TA.) ― -b4- A hollow in the ground, such as is called a jawobap, (K, TA,) the descent into which and the ascent from which are difficult; (TA;) as also qaEorapN↓. ― -b5- A city, or town; syn. baladN; (K;) such as El-Basrah or ElKoofeh. (AZ.) You say maA fiI hecaA AlqaEori mivoluhu There is not in this city, or town, the like of him. (K.) And maA xaraja mino Oaholi hecaA AlqaEori OaHadN mivoluhu, like as you say mino Oaholi hecaA AlgaAYiTi, There came not forth, of the people of this city, or town, any one like him. (AZ.) ― -b6- A [bowl, such as is called] jafonap. (Fr, IAar, K.)

qaEarN c
qaEarN Intellect, or intelligence: (K:) or full, or perfect, [or profound,] intellect or intelligence. (IAar, TA.) [See also qaEorN.]

qaEorapN c
qaEorapN: see qaEorN, in two places. ― -b2- What covers the bottom of a bowl; as also quEorapN↓. (K.) See qaEoraAnu.

quEorapN c
quEorapN: see qaEorapN.

qaSoEapN qaEirapN c
qaSoEapN qaEirapN: see qaEoraAnu. ― -b2- See also XafirapN.

qaEoraAnu c
qaEoraAnu A drinking-cup or bowl (qadaHN) made deep; i. q. muqaERarN. (S.) ― -b2- (tropical:) A vessel nearly full: (A:) or a vessel having something in its bottom: (K:) fem. qaEoraI: (TA:) and qaSoEapN qaEoraI, and qaEarpN↓, (tropical:) a bowl having in it what covers its bottom. (K, TA.)

qaEuwrN c
qaEuwrN: see qaEiyrN, in two places.

qaEiyrN c
qaEiyrN Deep; having a remote bottom; (A, K;) applied to a river; as also qaEuwrN↓, accord. to the K; but this is not mentioned by any one before the author of the K, and is a mistake for qaERuwrN↓, which occurs afterwards in the K. (TA.) You say biYorN qaEiyrapN, (A,) and qaERuwrN↓, (K, TA,) A deep well; (K, TA;) a well having a remote bottom. (TA.) And qaSoEapN qaEiyrapN (S, A) (tropical:) A deep bowl. (TA.) qaEuwrN↓ is also applied as an epithet to a woman's vulva: (Ibn-Habeeb, TA in art. xjI:) and, accord. to the K, to a woman. (TA in that art.)

qaEiyrapN c
qaEiyrapN: see qaEorN: ― -b2- and qaEiyrN. ― -b3- See also XafiyrapN.

qaERuwrN c
qaERuwrN: see qaEiyrN.

OaqoEaru c
[OaqoEaru Deeper.]

miqoEarN c
miqoEarN, (so in a copy of the A,) or muqaERarN↓, like muEaZRamN [in measure], (so in the TA,) [but the former I think the correct form, being agreeable with analogy,] A man who reaches the bottoms, or utmost points, of things, or affairs. (A, TA.)

muqaERarN c
muqaERarN: see qaEoraAnu: ― -b2- and miqoEarN.

muqaERirN c
muqaERirN: see muqaERbN in art. qEb.

miqoEaArN c
miqoEaArN, applied to a [cup of the kind called] qaEob, Wide and deep. (K.)

munoqaEirN c
munoqaEirN Uprooted. So in the Kur, [liv. 20,] kaOanRahumo OaEojaAzu naxolK munoqaEirK As though they were the lower parts of palm-trees uprooted: (TA:) or the meaning is, extirpated, by going into the bottom [or depth] of the earth, so as to leave no mark nor trace. (El-Basáïr, TA.)

1 qaEisa c
1. qaEisa, aor.
qaEasa
, (TK,) inf. n. qaEasN, (S, A, K,) He (a man, TK) had a protruding, or protuberant, breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back; qaEasN being the contr. of HadabN. (S, A, K, TK.) [And in like manner,] qaEasN in a bow is A bending outwards of its inner side, in its middle, and a bending inwards of its outer side. (TA.) ― -b2- See also 6, in two places. ＝ -A2- qaEasa AlXRaIoCa, [aor.
qaEasa
,] inf. n. qaEosN, He bent the thing; as also qERshu↓. (TA.)

2 qaERasa
2: see 1, last signification.

5 taqaERasa
5: see 6, in two places.

6 tqAEs c
6. tqAEs He made his [meaning his own] breast, or chest, to stick out. (A.) ― -b2- He drew back, and became refractory, and made himself like him who has a hollow, or receding, back, and a protruding, or protuberant, breast, or chest. (Har, p. 17.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) He drew back; held back; or hung back. (S, K.) You say, tqAEs Eani AlOamori (tropical:) He drew back, held back, or hung back, from the thing, or affair, and would not go forward in it; (S, TA;) as also qaEisa↓, inf. n. qaEasN; and tqERs↓: (TA:) in some copies of the S, instead of tqAEs, in this phrase, we find taqaEowasa↓. (TA.) And [in like manner,] AiqoEanosasa↓ (assumed tropical:) He drew back; he receded, or went backwards. (S, K.) When a man draws water without a pulley, pulling the rope at the head of the well, his back pains him, and it is said to him, waQjocibi AldRalowa AiqoEanosiso↓ (assumed tropical:) [Go thou backwards, and pull the bucket]. This verb is without idghám because it is quasi-coördinate to AiHoranojama. (S.) ― -b4- (assumed tropical:) He (a horse, S, K) drew back, or held back, and would not go forward: (S:) or would not submit to his leader; (K;) [as also AqEnss↓; as appears from an explanation of its part. n., below.] You say also, AldRaAbRapu tqERst↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) The beast of carriage stood still, and would not move from its place. (TA.) ― -b5- (assumed tropical:) [He (a man) and] it (might or strength) was, or became, firm, or steady, and resisted; [as also AqEnss↓; as appears from an explanation of its part. n., below:] and AqEnss↓ (assumed tropical:) he was, or became, firm, and did not bow his head: and qaEisa, inf. n. qaEasN, (assumed tropical:) he (a man) was, or became, inaccessible, or unapproachable, and mighty, or strong, and firm, or steady. (TA.) ― -b6- (tropical:) It (the night) was, or became, long, or protracted; as though it did not quit its place; like baraka. (A, TA.) See OaqoEasu.

Q. Q. 2 taqaEowasa c
Q. Q. 2. taqaEowasa: see 6.

R. Q. 3 UiqoEanosasa c
R. Q. 3. UiqoEanosasa: see 6, in five places.

qaEisN c
qaEisN: see OaqoEasu.

quEayosN c
quEayosN: see muqoEanosisN.

quEayosisN c
quEayosisN: see muqoEanosisN.

quEayosiysN c
quEayosiysN: see muqoEanosisN.

quEayonisN c
quEayonisN: see muqoEanosisN.

OaqoEasu c
OaqoEasu Having a protruding, or protuberant, breast, or chest, and a hollow, or receding, back; (S, A, K;) as also qaEisN↓ (S, K) and mutaqaAEisN↓: (S:) [or the last rather signifies making his breast, or chest, to stick out: see its verb:] fem. of the first, qaEosaMCu; (K;) applied to a woman [&c.]: and pl. quEosN: the dim. of the first is OuqayoEisu. (TA.) [See OajonaOu and Oafozaru.] ― -b2- Applied to a horse, Having the Sahowap [or place of the saddle], (K,) or the spine in that part, (S,) depressed, and the qaTaAp [or part next behind] elevated; (S, K;) [i. e., saddle-backed.] ― -b3- Applied to a camel, Having the head and neck and back inclining: (K:) or having the head and neck inclining towards the back: (S:) the latter is the right explanation. (TA.) Hence the saying, Aibonu xamosK EaXaMCu xalifaAtK quEosK, meaning, The tarrying of the moon five nights old until it sets is like the tarrying during the evening feed of pregnant camels having their heads and necks inclining towards their backs. (S, TA.) [See EatamapN.] The same epithet applied to a camel also signifies Having a shortness in the hind legs, and a sloping in the withers. (TA.) ― -b4- Also, the fem., qaEosaMCu, applied to an ant (namolap), Raising its breast and its tail: (K:) pl. quEosN and qaEosaAwaAtN. (TA.) ― -b5- And applied to a bow (qawos,) Having a bending outwards of its inner side, in its middle, and a bending inwards of its outer side. (TA.) ― -b6- Also OaqoEasu, applied to a man, (assumed tropical:) Inaccessible, or unapproachable, (S, K, TA,) and mighty, or strong, and firm, or steady. (TA.) You say also, EizRN OaqoEasu (A) and EizRapN qaEosaMCu (S, A) (tropical:) Firm might or strength. (S.) [See also muqoEanosisN.] ― -b7- layolN OaqoEasu (tropical:) A long, or protracted, night; (A, K;) as though it did not quit its place. (S, A.) And sinuwna quEosN (assumed tropical:) Years lasting long. (TA.)

muqoEanosisN c
muqoEanosisN (assumed tropical:) Drawing back; holding back; or hanging back: [see its verb:] (TA:) or strong; powerful; mighty: (S, K, TA:) also anything drawing in his head upon his neck, like him who refrains, or defends himself, from a thing: a camel that resists being led: anything that resists, or withstands: might, or power, that resists, or withstands, injury. (TA.) [See also OaqoEasu.] The pl. is maqaAEisu and maqaAEiysu; (S, K;) the addition of the I being in this case optional. (S.) The dim. is muqayoEisN, or muqayoEiysN, (Sb, S, K,) or quEayosisN and quEayosiysN, (TA,) or quEayonisN, (S, TA,) or quEayosN: (TA: and so in some copies of the K:) Mbr objected to the first and second of these, as not agreeable with analogy; and preferred the third and fourth, or, accord. to the S, the fifth, or, as some say, the last. (TA.)

mutaqaAEisN c
mutaqaAEisN: see OaqoEasu.

1 qaEaSahu c
1. qaEaSahu: see 4, throughout. ＝ -A2- quEiSati Alganamu The sheep, or goats, were seized, or affected, with the disease called quEaAS, q. v. (S, K.)

4 AqEShu c
4. AqEShu He slew him on the spot; (S, A, K;) as also qaEaSahu↓, (A, K,) aor.
qaEaSa
, (K,) inf. n. qaEoSN: (TK:) or both signify he slew him quickly: or the former signifies he struck, or shot at, it, (a thing, or an object of the chase,) and it died on the spot, before it was [struck or] shot: and he hastened and completed, or made sure or certain, his (a man's) slaughter: and qiEoSapN↓ is a subst. derived from it [app. signifying the act]. (L, TA.) You say also, AqEShu biAlrRumoHi, and qaEaSahu↓, He thrust him, or pierced him, with the spear, quickly: or from behind. (TA.)

7 AnqES c
7. AnqES He died. (K.)

qaEoSN c
qaEoSN A quick death: (S, A, K:) and a quick slaughter; as also qaEaSN↓. (TA.) You say, maAta qaEoSFA He (a man, S, A) died on the spot, from a blow or a shot. (S, A, K.) And it is said in a trad., mano xaraja mujaAhidFA fiI sabiyli QllRehi faqutila qaEoSFA faqadi Qsotawojaba AlmaMba [Whoso goeth forth as a warrior in the cause of God, and is slain quickly, or suddenly, has a just claim to the permanent abode of happiness in the other world]: (S, * TA:) alluding to the mMb mentioned in the Kur xxxviii. 24 and 39. (Az, TA.)

qaEaSN c
qaEaSN: see qaEoSN.

qiEoSapN c
qiEoSapN: see 4.

TaEonapN qaEoSaMCu c
TaEonapN qaEoSaMCu A thrust, or wound, with a spear or the like, that kills quickly. (TA.)

quEaASN c
quEaASN A certain disease which attacks sheep or goats, (S, A, K,) in consequence of which something flows from their noses, (TA,) killing them immediately, (S, A, K,) on the spot: (A:) and which kills men on the spot: (A:) and a certain disease in the breast, or chest, which is as though it broke the neck. (Lth, K.) It is said in a trad., wamuwtaAnN yakuwnu fiI AlnRaAsi kaquEaASi Alganami [And a mortality which shall be among men, like the qEAS of sheep or goats]. (S.)

qaERaASN c
qaERaASN: see what next follows.

miqoEaSN c
miqoEaSN: see what next follows.

miqoEaASN c
miqoEaASN A lion that kills quickly; as also miqoEaSN↓ and qaERaASN↓. (K.) ― -b2- See also what next follows.

ganamN maqoEuwSapN c
ganamN maqoEuwSapN Sheep, or goats, seized, or affected, with the disease called quEaAS: (S, K:) accord. to IAar, XaApN miqoEaASN↓ signifies a sheep, or goat, having the mortal disease so called. (TA.)

title.foreign: qET qEf qEqE qEl qEm qEn qEw qf

superEntry.entry:
1 qafiYati AlOaroDu c
1. qafiYati AlOaroDu, aor.
qafaAa
, inf. n. qafoCN, The land was rained upon, and its herbage became altered and spoiled thereby: (K:) or qafoCN [the inf. n.] signifies the falling of dust upon the herbs, or leguminous plants, (AHn, K, TA,) in consequence of which they are spoiled if the dust be not washed off. (AHn, TA.) [See faqaOat as said of the buhomaI.]

8 AqtfO Alxaroza c
8. AqtfO Alxaroza is said in the K to be syn. with AftqOhu, [q. v.,] and is expl. by Lh as meaning He repeated the [kind of sewing termed] xaroz [i. e. the sewing of skins and the like by means of an awl], and added, between the two kulbehs, another kulbeh, as is done with reed-mats when they are re-sewed. (TA.) [The kulbeh (kulobap, q. v.) is here described as a thong, or a strand (TaAqap) of [the membranous fibres that grow at the base of the branches of the palm-tree and are called] liyf, used in the same manner as the shoemaker's awl, &c., as in art. klb, q. v.; but what is here meant by this word is evidently, I think, a thong, or the like, with which a skin is sewed, agreeably with another explanation of it in art. klb.]

1 qafaxahu c
1. qafaxahu, (S, L,) aor.
qafaxa
, (L,) inf. n. qafoxN and qifaAxN, (S, L, K,) He struck him, or it: but the striking termed qfx is only on the head, or on something hollow, (S, L, K,) or on something hard [evidently a mistake for moist, or soft]; (L;) i. q. faqaxahu, (K,) and used by the people of ElYemen in the sense of SaqaEahu: (L:) he struck a person's head with a staff: (L:) he struck a person on the head with a staff. (As.) He broke a person's head: he broke a thing across: he broke the substance called EaromaD upon the surface of water. (L.)

1 qafida c
1. qafida, aor.
qafada
, inf. n. qafadN, He was, or became, Oaqofad, or characterized by what is termed qafadN, as explained below, [app. in all the senses of these two words]. (S, L, K, &c.) See Sadifa ＝ -A2- qafida, (IKtt,) inf. n. qafadN (S, L, K) and qafodaMCu, (K,)
He wound his turban in a particular manner, not making the end to hang down: (S, IKtt, L, K:) you say also, in this sense, taEamRama AlqafodaMCa, (IKtt,) and UiEotamRa AlqfdAC: (S:) accord. to Th, he wound his turban upon the qafod of his head: but he does not explain the word qafodN. (L.) ― -b2- qafada, aor.
qafida
, (inf. n. qafodN, L,) He struck a person on the back of his neck, (L, K,) or, on his head, (IKtt,) or, on his head at the part next the back of the neck, (L,) with the inside of his hand. (IKtt, L, K.) ＝ -A3- qafada, (inf. n. qafodN, TA) He did a deed, or work. (K.)

qafodN c
qafodN: see qafida.

qafadN c
qafadN [in the CK, incorrectly, qafodN] The quality denoted by the epithet Oaqofadu, as explained below, [app. in all the senses of this latter word]. (S, L.) ― -b2- An inclining of the foot of a man so that the fore part is seen [distinct] from the hinder part from behind. (L, K.) ― -b3- An erectness of the pastern, and its advancing upon the hoof of a horse: (S, L, K: *) it is only in the hind leg: (A, O, S, L:) is like quwaAmN in the fore legs: (IKtt:) and is a fault: (S, L:) or an elevation of [the tendon called] the EujaAyap, and of the hinder part of the hoof: (L:) or a rigidness in the pastern, as though the animal trod upon the fore part of his hoof. (ISh.) ― -b4- An inclining of a camel's foot (of the fore leg or hind leg, As, S) towards the inner side: (As, S, K:) and in like manner, of a solid hoof: (S, K, voce SadafN:) the verb is qafida; and the epithet, Oaqofadu: (As, S:) an inclining towards the outer side is termed SadafN; (TA;) and the epithet in this case is OaSodafu: (As, S:) or, as some say, a natural inclining of the fore part of the fore and hind leg of a beast towards the outer side. (L, TA.) ― -b5- A natural rigidness in the hind legs of camels. (L.)

qafadaAnN c
qafadaAnN (S, L) and qafadaAnapN↓ (L, K) A xariyTap of leather, for perfumes &c.; (L, K;) the xryTp of a dealer in perfumes: (IDrd, S:) a Persian word [originally qafodaAnu] arabicized. (S, L.)

qafadaAnapN c
qafadaAnapN: see qafadaAnN. ― -b2- Also, The cover (gilaAf) of a vessel in which collyrium (kuHol) is kept; (L, K;) it is made of mXAwr; [a word of which I find no appropriate meaning;] and sometimes, of leather. (L.)

Oaqofadu c
Oaqofadu Having the quality termed qafadN, as explained above, [app. in all the senses of this latter word]. (S, L.) See OaSodafu. ― -b2- A man (S, L) who walks upon the fore parts of his feet, next the toes, his heels not reaching the ground: (S, L, K.) the verb is qafida. (K.) ― -b3- A slave (L) having rigid and contracted arms and legs, with short fingers and toes: (L, K:) the verb is qafida. (K.) ― -b4- A man having a laxness in the heels: fem. qafodaMCu: and in like manner, an ostrich. (Lth, L.) ― -b5- A man weak, and with lax joints. The verb, applied to a member, is qafida, inf. n. qafadN. (L.) ― -b6- A man, and an ostrich, (L,) lax in the neck: (L, K:) the verb, applied to anything that has a neck, is qafida, aor.
qafada
, inf. n. qafadN: (IKtt:) or having a thick neck. (L, K.) ― -b7- A horse (S, L) having the pastern erect and advancing upon the hoof (S, L, K) of the hind foot. (AO, S, L.) See qafadN. ― -b8- A camel having his fore or hind foot inclining towards the inner side. (As, S, L.) See qafadN. ― -b9- EimRapN qafodaMCu A well-known mode of winding the turban, different from the mayolaMC. (T.) See qafida.

1 qafira c
1. qafira, aor.
qafara
, (K,) inf. n. qafarN, (TA,) It (food) was without seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- qafara Oavarahu, (S, K,) aor.
qafura
; (S;) and Aqtfrhu↓; and tqfRrhu↓; (S, A, K;) (tropical:) He followed his footsteps; tracked him: (S, A, K:) or he followed his footsteps by degrees, and leisurely; syn. tatabRaEahu: (TA:) accord. to Z, from Uiqotafara AlEaZoma. (TA.) It is said in a trad., AlEiloma Zahara qabolanaA naAsN yataqafRaruwna↓ There appeared before us men searching after knowledge time after time. (TA.) [See also 5 in art. fqr.]

4 Aqfr AlmakaAnu c
4. Aqfr AlmakaAnu The place became vacant, or void; (K;) destitute of herbage or pasturage, [and of water,] and of human beings. (TA.) Aqfrt AlOaroDu The land became destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water. (A.) Aqfrt AldRaAru The house became vacant. (S.) Aqfr AlrRajulu, (K,) or Aqfr mino Oaholihi, (A,) (tropical:) The man became apart from his family, (A, K,) and remained alone. (TA.) ― -b2- Aqfr He came, (S, Msb,) or went, or his course brought him, (S,) to the desert, where was no herbage or vegetable produce, nor water. (S, Msb.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He became destitute of food, and hungry. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- Aqfr Albalada He found the country, or town, to be what is termed qafor, (TS, K,) i. e., destitute [of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water, or] of people. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Aqfr (tropical:) He ate bread, (A,) or his food, (TA,) without seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He had no seasoning, or condiment, to render his food pleasant, or savoury, remaining with him, or in his abode. (S.) ― -b3- It is said in a trad., maA Oaqofara bayotN fiyhi xalRN (S, A) (tropical:) A house in which is vinegar is not destitute of seasoning, or condiment, to render food pleasant, or savoury; its inhabitants are not in want thereof: regarded by 'AObeyd as being from qaforN, meaning a country, or town, “ wherein is nothing. ” (TA.)

5 taqafRara
5: see 1, in two places.

8 Aqtfr AlEaZoma c
8. Aqtfr AlEaZoma He ate all the meat that was upon the bone, (K, * TA,) leaving nothing upon it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1.

OaroDN qaforN c
OaroDN qaforN, (S, A, Msb, K,) and qaforapN↓, (A, K,) and miqofaArN↓, (K,) and muqofirapN↓, (A,) Vacant, or void, land, (A, K,) destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water: (S, A, Msb:) and mafaAzapN qaforN, (S, Msb,) and qaforapN↓, and miqofaArN↓, (S,) a desert destitute of herbage or vegetable produce, and of water: (S, Msb:) or qaqorN signifies a place destitute of human beings, or desert, but sometimes containing a little herbage or pasturage: (Lth, TA:) or baladN qaforN a country, or town, wherein is nothing: (AZ, A'Obeyd:) and daArN qaforN a house destitute of inhabitants; deserted; or desolate: (Msb:) the pl. (of qaforN, S, Msb) is qifaArN (S, Msb, K) and qufuwrN: (K:) and you say also OaroDN qifaArN, (A, Msb, TA,) imagining it as comprising places; and in like manner, daArN qifaArN: (Msb, TA:) and [in a contrary manner,] OaraDuwna qafurN, and bilaAdN qaforN; as well as qifaArN: (A:) but when you make qafurN a subst., [not meaning OaroDN or the like to be understood,] (Msb,) or use a single term, (TA,) or apply it as an appellative to a land, (L, TA,) you add p, and say qaforapN↓, (Msb,) and UinotahayonaA UilaI qaforapK mina AlOaroDi [We came at last to a land destitute of herbage and of water]. (L, TA.) ― -b2- nazalonaA bibaniI fulaAnK fabitonaA Alqafora (tropical:) [We alighted at the abode of the sons of such a one, and passed the night] without being entertained by them as guests. (S.) ― -b3- nabotu Alqafori is a prov., meaning (assumed tropical:) The stone, and the rock. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qafaArN.

qaforapa c
qaforapa: see qaforN, in three places.

xubozN qafaArN c
xubozN qafaArN, (S, A, K,) and qaforN↓, (K,) and TaEaAm qafaArN, (TA,) and qafiyrN↓, (K,) (tropical:) [Bread, and food,] without any seasoning, or condiment, to render it pleasant, or savoury. (S, A, K.) You say Oakala xubozahu qafaArFA (tropical:) [He ate his bread without any seasoning, &c.]. (S.) And sawiyqN qafaArN (tropical:) [Meal of parched barley or wheat] not moistened with any seasoning, or condiment, &c. (K, * TA.)

qafiyrN c
qafiyrN: see qafaArN.

muqofiyrN c
muqofiyrN: see qaforN. ― -b2- Also, Destitute of food. (TA.)

miqofaArN c
miqofaArN: see qaforN, in two places.

1 qafaza c
1. qafaza, aor.
qafiza
, inf. n. qafozN (S, A, Msb, K) and qafazaAnN (S, Msb, K) and qufuwzN and qifaAzN, (Msb, and so in a copy of the K,) the last with kesr, (Msb,) or qufaAzN, (K accord. to the TA,) with damm, (TA,) or qafaAzN, (so in the CK,) He leaped, jumped, sprang, or bounded: (S, A, Msb, K:) he (an antelope) did so and alighted with his legs together. (TA, art. nfz.) ― -b2- qafaza AlHaAYiTa [He leaped the wall]. (O and K in art. zyf.) ＝ -A2- See also 5. ＝ -A3- qafiza, aor.
qafaza
, inf. n. qafaza, (tropical:) He (a horse) had fore legs white as high as his mirofaqaAni [properly signifying the elbows; but here, probably meaning, as it seems to do in some other instances, the knees], but not the kind legs. (IKtt, TA. [And qufRiza↓ app. has a similar meaning: see its inf. n. tqfyz below; and its part. n. muqafRazN, voce Oaqofazu.]) But see Oaqofazu, and qufRaAzN.

2 qafRaza
2: see what next precedes.

5 tqfRz c
5. tqfRz [He put on, or wore, a pair of gloves; as also qafaza↓, aor.
qafiza
, as appears from a quotation in the L, from Khálid Ibn-Jembeh, viz. AlqufRaAzaAni taqofizuhumaA AlmaroOapu:] he (a sportsman [or falconer]) put on, or wore, hawking-gloves (qufRaAzaAni): (A:) or took or prepared for himself the reticulated iron thing upon which the falcon sits. (TA, as from Z.) See qufRaAz. ― -b2- taqfRzt biQloHinRaMCi, said of a woman, (S, A,) (tropical:) She dyed her hands (A, K) to the wrists, (A,) and her feet, (K,) with HnRMC. (A, K.)

6 tqAfzwA c
6. tqAfzwA [They contended together, or vied, one with another, in leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding]. You say so of children playing at the game called qufRayozaI. (A, K.)

qufozapN c
[qufozapN A leap, jump, spring, or bound.]

qafazaI c
qafazaI A leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding. (K.) You say, jaMCati Alxayolu taEoduw AlqafazaI [The horses came running with a leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding, motion]; from Alqafozu [inf. n. of qafaza]. (S, TA.)

qafuwzN c
qafuwzN: see qafRaAzN.

qafiyzN c
qafiyzN A certain measure of capacity, consisting of ten makaAkiyk [pl. of makRuwko]; (S, Msb, K;) accord. to the people of El-'Irák: (TA:) or twelve times what is termed manR: (Mgh in art. rbE:) [see also jariybN, in three places: and see SaAEN:] pl. [of pauc.] OaqofizapN, and [of mult.] qufozaAnN (S, Msb, K) and qifozaAnN. (Fr, Sgh.) [See kurRN, throughout.] qafiyzu AlTRaHRaAni [The qfyz of the grinder] is when one says, “ I will grind for so much and a qfyz of the flour itself: ” so says Ibn-El-Mubárak: or when one hires a man to grind for him a certain quantity of wheat for a qfyz of its flour, (TA,) or when one says, “ I hire thee to grind this wheat for a pound of its flour, ” for instance; whether there be something else therewith or not: (Msb:) what is thus termed is forbidden. (Msb, TA.) ― -b2- Also, A certain measure of land; (T, Msb, K;) namely, the tenth of a jariyb, q. v.: (Msb:) or a hundred and fortyfour cubits. (K.)

qafRaAzN c
qafRaAzN That leaps, jumps, springs, or bounds, much, or often; (A, * Msb;) [and so qafuwzN↓, occurring in art. rfO in the M and K, applied as an epithet to a gazelle.] ― -b2- Hence, qafRaAzapN A female slave: because she seldom remains still. You say, yaA Qbona AlqafRaAzapi O son of the female slave. (A.)

qufRaAzN c
qufRaAzN A kind of glove; a thing which is made for the two hands, or hands and arms, stuffed with cotton, (S, L, K,) and having buttons which are buttoned upon the fore arms, (S, L,) worn by a woman as a protection from the cold; (S, L, K;) they are made of skins, and of felt; are worn by the women of the Arabs of the desert; and extend to the bones of the elbow: (L, TA:) a pair of them is called qufRaAzaAni: (S, L:) or a thing which the women of the Arabs of the desert make for themselves, stuffed with cotton, covering a woman's two hands, with her fingers, and, some add, having buttons upon the fore arm; like what the carrier of the falcon wears: (Msb:) or a thing which those women make for themselves, covering the fingers and hand and arm: and a thing which the sportsman [meaning the falconer] wears upon each hand, or hand and arm, of skin, or of felt, or wool: (Mgh:) or a kind of women's ornament for the hands and feet, or the hands and arms and the feet and legs: and a reticulated iron thing (HadiydapN muXabRakapN, accord. to the TA, as from the K, but in the CK muXotabikapN,) upon which the falcon sits. (K.) ― -b2- And [hence,] Whiteness in the OaXaAEir [or hairs next the hoof] of a horse. (K. [See also qafiza, and qufRaza, and Oaqofazu.])

qufRayozaI c
qufRayozaI A certain game of children, who set up pieces of wood, or a piece of wood, (the former accord. to the A, and the latter accord. to the K) and leap over them, or it. (A, K, TA.)

qaAfizN c
qaAfizN Leaping, jumping, springing, or bounding. (Msb.) ― -b2- xeayolN qaAfizapN, and qawaAfizu, Swift horses, that leap, jump, spring, or bound, in their running. (K.) ― -b3- AlqawaAfizu The frogs. (Sgh, K.)

Oaqofazu c
Oaqofazu (S, K) and muqafRazN↓ (S, A, K) (tropical:) A horse whose whiteness of the lower parts of his fore legs extends as far as his mirofaqaAni [properly signifying the elbows; but here, probably meaning, as it seems to do in some other instances, the knees], without his having the like in the hind legs; (S, K;) as though he had gloves (qufRaAzaAni) put upon him: (S:) or whose whiteness of the lower parts of the legs does not extend beyond the OaXaAEir [or hairs next the hoof]; as also munaERalN. (A, TA.)

taqofiyzN c
taqofiyzN A scattered whiteness intermingling in the shanks, as far as the knees, of a daAbRap [meaning, horse]: a signification wrongly assigned by Lth to taqofiyr. (TA in art. fqr.)

muqafRazN c
muqafRazN: see Oaqofazu.

1 qafaSahu c
1. qafaSahu, (S, M, A, Msb, K,) aor.
qafuSa
, (TK,) inf. n. qafoSN, (M, TA,) He collected it, gathered it, or put it, together; namely, a thing: (M, Msb:) or he put, or brought, one part, or parts, thereof near to another, or others: (K:) or he collected it, gathered it, or put it, together, and connected, or conjoined, one part, or parts, thereof with another, or others. (Jm, TA.) ― -b2- He collected, or put, together his legs; namely, those of a beast of carriage: (Msb:) or he tied, or bound, his legs, and collected, or put, them together; namely, those of an antelope; (AA, A 'Obeyd, M, A, K;) and those of a beast of carriage; as also qfRShu↓. (L.) ― -b3- He tied it, (namely, the yaEosuwb, K, i. e., the male bee, TA,) in the hive, with a thread, that it might not go forth. (K.)

2 qafRaSa
2: see 1.

4 AqfS c
4. AqfS He (a man, TA) had a cage, or coop, (qafaS,) of birds. (K.)

5 taqafRaSa
5: see 6.

6 tqAfS c
6. tqAfS It (a thing, M, A, meaning anything, TA) was, or became, complicated, or confused; [either properly, as when said of a cage or the like; or tropically, as when said of an affair of the mind;] (M, A, K, TA;) as also tqfRS↓: (TA:) or the latter signifies it was, or became, collected, gathered, or put, together. (IF, K, TA.)

qafoSN c
qafoSN: see what next follows.

qufoSN c
qufoSN: see what next follows.

qafaSN c
qafaSN A cage, coop, or place of confinement, (A, K,) or thing made of canes or reeds, or of wood, (M, TA,) [or of palm-sticks, &c.,] for a bird or birds: (S, M, A, K:) said by some to be an arabicized word [from the Persian qafasN]: by others, to be Arabic, from qafaSahu in the first of the senses explained above: (Msb:) pl. OaqofaASN. (S, A, Msb.) ― -b2- [It is also applied to The cageformed structure of the bones of the thorax: (see ZaribaAnN:) and is used in this sense in the present day.] ― -b3- Also, A certain implement for seedproduce; (K;) or a thing composed of two curved pieces of wood between which is a net; (M, L;) upon which wheat is conveyed to the heap where it is trodden out. (M, L, K.) ― -b4- fiI qafaSK mina AlmalaAYikapi, (M, Msb,) or qafaDK mina AlnRuwri, (M,) or mn AlmlAYkp fI qufoSK↓, or qufoSK mn Alnwr, [so in several copies of the K, but accord. to the TA, mn Alnwr qafoSK↓, being there said to be in the former case with damm, and in the latter with fet-h,] and qafaSK, (K,) occurring in a trad., (M, Msb, K,) means, (assumed tropical:) In an assemblage of angels: (Msb:) or in a confused assemblage of angels: and in a confused mixture of light. (M, Sgh, K.)

qafRaASN c
qafRaASN A maker of cages or coops. (TA.)

rjulN muqofiSN TayorFA c
rjulN muqofiSN TayorFA A man having a cage, or coop, of birds. (TA, from a trad.)

muqafRaSN c
muqafRaSN [in the L, and TA without any syll. signs: but in the latter said to be like mkrm, by which is generally meant mukoramN: in the L, however, it is mentioned after qafRaSa AlZRaboIa as meaning “ he tied, or bound, the legs of the antelope: ” and this indicates that it is as I have written it:] Having his arms and legs, or fore legs and hind legs, tied, or bound. (L, TA.) ― -b2- vawobN muqafRaSN A
garment, or piece of cloth, marked with lines in the form of a qafaS. (K.)

dictScrap.label: qfT qfE qfl qfn qfw: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
qayoqabN c
qayoqabN and qayoqabaAnN↓ A certain wood of which horses' saddles are made; (IDrd, S, O, K;) called in Pers. MzaAd diraxot. (IDrd, S, O.) [See also qaboqabN, in art. qb.] ― -b2- And, both words, A horse's saddle itself. (IDrd, O, K.) [See, again, qaboqabN.] ― -b3- And the former word signifies A strap, or thong, that surrounds the pommel and troussequin of a horse's saddle: (O, K:) or, as used by post-classical authors, a strap, or thong, that is put across behind the troussequin of a saddle. (IDrd, TA.) ― -b4- And [The bit-mouth, or mouth-piece of a bit; also called the Xakiymap; i. e.] the part of a bit in the middle of which is the faOos. (O, K.)

qayoqaAbN c
qayoqaAbN The xarazap [app. a polished stone, or a shell,] with which cloths are glazed. (O, K.) [See also qaboqaAbN, last sentence, in art. qb.]

qayoqabaAnN c
qayoqabaAnN: see the first paragraph, above.

dictScrap.label: ql: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qalabahu c
1. qalabahu, (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor.
qaliba
, (Msb, K.) inf. n. qalobN, (Msb,) He altered, or changed, its, or his, mode, or manner, of being; (A, Mgh, Msb, * K;) and qlRbhu↓ signifies the same, (K,) or is like qalabahu in the sense expl. above and in other senses but denotes intensiveness and muchness; (Msb;) and Aqlbhu↓ also signifies the same as qalabahu in the sense expl. above, (K,) on the authority of Lh, but is of weak authority. (TA.) Hence, (Mgh,) He inverted it; turned it upside-down; turned it so as to make its upper most part its undermost; (S, * A, * Mgh, Msb;) namely, a thing; (S;) for instance, a [garment of the kind called] ridaMC: (A, * Mgh:) and qlRbhu↓ has a similar meaning, but [properly] denotes intensiveness and muchness. (Msb. See two exs. of the latter verb voce qalabapN.)
