And, (A, K,) like qlRbhu↓, [except that the latter properly denotes intensiveness and muchness,] (K,) it signifies HawRalahu ZahorFA libaTonK (A, K) [He turned it over, or upsidedown as meaning so that the upper side became the under side; lit. back for belly; accord. to the TA, meaning back upon belly (ZahorFA EalaI baTonK); but this is hardly conceivable; whereas the former explanation is obviously right in another case: (see 5:) and another meaning of qalabahu and qulbhu↓, i. e. he turned it inside-out, is indicated in the TA by its being added, so that he knew what was in it]. ― -b2- See an ex. voce qalaAbi. One says, qalaba kalaAmFA [meaning He altered, or changed, the order of the words of a sentence or the like, by inversion, or by any transposition]. (TA.) [And in like manner, qalaba kalimapF He altered, or changed, the order of the letters of a word, by inversion, or by any transposition.] Es-Sakháwee says, in the Expos. of the Mufassal, that when they transpose [the letters of a word], they do not assign to the [transformed] derivative an inf. n., lest it should be confounded with the original, using only the inf. n. of the original that it may be an evidence of the originality [of the application of the latter to denote the signification common to both]: thus they say yaYisa, inf. n. yaOosN; and Oayisa is minohu maqoluwbN↓ [i. e. formed by transposition, or metathesis, from it], and has no inf. n.: when the two inf. ns. exist, the grammarians decide that each of the two verbs is [to be regarded as] an original, and that neither is mqlwb from the other, as in the case of jacaba and jabaca: but the lexicologists [in general] assert that all such are [of the class termed] mqlwb. (Mz, close of the 33rd nwE.) [And qalaba likewise signifies He changed, or converted, a letter into another letter; the verb in this sense being doubly trans.: for ex., one says, qalaba AlwaAwa yaMCF He changed, or converted, the w into I.] ― -b3- And [hence] one says, qalabahu Eano wajohihi (assumed tropical:) He turned him [from his manner, way, or course, of acting, or proceeding, &c.]: and Lh has mentioned Aqlbhu↓ [in the same sense], but as being disapproved. (TA.) And qalaba AlSRiboyaAna (tropical:) He (the teacher) turned away [or dismissed] the boys to their dwellings: (Th, A, TA:) or sent them [away], and returned them, to their abodes: and Lh has mentioned Aqlbhm↓ as a dial. var. of weak authority, saying that the former verb is that which is used by the Arabs in this and other [similar] cases. (TA.) And qalabotu Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) I turned away [or dismissed] the people, or party; (Th, S, O;) like as you say Sarafotu AlSRiboyaAna. (Th, S.) And qalaba QllRehu fulaAnFA Uilayohi (assumed tropical:) [God translated such a one unto Himself, by death: meaning God took his soul]; as also Aqlbh↓; (K, TA;) whence the saying of Anooshirwán, QllRehu muqolaba OawoliyaAYihi Oaqolabakumu↓ (assumed tropical:) [May God translate you with the translating of his favourites (mqlb being here an inf. n.), meaning, as He translates his favourites]. (TA.) ― -b4- And qalaba Eayonahu, and HimolaAqahu, (TA,) or HimolaAqa Eayonihi, (A,) [He turned about, or rolled, his eye, and therefore the parts of his eye that are occasionally covered by the eyelids,] on the occasion of anger, (A, TA,) and of threatening. (TA.) ― -b5- qalaba, aor.
qaliba
, inf. n. qalobN; and Aqlb↓ likewise, but this is of weak authority, mentioned by Lh; signify also He turned over bread, and the like, when the upper part thereof was thoroughly baked, in order that the under side might become so. (TA.) And you say, qalabotu AlUinaMCa EalaI raOosihi [I turned over the vessel upon its head]. (Msb, in explanation of kababotu AlUinaMCa.) And qalabotu AlOaroDa lilzRiraAEapi [I turned over the earth for sowing]: and qalRabotuhaA↓, also, I did so much.] (Msb.) And yuqolabu AltRuraAbu biAlHafori [The earth is turned over in digging]: whence qalabotu qaliybFA means I dug a well. (A.) ― -b6- And [hence also] one says, qalabotu AlXRaIoCa liloAibotiyaAEi I turned over the thing, or (assumed tropical:) I examined the several parts, or portions, of the thing, (taSafRaHotuhu,) [or I turned over the thing for the purpose of examining it,] with a view to purchasing, and saw its outer part or side, and its inner part or side: and qalRabotuhu↓, also, I did so much. (Msb.) And qalaba AlsRiloEapa (tropical:) He (a trafficker) examined the commodity, and scrutinized its condition: and qalRabahaA↓, also, he did so [much]. (A.) And qalaba AldRaAbRapa and AlgulaAma (tropical:) [He examined, &c., the beast, or horse, or the like, and the youth, or young man, or male slave]: (A:) and qalaba Almamoluwka, aor.
qaliba
, inf. n. qalobN, (tropical:) he uncovered and examined the male slave, to look at [or to see] his defects, on the occasion of purchasing. (O, TA.) And qalabotu AlOamora ZahorFA libaTonK (assumed tropical:) I considered [or turned over in my mind] what might be the issues, or results, of the affair, or case: and qalRabotuhu↓, also, I did so much. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- qalabN signifies AinoqilAbN, (S, A, O, K, TA,) meaning A turning outward, (TK,) and being flabby, (TA,) of the lip, (S, A, O, K,) or of the upper lip, (TA,) of a man: (S, A, O, K, TA:) it is the inf. n. of qalibat said of the lip (AlXRafapu); (TA;) [and also, accord. to the TK, of qaliba said of a man as meaning His lip had what is termed qalabN:] and hence Oaqolabu↓ as an epithet applied to a man; and [its fem.] qalobaMC↓ as an epithet applied to a lip. (S, A, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A3- qalabahu, (S, A, O, K,) aor.
qaluba
(Lh, K) and
qaliba
, (K,) He (a man, S, O) hit his heart. (S, A, O, K.) And It (a disease) affected, or attacked, his heart. (A.) And quliba He (a man) was affected, or attacked, by a pain in his heart, (Fr, A, * TA,) from which one hardly, or nowise, becomes free. (Fr, TA.) And quliba said of a camel, (As, S, O, K, TA,) inf. n. qulaAbN, (As, S, TA,) He was attacked by the disease called qulaAb expl. below: (As, S, O, K, TA:) or he was attacked suddenly by the [pestilence termed] gudRap, and died in consequence. (As, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qalaba AlnRaxolapa (tropical:) He plucked out the qalob, or qulob, meaning heart, of the palm-tree. (S, A, O, K.) ― -b3- And qalabati Albusorapu (assumed tropical:) The unripe date became red. (S, O, K.)

2 qalRaba
2: see 1, first quarter, in four places. You say, qalRabotuhu biyadiI [I turned it over and over with my hand], inf. n. taqoliybN. (S.) [And hence several other significations mentioned above.] See, again, 1, latter half, in four places. ― -b2- faOaSobaHa yuqalRibu kafRayohi, (A, O,) in the Kur [xviii. 40],
(O,) means fASbH yqlRb kfRyh ZahorFA libaTonK [And he began to turn his hands upside-down, or to do so repeatedly,] in grief, or regret: (Bd:) or (tropical:) he became in the state, or condition, of repenting, or grieving: (Ksh, A, O:) for taqoliybu AlkafRayoni is an action of him who is repenting, or grieving; (Ksh, O:) and therefore metonymically denotes repentance, or grief, like EaDRu AlkafRi and AlsRuquwTu fiI Alyadi. (Ksh.) ― -b3- [taqoliybu AlmaAli ligaraDi AlrRiboHi occurs in the A, in art. tjr, as an explanation of AltRijaArapu, meaning (assumed tropical:) The employing of property, or turning it to use, in various ways, for the purpose of gain.] And you say, qalRabotuhu fiI AlOamori, meaning SarRafotuhu [i. e. (assumed tropical:) I employed him to act in whatever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or I made him a free agent, in the affair: or I made him, or employed him, to practise versatility, or to use art or artifice or cunning, in the affair: and simply, I employed him in the managing of the affair]. (K in art. Srf.) [And qalRaba Alfikara fiI OmRrK (assumed tropical:) He turned over and over, or revolved repeatedly, in his mind, thoughts, considerations, or ideas, with a view to the attainment of some object, in relation to an affair.] And qlRb AlOumuwra, (TA,) inf. n. taqoliybN, (S, K, TA,) (tropical:) He investigated, scrutinized, or examined, affairs, [or turned them over and over in his mind, meditating what he should do,] and considered what would be their results. (TA.) waqalRabuwA laka AlOumuwra is a phrase occurring in the Kur-án [ix. 48,] (Msb,) and is tropical, (A,) meaning (tropical:) [And they turned over and over in their minds affairs, meditating what they should do to thee: or] they turned over [repeatedly in their minds] thoughts, or considerations, concerning the beguiling, or circumventing, thee, and the rendering thy religion ineffectual]: (Jel:) or they meditated, or devised, in relation to thee, wiles, artifices, plots, or stratagems; and [more agreeably with the primary import of the verb] they revolved ideas, or opinions, respecting the frustrating of thy affair. (Ksh, Bd.)

4 Oaqolaba
4: see 1, in six places. [Aqlbhu, said of God, also signifies (assumed tropical:) He made him to return from a journey: see an ex. in the first paragraph of art. SHb. (In the phrase OaqobilonaA bicimRapK, expl. in the TA in art. dm as meaning Restore us to our family in safety, OaqobilonaA is a mistranscription for OaqolibonaA.)] ＝ -A2- Aqlb as intrans., said of bread [and the like], It became fit to be turned over [in order that the other side might become thoroughly baked]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And Aqlb AlEinabu The grapes became dry, or tough, externally, (K, TA,) and were therefore turned over, or shifted. (TA.) ＝ -A3- Also He had his camels attacked by the disease called qulaAb. (S, O, K.)

5 tqlRb AlXRaIoCu ZahorFA lbiTonK c
5. tqlRb AlXRaIoCu ZahorFA lbiTonK [The thing turned over and over, or upside-down as meaning so that the upper side became the under side, (lit. back for belly,) doing so much, or repeatedly], like as does the serpent upon the ground vehemently heated by the sun. (S, O, TA.) tqlRb said of a man's face [&c.] signifies tSrRf [i. e. It turned about, properly meaning much, or in various ways or directions; or it was, or became, turned about, &c.]. (Jel in ii. 139.) And tataqalRabu fiyhi Qloquluwbu waQloOaboSaAru, in the Kur [xxiv. 37], means In which the hearts and the eyes shall be in a state of commotion, or agitation, by reason of fear, (Zj, Jel, TA,) and impatience; (Zj, TA;) the hearts between safety and perdition, and the eyes between the right side and the left. (Jel.) And fiI taqalRubihimo, in the Kur xvi. 48, means (assumed tropical:) In their journeyings for traffic. (Jel. [See also the Kur iii. 196, and xl. 4.]) You say, tqlRb fiI AlbilaAdi, (TA,) and fI AlOumuwri, (K, TA,) meaning taSarRafa fiyhaA kayofa XaMCa [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He acted in whatsoever way he pleased, according to his own judgment or discretion or free will, or as a free agent, in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, in the country, and in the disposal, or management, of affairs: and simply, he employed himself in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, in the country, and in the disposal, or management, of affairs: or tqlRb fI AlAmwr means he practised versatility, or used art or artifice or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs]. (K, * TA.) And huwa yataqalRabu fiI OaEomaAli AlsRuloTaAni (tropical:) He acts as he pleases, &c., or simply he employs himself, in the offices of administration, or in the provinces, of the Sultán]. (A.)

7 Anqlb c
7. Anqlb, of which munoqalabN is an inf. n., (S, O, K, TA,) syn. with AinqilaAbN, (TA,) and also a n. of place, (S, O, K, TA,) like munoSarafN, (S, O, TA,) is quasi-pass. of qalabotuhu: (S, O:) it signifies It, or he, was, or became, altered, or changed, from its, or his, mode, or manner, of being: (TA:) [and hence,] it (a thing) became inverted, or turned upside-down [&c.: see 1]. (S.) ― -b2- And [hence] AlAinoqilaAbu UilaI QllRehi means (assumed tropical:) The transition, and the being translated, or removed, to God, by death: and [in like manner] Almunoqalabu means the transition [&c.], of men, to the final abode. (TA. [See an ex. in p. 132, sec. col., from the Kur xxvi. last verse.]) ― -b3- And AlAinoqilaAbu means also (assumed tropical:) The returning, in an absolute sense: and, as also Almunoqalabu, particularly, from a journey, and to one's home: thus, in a trad., in the prayer relating to journeying, OuEuwcu bika mino kaMbapi Almunoqalabi (assumed tropical:) [I seek protection by Thee from the being in an evil state in respect of the returning from my journeying to my home]; i. e., from my returning to my dwelling and seeing what may grieve me. (TA.) The saying in the Kur xxii. 11 waUino OaSaAbatohu fitonapN Qnoqalaba EalaI wajohihi means (assumed tropical:) And if trial befall him, and [particularly such as] disease in himself and his cattle, he returns [to his former way, i. e., in this case,] to infidelity. (Jel. [See also other exs. in the Kur in ii. 138 and iii. 138.]) And one says, Anqlb Eani AlEahodi [meaning (assumed tropical:) He withdrew, or receded, from the covenant, compact, agreement, or engagement]. (S in art. Hwl.) [See also an ex. from the Kur-án (lxvii. 4) voce xaAsiYN.]

qalobN c
qalobN The heart; syn. fuWaAdN: (Lh, T, S, M, O, Msb, K, &c.:) or [accord. to some] it has a more special signification than the latter word: (O, K:) [for] some say that fWAd signifies the “ appendages of the mariIoC [or œsophagus], consisting of the liver and lungs and qalob [or heart]: ” (K in art. fOd:) [and, agreeably with this assertion,] it is said that the qlb is a lump of flesh, pertaining to the fWAd, suspended to the niyaAT [q. v.]: Az says, I have observed that some of the Arabs call the whole flesh of the qlb, its fat, and its HijaAb [or septum?], qalob and fuWaAd; and I have not observed them to distinguish between the two [words]; but I do not deny that the [word] qlb may be [applied by some to] the black clot of blood in its interior: MF mentions that fWAd is said to signify the “ receptacle, ” or “ covering, ” of the heart, (wiEaMCu Alqalobi, or giXaAWuhu, [i. e. the pericardium,]) or, accord. to some, its “ interior: ” the qalob is said to be so called from its taqalRub: [see 5:] the word is of the masc. gender: and the pl. is quluwbN. (TA.) banaAtu Alqalobi means (assumed tropical:) The several parts, or portions, [or, perhaps, appertenances,] of the heart. (TA in art. bnI.) [And qalobN is also used as meaning The stomach, which is often thus termed in the present day: so, for ex., in an explanation of Tanix, q. v.] ― -b2- qalobu AlEaqorabi (also called simply, Alqalobu, Kzw) is (assumed tropical:) A certain bright star, [the star a in Scorpio,] between two other stars, which is one of the Mansions of the Moon, (S, O,) namely, the Eighteenth Mansion; so called because it is in the heart of Scorpio: (MF:) [it rose aurorally, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, in Central Arabia, together with AlnRasoru AlwaqiEu (a of Libra) on the 25th of November, O. S.: (see manaAzilu Alqamari, in art. nzl:)] the commencement of the period when the cattle breed in the desert is at the time of its [auroral] rising and the [auroral] rising of Alnsr AlwAqE; these two stars rising together, in the cold season: the Arabs say, Alqalbo jaMCa AlXRitaMCu kaQlokalobo [When the heart of the Scorpion rises, the winter comes like the dog]: and they regard its nawoC [q. v.] as unlucky; and dislike journeying when the moon is in Scorpio: at its nawoC [meaning auroral rising], the cold becomes vehement, cold winds blow, and the sap becomes stagnant in the trees: its raqiyb is AldRabaraAnu [q. v.] (Kzw.) There are also three similar appellations of other stars: these are qalobu AlOasadi (assumed tropical:) [Cor Leonis, or Regulus, the star a of Leo]: qalobu AlvRawori, an [improper] appellation of AldRabaraAnu: and qalobu AlHuwti, a name of AlrRiXaMCu [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b3- And Alqalobu is syn. with
AlDRamiyru [signifying (assumed tropical:) The heart as meaning the mind or the secret thoughts]. (Msb in art. Dmr.) ― -b4- And (assumed tropical:) The soul. (TA.) ― -b5- And (assumed tropical:) The mind, meaning the intellect, or intelligence. (Fr, S, O, Msb, K.) So in the Kur l. 36: (Fr, S, O, TA:) or it means there endeavour to understand, and consideration. (TA.) Accord. to Fr, you may say, maA laka qalobN (assumed tropical:) Thou hast no intellect, or intelligence: (TA:) and maA qalobuka maEaka (assumed tropical:) Thine intellect is not present with thee: (O, TA:) and Oayona cahaba qalobuka (assumed tropical:) Whither has thine intellect gone? (TA.) [And hence, OafoEaAlu Alquluwbi (assumed tropical:) The verbs significant of operations of the mind; as ZanRa, and the like.] ― -b6- See also qulobN. ― -b7- [qalobu AljayoXi means (assumed tropical:) The main body of the army; as distinguished from the van and the rear and the two wings: mentioned in the S and K in art. xms; &c.] ― -b8- And qalobN signifies also (assumed tropical:) The pure, or choice, or best, part of anything. (L, K, * TA.) It is said in a trad. UinRa likulRi XaIoCK qalobFA waqalobu AlquroMni yesL (tropical:) [as though meaning, Verily to everything there is a choice, or best, part; and the choice, or best, part of the Kur-án is Yá-Seen (the Thirty-sixth Chapter)]: (A, O, L, TA:) it is a saying of the Prophet; [and may (perhaps better) be rendered, verily to everything there is a pith; and the pith &c.; from qalobN, as meaning, like qulobN, the “ pith ” of the palm-tree; but,] accord. to Lth, it is from what here immediately follows. (O.) One says, jiYotuka bihecaA AlOamori qalobFA, meaning (tropical:) I have come to thee with this affair unmixed with any other thing. (A, * O, L, TA.) ― -b9- Also (tropical:) A man genuine, or pure, in respect of origin, or lineage; (S, A, O, K;) holding a middle place among his people; (A;) and qulobN↓ signifies the same: (O, K:) the former is used alike as masc. and fem. and sing. and dual and pl.; but it is allowable to form the fem. and dual and pl. from it: (S, O:) one says EarabiIRN qalobN (S, A, * O) and qulobN↓ (O) (tropical:) a genuine Arabian man, (S, A, * O,) and AimoraOapN qalobN (S, * A, O *) and qalobapN (S, A, O) and qulobapN↓ (K) a woman genuine, or pure, in respect of origin, or lineage: (S, A, * O, K:) Sb says, they said hecaA EarabiIRN qalobN and qalobFA (assumed tropical:) [This is an Arabian genuine, or pure, &c., and being genuine, or pure, &c.]; using the same word as an epithet and as an inf. n.: and it is said in a trad., kaAna EalIRN quraXiyRFA qalobFA, meaning (assumed tropical:) 'Alee was a Kurashee genuine, or pure, in respect of race: or, as some say, the meaning is, an intelligent manager of affairs; from qalobN as used in the Kur l. 36. (L, TA.)

qulobN c
qulobN (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and qalobN↓ (S, O, Msb, K) and qilobN↓ (S, O, K) (tropical:) The lubR, (S, O,) or XaHomap, (A, K,) or jumRaAr, (Mgh, Msb,) [i. e. heart, or pith,] of the palm-tree; (S, A, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) which is a soft, white substance, that is eaten; it is in the midst of its uppermost part, and of a pleasant, or sweet, taste: (TA: [see also jumRaArN:]) or the best of the leaves of the palm-tree, (AHn, K [in which this explanation relates to all the three forms of the word, but app. accord. to AHn it relates only to the first of them], and TA,) and the whitest; which are the leaves next to the uppermost part thereof; and one of these is termed qulobapN↓, with damm and sukoon: (AHn, TA:) or qulobN, with damm, signifies the branches of the palm-tree (saEaf [in my copy of the Msb sEfp]) that grow forth from the qlb [meaning heart]: (T, TA: [see AlEawaAhinu and AlxawaAfiI, pls. of EaAhinN, or EaAhinapN, and xaAfiyapN:]) the pl. is qilabapN, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is of the second, (Msb,) [or of all,] and quluwbN, (Msb, K,) a pl. of the second, (Msb,) and OaqolaAbN, (Msb, K,) a pl. [of pauc.] of the first. (Msb.) ― -b2- And qulobN signifies also (tropical:) A bracelet (S, O, K, TA) that is worn by a woman, (K, TA,) such as is one qulob, (S, O, TA, but in the O, one qalob,) [as though meaning such as is single, not double,] or such as is one qilod, ('Eyn, T, MS, [and this is evidently the right reading, as will be shown by what follows,]) meaning such as is formed by twisting [or rather bending round] one TaAq [i. e. one wire (more or less thick), likened to a yarn, or strand], not of a double TaAq; (MS;) and they say siwaArN qulobN; (TA;) and qulobu fiDRapK i. e. a [woman's] bracelet [of silver], (A, Mgh, Msb, TA,) such as is not twisted [like a cord, or rope, of two or more strands, as are many of the bracelets worn by Arab women]: (Mgh, Msb, TA:) so called as being likened to the qulob of the palm-tree because of its whiteness; (A, Mgh, Msb, TA;) or, as some say, the converse is the case. (Mgh.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) A serpent: (S, O:) or a white serpent: (A, K:) likened to the bracelet so called. (S, O.) ＝ -A2- qulobN as an epithet, and its fem. qulobapN: see qalobN, last sentence, in three places.

qilobN c
qilobN: see the next preceding paragraph.

qulobapN c
qulobapN, as a subst.: see qulobN, former half. ＝ -A2- Also Redness. (IAar, O, K.)

maA bihi qalabapN c
maA bihi qalabapN There is not in him any disease, (S, A, Mgh,) thus says IAar, adding, for which he should be turned over (yuqalRab↓) and examined, (S,) and in this sense it is said of a camel [and the like], (TA,) or on account of which he should turn over upon his bed: (A:) or there is not in him anything to disquiet him, so that he should turn over upon his bed: (Et-Tá-ee, TA:) or thers is not in him any disease, and any fatigue, (K, TA,) and any pain: (TA:) or there is not in him anything; said of one who is sick; and the word is not used otherwise than in negative phrases: accord. to IAar, originally used in relation to a horse or the like, meaning there is not in him any disease for which his hoof should be turned upsidedown (yuqalRab↓) [to be examined]: (TA:) or it is from AlqulaAbu, (Fr, S, A, TA,) the disease, so termed, that attacks camels; (TA;) or from quliba [q. v.] as said of a man, and means there is not in him any disease on account of which one should fear for him. (Fr, TA.)
OawodaI AlXRabaAbu waHubRu AlxaAlapi AlxalibahN
waqado bariYotu famaA biAlqalobi mino qalabahN
[Youthfulness has perished, and the love of the proud and self-conceited, the very deceitful, woman, (thus the two epithets are expl. in art. xlb in the S,) and I have recovered so that there is not in the heart any disease, &c.]; meaning I have recovered from the disease of love. (S, TA.)

qalaAbi c
qalaAbi [as used in the following instance is an attributive proper name like fajaAri &c.]. Aiqolibo qalaAbi [Alter, O alterer,] is a prov. applied to him who turns his speech, or tongue, and applies it as he pleases: accord. to IAth, to him who has made a slip of the tongue, and repairs it by turning it to another meaning: yaA, he says, is suppressed before qlAb. (TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 247.])

qulaAbN c
qulaAbN A certain disease of the heart. (Lh, K.) And (K) A disease that attacks the camel, (As, S, O, K,) occasioning complaint of the heart, (As, S, O,) and that kills him on the day of its befalling him: (As, S, O, K:) or a disease that attacks camels in the head, and turns it up. (Fr, TA.) [It is also mentioned as an inf. n. of quliba, q. v.] Accord. to Kr, it is the only known word, signifying a disease, derived from the name of the member affected, except kubaAdN and nukaAfN. (TA in art. kbd.)

qilaAbN c
qilaAbN: see qilRiybN.

qaluwbN c
qaluwbN, (O, K,) as an epithet applied to a man, (O, TA,) i. q. mutaqalRibN kaviyru AltRaqalRubi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) Who employs himself much in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, or in the disposal, or management, of affairs: or who practises much versatility, &c.: see 5, last sentence but one]. (O, K.) ― -b2- See also qilRiybN. ＝ -A2- qaluwbu AlXRajari means What are soft, or tender, of succulent herbs: these, and locusts, [it is said,] were eaten by John the son of Zachariah. (O.)

qaliybN c
qaliybN Earth turned over (turaAbN maqoluwbN): [app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant:] this is the primary signification. (A.) ― -b2- And hence, (A,) a masc. n., (A, * Msb,) or masc. and fem., (S, O, K,) A well, (Msb, K, TA,) of whatever kind it be: (TA:) or a well before its interior is cased [with stones or bricks]: (S, A, Mgh, O:) or an ancient well, (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K, TA,) of which neither the owner nor the digger is known, situate in a desert: (TA:) or an old well, whether cased within or not: (TA:) or a well, whether cased within or not, containing water or not, of the kind termed jafor [q. v.] or not: (ISh, TA:) or a well, whether of recent formation or ancient: (Sh, TA:) so called because its earth is turned over (Sh, A, TA) in the digging: (A:) or a well in which is a spring; otherwise a well is not thus called: (IAar, TA:)
the pl. (of pauc., S, O) OaqolibapN (S, O, K) and (of mult., S, O) qulubN (S, Mgh, O, K) and qulobN, (O, K,) the first and last of which are said to be pls. in the dial. of such as make the sing. to be masc., and the second the pl. in the dial. of such as make the sing. to be fem., but the last, as MF has pointed out, is a contraction of the second like as rusolN is of rusulN, (TA,) and qulobaAnN also is mentioned as a pl. of qaliybN on the authority of AO. (TA voce badiIoCN.) ― -b3- El-'Ajjáj has applied the pl. qulub to (tropical:) Wounds, by way of comparison. (S, O.)

qulayobN c
qulayobN [dim. of qalobN: and hence, perhaps,] (assumed tropical:) A xarazap [i. e. bead, or gem,] for captivating, fascinating, or restraining, by a kind of enchantment. (Lh, K.)

rajulN qulRabN c
rajulN qulRabN (assumed tropical:) A man who employs himself as he pleases in journeying, for traffic or otherwise, or in the disposal, or management, of affairs: or in practising versatility, or using art or artifice or cunning, in the disposal, or management, of affairs. (TA.) And HuwRaliIRN qulRabN (S, O, K) and HuwRalN qulRabN and HuwRaliIRN qulRabiIRN (O, K) or qulRabN HuwRalN (A) (tropical:) One who exercises art, artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill, and excellence of consideration or deliberation, and ability to manage according to his own free will, with subtilty; knowing, skilful, or intelligent, in investigating, scrutinizing, or examining, affairs, [or turning them over and over in his mind,] and considering what will be their results. (S, A, * O, K, TA. [See also art. Hwl.])

qilRaAbN c
qilRaAbN: see qilRiybN.

qilRawobN c
qilRawobN and qalRuwbN: see what next follows.

qilRiybN c
qilRiybN and qilRawobN↓ The wolf; (S, O, K;) as also qalRuwbN↓ and qaluwbN↓ and qilaAbN↓, the last like kitaAbN, (K,) or qilRaAbN↓. (O: thus there written.) ― -b2- And The lion. (O, in explanation of the first and second.)

qaAlabN c
qaAlabN, with fet-h to the l, (S, MA, O, Msb, K, KL,) and qaAlibN↓, (MA, O, Msb, K,) but the former is the more common, (Msb, K,) A model according to which the like thereof is made, or proportioned: (T in art. mvl, MA, KL, MF:) the model [or last] (KL,) of a boot, (S, O, Msb, KL,) and of a shoe, (KL,) &c.: (O, Msb, KL:) and a mould into which metals are poured: (K:) qaAlabN is an arabicized word, as is shown by its form, which is not that of an Arabic word; though Esh-Shiháb, in his Expos. of the Shifè, denies this: its original is [the Pers. word] kaAlabN: (MF:) the pl. is qawaAlibu, (MA,) and qawaAliyb is used by El-Hareeree to assimilate it to OasaAliyb. (Har p. 23.) [A fanciful and false derivation of qaAlibN used in relation to a boot &c., as though it were of Arabic origin, is given in the O, and in Har p. 23.] ― -b2- AlkalaAmi qado radRa qaAliaba↓ waqado TabRaqa AlmafoSila wawaDaEa AlhinaMCa mawaADiEa AlnRuqobi [app. meaning (assumed tropical:) He has returned in reply the model, or pattern, of speech; and has hit the joint so as to sever the limb; (that is to say, has hit aright, or hit upon, the argument, proof, or evidence, agreeably with an explanation in art. Tbq;) and has put the tar upon the places of the scabs;] is mentioned by AZ as said of an eloquent man. (O, TA. * [The TA, in this art. and in art. Tbq, has wrd (to which I cannot assign in this case any apposite meaning) instead of radRa, the reading in the O.]) ― -b3- And qaAliabN↓, (O, L, TA,) with fet-h and with kesr to the l, (L, TA,) signifies also A [clog, or] wooden sandal, (O, L, TA,) like the qaboqaAb [q. v.]: in this sense likewise said to be an arabicized word: and qawaAliybu is its pl., [properly qawaAlibu,] occurring in a trad., in which it is said that the women of the Children of Israel used to wear the wooden sandals thus called: (L, TA:) it is related in a trad. of Ibn-Mes'ood that the woman used to wear a pair of the kind of sandals thus called in order thereby to elevate herself (O, L, TA) when the men and the women of that people used to pray together. (O.)

qaAlibN c
qaAlibN Red unripe dates: (S, O, Msb, K:) so in the dial. of Belhárith Ibn-Kaab: (El-Umawee, TA:) [app. an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant; for busorN qaAlibN:] or an unripe date when it has become wholly altered [in colour] is termed qaAlibN. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- And XaApN qaAlibu lawonK A ewe, or she-goat, of a colour different from that of her mother: (O, * K, TA:) occurring in a trad. (O, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also qaAlabN, in three places.

Oaqolabu c
Oaqolabu as an epithet applied to a man: and qalobaMCu as an epithet applied to a lip (XafapN): see 1, near the end.

UiqlAbyp c
UiqlAbyp [app. UiqolAbiyRapN] A sort of wind, from which sailors on the sea suffer injury, and fear for their vessels. (TA.)

taqalRubaAtN c
[taqalRubaAtN (assumed tropical:) Vicissitudes of fortune or of time.]

miqolabN c
miqolabN The iron implement with which the earth is turned over for sowing. (S, O, K.)

muqalRibu Alquluwbi c
muqalRibu Alquluwbi (assumed tropical:) [The Turner of hearts: an epithet applied to God]. (TA in art. Hrk, from a trad.)

maqoluwbN c
maqoluwbN pass. part. n. of qalaba AlXRaIoCa. (A, O.) You say HajarN maqoluwbN [generally meaning A stone turned upside-down]. (A.) And sariyrN maqoluwbN i. e. [A couch-frame] of which the legs are turned upwards. (Mgh.) And kalaAmN maqoluwbN [A sentence, or the like, altered, or changed, in the order of its words, by inversion, or by any transposition]. (A.) And in like manner mqlwb is applied to a word: see 1, former half. ＝ -A2- Also a man attacked by a disease of the heart. (A.) And A camel attacked by the disease termed qulaAb [q. v.]: (S, O, K:) fem. with p. (S.)

Almaqoluwbapu c
Almaqoluwbapu [A subst., rendered such by the affix p,] The ear. (O, K.)

mutaqalRabN c
mutaqalRabN i. q. mutaSarRafN (assumed tropical:) [Place, or room, or scope, for free action, &c.: see srb: and see an ex. voce sabaHa]. (Jel. in xlvii. 21.) ― -b2- See also the following paragraph, in two places.

munoqalabN c
munoqalabN An inf. n. of 7 [q. v.]. (S, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And also a n. of place from the same [for which Freytag seems to have found in a copy of the S muqalRabN, a mistranscription], (S, O, K, TA,) like munoSarafN. (TA.) [As a n. of place it signifies A place in which a thing, or person, is, or becomes, altered, or changed, from its, or his, mode, or manner, of being: and hence, a place in which a thing becomes inverted, or turned upside-down, &c. ― -b3- Hence, also, (assumed tropical:) The final place to which one is translated, or removed, by death; and so mutaqalRabN↓.] One says, kulRu OaHad yaSiyru UilaI munoqalabihi and mutaqalRabihi↓ (tropical:) [Every one reaches, or will reach, his final place to which he is to be translated, or removed]. (A.) ― -b4- [And A place to which one returns from a journey &c.]

1 qalita c
1. qalita, aor.
qalata
, inf. n. qalatN, (S, * Mgh, O, * Msb, K,) He, or it, perished, or died. (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K.) One says, maA QnofalatuwA walekino qulituwA [They did not escape, but they perished, or died]. (S, O. [Golius and Freytag appear to have read AnqltwA; for they have said, as on the authority of J, that the seventh form of the verb is not to be used for the first form.])

4 Aqlthu c
4. Aqlthu He, or it, destroyed him; (K, TA;) said of God, and of a long journey: (TA:) or he (i. e. a man, O) exposed him to destruction; (O, K, TA;) and made him to be on the brink thereof. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And Aqltt She was, or became, such as is termed miqolaAtN [q. v.]. (S, O, K, TA.)

qalotN c
qalotN A [hollow, or cavity, such as is termed] nuqorap, [generally meaning such as is small, or not large, or such as is round,] in a mountain, (T, S, O, Msb, K,) in which water stagnates, (T, S, O, Msb,) i. e. the water of the rain, (Msb,) when a torrent pours down; (TA;) similar to what is termed waqob: (T, TA:) in some instances so large as to be capable of containing a hundred times as much as the contents of the [leathern water-bag called] mazaAdap: (Msb:) or a nuqorap in a rock: (A:) and any nuqorap in the ground, or in the body: of the fem. gender: (T, O, TA:) and [therefore] its dim. is qulayotapN↓: (O:) pl. qilaAtN. (T, S, O, Msb.) Hence the saying, Oasowadu mino maMCi Alqaloti [Blacker than the water of the qalot]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- Also A round hollow, or cavity, which water dropping from the roof of a cavern forms in the course of ages in soft stone or in hard ground. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence,] qalotu AlvRariydapi (tropical:) The hollow, or depression, of the mess of crumbled bread moistened with gravy, in which the gravy collects. (S, A, O, TA.) ― -b4- And qalotN signifies (tropical:) Any small hollow, or depression, in a member. (A.) ― -b5- And Alqalotu [alone], (TA,) or qalotu AltRaroquwapi, (A,)
(tropical:) The hollow, or depression, that is between the collar-bone and the neck. (A, * TA.) And qalotu AlEayoni (tropical:) The cavity of the eye. (S, A, O.) And qalotu AlSRudogi (tropical:) [The depression of the temple.]. (S, O, TA.) And qalotu AlUibohaAmi (tropical:) The hollow that is in the lower part of the thumb. (S, O, TA.) And qlt AlkafRi [app. signifies the same;] (tropical:) The part that is between the tendon of the thumb [i. e. of the flexor longus pollicis] and the fore finger; which is the middle part between these two [or between the thumb and the fore finger]. (TA.) And qalotu AlxaASirapi (tropical:) The depressed part of the flank: (AZ, TA:) or what is termed HuqRu Alwariki [app. meaning the socket, or turning-place, of the head of the thigh-bone]. (A, TA.) And qalotu AlrRukobapi (tropical:) The Eayon of the knee. (A, TA. [This, I should have thought, might mean the popliteal space, which is slightly depressed between the two hamstrings: but see EayonN.]) And the qalot (JK, TA) of the mouth (JK) of the horse (TA) is (tropical:) What is between the lahawaAt [app. meaning the furthest, or innermost, parts of the mouth], extending to the muHanRak [or place where the palate, or soft palate, is rubbed, or pierced, to make it bleed]. (JK, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also A man having little flesh: and so qalitN↓. (Lh, O, K.) ― -b2- And qalotapN (JK, K, TA, in the CK qalitapN, in the O qaltapN,) A ewe or she-goat whose milk is not sweet. (JK, O, K.)

qalatN c
qalatN [inf. n. of 1: used as a simple subst.,] Perdition; a state of destruction; or death. (S, O, K.) An Arab of the desert said, UinRa AlmusaAfira wamataAEahu laEalaI qalatK UilRaA maA waqaI QllRehu [Verily the traveller and his goods are in danger of destruction, except what God protects]. (S, O.) And one says, OaSobaHa EalaI qalatK i. e. [He became] on the brink of destruction: or in fear of a thing that beguiled him to venture upon an evil undertaking. (TA.) And OamosaI EalaI qalatK i. e. [He became] in a state of fear. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The state, or condition, of such as is termed miqolaAtN. (O, TA.)

qalitN c
qalitN: see qalotN, last sentence but one.

qalotapN c
qalotapN The channel [or oblong depression] between the two mustaches, against the partition between the two nostrils: also called the xunoEubap and nuwtap and vuwmap and hazomap and wahodap. (TA.)

qulayotapN c
qulayotapN dim. of qalotN: see the latter, first sentence.

maqolatN c
maqolatN: see maqolatapN.

muqolitN c
muqolitN: see miqolaAtN.

maqolanapN c
maqolanapN A place of perdition or destruction or death; (S, O, Msb, K;) as also maqolatN↓. (MF.) And hence, A desert, or waterless desert. (Msb.) And A place that is feared. (TA.)

miqolaAtN c
miqolaAtN (Lth, S, A, O, K) and muqolitN↓ (TA) A she-camel that brings forth one only, and does not conceive after: (Lth, S, O, K:) or whose young one has died; as also nakodaMCu:) (L in art. nkd:) and a woman of whom no child lives: (S, A, O, K:) or, accord. to Lth, a woman who has only one child; but Az disallowed this explanation: (O:) or a woman who brings forth one child, and does not bring forth any after that: (TA:) or any female to which there has remained no offspring: (Lh, TA:) pl. of the former maqaAliytu. (S, A, O.) [See an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph or art. Xxb.] Bishr Ibn-Abee-Kházim says, (S, * O,) mentioning the slaughter of Makhzoom Ibn-Dabbà ElAsadee, (O,)
taZalRu maqaAliytu AlnRisaMCi yaTaOonahu
yaqulona OalaA yuloqaI EalaI AlmaroCi miYozaru
[The women of whom no offspring lived, &c., passing the day treading upon him, saying, Shall not a waist-wrapper be thrown upon the man? for it seems that his body was indecently exposed]: in explanation of which it is said, the Arabs used to assert that when the mqlAt trod upon a noble, or generous, man, who had been slain perfidiously, her child lived. (S, O.)

1 qaliHato OasonaAnuhu c
1. qaliHato OasonaAnuhu, (A, Msb, K, *) aor.
qalaHa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. qalaHN, (A, * Msb, K, *) His (a man's, or- other creature's, TA) teeth became yellow: (A, K:) or became altered by yellowness or xuDorap [here meaning a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour; and in like manner are to be rendered similar words (primarily denoting “ greenness ”) in this art.]: (Msb:) or became discoloured by much yellowness, which thickened, and then became black, or of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour: (L:) HiborN signifies yellowness in the teeth; and when this become much in quantity, and thick, and black, and of a dark, or an ashy, dustcolour, it is termed qalaHN: (Sh:) or his teeth became yellow, and incrusted with dirt, from long disuse of the tooth-stick which is employed for cleaning them: (A'Obeyd:) or, as some say, his (a man's) teeth became yellow; and his (a camel's) teeth became of a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour. (MF. [But this is said in the TA to be strange.]) ― -b2- And qaliHa AlrRajulu The man had yellowness [&c.] in his teeth. (S.)

2 qalRaHotu OasonaAnahu c
2. qalRaHotu OasonaAnahu I removed the qalaH, i. e. yellowness [&c.] of his teeth. (A.) ― -b2- And qlRHhu He [cleansed and] cured of their qalaH [or yellowness &c.] his (a man's, and a camel's,) teeth: (TA:) a verb of the same class as qarRadotu in the phrase qarRadotu AlbaEiyra (S, K,) meaning “ I plucked off the ticks from the camel. ” (S.) EawodN yuqalRaju An aged camel whose teeth are cleansed (S, K) and cured of their yellowness [&c.] (S, A, K) is a prov.; (S, A;) applied to the aged that is disciplined and trained; (Meyd, A; *) or to one advanced in age with whom is done what is done with youths, or who does what do young men. (Ham p. 820.)

4 AqlH OasonaAnahu c
4. AqlH OasonaAnahu, said of time, It rendered his teeth yellow [&c.: see 1]. (A.)

5 AlmaroOapu UicaA gaAba zawojuhaA taqalRaHato c
5. AlmaroOapu UicaA gaAba zawojuhaA taqalRaHato i. e. (assumed tropical:) [The woman when her husband is absent] becomes dirty in her clothes; does not pay frequent attention to the cleansing of her person and her clothes: a saying in a trad., which some relate otherwise, saying tflRHt, with f: (TA in this art.:) but El-Khattábee holds the former to be the right, and to be from the yellowness that comes upon the teeth. (TA in art. flH.) ＝ -A2- And tqlRH AlbilaAda He applied himself to the earning, or gaining, of sustenance, or wealth, in the towns, or districts, in the case of drought, or barrenness of the earth. (K.)

qaloHN c
qaloHN An ass [app. a wild ass] advanced in age: (K:) and so qaloxN. (Lth and K in art. qlx.) [See art. qlx for two other significations mentioned in this art. (one of them inexactly) by Golius and Freytag.]

qiloHN c
qiloHN A dirty garment. (K.)

qalaHN c
qalaHN (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and qulaAHN↓, (Msb, K,) the former being the inf. n. of qaliHa, and the latter a simple subst., (Msb,) Yellowness in, or of, the teeth: (S, A, K:) or alteration of the teeth by yellowness or xuDorap [here meaning, as expl. before, a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]. (Mgh, * Msb.) [See also 1.]

qaliHN c
qaliHN: see OaqolaHu. ― -b2- Also Clad with, or wearing, a dirty garment, which is termed qiloHN. (Sh, TA.)

qulaAHN c
qulaAHN: see qalaHN.

OaqolaHu c
OaqolaHu (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb) and qaliHN↓, (A,) applied to a man, (S, A, L, Msb,) and to other than man, (L,) Having, in his teeth, what is termed qalaH [expl. above as a yellowness, &c.]: (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb:) fem. of the former qaloHaMCu: and pl. quloHN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And AlOaqolaHu signifies The juEal [or species of black beetle called cantharus]; (A, K, TA;) because of the filthiness of its mouth: (A, TA:) an epithet in which the quality of a subst. is predominant. (TA.)

muqalRaHN c
muqalRaHN (tropical:) Experienced, or expert, in affairs; whose qualities have been tried, or proved; (A, TA;) and rendered tractable, or submissive: applied to a man. (TA.)

1 qalaxa c
1. qalaxa, (S, L, K,) aor.
qalaxa
, (K,) inf. n. qaloxN (S, K) and qulaAxN (L) and qaliyxN, (Sb, S, K,) He (a stallion-camel) brayed: (S, L, K:) or began to bray: or brayed vehemently, as though he pulled out the sound from his chest. (L.) ― -b2- And qalaxa AlXRajarapa He pulled out, or up, the tree: (K, TA:) the x being substituted for E. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And qalaxa He struck a dry thing upon, or against, a dry thing. (K.)

2 qlRxhu biAlsRawoTi c
2. qlRxhu biAlsRawoTi, inf. n. taqoliyxN, He struck him a most vehement stroke with the whip. (K.) ＝ -A2- And qlRx AlnRabotu The plant, or herbage, became strong. (K.)

qaloxN c
qaloxN A stallion-camel excited by lust, (K, TA,) when he is [braying vehemently, as though] pulling out the sound of braying [from his chest: see 1]. (TA.) ― -b2- And An ass [app. a wild ass] advanced in age: (K, TA:) and so qaloHN; with H as well as with x. (TA; and K in art. qlH.) ― -b3- Also, [or perhaps qaSabN qaloxN,] Hollow reeds or canes. (K.)

qalaxo qalaxo c
qalaxo qalaxo, (K, TA,) with the final letter quiescent, (TA,) An expression uttered to the stallion-camel on the occasion of covering. (K.)

qulaAxN c
qulaAxN: see qalRaAxN. ― -b2- Also Large in the haAmap [or head; or crown, or upper part, of the head]: and hence used as a proper name, with the article Al, of the poet El-'Amberee, and of others. (TA.)

qalRaAxN c
qalRaAxN and qulaAxN↓ A braying stallion-camel: or one that brays vehemently. (L.)

1 qalada c
1. qalada, (aor.
qalida
, inf. n. qalodN, L.) He twisted, wound, or wreathed, a thing (or anything, L,) upon (ElI) another thing; (L, K;) as a qulob (the ornament so called) upon another qulob. (L.) ― -b2- [Hence,] aor. and inf. n. as above (S, L) He twisted a rope. (S, L, K.) qulida Haboluhu (tropical:) His rope was twisted: said of an old man who has become weak in judgment by reason of age, and whose opinion is not regarded. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- [Hence, also,] He made a piece of iron slender, and twisted, wound, or wreathed, it (K) upon a similar piece, (TA,) or upon another thing. (K.) ― -b4- qaladatohu AlHumRaI, (aor.
qalida
, inf. n. qalodN, L,) (assumed tropical:) The fever seized him every day. (L, K.) See qilodN. ＝ -A2- qalada, (aor.
qalida
, inf. n. qalodN, L,) He irrigated growing corn. (L, K.) ＝ -A3- qalada, aor.
qalida
, (inf. n. qalodN, L,) He collected water in a tank or cistern, (L, K,) and milk in a skin, (IAar, L, K,) ladling each out with a bowl, and pouring it into the tank or the skin, (AZ,) and clarified butter in a skin, (L,) and beverage, or wine, in his belly. (L, K.) See also qrd. ― -b2- qalada mina AlXRaraAb fiI jawofihi He drank of the beverage, or wine. (IKtt.)

2 qalRadahaA c
2. qalRadahaA, inf. n. taqoliydN; (S;) and qlRdhA qilaAdapF; (Msb, K;) He put a qlAdp [or necklace] upon her (a woman's, S, Msb) neck; (S, * K;) attired her therewith. (Msb.) [And so,] qaladotuhu AlsRayofa, I hung upon him the sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck or shoulder. (A.) [And] qlRd Albadanapa, inf. n. taqoliydN, He hung upon the neck of the camel or cow or bull brought as an offering to Mekkeh for sacrifice something to show that it was such an offering; (T, S, A, L, K, &c.;) namely, an old worn-out sandal, (JK,) or a piece of a skin, (Msb,) or of a sandal, (T, Mgh,) or of a mizaAdap, (Mgh,) or the loop of a mzAdp. (T.) The pagan Arabs used also to hang upon the necks of their camels pieces of the bark (lisHaMC) of the trees of the sacred territory of Mekkeh, as a means of protection against their enemies. (Zj, on verse 2 of ch. v. of the Kur.) ― -b2- Hence, taqoliydu AlwulaApi AlOaEomaAla (tropical:) [The investing of prefects, or the like, with offices of administration]. (S, L, K.) You say, qlRdhu EamalFA (tropical:) [He invested him with an office of administration]. (A, L.) qalRdhu niEamahu (tropical:) [He conferred upon him permanent badges of his favours]. (A.) [See qilaAdapN: and see also TawoqN and TwRq.] ― -b3- Hence, also, AltRaqoliydu fiI AldRiyni (tropical:) [The investing with authority in matters of religion]: (S, L:) Altqlyd means a man's following another in that which he says or does, firmly believing him to be right therein, without regard or consideration of the proof, or evidence; as though the former made the saying or deed of the other a qilaAdap upon his neck. (KT.) ＝ -A2- qlRdhu AlOamora (tropical:) He obliged him, or constrained him, to do the thing, or affair; he imposed upon him the thing, or affair. (L.) ＝ -A3- qulRida fulaAnN qilaAdapa sawoCK (tropical:) Such a one was satirized with that which left upon him a lasting stigma. (A.)

4 Aqld AlbaHoru Ealayohimo c
4. Aqld AlbaHoru Ealayohimo (tropical:) The sea drowned them. (K.) Aqld AlbHr ElI xaloqK kaviyrK (tropical:) The sea drowned a great number of people; as though it closed upon them: (S, L:) or, closed upon them, and covered them, when they were drowned therein. (A.)

5 tqlRd c
5. tqlRd, (K,) and tqlRdt, (S,) and tqlRd qilaAdapF, (L,) and tqlRdthA, (Msb,) He put on his neck, or attired himself with, a qlAdp [or necklace], and she did the same. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- tqlRd AlsRayofa (S, A, L) He hung upon himself the sword, putting its suspensory belt or cord upon his neck [or shoulder]. (A.) A poet says,
yaA layota zawojaki qado gadaA
mutaqalRidFA sayofFA warumoHFA
[Would that thy husband had gone hanging upon him a sword and bearing a spear]: he means, waHaAmilFA rumoHFA. (S, L.) [See a similar saying voce jadaEa.] ― -b3- tqlRd AlEamala (tropical:) [He became invested with an office of administration, or a prefecture]. (A.) ― -b4- tqlRd AlOamora (tropical:) He took, or imposed, upon himself, or undertook, the thing, or affair; (L;) syn. Ailotazamahu. (JK.) See Ham. p. 127.

qalodN c
qalodN: see maqoluwdN.

qilodN c
qilodN A single strand, or twist, of a rope; (AHn, ISd;) and the like of a bracelet: (see qulobN:) pl. OaqolaAdN and quluwdN. (AHn, ISd.) See maqoluwdN. ― -b2- The day on which a fever comes: (L, K:) or, on which a regular intermittent fever returns, seldom failing to do so at a particular time: (L:) or, on which a quartan fever comes: (S, L, K: *) pl. OaqolaAdN. (L.) ― -b3- Hence, (S, L.) The caravans from Mekkeh to Juddeh. (S, L, K.) ― -b4- Accord. to As, A man attacked by a quartan fever on the day of its attack. (L.) ＝ -A2- Irrigation of growing corn: (Az, L:) as also qaliydN↓. (L.) ― -b2- [And] qilodN signifies The day of irrigation. (L.) OaqaAma qilodahu mina AlmaMCi He performed the work of irrigating his land on the day appointed for his doing so. (L, from a trad.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) Irrigation by rain every week. (K.) You say, saqatonaA AlsRamaMCu qilodFA fiI kulRi OusobuwEK (assumed tropical:) The heaven rained upon us at a particular time every week: (S, L:) from the qilod of a fever. (L.) ― -b4- saqaI Uibilahu qilodFA (assumed tropical:) He watered his camels every day at noon. (Fr, L.) ― -b5- kayofa qilodu naxoli baniI fulaAnK [How is the watering of the palm-trees of the sons of such a one?] a question to which one may answer, They are watered (lit. they drink) once in every ten [nights]. (L.) ― -b6- A portion of water: (L, K:) [pl. OaqolaAdN, occurring in the A.]: and qilodapN↓ a draught of water. (A.) ＝ -A3- OaEoTayotuhu qiloda OamoriI (tropical:) I committed to him [the management of] my affair. (A, K.)

qilodapN c
qilodapN i. q. qiXodapN; (S, L, K;) i. e., The dregs, or sediment, of clarified butter; also called kudaAdapN. (L.) ― -b2- Also, Dates, and meal of parched barley or wheat (sawiyq), with which butter is clarified. (L, K.) ＝ -A2- And see qildN.

qalodapN c
qalodapN [as also qalotapN] i. q. xunoEubapN and nuwnapN and tuwmapN and hazomapN and wahodapN and harovamapN and EarotamapN and Hbrmp [?]: so says IAar.; and Lth says, that the xnEbp is The part where the mustaches divide, against the partition between the two nostrils. (L.)

qaliydN c
qaliydN and maqoluwdN↓ A twisted rope. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- and see qilodN ＝ -A3- and OaqoliydN.

qilaAdapN c
qilaAdapN [A necklace; a collar; and the like;] that which is upon the neck; (S;) what is put upon the neck (L, K) of a human being, and a horse, and a dog, and a camel or cow or bull that is brought as an offering to Mekkeh for sacrifice, [see 2,] and the like: (L:) Esh-Shiháb observes, in the 'Ináyeh, that the measure fiEaAlapN, in the case
of a word not an inf. n., denotes a thing that envelops, or that surrounds, another thing; as in the instances of lifaAfapN and EimaAmapN and qilaAdapN: (TA:) pl. qalaAYidu: (Msb:) qilaAdN also occurs, either as a pl. of qilaAdapN, in which case the kesreh and A in the pl. are different from the kesreh and A in the sing., [being the proper characteristics of the pl.,] or as a coll. gen. n., of which qilaAdapN is the n. un. (ISd, L.) ― -b2- Hasobuka mina AlqilaAdapi maA OaHaATa biAlEunuqi (assumed tropical:) [Sufficient for thee is the necklace that surrounds the neck]. A proverb. (TA.) Said by 'Okeyl Ibn-'Ullufeh, on his being asked why he did not censure his enemies in a longer satire. (Z.) ― -b3- niEomatuka qilaAdapN fiI EunuqiI laA yafukRuhaA AlmalawaAni (tropical:) [Thy beneficence is a permanent badge upon my neck which day and night will not loose]. (A.) ― -b4- liI fiI OaEonaAqihimo qalaAYidu niEamK raAhinapN (tropical:) [To me are owing acknowledgments required by permanent badges of favours firmly fastened upon their necks: see 2]. (A.) [This use of qlAdp in a good sense is more common than the meaning (tropical:) A disgrace attaching constantly or a permanent badge of infamy: see Ham. p. 127.] ＝ -A2- qalaAYidu AlXRiEori, (K,) and muqalRadaAtuhu↓, (L, K,) (assumed tropical:) Verses, or poems, that last throughout time. (L, K.) See 2. ＝ -A3- AlqilaAdapu A certain asterism. (See Albalodapu.)

qilRiydN c
qilRiydN: see miqolaAdN.

UiqolaAdN c
UiqolaAdN: see UiqoliydN.

OaqoliydN c
OaqoliydN: see UiqoliydN ＝ -A2- Oaqamotu OaqoliydiI, or AqlydatiI, [as in different copies of the A: perhaps mistakes for qaliydiI↓:] I irrigated my land with my qilod [or portion of water]. (A, TA.)

UiqoliydN c
UiqoliydN, (S, L, K,) or OaqoliydN↓, with fet-h to the C, (A,) said to be of the dial. of El-Yemen, and said to be arabicized, (Msb, TA,) originally klyd [i. e., kaliydo or kiliydo, which is Persian,] (TA) or originally Aqlyds, (Msb, MF,) which is Greek, [i. e., κλειδὸσ, gen. of κλεὶσ,] (MF,) A key; (S, A, L, Msb, K;) as also miqoladN↓ (L, K) and miqolaAdN↓ (K) and miqoliydN↓ (A Heyth, L) and UiqolaAdN↓: (L:) pl. OaqaAliydu (L, Msb, El-Basáïr) and maqaAliydu, (Msb, El-Basáïr,) the latter a pl. similar to malaAmiHu and maHaAsinu and maXaAbihu and macaAkiyru, (El-Basáïr,) or [rather] a [reg.] pl. of miqolaAdN or miqoliydN or miqoladN, (Esh-Shiháb, in the 'Ináyeh,) or it has no [proper] sing.; (As;) [and pl. of miqoladN, maqaAlidu of which see an ex. below]. [You say] fataHa AlbaAba biAlOaqoliydi↓, [or bAlUiqoliydi,] He opened the door with the key. (A.) ― -b2- lahu maqaAliydu QlsRamawaAti waQloOaroDi [Kur xxxix. 63, and xlii. 10,] may signify (assumed tropical:) To Him belong the keys of the heavens and of the earth: (L, Msb:) Zj says, that the meaning is, God is the Creator, and the Opener of the door, of everything in the heavens and in the earth: (L:) some say that it may signify to Him belong the treasuries of the heavens and of the earth. (Es-Suddee, L, Msb.) ― -b3- Oaloqayotu Uilayohi maqaAliyda AlOumuwri (tropical:) [lit., I threw to him the keys of the affairs; meaning, I committed to him the disposal, or management, of the affairs]. (A.) ― -b4- DaAqato maqaAliyduhu, and maqaAliduhu, (K,) and DaAqato Ealayohi AlmaqaAliydu, (A,) (tropical:) [His means, likened to keys, became straitened: or] his affairs became straitened, or difficult, to him: (A, K:) accord. to Esh-Shiháb, from miqoladN, signifying a twisted rope: this he says considering maqaAliydu as syn. with qalaAYidu; but its use in this sense is not established. (TA.)

miqoladN c
miqoladN A kind of key, like a reaping-hook, (S, L, K,) with which, sometimes, herbage is twisted, (yuqoladu, i. e., yufotalu,) like as [the kind of trefoil, or clover, called] qatR is twisted when it is made into ropes; pl. maqaAliydu: (S:) a stick with a crooked head, (L, K,) which is used for that purpose: (L:) also, a reaping-hook with which qatR is cut. (L.) See also UiqoliydN.

miqolaAdN c
miqolaAdN A repository, magazine, store-room, or treasury; (L, K;) as also qilRiydN↓: (K:) pl. maqaAliydu. (L.) ＝ -A2- And see UiqoliydN.

maqoluwdN c
maqoluwdN: see qaliydN. ― -b2- A bracelet formed of two bracelets of the kind called qulob twisted together: (L:) a twisted bracelet; as also qalodN↓: (L, K [the latter said in the K to be with fet-h, but in the L written qilodN:]) and the latter, [in the S written qalodN,] a bracelet made of twisted silver. (S, L.)

muqalRadN c
muqalRadN The place of the qilaAdap [or necklace, or collar, upon the neck]; (K;) [the neck of a woman, and of a horse, &c.]. ― -b2- The place of the suspensory belt or cord of the sword, upon the shoulders. (S, K.) ― -b3- [Having a qilaAdap or the like put upon his neck]. ― -b4- A horse which outstrips others, (S, L, K,) which has something put upon his neck in order that it may be known that he has outstripped. (S, L.) ― -b5- A chief upon whom are imposed the affairs of his people. (Ham p. 127.)

1 qalasa c
1. qalasa, aor.
qalisa
, inf. n. qalosN, He belched up, (S, * A, * Msb, K,) from his throat, (S, A, K,) or from his belly, to his mouth, (Msb,) as much as filled his mouth, or less, (S, A, Msb, K,) of [acid and undigested] food or drink, whether he cast it forth or returned it to his belly: when it overcomes [or is repeated (accord. to an explanation of qalosN or qalasN below,)] it [the action] is termed qaIoCN: (Msb:) or he vomited (qaMCa) as much as filled his mouth: (Mgh:) or he, or it, vomited, or cast forth; syn. qacafa. (S.) The act termed qalosN is an impurity which necessitates the performance of the ablution termed wuDuwoC: (A, Mgh:) so in a trad. (A.) ― -b2- qalasato nafosuhu, (A, K,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) His soul, or stomach, heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit: (A, K:) [like laqisato.] ― -b3- [Hence,] qalasati AlTRaEonapu biAldRami (tropical:) [The wound made with a spear or the like belched forth blood]. (A.) ― -b4- And qalasati AlsRaHaAbapu biAlnRadaI (tropical:) The cloud cast forth moisture, or fine rain; not vehement rain. (A, * TA.) ― -b5- And qalasati AlkaOosu, (S, K, *) aor. and inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) The cup of wine cast forth [or overflowed with] the beverage, in consequence of its being very full. (S, K. *) ― -b6- And qalasa AlbaHoru, aor. and inf. n. as above, (assumed tropical:) The sea, or great river, cast forth [or overflowed with] water, in consequence of its being very full. (K, * TA.)

2 qalRasa
2: see Q. Q. 1.

5 taqalRasa
5: see Q. Q. 2.

Q. Q. 1 qalosaAhu c
Q. Q. 1. qalosaAhu (S, K) and qalonasahu (K) He attired him with a qalanosuwap; (S, K;) as also qalRasahu↓, (A,) inf. n. taqoliysN. (TA.)

Q. Q. 2 taqalosaI c
Q. Q. 2. taqalosaI and taqalonasa He attired himself with, or wore, a qalanosuwap; (S, K;) as also taqalRasa↓. (S, A.) [The last of these verbs is used by ElHemedhánee transitively, as meaning, He attired himself with a cap of the kind called danRiyRap as a qlnswp: (see De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., T. iii., p. 90 of the Arabic text:) but perhaps this usage is only post-classical.]

qalosN c
qalosN, (A, K, and so in a copy of the S,) or qalasN↓, (A, Mgh, Msb, TA, and so in a copy of the S,) the former being the inf. n., (Mgh, Msb,) and qalasaAnN↓, (TA,) [but this last is more like an inf. n.,] What comes forth, (Kh [accord. to the S], or Lth, AZ [accord. to the TA], S, A, Msb, K,) from the throat, (Kh or Lth, S, A, K,) or from the belly, to the mouth, (AZ, Msb,) as much as fills the mouth, or less, (Kh or Lth, S, A, Msb, K,) of [undigested] food or drink, (AZ, Msb,) peculiarly, with acidity, and that acid humour itself, (Meyd, as cited by Golius,) whether the person cast it forth or return it to his belly: (AZ, Msb:) when it is repeated, (Kh, S, A, K,) or overcomes, (Lth, TA,) it is termed qaIoCN: (Kh or Lth, S, A, K:) or what comes forth, of vomit, being as much as fills the mouth: (Mgh:) pl. OaqolaAsN. (TA.)

qalasN c
qalasN: see qalosN.

qalosaApN c
qalosaApN: see qalanosuwapN.

qalosuwapN c
qalosuwapN: see qalanosuwapN.

qalasaAnN c
qalasaAnN: see qalosN.

qalanosuwapN c
qalanosuwapN (S, A, Msb, K) and qulanosiyapN↓ (S, K) and qalosuwapN↓ and qalosaApN↓ (TA) A certain thing that is worn upon the head, (K, TA,) well known; (TA;) [a cap, generally high and pointed, but sometimes close-fitting, which was worn by the Arabs, sometimes alone, and sometimes beneath the turban: there was also one kind which was round, like a melon: (see OuroSuwSapN:) and a cowl, or hood, of a pointed form: see TuroTuwrN, and buronusN, and EaraqiyRapN: 'Abd-El-Lateef applies the term qalanosuwap nuHaAs to the cap of copper which covered the head of the
obelisk standing on the site of Heliopolis, now called El-Matareeyeh:] the kind worn by the Companions [of the Prophet] was such as fitted close to the head, [not pointed, or] not going away into the air: (K in art. bTH:) pl. qalaAnisu and qalaAsK (S, Msb, K) and qalaAniysu and qalaAsiIRN and qalanosK, which last is [properly a coll. gen. n. of which qalanosuwapN is the n. un., being] originally qalanosuwN, for there is no noun ending with an infirm letter preceded by a dammeh, wherefore the w is changed into I, and the dammeh into a kesreh, and then the word becomes like qaADK [for qaADiIN]. (S, K.) The dim. is qulayonisapN↓ and qulayosiyapN↓ and qulayoniysapN↓ and qulayosiyRapN↓: (S, K:) but not qulayoniysiyapN; for the Arabs form no dim. of a word of five [or more] letters so as to preserve all the letters, unless the fourth be a letter of prolongation. (TA.)

qulanosiyapN c
qulanosiyapN see qalanosuwapN.

qulayosiyapN c
qulayosiyapN and qulayosiyRapN: see qalanosuwapN.

qulayonisapN c
qulayonisapN and qulayoniysapN: see qalanosuwapN.

qalaAnisiIRN c
qalaAnisiIRN: see qalRaAsN.

qalRaAsN c
qalRaAsN: see qaAlisN, in two places. ＝ -A2- A maker [or seller] of what is called qalanosuwap [or rather of qalaAnis, the pl.; and so qalaAnisiIRN↓; or this latter is perhaps post-classical]. (TA.)

qaAlisN c
qaAlisN act. part. n. of 1, in the first and subsequent senses. (S, A.) ― -b2- You say, TaEonapN qaAlisapN and qalRaAsapN↓ (tropical:) [A wound made with a spear or the like belching forth blood, and belching forth much blood]. (A.) And [in like manner], baHorN qalRaAsN↓ (assumed tropical:) A sea, or great river, casting forth [much water (see 1)] or froth or foam: (S:) or flowing with a very copious and high tide of water. (K.)

1 qalaSa c
1. qalaSa, (S, M, A, &c.) aor.
qaliSa
, inf. n. quluwSN, (S, M, Msb, K,) [has, among its significations, three which I mention together because two of them are assigned to it in one of the phrases here following, and all of them in another:] It contracted, or shrank; or became contracted or shrunk; (S, M, Mgh, L, Msb, K; *) as also qlRS↓, (S, Mgh, K, *) inf. n. taqoliySN; (K;) and tqlRS↓: (S, M, * Mgh, Msb, * K:) and i. q. AirotafaEa; [which has two significations: it rose, or became raised: and it went away:] (S, M, * A, Mgh, Msb, * K; *) as also qlRS↓, and tqlRS↓. (A, Mgh.) You say, qalaSa AlZRilRu, (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) and qlRS (TA) and tqlRS (Mgh) and AqlS↓, (Fr, TA,) The shade contracted, or shrank, (M, K, TA,) EanRiI from me: (M, K:) or decreased: (TA:) or went away; syn. AirotafaEa: (S, Msb, TA:) all of which explanations are correct. (TA.) And qalaSato Xafatuhu His lip became contracted; (S, M, Msb, K;) as also tqlRSt↓: (Msb:) or became contracted upwards. (A, TA.) And qalaSa AlDRaroEu The udder became drawn together. (TA.) And qalaSa AlvRawobu baEoda Algasoli The garment, or piece of cloth, contracted, or shrank, after the washing. (S, Msb, K.) And AlqamiySu qlRS↓, inf. n. taqoliySN; (K, TA;) or tqlRS↓; (M, TA;) The shirt became contracted, or raised, or tucked up: (M, K, TA:) and in like manner, AldRiroEu qlRSt↓, and tqlRSt↓, [the coat of mail became contracted,] most frequently meaning upwards. (TA.) ― -b2- It (water) collected in a well, and became abundant: (IKtt, TA:) or rose (S, M, K) in a well; (S;) syn. AirotafaEa: (S, M, K:) or, when said of the water of a well, it signifies AirotafaEa as meaning it went away: and also as meaning it rose by its becoming copious: (A, TA:) thus it has two contr. significations: and it is also said that qalaSati AlbiYoru signifies the water of the well rose to its upper part: and the well became nearly, or entirely, exhausted: (TA:) and qalaSa Algadiyru the water of the pool left by a torrent went away. (M.) ― -b3- qalaSato nafosuhu, (M, K,) aor.
qaliSa
, inf. n. qaloSN, (M,) and qaliSato, (M, K,) with kesr; (K;) His soul heaved; or became agitated by a tendency to vomit; syn. gavato: (M, K:) and a dial. form thereof is with s [i. e. qalasato, and also laqisato]. (TA.) ― -b4- Also qalaSa, aor.
qaliSa
, inf. n. quluwSN, He leaped, sprang, or bounded. (AA, K.) ― -b5- qalaSati AlUibilu; (so in a copy of the A;) and qlRSt↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taqoliySN; (K;) [probably signify the same: or] the former signifies The camels rose in their pace, or going: (A:) and the latter, they (the camels) were light, or active, and quick, or were vigorous, (XamRarato,) in their pace, or going: (M:) or went on in one regular, uniform, or constant, course. (K.) ― -b6- qalaSa, inf. n. quluwSN, also signifies He went away; (IB, TA;) and so qlRS↓, inf. n. taqoliySN: (TA:) each likewise signifies the same, but the latter in an intensive sense, said of tears; and so the latter when said of anything: (TA:) and so tqlRS↓ said of an animal's milk. (Mgh.) ― -b7- Also, qalaSa Alqawomu, inf. n. quluwSN, The company of men took up their luggage, (O, TS, K,) or collected themselves together, (L,) and went, or departed: (O, TS, L, K:) or they became distant, or remote: (TA:) or removed, or migrated, quickly from the dwelling. (A, TA.) ― -b8- And qalaSa AlgulaAmu, inf. n. as above, The boy grew up and walked. (TA.) See qaluwSN.

2 qalRaSa
2: see 1, passim: ― -b2- see also 4. ＝ -A2- qlRS qamiySahu He contracted his shirt; he raised it, or tucked it up. (M, K, * TA.) Thus the verb is trans. as well as intrans. (K.) ― -b2- qlRS biyona AlrRajulayoni He separated the two men, each from the other, in a case of reviling or fighting; syn. xalRaSa. (M.)

4 AqlS c
4. AqlS: see 1, second sentence. ― -b2- It (a camel's hump) began to come forth: (IKtt, TA:) and, said of a camel, his hump appeared in some degree, (ISk, S, K, TA,) and rose: (TA:) and in like manner AqlSt said of a she-camel: (TA:) or the latter signifies she (a camel) became fat in her hump; as also qlRSt↓; and in like manner one says of a he-camel [AqlS and qlRS↓]: (M:) or she became fat in the [season called] Sayof: (S, M, * K:) or i. q. gaArato; [so in the copies of the K, evidently a mistake for gaArRato, q. v.;] and her milk went away, or became drawn up; (K;) [a signification nearly agreeing with explanations of gArRt;] opposed to Oanozalato. (TA.) See also qalaSN.

5 taqalRaSa
5: see 1, passim.

qaloSN c
qaloSN Abundance of water: and, contr., paucity thereof: (TA:) and qalaSapN↓ and qaloSapN↓ have the former of these significations: (M:) or qalaSapN↓ signifies water of a well collecting therein and rising: (S, K:) and so qaloSapN↓, accord. to some lexicologists, as mentioned by Ibn-El-Ajdábee: (IB:) the pl. of qalaSapN is qalaSaAtN: (S, K:) and the pl. [or rather quasi-pl. n.] of qaloSapN is qalaSN↓. (IB.) An Arab of the desert is related to have said, mina AlmaACi famaA wajadotu fiyhaA UilRaA qaloSapF↓, meaning, And I found not in it [i. e. the well] save a little quantity of water. (TA.)

qalaSN c
qalaSN: see qaloSN. ＝ -A2- The beginning of a she-camel's becoming fat; as also quluwSN↓. (M.) See 4.

qaloSapN c
qaloSapN and qalaSapN: see qaloSN, throughout.

qaluwSN c
qaluwSN A young, or youthful, she-camel; (S, M, Msb, K;) i. e. among camels (Mgh, Msb) the like of a jaAriyap among women: (S, Mgh, Msb:) or such as endures journeying; (Lth, K;) so called until her tush grows forth, [in her ninth year,] when she ceases to be so called: (Lth:) or a young, or youthful, Arabian camel: (TA:) or a she-camel from the time when first ridden, until she sheds the central incisor, [in her sixth year,] when she is called naAqapN; (El-'Adawee, S, Sgh, K;) the he-camel during that period being called qaEuwdN, and then jamalN: (El-'Adawee, S, Sgh:) or any sh-camel from the time when she is ridden, whether she be a binotu labuwnK or a HiqRap, until she becomes a bakorap, or until her tush grows forth: (M:) or a she-camel in her sixth year: or in her second year: (M:) and sometimes a she-camel just born is thus called: (M:) the qlwS is so called because of the length of her legs, and her not being yet bulky in the body: (T, TA:) and a long-legged she-camel is so called, (S, K,) sometimes: (S:) the term is only applied to a female: (IDrd, K:) [dim. qulayRiSapN, of the pl. of which (qulayRiSaAtN) see an ex. in a verse cited in art. dh:] pl. qalaAYiSu and quluSN (S, M, A, Mgh, Msb, K) and quloSaAnN (M, L) and (pl. pl., K, i. e. pl. of quluSN, S) qilaASN. (S, M, Msb, K.) [Hence,] qilaASu AlvRaloji (tropical:) The clouds that bring snow. (A, TA.) [Hence also,] qilaASu AlnRajomi [also called AlqilaASu and AlqalaAYiSu] (assumed tropical:) Twenty stars, which, as the Arabs assert, AldRabaraAn drove before him in demanding in marriage AlvRurayRaA; (TA;) some small stars before AldbrAn, following AlvryRA: (Mir-át ez-
Zemán:) [by some applied in the present day to the Hyades:] or the qilaAS are the stars around AldRabaraAn. (Kzw.) ― -b2- Also, (tropical:) A young, or youthful, female of the ostrich-kind; like the qlwS of the camel-kind; (M, TA;) the female of riYaAl [or young ostriches, or young ostriches a year old]; i. e. a raOolap; (TA;) a female of the ostrich-kind, of such as are termed rYAl: (S:) or a female of the ostrich-kind: (A, O, K:) and of such as are termed rYAl: (K:) or quluSu AlnRaEaAmi signifies the rYAl of the ostrich: (IDrd, TA:) or qlwS [so in the TA, app. a mistake for quluS,] signifies the offspring of the ostrich; its HafRaAn and its rYAl: so says IKh, on the authority of El-Azdee. (IB, TA.) ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) The young of the [species of bustard called] HubaAraI: (K:) or the female of the HbArI: or a little female HbArI. (M.) ― -b4- quluSN is also metonymically applied to signify (tropical:) Young women; (K;) as also qalaAYiSu: (TA:) and the latter, to signify women [in a general sense]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- biYorN qaluwSN A well having abundance of water: pl. qalaAYiSu. (M.)

quluwSN c
quluwSN: see 1, (of which it is an inf. n.,) throughout: ― -b2- and see qalaSN.

qaliySN c
qaliySN: see qaAliSN.

qalRaASN c
qalRaASN: see qaAliSN.

ZilRN qaAliSN c
ZilRN qaAliSN Shade [contracting, or shrinking, from one: (see 1:) or] decreasing: (S, TA:) [or going away.] XafapN qaAliSapN A contracting lip: (S:) and rajulN qaAliSu AlXRafapi a man having a contracting lip. (Msb.) vawobN qaAliSN A garment contracted and short: (Sh, TA:) and qmyS muqalRiSN↓ a short shirt: (A:) or a shirt contracted, or raised, or tucked up: and diroEN muqalRiSapN↓ [a coat of mail contracted]: most frequently meaning upwards. (TA.) ― -b2- maMCN qaAliSN and qaliySN↓ and qalRaASN↓ Water collecting and becoming abundant in a well: (TA:) or rising, or high, (S, M, K,) in a well: (S:) the pl. of qaliySN is quluSN. (TA.) See also 1.

muqalRiSN c
muqalRiSN: see qaAliSN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, applied to a horse, Long in the legs, and contracted in the belly: (M, TA:) or light, or active, and quick, (muXamRirN,) tall, and long in the legs: (S, K:) or tall. (A.)

miqolaASN c
miqolaASN A she-camel fat in the hump; and in like manner, a he-camel: (M:) or a she-camel that becomes fat in the [season called] Sayof: (S, M:) and also, a she-camel that becomes fat and lean in the winter. (Ks, TA.)

dictScrap.label: qlE qlf qlq: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
quloqaAsN c
quloqaAsN [The colocasia; or arum. colocasia of Linnæus: or its root:] the root of a certain plant, which is eaten cooked, (AHn, K,) and used medicinally: (AHn:) the decoction thereof increases the venereal faculty, and fattens; but the taking it constantly engenders black bile. (AHn, K.) [See De Sacy's “ Relation de l'Egypte par Abd-allatif, ” pp. 94 — 98.]

dictScrap.label: qlm qlw qlI qmR: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qamaOati AlmaAXiyapu c
1. qamaOati AlmaAXiyapu, aor.
qamaAa
; (AZ, S, O, K;) and qamuWat, (O, K,) aor.
qamuAa
; (K;) inf. n. qumuwoCN and qumuwCapN, (AZ, S, O, K) both of the former verb, (AZ, S, O,) and qamoCN (K) and qamaMCapN, (O, K,) which is of the latter verb, (O, TA,) and qamaMCN, (K,) also of the latter verb; (TA;) The cattle became fat, or plump; (AZ, S, O, K;) as also AqmOt↓: (K:) the first is expl. in the T as meaning the cattle became full with fatness: and the epithet applied to them is there said to be qaAmiYapN↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And qamaOati AlUibilu biAlmakaAni, (K, TA,) and qamuWat, (K,) The camels abode in the place, (K, TA,) and were pleased with it, (TA,) because of its abundant pasture, and became fat, or plump, (K, TA,) in it. (TA.) And qamaOati AlmaAXiyapu makaAna kacaA HatRaI saminato [The cattle abode in such a place until they became fat, or plump]. (TA.) See also 5. ― -b3- And qamaOotu biAlmakaAni, (O, TA,) inf. n. qamoCN, (TA,) I abode in the place: (O:) or I entered the place and abode in it. (TA.) And qamaOa UilaI manozilK He went into an abode. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qamaOahu is also syn. with qamaEahu [q. v.]: (K:) the latter is affirmed to be the original word: (MF:) you say qamaOotu AlrRajula, meaning qamaEotuhu. (O.) ＝ -A3- qamuWa, (S, O, K,) aor.
qamuAa
; and qamaOa, aor.
qamaAa
; (K;) inf. n. qamaMCapN (S, O, K) and qamaMCN, both of the former verb, (S, O,) and qumoCN and qimoCN, (so in copies of the K,) or qumoOapN and qimoOapN, (so in the TK,) and qamoOapN, (K,) which last is not an inf. n. un., (L, TA,) said of a man, (S, O, TA,) and of other than a man, (TA,) He was, or became, little and despicable (S, O, K, TA) in the eyes [of others]: (TA:) the former verb is the better known in this sense. (MF, TA.)

3 maA qaAmaOahu c
3. maA qaAmaOahu It (a thing, TA) did not suit him: (K, TA:) and so mA qaAnaOahu. (TA.)

4 AqmOt AlmaAXiyapu c
4. AqmOt AlmaAXiyapu: see 1, first sentence. ― -b2- AqmO Alqawomu The people, or party, had their camels in a fat, or plump, state. (S, O, K.) ― -b3- AqmO AlmaroEaI AlUibila The pasture, or place of pasture, suited the camels, (K, TA,) and rendered them fat, or plump. (TA, as from the K.) And AqmOhu It (a thing, S, O, or a place, or pasture or a place of pasture, TA) pleased him. (S, O, K, TA.) ＝ -A2- And AqmOhu He rendered him little and despicable. (S, O, K.)

5 tqmROa AlmakaAna c
5. tqmROa AlmakaAna (in the CK AlmkAnu) [He found that] the place suited him, and consequently he abode in it. (O, K.) ― -b2- tqmRO AlXRaIoCi He took the best of the thing. (Th, K.) ― -b3- And He collected the thing little by little: (S, O:) and accord. to Z, AlXRaIoCi AqtmO↓ signifies He collected the thing. (TA.)

8 UiqotamaAa
8: see what immediately precedes.

qamoCN c
qamoCN A place in which a she-camel, and a hecamel, and a woman, and a man, abides until she, or he, becomes fat, or plump. (TA.)

qamoOapN c
qamoOapN Abundance of herbage, or of the goods, conveniences, and comforts, of life; and ease, repose, or freedom from trouble or inconvenience or from toil or fatigue; as also qumoOapN↓. (K.) ― -b2- Also, and maqomaOapN↓ and maqomuWapN↓, (like mqnO [a mistranscription for mqnOp] and mqnWp, TA,) A place on which the sun does not come: (O, K:) pl. of the first word qimaMCN. (TA.)

qumoOapN c
qumoOapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

qamiIoCN c
qamiIoCN Little and despicable (S, O, K, TA) in the eyes [of others]; fem. qamiyYapN: (TA:) pl. qimaMCN and qumaMCN; (K;) the latter of a [very] rare form. (TA.)

qaAmiYapN c
qaAmiYapN, fem. of qaAmiYN: see 1, first sentence.

maqomaOpN c
maqomaOpN and maqomuWapN: see qamoOapN.

1 qamiHahu c
1. qamiHahu, (S, A, L, K,) aor.
qamaHa
, (K,) inf. n. qamoHN; (S;) and AqtmHhu↓; (S, A, L, K;) He ate it, or took it into his mouth, (S, K,) namely, meal of parched barley or wheat, &c., (S, A, L,) not bread nor dates nor the like, but only what is eaten in the manner termed safRN, (L,) without moistening it, or kneading it with water &c.; syn. AisotafRahu; (S, K;) he took it in the palm of his hand (A, L) [and conveyed it] to his mouth (A) or licked it up. (L.) And qumoHapF minohu AiqotamaHotu↓ [I so ate a mouthful thereof, i. e. of what is eaten in the manner described above]. (A.) ― -b2- And AqtmHhu↓ likewise signifies, (L, K,) as also qamiHahu, (L,) He drank it, namely, what is called nabiyc, (L, K,) and XaraAb [app. as meaning wine], and water, and milk. (L.) ＝ -A2- And, from qamiHahu signifying as expl. above, you say, qamaHa Eani AlmaMCi, (A,) or [simply] qamaHa, (S, L, K,) with fet-h, (S,) aor.
qamaHa
, (L,) inf. n. qumuwHN; (S, L, K;) as also qamaha, aor.
qamaHa
, inf. n. qumuwhN; (L;) and qAmH↓, (A, L,) inf. n. muqaAmaHapN and qimaAHN; (A;) and tqmRH↓, and
AnqmH↓; (S, L, K;) He (a camel) raised his head (S, A, K) from the water (A) or at the watering-trough, and refused to drink, (S, K,) his thirst being satisfied, (S, A,) or by reason of loathing, or of the coldness of the water, or of some disease. (A.) And AlUibilu qaAmaHati↓ The camels came to the water and did not drink, (S, K,) but raised their heads, (S,) by reason of disease, or of cold, (S, K,) or of the coldness of the water, or because their thirst was satisfied. (TA.) And Xariba fataqamRaHa↓ and QnoqamaHa↓ [He drank] and raised his head and left drinking by reason of his thirst's being satisfied. (S.) And fulaAnN mina AlmaMCi tqmRH↓ Such a one drank water, or the water, with dislike, or loathing. (AZ.) OaXorabu faOataqamRaHu↓, said by Umm-Zara, means (tropical:) [I drink] and I satisfy my thirst until I am not able to drink more, so I raise my head like the [camel that is said to be] muqaAmiH: (A, TA: *) Az says that AltRaqamRuHu primarily relates to water, but is metaphorically used by her in relation to milk: she means that she satisfied her thirst with milk until she raised her head from drinking it like as does the camel when he dislikes drinking water: (TA:) or, as some relate her words, she said, faOataqanRaHu, (A, TA, *) which [likewise] means, “ and I raise my head in consequence of the being satisfied with drinking. ” (A.) [See also art. qnH.] ― -b2- qamaHa, aor.
qamaHa
, inf. n. qumuwHN, is also expl. by Lth as signifying He (a camel) became very languid by reason of vehement thirst: but accord. to Az, this is wrong. (L.)

2 qmRHhu c
2. qmRHhu, (A, K,) inf. n. taqomiyHN, (K,) (tropical:) He repelled him (i. e. his companion, A) with a small and paltry thing, in lieu of much that was due to him; (A, K; *) like as the wronging commander does to him who engages with him in a warring, or warring and plundering, expedition, by doling to him the least, or meanest, thing, and choosing for himself in preference to him in the partition of the spoil. (A, TA.)

3 qaAomaHa
3: see 1, near the middle, in two places. ― -b2- Hence, (S, A,) XahoraA qimaAHK, (S, A, K,) also called XahoraA qumaAHK↓, (K,) The two coldest, (S, K,) or two of the coldest, (A,) months (S, A, K) of winter; (A;) said by Sh to be XiybaAnu and miloHaAnu; (TA; [in which it is also here said that they are the two months whereof each is called kaAnuwn: if so, corresponding to December and January O. S.: but see XiybaAnu, in art. Xyb:]) so called because the camels, when they come therein to water, find its coldness hurtful to them, and therefore raise their heads from it. (S.)

4 OuqomiHa c
4. OuqomiHa, (MA,) [in my MS. copy of the K indefinitely written AqmH, and in the CK MqomaHa, but it is correctly OuqomiHa, as is shown by its being added, after the explanation, in the TA, “ whence muqomaHuwna↓ in the Kur ” (xxxvi. 7,] and by explanations of this epithet in several of the expositions of the Kur-án, and the like is also indicated in the S,] inf. n. UiqomaAHN, (S,) said of a camel, (MA,) or of a man, and [in this case, but not when said of a camel,] tropical, (TA,) He raised his head, and contracted his eyes: (S, MA, K, TA:) [or he was made to raise his head and to contract his eyes:] it is expl. by Z as in the K. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, (S,) OaqomaHahu AlgulRu (tropical:) The gulR [i. e. the ring, or collar, of iron, for the neck, or the shackle for the neck and hands, consisting of two rings, one for the neck and the other for the hands, connected by a bar of iron,] caused his (i. e. a captive's K) head to be raised, by reason of the straitness thereof; (S, K, TA;) meaning that the bar of the gulR, which [by its projecting above the ring around the neck] pricked his chin, did not let him lower his head; as is said in the A. (TA.) ― -b3- AlUiqomaAHu [as inf. n. of OuqomiHa, like OukomiHa (with k and H) in form and in meaning,] also signifies (assumed tropical:) The elevating of the head by reason of pride: and so AlUikomaAxu. (L and TA in art. kmx: but in the CK, in that art, AlAiqomAxu, with x.) And AqmH biOanofihi [i. e. OuqomiHa] signifies Xamaxa [i. e. Xamaxa biOanofihi, (assumed tropical:) He magnified, or exalted, himself; was proud; behaved proudly, or disdainfully; or elevated his nose, from pride]; (K, TA;) and raised his head, scarcely ever, or never, lowering it: as though the verb had two contr. significations. (TA.) ― -b4- AqmH said of thirst is expl. by Lth as signifying It rendered a camel very languid: but accord. to Az, this is wrong. (L.) ＝ -A2- AqmH AlsRunobulu The ears [of wheat] became pervaded by the farinaceous substance. (K.) ― -b2- And AqmH AlburRu, so in the T and L and other lexicons, but in all the copies of the K AlburRu AiqotamaHa↓, The wheat becomes mature qamoH. (TA.)

5 taqamRaHa
5: see 1, near the middle, in four places.

7 UinoqamaHa
7: see 1, near the middle, in two places.

8 UiqotamaHa
8: see 1, first quarter, in three places: ＝ -A2- and see also 4, last sentence.

qamoHN c
