qamoHN Wheat, syn. burRN, (S, A, Mgh, L, Msb, K,) and HinoTapN, and TaEaAmN, (Msb,) when the farinaceous substance pervades the ears, or from the time when it has attained its full growth to the time when it has become compact: (L:) [and the grain of wheat; as also burRN and HinoTapN and TaEaAmN:] a word of the dial. of Syria. and sometimes used by the people of El-Hijáz; or, as some say, a Coptic word; but the former assertion is the more correct: (TA:) the word burRN is more chaste: (S in art. br:) qamoHapN↓ signifies a single grain thereof. (Msb.) ― -b2- jaraI AlqamoHu fiI AlsRunobuli means The farinaceous substance pervaded the ears [of wheat]. (L.)

qamoHapN c
qamoHapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

qumoHapN c
qumoHapN A mouthful of qamiyHap [q. v.]: (S, K:) or, as more than one have said of water. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also AlqumRaHaAnu.

AlqimoHaI c
AlqimoHaI and AlqimoHaApu The qayoXap [q. v.. generally meaning the glans of the penis]. (K.)

AlqimoHaAnapu c
AlqimoHaAnapu The part between the qamaHoduwap [or occiput] and what is termed nuqorapu AlqafaA [which is the small hollow in the back of the neck]. (K.)

AlqumRaHaAnu c
AlqumRaHaAnu, thus accord. to the Basrees, (TA,) and AlqumRaHaAnu, and AlqumoHapu↓, (K,) The [plant called] waros [q. v.]: (S, K, TA:) or [the kind of perfume called] AlcRariyrapu: (TA:) or (so accord. to the K and TA, but in the S “ also, ”) a substance that comes upon the surface of wine, like AlcRariyrap: (S, K, TA:) it is the froth, or scum, thereof: (L, TA:) or, as some say, (TA, but in the K “ and, ”) saffron: (K, TA:) or a certain perfume: or a white substance that overspreads wine resembling AlcRariyrap: this last is said to be what is meant in the following verse by En-Nábighah [Edh-Dhubyánee], the only poet known by AHn to have mentioned AlqmRHAn:
UicaA fuDRato xawaAtimuhu EalaAhu
yabiysu AlqumRaHaAni mina AlmudaAmi
[When its seals are broken, what is exsiccated of the white substance resembling particles of calamus aromaticus of the wine comes, or appears, upon its surface]. (L, TA.)

qumaAHN c
qumaAHN, a subst. from qamaHa or qaAmaHa, Aversion of a camel from drinking, by reason of the thirst's being satisfied, or of loathing, or of the coldness of the water, or of some disease. (L. [See also HumaAmN.]) Hence XahoraA qumaAHK, also called XahoraA qimaAHK: see 3.

UinRahu laqamuwHN lilnRabiyci c
UinRahu laqamuwHN lilnRabiyci Verily he is a great drinker of the beverage called nebeedh. (ISh.)

qamiyHapN c
qamiyHapN a subst. signifying What is eaten in the manner termed AiqotimaAH, [see qamiHa,] (S, L,) of the meal of parched barley or wheat, &c., (L,) or such as a digestive stomachic (juwaAriX [often written jawaAriX], &c.: (S:) expl. in the K by the word juwaAriX [only], in some copies with the addition of a final n [evidently a mistake for t, since its original in the Pers. GuwaAriXo or GuwaAriXot]: (TA:) app. from AlqamoHu meaning AlburRu. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, maA OaSaAbati AlUibilu UilRaA qamiyHapF mino kalaOK (tropical:) The camels obtained not [aught] save somewhat of dry herbage which they took into the mouth unmoistened, or licked up. (A, TA.)

qaAmiHN c
qaAmiHN A camel raising his head (S, A, K) from the water (A) or at the watering-trough, and refusing to drink, (S, K,) his thirst being satisfied, (S, A,) or by reason of loathing, or of the coldness
of the water, or of some disease: (A:) and disliking water from any cause: (K:) and muqaAmiHN↓ signifies the same, applied to a he-camel, (As, S, A,) and to a she-camel: (As, S, K:) pl. of the former qumRaHN; (S, K;) and of ↓the latter qimaAHN, which is anomalous, (S,) or this is pl. of qaAmiHN, or it is [an inf. n.] syn. with muqaAmaHapN, used as an epithet; you say UibilN qimaAHN; (A;) and UibilN muqaAmiHapN↓. (S.) ― -b2- Also, (K,) as expl. by Lth, and so muqaAmiHN↓, but, accord. to Az, wrongly, (L,) A camel very languid by reason of vehement thirst. (L, K.)

muqomaHuwna c
muqomaHuwna: see 4, first sentence.

muqaAmiHN c
muqaAmiHN, and its fem.: see qaAmiHN, in three places.

AlqamaHoduwapu c
AlqamaHoduwapu What is behind the head; (S, in art. qHd; and Msb;) that is to say, (Msb,) the [occiput or] hinder part of the back of the head; (T, Msb, K;) i. e., the surface between the cuWaAbap [here app. meaning the hair that surrounds the round part of the head] and what is termed faOosu AlqafaA [or the small protuberance above the back of the neck]: (T:) also, the protuberance above the back of the neck, (L, K,) between the cuWaAbap [see above] and the back of the neck, sloping down from the haAmap [or middle, or crown, or top, of the head]; it is the part of the head which touches the ground when a man lies on his back: (L:) also, the upper part of the back of the head: (L, K:) or that part of the bone of the head which projects over the back of the neck; the hAmp being above it; and the qacaAl, below it, next the part of the back of the neck that is between the ears: (AZ, L:) pl. qamaAHidu (S, L, K, &c.) and qamaAHiydu and qamaHoduwaAtN. (L.) Accord. to J and AHei, the m is an augmentative letter; but others hold it to be a radical; and F says, that J's mentioning this word in art. qHd requires consideration. (TA.)

1 qamida c
1. qamida, aor.
qamada
, (TA,) inf. n. qamadN, (K,) He, or it, was, or became, tall, or long: or he was, or became, large and long in the neck. (K, TA.)

Q. Q. 4 UiqomahadRa c
Q. Q. 4. UiqomahadRa [in which the h is an augmentative letter accord. to J, is said by F to be improperly assigned by J to this art.] see art. qmhd.

qumudRN c
qumudRN (Lth, S, L, K) and qumudN (K) or qumodN (L) and qumodudN (Lth, L) and qumoduwdN and qumaAdN and qumaAdiIRN (K) and qumudRaAnN and qumudRaAniIRN (L, K) Strong: (Lth, S, K:) or strong and hard or hardy: (L:) or gross, thick, coarse, or rude, (K,) and hard, or hardy: (TA:) applied to a man: (L, K:) fem. qumudRapN (S) and qumudRaAnapN and qumudRaAniyRapN. (L.) ― -b2- UinRahu laqumudRN qumodudN Verily he is very strong. (Lth, L.) ― -b3- cakarN qumudRN Penis vehementer se erigens, (L, K,) or AlqumudRu is a name of the penis. (L.) ― -b4- See also Oaqomadu.

Oaqomadu c
Oaqomadu, fem. qamodaMCu, (L, K,) and qumudRN↓ and [fem.? see qumudRu above] qumudRapN and qumudRaAniyRapN, (K,) Large and long in the neck: or tall, (L, K,) in a general sense: applied to a human being. (L.) ― -b2- naHonu qumodu AlOaqomaAdi We are thick-necked. (L.) ― -b3- See also qumudRN.

1 qamira c
1. qamira, aor.
qamara
, (S, A, K,) inf. n. qamarN, (S,) He, (a man, S, A, K, and an antelope, and a bird, TA,) and it, (a man's sight, A,) became dazzled (S, A, K) in the moonlight, (A,) or by snow, (S, A, K,) so that he could not see: (S, A:) he (an antelope) became deprived of his sight by the light of the moon, so that he was perplexed, and unable to see his right course. (IKtt.) ― -b2- qamira, aor.
qamara
, (K,) inf. n. as above, (TA,) He (a man, TA,) was, or became, sleepless in the moonlight. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 3, throughout.

3 qAmrhu c
3. qAmrhu, inf. n. qimaArN (S, A, Msb, K) and muqaAmarapN, (S, K,) (tropical:) He contended with him for stakes, or wagers, laid by both of them to be taken by the winner; syn. raAhanahu; (K;) [he contended with him in a game of hazard, such as that called Almayosir, or the like: (see Bd and Jel, ii. 216:)] in common modern conventional language, he played with him at a game in which it is generally made a condition that the winner shall receive something of the loser: (so accord. to an explanation which I find in several copies of the KT:) from taqamiarahu signifying “ he deceived him; ” because qimaAr is [often] deception. (A.) You say qaAmarahu faqamarahu↓, aor. of the latter
qamura
(JK, S, A, Msb, K) and
qamira
, (JK,) inf. n. qamorN, (S, Msb,) (tropical:) He contended with him for stakes, or wagers, &c., (S, * K,) and overcame him therein; (S, A, Msb, K;) and qaAmarahu fataqamRarahu↓ signifies the same: (K:) or tqmRr↓ signifies he overcame him who contended with him in the contest termed qimaAr: and qamarahu↓, aor.
qamira
, inf. n. qamorN, he played with him in the manner termed qimaAr and overcame him: (S:) or qamarahu↓, inf. n. qamorN, he overcame him in play; and so Oaqomarahu↓: (IKtt:) or qamara↓, aor.
qamira
, (K,) inf. n. qamorN, (TA,) i. q. qAmr, (K, * TK,) and is transitive: (TA:) you say qamara biAlqidaAHi, and biAlnRarodi, [he contended for stakes, or wagers, &c., with the gaming-arrows, and with the apparatus for trictrac or backgammon]: (A:) and qamarahu↓ [as syn. with qaAmarahu]: (TA:) and AlmaAla qamarotuhu↓, aor.
qamira
, [so in a copy of the A, doubly trans., app. meaning I contended with him in a game of hazard for the property: or I so contended with him for the property and overcame him.]

4 Aqmr AlhilaAlu c
4. Aqmr AlhilaAlu The new moon became what is termed qamar, in the third night. (A.) ― -b2- Aqmrt layolatunaA Our night became bright [with light of the moon]. (S, TA.) ― -b3- OaqomaronaA [We entered upon the time of moonlight;] the moon rose upon us. (S, TA.) ― -b4- Aqmr He (a man, TA) watched, or waited, for the rising of the moon. (K.) ＝ -A2- See also 3.

5 tqmRrhu c
5. tqmRrhu He came to him in the moonlight. (S.) ― -b2- tqmRr AlZRibaMCa, (A, TA,) and AlTRayora, (TA,) He hunted, or pursued, the antelopes, (A, TA,) and the birds, (TA,) in the moonlight, so that their sight was dazzled. (A, TA.) ― -b3- tqmRr AlOasadu The lion went forth in the moonlight in quest of prey. (S, K. *) ＝ -A2- tqmRrhu He deceived, beguiled, or circumvented, him; desired to do him some evil action without his knowing whence it proceeded. (A.) ＝ -A3- See also 3, in two places.

6 tqAmrwA c
6. tqAmrwA They played [together] in the manner termed qimaAr: (S:) they contended together for stakes, or wagers, &c.; (K;) [they contended together in a game of hazard, such as that called Almayosir, or the like: see 3.]

Alqamaru c
Alqamaru The moon in its third night [and after]: (ISd, A, K:) or the moon during the interval between the first two and last two nights: (AHeyth:) or after three nights until the end of the month: (S:) [and the moon, absolutely, in many instances:] so called because of its whiteness, (S, Msb, TA,) from Alqumorapu: (TA:) of the masc. gender: pl. OaqomaArN. (TA.) The dim., qumayorN, is found to occur: (S:) and is applied to The moon at the time called muHaAq [which is generally said to be applied to the last three nights of the month]: you say gaAba qamayorN [The moon at the time called muHaAq set, or disappeared]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- AisotaroEayotu maAliIa Alqamara (tropical:) I left my cattle to pasture without a pastor to take care of them in the night: and [in like manner,] AstrEyth AlXRamos, in the day. (TA.) ― -b3- AlqamaraAni The sun and the moon: one of them [namely the latter] being made predominant. (TA.)

qamirN c
qamirN: fem. with p: see Oaqomaru.

qumorapN c
qumorapN A colour inclining to greenness: (A, K:) or whiteness inclining to dinginess or duskiness: (A:) or whiteness in which is a dinginess or duskiness: (K:) or clear, or pure, whiteness. (TA.) See also Oaqomaru.

qamariIRN c
qamariIRN [Of, or relating to, the moon; lunar]. Ex. AlsRanapu AlqamariyRapu The lunar year. (Mgh, art. Xms.)

qumoriIRN c
qumoriIRN is a rel. n. from TayorN qumorN: and qumorN is either pl. of Oaqomaru, like as HumorN is of OaHomaru, or pl. [or rather coll. gen. n.] of qumoriIRN, like as ruwmN is of ruwmiIRN: (S, Msb:) or qumoriIRN is a rel. n. from the name of a mountain, or of a place, or some other thing, accord. to different authors: or its I is
added to give intensiveness to its signification: (TA:) the qumoriIR is [A bird] of the [species called] fawaAxit; [pl. of faAxitapN;] (Msb;) a certain species of bird; so called because Oaqomar [q. v.] in colour, like the faAxitap in El-Hijáz; (JK;) [a species of collared turtle-dove, of a dull white colour marked with a black collar: such I have see in Egypt, caged; but they are rare there; and, I believe, are brought from Arabia:] the qumoriyRap is a species of HamaAm, (K,) HamaAYim [i. e. pigeons]: (M, TA:) or qumoriyRapN is applied to the female; and the male is called saAqu HurRK: (S, Msb, K: see saAqu HurRK in art. swq): and the pl. is qumaAriIRu, (S, Msb, K,) imperf. decl.; (S;) and accord. to some, qamaAraI; (TA;) and qumorN. (K.)

qimaArN c
qimaArN: see 3. [It is often used as a subst., signifying (tropical:) A game of hazard, such as that called Almayosir, and the like.]

qamiyrN c
qamiyrN (tropical:) An antagonist in the contention termed qimaArN: (IJ, K:) pl. OaqomaArN, (IJ, K,) which is anomalous, like OanoSaArN, pl. of naSiyrN. (TA.)

Oaqomaru c
Oaqomaru Of a colour inclining to xuDorap: or of a dull or dingy or dusky white: (K:) and white: (S, Msb, K:) or intensely white: (IKtt:) fem. qamoraMCu: (S, K:) pl. qumorN. (S, Msb.) You say HimaArN Oaqomaru (S, A, Msb, K) An ass of the colour termed qumorap: (K:) or a white ass: (S, A, Msb:) and OataAnN qamoraMCu a she-ass of the colour termed qumorap: (K:) or a white she-ass. (S.) The Arabs say, that when the sky appears of the hue of the belly of a she-ass of this colour, it is most abundant in rain. (TA.) Also farasN Oaqomaru A moon-coloured horse. (Mgh.) And saHaAbN Oaqomaru A cloud, or clouds, of a white colour: (S:) or intensely bright, by reason of the abundance of water therein: and [hence] full [of water]. (TA.) ― -b2- layolapN qamoraMCu, (S, A, K,) and muqomirapN, (A, Msb, K,) and muqomirN↓, (K) and qamirapN↓, (IAar, K,) which last is held by ISd, to be a kind of rel. n., or possessive epithet, (TA,) A moon-lit night; a night in which the moon shines: (A, K:) or a light, or bright, night: (S:) or a white night. (Msb.) IAar, mentions layolN qamoraMCu; but ISd, says this is strange, and I think, he adds, that by lyl he means lylp, or that he makes lyl fem. as a pl. (TA.) You also say layolapu AlqamoraMCi, meaning The night of moonlight: (Lth, A, Mgh:) for AlqamoraMCu also signifies the moonlight. (Lth, A, Mgh, K.) And qaEadNnaA fiI AlqamoraMCi We sat in the moonlight. (A.) And Oatoyotuhu fiI AlqamoraMCi [I came to him in the moonlight]. (S.) ― -b3- wajohN Oaqamaru A face likened to the moon (K, * TA) in respect of whiteness. (TA.)

muqomirN c
muqomirN: see Oaqomaru. ― -b2- UinRa AllRayola TawiylN waOanota muqomirN [Verily the night is long, and thou hast the light of the moon: a proverb:] meaning, Wait thou patiently for the accomplishment of thy want. (JK.) [See Freytag's Arab. Prov., i. 45.]

1 qamasa c
1. qamasa, (S, K,) aor.
qamisa
and
qamusa
, (K,) inf. n. qamosN (S, A, K) and qumuwsN, (TA,) He, or it, (i. e. anything, TA,) dived, or plunged, (S, A, K,) in water: (TA:) he, or it, dived, or plunged, or became immersed, therein, and then rose: (TA:) he (a man) disappeared in water: (Sh:) and Anqms↓ [signifies the same as qamasa: or] he, or it, became immersed, in water: (S:) and this latter, he leaped into a well. (Sh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] It (a child, or fœtus,) was, or became, in a state of commotion in the belly (S, K) of its mother: (S:) or in the membrane which enclosed it in the belly. (TA.) ＝ -A2- qamasahu, (S, A,) [aor., app., as above,] inf. n. qamosN, (K,) He immersed, dipped, plunged, or sunk, him or it, (S, A, K, [in the CK Alqamosu is put by mistake for Algamosu,]) in water; (S, A;) as also Oaqomasahu↓, (S,) inf. n. UiqomaAsN. (K.) See also gamasahu. You say also, qamasotu bihi fiI AlbiYori I cast him into the well. (Sh.) ― -b2- qaAmasotuhu faqamasotuhu: see 3.

3 qAmshu c
3. qAmshu, (K,) inf. n. muqaAmasapN, (TA,) He vied, or contended, with him in diving. (K, * TA.) You say, qaAmasatuhu qaqamasotuhu↓, (S,) [aor. of the latter, accord. to rule,
qamusa
only,] inf. n. qamosN, (K,) I vied, or contended, with him in diving, (TA,) and I overcame him therein. (K, TA.) You say of him who contends, disputes, or litigates, with an adversary, (A,) or who disputes with one more knowing than himself, (S, K,) fulaAnN yuqaAmisu HuwtFA (tropical:) [Such a one vies, or contends, in diving with a fish]. (S, A, K.) You say also, fulaAnN yuqaAmisu fiI sirRihi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one hides himself at one time and appears at another. (TA.)

4 Aqms c
4. Aqms: see 7. ＝ -A2- Aqmshu: see qamasahu.

6 AlSRiboyaAnu yataqaAmasuwna fiI AlbaHori c
6. AlSRiboyaAnu yataqaAmasuwna fiI AlbaHori The children vie, or contend, one with another, in diving in the sea, or great river; syn. yatagaATRuwna. (A.)

7 Anqms c
7. Anqms: see qamasa, in two places. ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) It (a star) set, or descended in the west; (S, K;) as also Aqms↓. (TA.)

qamiysN c
qamiysN: see qaAmuwsN.

qamRaAsN c
qamRaAsN: see qaAmisN.

qaAmisN c
qaAmisN (TA) and qamRaAsN↓, (S, TA,) [but the former is a simple epithet, and the latter intensive,] A diver: (S, TA:) a diver for pearls. (TA.)

qawomasN c
qawomasN: see qaAmuwsN.

qaAmuwsN c
qaAmuwsN The sea; syn. baHorN; (IDrd, K;) as also qamiysN↓: (O:) or the deepest part thereof: (A 'Obeyd, A, K:) or the main body of the water thereof; as also qawomasN↓: (K, A, TA:) or the middle, and main body, thereof. (S.)

munoqamasN c
munoqamasN The time of a star's setting at dawn. (S, * TA.)

1 qamaXa c
1. qamaXa, aor.
famiXa
, (M, TA,) inf. n. qamoXN, (S, M, K,) He collected (S, M, K) a thing, (S,) or qumaAX, (M, K,) meaning small rubbish, or broken particles of things, on the surface of the ground, (K,) hence and thence; (S, TA:) as also qmRX↓, inf. n. taqomiyXN. (S, TA.) Hence, qamoXu AlrRiyHi AltRuraAba [The wind's collecting the dust]. (TA.)

2 famRaXa
2: see 1.

5 tqmRX c
5. tqmRX, (K,) or tqmRX AlqumaAXa, and AqtmXhu↓, (M, TA,) He ate what he found, (K, TA,) hence and thence, (TA,) even though it might be vile: (K, TA:) or he ate what is termed qmAX, hence and thence. (M.)

8 UifotamaXa
8: see 5.

qamoXN c
qamoXN The bad [or refuse] of anything: pl. qumaAXN; like as EuraAqN is pl. of EaroqN; (Yaakoob, ISk, M;) and qumaAXapN↓ is like it: (TA:) and qamoAXN↓ is also a sing., like qamoXN. (M, TA.) qumaAXN also signifies What is collected hence and thence: (S:) or small particles, or fragments, of anything; as also qumaAXapN↓; (M, IKtt;) and so quXaAmapN: (IKtt, TA:) or small rubbish, or broken particles of things, on the surface of the ground. (K.) You say, maA OaEoTaAniI UilRaA qumaAXFA He gave me not aught save the worst of what he found. (K.) [Hence,] qumaAXN Albayoti Household goods, or utensils and furniture. (S.) [Hence also,] qumaAXu AlnRaAsi The refuse, or meanest sort, of the people, or of mankind. (K, * TA.) [The application of qumaAXN to Any kind of woven stuff, whether linen, cotton, or silk, &c., is post-classical. Its pl. is OaqomiXapN.]

qumaAXN c
qumaAXN: see qamoXN, throughout.

qumaAXapN c
qumaAXapN: see qamoXN, in two places.

qamRaAXN c
qamRaAXN One who sells household goods, or furniture and utensils. (TA.)

1 qamaSa c
1. qamaSa, aor.
qamuSa
(S, M, A, Msb, K) and
qamiSa
, (S, M, Msb, K,) inf. n. qamoSN (S, Msb, K) and qimaASN, (S, M, A, K, or this is a simple subst., Msb,) and qumaASN, (M, K, or this last is not allowable, S,) He (a horse or other animal, S, A, K, or a camel, Msb) raised his fore legs together and put them down together, (S, A, Msb, K,) on being mounted or ridden, (Msb,) and beat the ground (Eajana) with his hind feet; (S, K;) like AisotanRa; (S;) as also qmRS↓: (A:) or qumaASN, with damm,
is the inf. n. when it signifies he did so usually: (K:) and, inf. n. qimaASN and qumaASN, he pranced, leaped, sprang, or bounded: (M, K:) and, inf. n. qimaASN, (tropical:) he was, or became, restless, unquiet, or unsteady, (K, TA,) and took fright, and ran away at random, or shied: (TA:) and, inf. n. qumaASN, (assumed tropical:) it (a bird of the kind called nugar) remained not steadily in a place, but leaped from its place impatiently: and, inf. n. qamoSN, (assumed tropical:) he took fright, and ran away at random, or shied, and turned aside or away. (TA.) You say, hecihi AldRaAbRapu fiyhaA qimaASN; you should not say qumaASN; (S;) or you say qumaASN also; (TA;) and qamaASN, which last is the most chaste; (L, TA;) This beast has in her a property of raising and putting down her fore legs together, and beating the ground with her hind legs. (S.) And it is said in a proverb, (S,) maA biAlEayori mino qimaASK, (S, A, K,) and qumaASK; (Sgh, TA; and so, as well as qimaASK, in two copies of the S;) i. e. AlHimaAr; (S;) [There is not in the ass any power of raising and putting down his fore legs together, &c.;] applied to him who has become low, or mean, after being high, in rank, or condition; (S, A, K;) and to a weak man, in whom is no activity: (A, K:) or, as the proverb is related by Sb, OafalaA qumaASa biAlEayori [Is there not, then, any power &c. in the ass?] (M, TA.) And in a trad., faqamaSato bihi faSaraEatohu And it leaped, or sprang, or bounded, and took fright, and ran away at random, or shied, with him, and threw him down. (TA.) You also say, AlnRaAqapu biAlrRadiyfi qamRaSati↓ (tropical:) The she-camel went briskly with the rider upon the hinder part. (A.) And qamaSa AlbaHoru biAlsRafiynapi, (S, K,) or bihaA qamRaSa↓, (A,) (tropical:) The sea put the ship in a state of commotion (S, A, K) by the waves (S, A) thereof. (A.) And it is said in a trad., lataqomiSanRa bikumu AlOaroDu qumaASa AlnRugari (assumed tropical:) Verily the earth shall be in a state of commotion with you [like the commotion of the kind of bird called ngr]. (TA.) You say also, Oaxacahu AlqimaASu (tropical:) Restlessness, or inquietude, or unsteadiness, seized him. (A, TA.) And, of a horse whose sciatic vein or nerve is contracted, (Xanija, [not XbH as in Freytag's Lexicon,]) qamaSato rijolupu [app. meaning, His hind leg became twitched up, as in springhalt]: in which case you also say of him, AlEuroquwbi UinRahu laqaAmiSu↓ [as though meaning, verily he has a twitching up of the hock]. (S, TA.) [See also EusaAfN.]

2 qamRaSa
2: see 1, in three places. ＝ -A2- qmRShu qamiySFA He clad him with a qmyS [or shirt]: (S, Msb, K:) and qmRShu vawobFA [he clad him with a garment as a shirt]. (A.) [Hence] you say, qmRShu QllRehu waXoIa AlxilaAfapi (tropical:) [God invested him with the variegated robe of the office of Khaleefeh]. (A.) And it is said in a trad., (K, TA,) that Mohammad said to 'Othmán, (TA,) UinRa QllReha sayuqamRiSuka qamiySFA, meaning (tropical:) Verily God will invest thee with the apparel of the office of Khaleefeh, (K, TA,) and will ennoble and adorn thee like as he is ennobled and adorned who has a robe of honour conferred upon him. (TA.) ― -b2- qmRS AlvRawoba, (inf. n. taqomiySN, TA,) He cut out a qamiyS [or shirt] from the piece of cloth. (Lh, M, A, TA.)

5 tqmRS fiI AlnRahori c
5. tqmRS fiI AlnRahori He turned over, and became immersed, in the river. (TA.) ＝ -A2- tqmRS, (K,) or tqmRS qamiySFA, (S, M, A, Msb,) He clad himself with a qmyS [or shirt]. (S, M, A, Msb, K.) [Hence] you say, tqmRS AlUimaArapa and AlwilaAyapa (tropical:) [He became invested with the office of commander, prefect, or the like]. (TA.) And tqmRS libaAsa AlEizRi (tropical:) [He became invested with might, or nobility. (A, TA.)

6 tqAmS AlSRiboyaAnu c
6. tqAmS AlSRiboyaAnu [app., The boys contended in leaping, springing, or bounding, raising both the legs together and putting them down together]: and bayonahumo muqaAmaSapN [between them is a contending in leaping, &c.]. (A, TA.)

UinRahu laHasanu AlqimoSapi c
UinRahu laHasanu AlqimoSapi [Verily he has a good mode of attiring himself with the shirt]. (Lh, M.)

qimiSRaI c
qimiSRaI i. q. quimaASN, i. e. A leaping, springing, or bounding: (Kr, M:) or i. q. qibiSRaI, (K,) i. e. a quick run. (Fr, TA.)

qamaASN c
qamaASN and qumaASN and qimaASN: see 1, passim.

qamuwSN c
qamuwSN A beast of carriage that leaps, springs, or bounds, (taqomiSu, K, i. e. tavibu, TA,) with its master; as also qamiySN↓; (K;) likewise signifying a hackney (birocawon) that leaps, &c., much. (TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) Restless; unquiet; that does not remain steadily in a place. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) The lion: (IKh, L:) because he goes about in search of his prey. (TA.) ― -b4- UinRahu laqamuwSu AlHanojarapi (tropical:) Verily he is a liar; (Kr, M, A;) as also gmwS. (TA.)

qamiySN c
qamiySN: see qamuwSN. ＝ -A2- [A shirt; a shift;] a certain thing that is worn, (S,) well known; (M, K;) accord. to El-Keiyim Ibn-El-Jezeree, and others, a sewed garment with two sleeves, not opened [down the front], worn beneath the [other] clothes; (TA;) accord. to El-Hulwánee, that of which the slit is towards, or to, the shoulder-joint; thus differing from a woman's diroE, of which the opening for the head to pass through extends towards, or to, the bosom; but this [says Mtr] I find not in the lexicons: (Mgh, art. drE:) “ or, ” as in some copies of the K, but in others “ and, ” (TA,) only of cotton, (K,) or of linen; (TA;) not of wool: (Sgh, K:) or by this is app. meant that such is generally the case: (Ibn-El-Hajar El-Mekkee, TA:) accord. to some, it may be from the skin [so called] which is the pericardium; [but accord. to Z, the reverse is the case;] or from taqayRaSa signifying “ he turned himself over: ” (TA:) sometimes fem.: (K:) or masc.; but sometimes meaning a coat of mail (diroEN), and then it is fem.: (M, TA:) pl. [of pauc.] OaqomiSapN (S, M, K) and [of mult.] qumoSaAnN (S, M, Msb, K) and qumuSN. (M, Msb, K.) In a trad. mentioned above, (see 2,) it is used tropically. (TA.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) The membrane that encloses a child in the womb. (Sgh, K.) ― -b3- Also, (K,) or qamiySu Alqalobi, (A,) (tropical:) The pericardium: (IAar, K:) or the latter signifies the fat of the heart; app. as being likened to the garment above mentioned: (M:) [and, by a synecdoche, the heart itself, with its appertenances: see an ex. in a verse cited in art. swd, conj. 9.] You say, hataka Alxawofu qamiySa qalobihi (tropical:) [Fear rent open his pericardium, or the fat of his heart]. (A, TA.)

qamRaASN c
qamRaASN A seller of qumoSaAn [or shirts]. (TA.)

qaAmiSN c
qaAmiSN: see 1, of which it is the act. part. n.: and see an ex. voce mawoquwSN. ― -b2- Kicking; striking with the foot. (TA.) ― -b3- qaAmiSu AlEuroquwbi: see 1, last signification.

1 qamaTa c
1. qamaTa, aor.
qamuTa
(S, M, Mgh, Msb, K) and
qamiTa
, (M, K,) inf. n. qamoTN, (S, M, Mgh, Msb,) He bound a child (S, Msb) in the cradle, and a sheep or goat on the occasion of slaughtering it, (S,) with the qimaAT [q. v.]: (S, Msb:) or qamaTahu signifies he bound his arms and legs, or hands and feet, together, like as is done with a child in the cradle, (K, TA,) and elsewhere, putting his limbs [or arms] next to the body, and then winding upon him the qimaAT: (TA:) and he bound his (a captive's, Mgh, Msb, K, or others', Mgh) arms and legs, or hands and feet, together, (Mgh, Msb, K, *) with a rope; (Mgh, Msb;) as also qmRThu↓, (M, K,) inf. n. taqomiyTN: (M, TA:) and qumiTa he (a captive) was thus bound. (S, TA.) ― -b2- qamaTa AlUibila, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He disposed the camels in a file, string, or series. (K, TA.)

2 qamRaTa
2: see 1.

qimoTN c
qimoTN: see qimaATN, in two places.

qimaATN c
qimaATN The thing, (S,) or wide piece of rag, (Msb,) with which a child is bound (S, Msb) in the cradle: (S:) or the piece of rag, (Mgh, K,) or wide piece of rag, (TA,) which is wound upon a child (M, K, TA) when he is bound in the cradle: (Mgh, TA: *) pl. qumuTN. (Mgh, Msb.) ― -b2- A rope with which the legs of a sheep or goat are bound (S, Mgh, K) on the occasion of the slaughtering; (S, K;) as also qimoTN↓: (K:) or a rope with which the arms and legs, or hands and feet, of a captive are bound together: (Msb, K:) pl. as above; (Mgh;) and the pl. of qumuTN [probably a mistranscription for qimoTN] is OaqomaATN. (TA.) ― -b3- qumuTN also signifies The XuruT, (Mgh, Msb,) meaning wide woven ropes, (Mgh,) of fibres or leaves of the palm-tree, by which a booth of reeds
or canes is bound: or, as some say, the pieces of wood that are upon the outside of a booth of reeds or canes, or in its inside, to which are bound the bundles of reeds or canes that form the roof: (Mgh, Msb:) or the heads [or extremities] thereof: (Msb:) or qmT, with damm, [app. meaning qumuTN, with damm to the second letter as well as the first, or qumoTN as a contraction of qumuTN, like as kutobN, accord. to some, is a contraction of kutubN,] as IAth says, on the authority of Hr, (TA,) or qimoTN↓, with kesr, (S, K,) signifies the thing, (S,) or rope, (K, TA,) of fibres or leaves of the palmtree, (TA,) with which booths of reeds or canes are bound: (S, K, TA:) and hence maEaAqidu AlqimoTi [the places where such ropes are tied]. (S.) ― -b4- Also qimaATN (assumed tropical:) The snares by which one snares men: and [its pl.] qumuTN, accord. to the A, (tropical:) the cords of stratagems or tricks. (TA.) [Hence,] waqaEotu EalaI qimaATihi (assumed tropical:) I became acquainted with his stratagems, or tricks, (Lth, K,) or his snares by which he snares men. (TA.) [The explanation of this phrase by Lth is wqEt EalI bunuwdihi: that in the K, faTinotu bunuwdahu: another explanation is given in the TA, which is, faTinotu lahu fI tuWadapK: in the JK, faTanotu bituWawdapK: the right reading in the K and JK seems to be faTinotu bibunuwdihi: and that of the explanation in the TA mentioned in this sentence is most probably, I think, faTinotu lahu fiI bunuwdihi I understood him in his stratagems, &c.]

qamRaATN c
qamRaATN A maker of qumuT [pl. of qimaAT] for children. (TA.) ― -b2- A rope-maker. (TA.)

Q. 4 UiqomaTarRa c
Q. 4. UiqomaTarRa It (a day, S) was, or became, distressful, or calamitous. (S, K.)

qamoTarN c
qamoTarN: see qamoTariyrN.

qimaTorN c
qimaTorN and qimaTorapN (S, Msb, K) and with tesh-deed, [i. e. qimRaTorN and qimRaTorapN,] but this pronunciation is extr., (K,) or, accord. to Yaakoob, (S,) or ISk, (TA,) not allowable, (S, TA,) A repository for books or writings, (S, Msb, K, TA,) resembling a safaT, [q. v., (in the TA, sqT, which is evidently a mistake,)] made of reeds woven together: (TA:) the first word is fem., like the second, as well as masc.: (Msb:) pl. qamaATiru. (S, Msb.)

yawomN qamoTariyrN c
yawomN qamoTariyrN, and qumaATirN↓, (S, K,) and muqomaTirRN↓, (TA,) A distressful, or calamitous, day: (S, K:) or a day that makes one knit the brow, or contract the skin between the eyes: so the first is explained by some as occurring in the Kur lxxvi. 10. (TA.) ― -b2- XarRN qamoTariyrN, (TA,) and qumaATirN↓, and qamoTarN↓, (Lth, TA,) and muqomaTirRN↓, (TA,) Intense evil. (Lth, TA.)

qumaATirN c
qumaATirN: see qamoTariyrN, in two places.

muqomaTirRN c
muqomaTirRN: see qamoTariyrN, in two places.

dictScrap.label: qmE qml qmn: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
Q. 4 UiqomahadRa c
Q. 4. UiqomahadRa He (a man, L, and a camel, S, L,) raised his head. (S, L, K.) Mentioned by J in art. qmd, q. v.

dictScrap.label: qn: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qanaOa c
1. qanaOa, aor.
qanaAa
, inf. n. qunuwoCN, It (a thing, TA) was, or became, intensely red: (K:) and qanaA, without C, is a dial. var. thereof, (TA in this art.,) aor. yaqonuw, inf. n. qunuwRN. (TA in art. qnw.) You say, qanaOato liHoyatuhu, aor. and inf. n. as above, His beard was, or became, intensely red from the dye: (S, O:) or, was, or became, black with the dye. (TA.) And qanaOato OaToraAfu AljaAriyapi biAlHinRaMCi The extremities of the girl, or young woman, were, or became, black, or, accord. to the T, intensely red, with the hinnà (TA.) And qanaOati Albusorapu The full-grown unripe date began to have its redness intermixed with blackness. (M in art. nvr.) ― -b2- See also 2. ＝ -A2- qanaOahu He mixed it, i. e. milk (O, K, TA) with water. (TA.) ＝ -A3- And, (O, K, TA,) aor.
qanaAa
, (TA,) inf. n. qanoCN, (O, TA,) He killed him: (O, K, TA:) or he incited him, or induced him, to kill him; as also AqnOhu↓, (K, TA,) inf. n. UiqonaMCN: (TA:) [but this is a strange rendering of a verb with a single objective complement; and it appears that AqnOhu should be followed by Ealayohi, to give this sense; and so should qanaOahu, if used in the same sense; for, accord. to Sgh,] Ealayohi OaqonaOotuhu↓ signifies I incited him, or induced him, to kill him. (O.) ＝ -A4- qanaOa Aljilodu, (AHn, K, TA,) [if not a mistranscription, for quniYa, as seems to be probably the case from what follows,] inf. n. qunuwoCN, (AHn, TA,) The skin was thrown into the tan, (AHn, K, TA,) after the removal of its hair and dirt: and qanaOahu SaAHibuhu [Its owner threw it into the tan, &c.]. (AHn, TA.) ＝ -A5- qaniYa, (O, K, TA,) aor.
qanaAa
, inf. n. qunuwoCN, (TA,) He died. (O, K.) One says, Darabotuhu HatRaI qaniYa I beat him until he died. (TA.) ― -b2- And qaniYa said of a hide, It became spoiled, or rendered unsound. (O, K.)

2 qnRO c
2. qnRO, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taqoniYapN, (S, O,) or taqoniIoCN, (K,) He rendered (S, O, K) a thing, (K,) or his beard, (S, O,) intensely red (S, O, * K) with dye. (S, O.) And He dyed his beard black; as also qanaOa↓. (K.)

3 maA qaAnaOahu c
3. maA qaAnaOahu It (a thing) did not suit him; i. q. mA qaAmaOahu. (TA in art. qmO.) [See also qaAnaI, in art. qnI.]

4 AqnO c
4. AqnO He spoiled a hide, or rendered it unsound. (O, K.) ＝ -A2- OaqonaOaniI AlXRaIoCu The thing became possible to me, or within my power, (K, TA,) and near to me. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, in two places.

qunoOapN c
qunoOapN [or qanoOapN]: see maqonaOapN.

XaIoCN OaHomaru qaAniYN c
XaIoCN OaHomaru qaAniYN A thing intensely red. (S, O.) See an ex. of the fem. qaAniYapN, applied to the sun, by a poet who was drinking, or watering, with a party, and was prevented by them from taking his share of the water until the sun became red. (TA.)

maqonaOapN c
maqonaOapN and maqonuWapN (S, K) i. q. maqomaOapN [and maqomuWapN], (K,) A place on which the sun does not come; (AA, S, TA;) as also qunoOapN↓ [perhaps a mistranscription for qanoOapN like its syn. qamoOapN]: (TA:) some say that maqonaApN and maqonuwapN, [thus] without C, signify the contr. of maDoHaApN [which means a place from which the sun is hardly ever, or never, absent]. (S, TA.)

1 qanaba fiyhi c
1. qanaba fiyhi, (JK, A, O, K,) aor.
qanuba
, (JK, O,) inf. n. qunuwbN, (JK,) (tropical:) He entered into it, (JK, A, O, K,) namely, his house, or tent; as also tqnRb↓. (JK, A.) ― -b2- And qanabati AlXRamosu, (A, K,) aor. as above, (TA,) and so the inf. n., (K,) (tropical:) The sun set, (A, K, TA,) so that nothing thereof remained. (TA.) ― -b3- qanaba bimixolabihi, aor.
qaniba
, inf. n. qanobN, He (a lion) withdrew his claw into its receptacle. (O.) ＝ -A2- qanaba Alkaroma, (A,) or AlEinaba, (JK, K,) inf. n. qanobN, (JK,) He cut off from the grape-vine what would be injurious (A, K) to its produce; (K;) as also qnRbhu↓: (A:) or he cut off from its upper part what would not bear and what would perhaps injure its produce: (En-Nadr, TA:) or he cut off some of the shoots thereof in order to thin it and that others might receive the whole of its strength. (AHn, TA.) ＝ -A3- qanaba AlzRahoru The flowers, or blossoms, came forth from their calyxes. (K.)

2 qnRb AlzRaroEu c
2. qnRb AlzRaroEu, (IDrd, S, O, K,) inf. n. taqoniybN, (IDrd, S, K,) The seed-produce put forth the qunRaAbap [or quinaAb i. e. the leaves enclosing the ears of corn]; (K;) i. q. OaEoSafa [i. e. put forth its EaSof, here meaning the leaves of the ears of corn]. (IDrd, S, O.) ＝ -A2- qanRabuwA, (O, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) They became a [troop such as is termed] miqonab; as also OaqonabuwA↓; (O, K;) and so taqanRabuwA↓. (A, O, K.) ― -b2- And qnRbwA is said to mean They journeyed, or travelled, far: (O:) [or] so AqnbwA↓: (T, TA:) and nHowa qawomK tqnRbwA↓ They journeyed towards a people, or party. (JK.) ＝ -A3- See also 1.

4 Oaqonaba
4: see 2, in two places. ＝ -A2- Aqnb also signifies (tropical:) He hid himself from a creditor, or from a Sultán. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- And It (a plant) put forth the calyxes of its flowers, or blossoms. (AHn, O, * TA.)

5 taqanRaba
5: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see 2, in two places.

qunobN c
qunobN The sheath of the penis (S, A, O, K) of a beast, or of a solid-hoofed animal, (K,) [i. e.] of the horse, (S, A, O,) and of other than the horse (S, O) among the solid-hoofed; (S;) or originally, of the solid-hoofed, and afterwards used in relation to others, as of the camel. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qunobu AlOasadi, i. e. (assumed tropical:) The sheath of the penis of the Lion, is a name by which the Arabs call the star [b] upon the hinder part of the tail of Leo: [this, is should be observed, is the place of the star in the figure of Leo commonly known; but the ancient Arabs, or many of them, extended the figure of that constellation (as they did also that of Scorpio) far beyond the limits which we assign to it: (see AlcRiraAEu:) another meaning of qunob in relation to a lion, which will be found below, may perhaps be intended in this case, but I think it unlikely:] the Arabs also called the same star AlSRarofapu [q. v.]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- [Hence, likewise,] qunobN signifies also (tropical:) The baZor of a woman; (K;) [meaning the prepuce of the clitoris; as being likened to a qunob properly so called; i. e.] it is metonymically [thus] applied to the part that is circumcised, of a woman. (JK, A.) ― -b4- See also qinaAbN, in two places. ＝ -A2- Also A large sail, (O, K,) one of the greatest of the sails of a ship. (O.)

qunaAbN c
qunaAbN: see qunRaAbapN.

qinaAbN c
qinaAbN The claw of the lion; as also qunobN↓ and miqonabN↓ and miqonaAbN↓: (K:) or the claw of the lion in its covering; (O, TA;) as also miqonabN↓: or this last signifies the fore paw of the lion: and qunobN↓, of which the pl. is qunuwbN, signifies the part of the fore paw of the lion into which the claws enter [or are withdrawn]; as also miqonaAbN↓; and in like manner this word [or app. each of these words] is used in relation to the hawk and falcon. (TA.) ― -b2- Also (i. e.qinaAbN) The string of a bow. (K.) ― -b3- And i. q. qunRaAbapN, q. v. (K.) ― -b4- See also qinRabN.

qunuwbN c
qunuwbN [mentioned in the next preceding paragraph as pl. of qunobN] signifies [also] The calyxes of the flowers of a plant. (AHn, O, K. *)

qaniybN c
qaniybN Companies of men. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- And hence, as being likened thereto, (TA,) (tropical:) Clouds (O, K, TA) such as are dense, or compact. (TA.)

qunaAbapN c
qunaAbapN: see qunRaAbapN.

qinRabN c
qinRabN (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and qunRabN (K) [Cannabis, or hemp;] i. q. OabaqN [a less-known word]; a genuine Arabic word; (S, O;) or, accord. to AHn, a Pers. word [kanabN] which has become current in the language of the Arabs; (Mgh;) vulgarly pronounced qinRib; (TA;) [loosely expl. as] a sort of katRaAn [or flax], (K, TA,) i. e. the coarse [sort], of which are made ropes and the like; (TA;) a plant of which the skin, or rind, is twisted into ropes; (Msb;) its stems are bruised until the culms becomes strewn in fragments and the rind thereof becomes detached; and one says HibaAlu AlqinRabi [the ropes of hemp]: (AHn, Mgh:) it has a grain called XahodaAnaj [q.v.]: (Mgh, Msb:) qinaAb↓, [thus without teshdeed,] occurring in a verse of Aboo-Heiyeh En-Numeyree, is said to signify the same as qinRab; but whether it be a dial. var. or altered therefrom [by poetic license] is doubtful. (L, TA.) [See also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 269.]

qunRaAbapN c
qunRaAbapN, (O, K,) like rumRaAnapN, (K,) or qunaAbapN↓, (S, [thus in my copies, without teshdeed,]) The combined leaves in which are the ears of corn; (S, O, K;) also called EaSiyfapN: (S, O:) so says IDrd: (S:) and [it is said that] qunaAbN↓, with damm, (O, K,) as also qinaAbN↓, with kesr, (K,) signifies the leaves surrounding the heads of growing corn, (O, K, TA,) i. e. the ears, (TA,) in the beginning of its fruit-bearing: (O, K, TA:) by which explanation is meant the same that is meant by the explanation immediately preceding. (TA.)

qaAnibN c
qaAnibN The howling wolf. (O, K.) See also maqaAnibu. ― -b2- And A quick, or brisk, fayoj [i. e. foot-messenger, or courier who journeys on foot]; as also qayonaAbN↓. (O, K. [In the CK, AlfayoHu is put for Alfayoju.]) ― -b3- And waAdK qaAnibN [A valley, or water-course,] of which the torrent comes from afar. (O.)

qayonaAbN c
qayonaAbN: see the next preceding paragraph.

miqonabN c
miqonabN A thing that the sportsman has with him, (S,) his bag, (xariyTap, O, or wiEaMC, K,) or a thing resembling a mixolaAp or a xariyTap, (TA,) in which he puts the game that he takes. (S, O, TA.) ― -b2- See also qinaAbN, in two places. ― -b3- Also A ring of gold. (JK.) ＝ -A2- And A troop of horses or horsemen, (S, O, K,) or of both, (TA,) from thirty to forty, (S, O, K, TA,) or less than a hundred, (TA,) or as many as three hundred: (Lth, O, K, TA:) or a troop of horses or horsemen that assemble for a hostile, or predatory, incursion: pl. maqaAnibu. (Kf, TA.)

miqonaAbN c
miqonaAbN: see qinaAbN, in two places.

maqaAnibu c
maqaAnibu Rapacious, or ravening, wolves: (O, K, TA:) a pl. without a sing.; or it is an irreg. pl. of qaAnibN↓ [q. v.]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also pl. of miqonabN [q. v.]. (Kf, TA.)

qunoburN c
qunoburN and qunoburaMCu A species of the [kind of bird called] HumRar: (TA:) [or resembling the HumRar:] i. q. qubRarN [i. e., the lark]: (S, K, art. qbr:) n. un. qunoburapN, (S, Msb, art. qbr:) also pronounced qunobarapN: (Msb, ibid.:) pl. qanaAbiru. (TA.) See qubRarN.

qunRabiyTN c
qunRabiyTN [Cauliflower;] the thickest species of kurunob; (K;) called in the dial. of Egypt qaronabiyTN; mentioned in the S in art. qbT; [but only as a thing well known;] the author of the S regarding the n as augmentative: (TA:) it renders the breath stinking; and causes a thickness, or grossness, [app. of the humours;] and she who uses its seed in the manner of a suppository in the vagina will not become pregnant: (K:) so say the physicians. (TA.)

1 qunuwtN c
1. qunuwtN is the inf. n. of qanata, (MA, Msb,) aor.
qanuta
, (Msb,) and signifies The being obedient: (S, M, MA, Mgh, K, TA:) or the being constantly obedient: (IAmb, O, TA:) the former is the primary meaning: and hence, in the Kur [xxxiii. 35], waQloqaAnitaAti↓ waQloqaAnitiyna↓ [And the obedient men and the obedient women]. (S, M, TA.) One says, qanata lilRehi, (MA,) and qanata QllReha, (TA,) [but this latter is unusual, the former only being authorized by the Kur-án (in iii. 38 and xxxiii. 31),] meaning He was obedient to God. (MA, TA.) And it is said in the Kur [ii. 110 and xxx. 25], kulRN lahu qaAnituwna↓ i. e. All are obedient unto Him: but the meaning here is, that the beings in heaven [and earth] are created by the will of God, and that none of them can alter the form in which it is created; the obedience here spoken of being obedience to the will [of God], not the obedience of religious service; some of them being obedient [in this sense], and others being disobedient. (L, TA.) [It is said that] the proper signification of AlqaAnitu↓ [or the signification that implies all the meanings of the word] is The performer of the command of God. (L, TA.) ― -b2- It signifies also The act of standing; (Mgh, TA;) mentioned by Th, and asserted by him to be the primary meaning. (TA.) And (TA) The standing long. (IAmb, O, TA.) And (TA) The standing in the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (S, Msb, K, TA.) [See also 4.] Hence, (Mgh, Msb, TA,) it is said in a trad. (S, TA) of the Prophet, as a reply given by him to the question OaIRu AlSRalaApi OafoDalu, (TA,) OafoDalu AlSRalaApi Tuwlu Alqunuwti (S, Mgh, Msb, TA) i. e. [The most excellent characteristic of the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer is] the long continuance of the standing. (Mgh, * Msb, * TA.) And hence, qunuwtu Alwitori; (S; [see art. wtr;]) or [as it is also termed] duEaMCu Alqunuwti, which means The supplication of the standing; (Msb;) for one utters the supplication standing: (TA:) and what is thus termed (duEaMCu Alqunuwti) is as follows: AallRahumRa UinRaA nasotaEiynuka wanasotagofiruka wanuWominu bika wanatawakRalu Ealayoka wanuvoniI Ealayoka Alxayora walaA nakofuruka wanaxolaEu wanatoruku mano yafojuruka AallRehumRa UiyRaAka naEobudu walaka nuSalRiI wanasojudu waUilayoka nasoEaI wanaHofidu narojuw raHomataka wanaxoXaI EacaAbaka UinRa EacaAbaka biAlkufRaAri muloHiqN i. e. O God, verily we beg of Thee aid to be obedient and to forsake disobedience, and we beg of Thee forgiveness of sins, [and we believe in Thee, and we rely
upon Thee,] and we laud Thee well, and we will not be unthankful to Thee for Thy favour, and we cast off and forsake him who disobeys Thee: [O God, Thee we worship, and to Thee we perform the divinely-appointed act of prayer, and prostrate ourselves;] and we are quick in working for Thee and in serving Thee: we hope for Thy mercy, and we dread Thy punishment: verily Thy punishment overtakes the unbelievers; thus this clause is expl. on the authority of Ks: or, as some say, it means, causes others to overtake, or become associated with, the unbelievers. (Mgh. [See also art. lHq.]) It is said of the Prophet, qanata XahorFA fiI SalaApi AlSRuboHi baEoda AlrRukuwEi yadoEuw EalaI riEolK wacakuwaAna [He stood during a month, in the prayer of daybreak, after (the prayers of) the rukuwE (pl. of rakaEa, q. v.), cursing (the tribes of) Rial and Dhekwán]. (TA.) ― -b3- Also The act of supplicating [God]: (Zj, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA:) this is the signification [most] commonly known. (Zj, Mgh, O, TA.) And [particularly, accord. to general usage,] The supplicating God [by addressing Him with the form of words mentioned above as used in what is termed duEaMCu Alqunuwti], doing so standing. (TA.) ― -b4- And The divinely-appointed act of prayer; syn. SalaApN. (IAmb, O, TA.) ― -b5- And The being silent; (O, Msb, K, TA;) by which is meant (O, * TA) the withholding oneself from talking; (O, * K, TA;) in, or during, [the prayer called] AlSRalaAp. (O, * Msb, TA.) Hence, (O, Msb, TA,) accord. to a trad., (O, TA,) the saying in the Kur [ii. 239], waquwmuwA lilRehi qaAnitiyna↓ [And stand ye unto God, in the divinely-appointed act of prayer, refraining from talking]. (O, Msb, TA.) ― -b6- And The serving of God. (TA.) ― -b7- And The continuing of the performance of the pilgrimage. (TA.) One says, [qanata and] Aqnt↓, meaning He continued the performance of the pilgrimage. (IAar, O, K, TA.) ― -b8- And The prolonging of engaging in warring, or warring and plundering. (TA.) One says, [qanata and] Aqnt↓, meaning He prolonged the engaging in warring, or warring and plundering. (IAar, O, K, TA.) ― -b9- And The confessing, or acknowledging, one's being in the condition of a servant [to God]. (TA.) ― -b10- And The being lowly, humble, or submissive: (A, TA:) or the keeping to obedience [to God], with lowliness, humility, or submissiveness. (Er-Rághib, TA.) One says, qanata lahu He was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, to him. (TA.) And qanatati AlmrAp lizawojihaA, (A,) or libaEolihaA, (TA,) The woman was, or became, lowly, humble, or submissive, and obedient, to her husband: (A:) or was, or became, quiet and submissive; syn. OaqarRat. (TA.) [See also 4, and 8.] ＝ -A2- qanaAtapN [is an inf. n., of which the verb is qanuta, like qatuna, and] signifies The eating little [like qataAnapN]. (K.)

4 Aqnt c
4. Aqnt He stood long in the performance of the divinely-appointed act of prayer. (O, K.) [And qanata has the same, or nearly the same, meaning; as is shown above.] ― -b2- Also, [like qanata EalaI EaduwRihi,] He cursed his enemy. (IAar, O, K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last quarter, in two places. ― -b4- Also He lowered, humbled, or submitted, himself to God. (IAar, O, K.)

8 Aqtnt c
8. Aqtnt He was, or became, tractable, or submissive. (TA.) [And Aktnt has a similar meaning.]

qanuwtN c
qanuwtN A woman lowly, humble, or submissive, and obedient [to her husband]. (A.)

qaniytN c
qaniytN A woman who eats little: (O, K:) as also qatiynN. (O.) ― -b2- siqaMCN qaniytN i. q. misRiykN, so in a copy of the K, meaning [A skin] that retains the water; and this is the right explanation: (TA:) but accord. to AZ and Z, the word msyk thus used is like OamiyrN; and siqaMCN masiykN is expl. by Z as meaning [a skin] that does not exude, and by AZ as meaning [a skin] that retains the water so that it does not exude: (TA in art. msk:) in the present art., in some of the copies of the K, musiylN, the act. part. n. from OasaAla AlmaMCa; and thus in a copy of the Tekmileh. (TA in the present art.: in the O, in this art., it is masiylN.)

qaAnitN c
qaAnitN [part. n. of qanata in all its senses]: see three exs. in the first quarter of the first paragraph, and another ex. in the last quarter; its [broken] pl., in all its senses is qanRatN. (ISd, TA.)

1 qanaHahu c
1. qanaHahu, (S, K, TA,) aor.
qanaHa
, (K, TA,) inf. n. qanoHN, (S, TA,) He bent it, or curved it, (S, K, TA,) i. e. a thing, (S,) or a stick, or branch, (TA,) [at the end,] like a miHojan, (S, K, TA,) or SawolajaAn. (TA.) ― -b2- And qanaHa AlbaAba He hewed, or cut out, a wooden implement, (called a qunRaAHap [q. v.], L,) and with it raised [and opened] the door; as also AqnHhu↓: (T, L, K, TA:) or [simply] he raised [and opened] the door with the wooden implement called a qunRaAHap; and so qnRHhu↓: (A:) [or] AlbAlba qnRH↓, (S, K,) inf. n. taqoniyHN, (K,) He adjusted (OaSolaHa) a qunRaAHap to the door. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- And qanaHa, (K, TA,) aor. and inf. n. as above, (TA,) said of one drinking, He satisfied his thirst, and, by reason thereof, raised his head; and showed, or expressed, dislike of drinking (takaAraha EalaI AlXRurobi); like tqnRH↓; (K, TA;) which is the more approved [and to which, as well as to the former verb, both of the clauses of the explanation above relate, as will be shown by what follows]: in some of the copies [of the K] like qnRH↓: accord. to AHn, one says, qanaHa mina AlXRaraAbi, aor. and inf. n. as above, meaning he sipped [of the wine or beverage]; and accord. to Az, taqanRaHotu↓ mina AlXRaraAbi, which, he says, is the prevailing expression: hence the saying of Umm-Zara, OaXorabu faOataqanRaHu↓, i. e. I [drink, and] stop, or interrupt, drinking, and proceed leisurely therein: or, I drink after the satisfying of thirst: which latter explanation, mentioned on the authority of AZ, is that which is approved by Sh and Az, in opposition to Aboo-'Abd-Allah Et-Tuwál, who thought it to mean I drink by little and little. (TA. [See also this saying of Umm-Zara, with another reading of it, in the last sentence but one of art. qmH.])

2 qanRaHa
2: see above, second sentence, in two places: ＝ -A2- and see also the third sentence.

4 OaqonaHa
4: see 1, second sentence.

5 taqanRaHa
5: see 1, third sentence, in three places.

qinoHN c
qinoHN [thus accord. to the L] is expl. in the 'Eyn as meaning Thy making a qunRaAHap with which thou wilt fasten (taXudRu) the side-post of thy door and the like; termed by the Persians qAnh [app. a mistranscription for faAnahN, a wooden peg, which, dropping into the bolt of a lock, or the like, prevents its being opened until the said peg is pulled up]; but ISd says, I know not how this is, for the explanation is not good; and I think qinoHN here is a dial. var. of qunRaAHN [q. v.]. (L.)

qanRaAHN c
qanRaAHN and qanRaAHapN↓ [thus in the L, but app. the q should be with damm in both words,] A stick, or branch, bent, or curved, [at the end,] like a SawolajaAn [q. v.]. (L.)

qunRaAHN c
qunRaAHN A bar (mitoras [or mataros]) of a door. (IAar, L.)

qanRaAHapN c
qanRaAHapN: see qanRaAHN.

qunRaAHapN c
qunRaAHapN A crooked, or curved, long mifotaAH [or instrument for opening a door]: (S, L, K:) [from what here follows, it seems to be a kind of wooden lever, with a crooked, or curved, end, with which a door is raised and opened: (see also 1:)] a wooden implement with which a door is raised [and opened, app. by lifting the lower pivot (which serves as a hinge) out of its socket]: (A, L:) and any piece of wood that is inserted beneath another [as a lever] in order to move it. (L.)

4 Aqnd AlsRawiyqa c
4. Aqnd AlsRawiyqa He put qanod into the swyq [or meal of parched barley or wheat]. (IKtt.)

qanodN c
qanodN (S, A, L, Msb, K) and qanodapN↓ and qinodiydN↓ (L, K) The honey (or expressed juice, TA) of the sugar-cane, (S, A, L, K,) when it has become concrete, (L, K,) or when it has been rendered concrete; (as in some copies of the K;) [or sugar-candy;] see also TabarozadN; with which faAniyd is made: (L:) or that of which sugar is made; so that sugar is to qnd like clarified butter to fresh butter: the pl. of qnd is qunuwdN: (Msb:) it is (as some say, Msb) an arabicized word, (Msb, K,) from [the Pers.] kanodN [or qanodo]. (TA.)

qanodapN c
qanodapN: see qanodN.

qinodidN c
qinodidN: see qinodiydN.

qinodiydN c
qinodiydN: see qanodN. ― -b2- Wine: (AA, IAar, S, L, K:) or it is not wine, (As, S, IJ,) but like UisofinoTN, i. e., (As, S,) expressed juice (As, T, S, L, K) of grapes, (T, L,) boiled, (As, T, S, L,) with aromatics put in it, (As, T, S, L, K,) and then rendered more fragrant by an admixture of other perfumes: [so I render yufotaqu:] (T, L, K:) or beverage, or wine, (XaraAbN,) made of qanod: (A:) pl. qanaAdiydu. (IAar, L.) ― -b3- Ambergris. (Kr, L, K.) ― -b4- Camphor. (K.) ― -b5- Musk. (K.) ― -b6- A perfume made with saffron, (K,) or with [the plant called] waros. (TA.) ― -b7- [The plant called] waros: (K:) or excellent waros. (L.) ― -b8- The state, or condition, of a man, whether good or bad; as also qinodidN↓: (K:) pl. of the former qanaAdiydu. (IAar.) ― -b9- jaMCa biAlOamori EalaI qanaAdiydihi [He did the thing] in its [proper] manner. (K.)

qinodaOowN c
qinodaOowN is mentioned among the words whose last radical letter is E. (K.) Aboo-Málik says, that rajulN qinodaAwapN, of the measure fiEolaAwapN, signifies A light, or active, man: and naAqapN qinodaAwapN a swift she-camel: (S:) and a bold she-camel: (Fr, S:) and the epithet is with and without E: (Fr:) and jamalN qinodaAwN a swift he-camel: and qaduwmN qinodaOowapN a sharp adz: but others say finodaOowapN, with f. (S.)

muqanodFI c
muqanodFI: see the next paragraph.

sawiyqN maqonuwdN c
sawiyqN maqonuwdN, and muqanRadN↓, (S, A, L, Msb, K,) and muqanodFI↓, (K,) [Meal of parched barley or wheat] prepared [or sweetened] with qanod. (L, Msb.) [See an ex. in art. Hlq.] ― -b2- kalaAmN maqonuwdN, and muqanRadN↓, (tropical:) [Sugared speech]. (A.)

muqanRadN c
muqanRadN: see the preceding paragraph in two places.

1 qanaSahu c
1. qanaSahu, (S, M, A, K,) aor.
qaniSa
, (M, A, K,) inf. n. qanoSN (S, M,) and qanaSN; (M;) and AqtnShu↓; and tqnRShu↓; (S, M, A, K;) He took, captured, or caught, it; made it his prey; snared, insnared, or entrapped, it; hunted, or chased, it; or sought to take, capture, or catch, it; syns. SaAdahu, (S, M, A, K,) and AiSoTaAdahu, (S, K,) and taSayRadahu; (S;) namely, a wild animal, or a number of wild animals. (M, A.) [Hence] you say, huwa yaqoniSu AlfurosaAna, and yaqotaniSuhumo↓, (tropical:) He captures the horsemen. (TA.)

5 taqanRaSa
5: see 1.

8 UiqotanaSa
8: see 1, in two places. ― -b2- As being likened to “ the taking ” of the object of the chase, AlAiqotinaASu signifies (tropical:) The taking anything quickly. (Kull.) ― -b3- [And hence, (assumed tropical:) The apprehending quickly.]

qanaSN c
qanaSN [originally an inf. n.] What is taken, captured, caught, insnared, entrapped, hunted, or chased, of wild animals or the like; as also qaniySN↓. (S, M, A, K.)

qaniySN c
qaniySN: see qanaSN: ＝ -A2- and qaAniSN, in two places.

qanRaASN c
qanRaASN: see qaAniSN.

qaAniSN c
qaAniSN One who takes, captures, catches, insnares, entraps, hunts, or chases, wild animals or the like; as also qaniySN↓ (S, M, A, K) and qanRaASN↓: (S, M, K:) or qaniySN↓ signifies persons who do so, collectively; and is [a quasi-pl. n.] similar to kaliybN and maEiyzN and HamiyrN: (IJ, TA:) the pl. of qaAniSN is qunRaASN: (A, TA:) and qaAniSapN↓ signifies the same as the pl.: and also low, vile; or mean, persons. (TA. [See also TumoruwrN, in an explanation of which the sing. qaAniSN is app. used in like manner.]) You say, jaMCa AlqaniySu biAloqaniySi The sportsman came with the game taken. (A.) And it is said in a trad., fatuxoriju AlnRaAru Ealayohimo qawaAniSa (assumed tropical:) [And the fire of hell shall send forth against them snatchers]; meaning, it shall snatch them in pieces like as the beast or bird of prey snatches its prey: the sing. is qaAniSapN↓: (K, TA:) or, as some say, the meaning is, sparks like the qawaAniS of birds, i. e., their HawaASil. (TA.) See what follows.

qaAniSapN c
qaAniSapN: see qaAniSN, in two places. ― -b2- Also, sing. of qawaAniSN, which signifies [The intestines, or bowels, of a bird, into which the food passes from the stomach;] in a bird, what the maSaAriyn are in other creatures: (S, K:) or the pl. [or sing. (K, art. jrO,)] signifies i. q. jirRiYapN: (L, TA:) or the qaAniSap is, in a bird, like the HawoSalap [or lower part of the belly] in a man: (M, TA:) or [the stomach, or triple stomach, or the crop, or craw, of a bird;] in a bird, like the kariX [in other creatures]: (TA:) [see AljirRiYahN:] or a thing like a little burrow in the belly of a bird: (T, A, L:) [in the present day it is applied to the gizzard, or true stomach, which is perhaps meant by the last of the preceding explanations; and is also pronounced qawoniSap:] or the pl., in relation to a bird, signifies i. q. HawaASil [pl. of HawoSalap]: (TA:) the word is also written with s; but is better with S. (TA.)

1 qanaTa c
1. qanaTa, aor.
qaniTa
; and qanaTa, aor.
qanuTa
; and qaniTa, aor.
qanaTa
; (S, Msb, K;) and qanuTa, aor.
qanuTa
; (K;) and qanaTa, aor.
qanaTa
; and qaniTa, aor.
qaniTa
; each of the last two being a mixture of two dialects; (Akh, S, K;) inf. n. qunuwTN, (S, Msb, K,) which is of the first and second, (S, K, TA,) and of the fourth and sixth also; (K; [but this is doubtful;]) and qanaTN, which is of the third; (S, K;) and qanaATapN, which is also of the third, (S, K,) or [more probably, agreeably with analogy,] of the fourth; (TK;) He despaired (S, Msb, K) of (mino) the mercy of God, (Msb,) or, as in the T, of good: or, as some say, he despaired most vehemently of a thing. (TA.) It is said in the Kur, [xv. 56,] accord. to different readings, wamano yaqoniTu mino raHomapi rabRihi UilRaA AlDRaAlRuwna and yaqonuTu (Bd, TA) and yaqonaTu (Bd) [And who despaireth of the mercy of his Lord except those who are in error?] ＝ -A2- qanoTN is also syn. with manoEN. (K.) You say, qanaTa maMCahu EanRaA He withheld, kept, or debarred, his water from us. (Sgh on the authority of Ibn-'Abbád.)

2 qnRThu c
2. qnRThu, (Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoniyTN, (K,) He made him to despair; (Msb, K;) as also AqnThu↓. (Msb.) You say, XarRu AlnRaAsi AlRaciyna yuqanRiTuwna AlnRaAsa mino raHomapi AllRehi The worst of men are those who make men to despair of the mercy of God. (TA.)

4 OaqonaTa
4: see 2.

qaniTN c
qaniTN: see what follows.

qanuwTN c
qanuwTN: see what follows.

qaAniTN c
qaAniTN (S, Msb) and qaniTN↓ (S, TA) and qanuwTN↓, (Msb, TA,) but the last has an intensive signification, (Bd, xli. 49,) Despairing: (S, Msb, TA:) pl. of the first with wn; (Kur xv. 55, accord. to the prevailing reading;) and so of the second. (S, TA.)

Q. 1 qanoTara AlXRIoCi c
Q. 1. qanoTara AlXRIoCi i. q. Eaqadahu waOaHokamahu [He tied, or knit, the thing; or, agreeably with modern usage, he arched, or vaulted, it; and made it firm, or strong]. (Zj.) Hence what is called a qanoTarap is thus called because of its being firmly, or strongly, knit together, or arched, or vaulted, liUiHokaAmi EaqodihaA. (MF.) [It seems to signify He compacted the thing. ― -b2- Also, He collected the thing together into one aggregate; he aggregated it. See the pass. part. n., below.] ＝ -A2- qanoTara He (a man, TA) possessed property by the qinoTaAr: (K:) or became possessed of a qnTAr of property: (TA:) or possessed large property, as though it were weighed by the qnTAr. (ISd, TA.)

2 taqanoTara bihi farasuhu c
2. taqanoTara bihi farasuhu, for taqaTRara bh: see qaTRarahu.

qanoTarapN c
qanoTarapN [accord. to the Msb, of the measure fanoEalapN, belonging to art. qTr, the n being augmentative; and the same is perhaps meant to be indicated by the place in which it is mentioned in the S and some other lexicons; but accord. to the K, the n is a radical letter; A bridge;] what is built over water, for crossing or passing over (Mgh, Msb) upon it; (Msb;) an Oazaj [or oblong arched or vaulted structure], built with backed bricks or with stones, over water, upon which to cross or pass over: (Az, TA:) or i. q. jisorN: (S, K:) or this latter is a more common term; (Mgh, * Msb;) for it signifies that which is built and that which is not built: (Msb:) a lofty structure: (K:) [pl. qanaATiru.] See 1.

qinoTaArN c
qinoTaArN [accord. to the Msb, of the measure finoEaAlN, belonging to art. qTr, the n being augmentative; and the same is perhaps meant to be indicated by the place in which it is
mentioned in the S and some other lexicons; but accord. to the K, the n is a radical letter;] A certain miEoyaAr [or standard of weight or measure]: (S, TA:) or, accord. to some, a quantity of no determinate weight: (Msb:) or a large unknown quantity or aggregate, of property: (TA:) or much property heaped up: (Msb:) or four thousand deenárs: (Th, Msb:) this is what most of the Arabs hold to be the truth: (Th:) or four thousand dirhems: (Th:) or one thousand two hundred ookeeyehs: (A 'Obeyd, S, K:) so accord. to Mo'ádh Ibn-Jebel: (S:) or [which is the same] a hundred ritls: (Msb:) [this is its weight in the present day; i. e., a hundredweight, or a hundred pounds:] or a hundred ritls of gold or of silver: (Es-Suddee, K:) or a hundred and twenty ritls: (S, L:) or a thousand ookeeyehs of gold: or of silver: (Th:) or twelve thousand ookeeyehs, accord. to Aboo-Hureyreh, on the authority of the Prophet: (TA:) or a hundred ookeeyehs of gold: or of silver: (Th:) or a hundred mithkáls; (I 'Ab, Msb, TA;) the mith- kál being twenty keeráts: (I 'Ab, TA:) or forty ookeeyehs of gold: (K:) or one thousand two hundred deenárs: (K:) or one thousand one hundred deenárs: (L:) or seventy thousand deenárs: (K:) or, in the language of Barbar, a thousand mithkáls of gold or of silver: (TA:) or eighty thousand dirhems: (I 'Ab, K:) or a hundred dirhems: (Msb:) or a hundred menns: (Msb:) or a quantity of gold, (S, K,) or of silver, (K,) sufficient to fill a bull's hide: (S, K:) so in the Syriac language, accord. to Es-Suddee: (TA:) and there are other definitions of the word: (S:) pl. qanaATiyru. (S.)

muqanoTarN c
muqanoTarN Collected together into one aggregate; aggregated; made up; or completed; syn. mukamRalN. (K.) You say qanaATiyru muqanoTarapN, (S,) meaning, Much riches collected together: (Jel. in iii. 12:) the latter word is a corroborative. (Bd. ibid.)

dictScrap.label: qnE qnf: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
qunofudN c
qunofudN i. q. qunofucN. (Ktr, Kr, K.)

dictScrap.label: qnfc, or, accord. to some, qfc

superEntry.entry:
qunofucN c
qunofucN and qunofacN [The male hedge-hog;] (S, L, Msb, K;) i. q. XayohamN: (M, L, K:) or the male and female: (Msb:) or the fem. is with p, (S, L, Msb, K,) sometimes; and the male is called XayohamN and dulodulN: (Msb:) pl. qanaAficu. (S.) Some hold that the n is an augmentative letter: others, that it is a radical. (TA.)

dictScrap.label: qnw: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qahiba c
1. qahiba, aor.
qahaba
, (K, TA,) inf. n. qahabN, (TA,) He, or it, was, or became, of the colour termed quhobapN [q. v.]. (K, TA.)

4 Aqhb Eani AlTRaEaAmi c
4. Aqhb Eani AlTRaEaAmi He abstained from food, or the food, and did not desire it. (O, K.)

qahobN c
qahobN [and Oaqohabu↓] White overspread with duskiness: (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K:) fem. [of the former] qahobapN and [of the latter] qahobaMCu↓, (S,) [and] qahibapN↓ is a fem. epithet having the same meaning: (K, TA:) or white; (TA;) and so quhaAbN↓ and quhaAbiIRN↓; (Lth, O, K, TA;) or all signify thus in respect of skin, or hide: (Az, TA:) or qahobN signifies thus as an epithet applied to the young of goats and oxen, (Lth, O, TA,) and the like thereof, and in respect of skin, or hide: (Lth, O:) and Oaqohabu↓ signifies dust-coloured with an inclining to blackness: (As, S, O:) or red with an intermixture of dust-colour: (IAar, S, O:) or a dusky white: (S, O:) or having a colour inclining to duskiness, with whiteness or blackness (mE AlbyAD llswAd [which I suppose to be a mistake for mE AlbyAD Aw AlswAd]). (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also [or app. jabalN qahobN] A great mountain; (S, K;) accord. to AA: (S:) or, accord. to him, a long mountain: (O:) pl. qihaAbN: or this [or jibaAlN qihaAbN?] signifies mountains of a black colour intermixed with redness. (TA.) ― -b2- And Advanced in age; (O, TA;) applied to an elder; like qaHobN and qaHorN: (TA:) and old in respect of origin; used in this sense by Ru-beh: (O, TA:) or [jamalN qahobN signifies] a camel advanced in age (K, TA) beyond such as is termed baAzilN: (TA:) or a great camel. (AA, TA.)

quhobapN c
quhobapN The colour of that which is termed qahobN; i. e. whiteness overspread with duskiness: (K:) or the colour of that which is termed Oaqohabu; i. e. a dusky whiteness: or, accord. to As, dust-colour inclining to blackness: or, accord. to IAar, redness with an intermixture of dust-colour: (S, O:) or, accord. to IAar, blackness inclining to xuDorap [by which word is here app. meant a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]. (TA voce HusobapN.)

qahibapN c
qahibapN: see qahobN, first sentence.

qahobiIRN c
qahobiIRN The yaEoquwb; (Lth, O, K;) i. e. the male partridge. (Lth, O.)

quhaAbN c
quhaAbN: see qahobN, first sentence.

quhayobN c
quhayobN: see quhayobapN.

qahawobapN c
qahawobapN, (K accord. to the TA,) or qahuwbapN, (O, and so in the CK and in my MS. copy of the K,) like rakuwbapN, (O,) and qahawobaApN, (O, K, TA, [in the O, in which it is restricted to the last of the following meanings, carelessly written qahuwobaAC, but there said to be with fet-h to the h, and with h, by which is meant p,]) accord. to MF with damm to the f, but this is a mistake, (TA,) An arrow-head (O, K *) having three XuEab [i. e. barbs]: (O, K:) and in some instances having two pieces, or two small pieces of iron, (HadiydataAni, O, or HdyRdtAn, TA,) which sometimes contract, and sometimes diverge, or open: (O, TA:) or a small arrow, that hits the butt: (K:) or qahuwbaAtN, which is the pl., signifies short arrows, that hit the butt: this is said by Az to be the right explanation: and IDrd has mentioned qahawobaApN as signifying broad heads of arrows or the like: (O:) accord. to Sb, (TA,) there is no other instance [than qahowobaApN] of a word of which the [primitive] measure is faEawolaI. (K, TA. [XajawojFI and similar words are of the measure faEawoEalN.])

quhayobapN c
quhayobapN, (thus accord. to SM's copy of the K,) in the form of a dim.; accord. to another copy of the K, quhobiyRapN; [accord. to another copy, quhabiyRapN; accord. to the CK, qahiybapN;] and accord. to the L, quhayobN↓ [app. a coll. gen. n. of which quhayobapN is the n. un.]; (TA;) A certain bird, (K, TA,) found in Tihámeh, in which are whiteness and xaDorap [here app. meaning, as in an instance mentioned above, a dark, or an ashy, dust-colour]; a species of partridge. (TA.)

quhaAbiIRN c
quhaAbiIRN: see qahobN, first sentence.

Oaqohabu c
Oaqohabu, and its fem. qahobaMCu: see qahobN, first sentence, in three places. ― -b2- AlOaqohabaAni means The elephant and the buffalo: (S, A, O, K:) each of them is termed Oaqohabu because of his colour, (O, TA,) or because of his greatness. (A, TA.)

qahodN c
qahodN Clear in colour. (L, K.) ― -b2- White; as also qahobN: (A 'Obeyd, L:) by some specially applied to the young of antelopes and cows: (L:) or of a dingy, or dusky, white; as also qahobN. (S, L.)

1 qaharahu c
1. qaharahu. (aor.
qahara
, A, K,) inf. n. qahorN, He overcame, conquered, subdued, subjected, subjugated, overbore, overpowered, mastered, or prevailed or predominated over, him, or it; he was, or became, superior in power or force, to him, or it. (S, A, Msb, K, TA.) ― -b2- [He abased him. (See 4.) ― -b3- He oppressed him. So in the Kur., xciii. 9, faOamRaA Alyatiyma falaA taqoharu [Therefore, happen what may, the orphan thou shalt not oppress; i. e., as explained in the Expos. of the Jel., by taking his property, or otherwise.] ― -b4- He forced, compelled, or constrained, him. So in the following ex.] qaharahu EalaI AlOamori [He forced, compelled, or constrained, him to do the thing]. (S, K, art. qsr.) ― -b5- [He coerced him.] ― -b6- He took him [by force;] against his will, or approval; and so Oaxacahu qahorFA. (A, TA.) ＝ -A2- quhira AllRaHomu (tropical:) The flesh-meat became, (S,) or
began to be, (A, TA,) affected, or acted upon, (lit. taken,) by the fire, so that its juice flowed. (S, A, TA.)

4 Aqhr c
4. Aqhr He became in a state in which to be overcome, conquered, subdued, subjected, subjugated, overborne, overpowered, mastered, or prevailed over: (Msb:) his case became that of one overcome, &c. (S, TA.) ― -b2- His companions became overcome, conquered, subdued, &c., (K, TA,) and abased. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Aqhrhu He found him to be overcome, conquered, subdued, overpowered, mastered, or prevailed over. (S, Msb, K.)

7 Anqhr c
7. Anqhr [quasi-pass. of qaharahu; He was, or became, overcome, &c.]. (TA in art. DgT.)

quhorFA wabuhorFA c
quhorFA wabuhorFA, with damm to each, [a form of imprecation, meaning, May he, or they, be overcome and subdued]. (TA.)

fulaAnN quhorapN llinRaAsi c
fulaAnN quhorapN llinRaAsi Such a one is a person to be overcome, conquered, subdued, &c., by everyone. (A.) ― -b2- Oaxacotu qulaAnFA quhorapF I took such a one by constraint, or compulsion. (S.)

quharapN c
quharapN A woman abounding in evil, injustice, or corruptness; very evil or bad, unjust, or corrupt: (K, TA:) pl. quharaAtN. (TA.)

qahRaArN c
qahRaArN: see qaAhirN.

qaAhrN c
qaAhrN One who overcomes, conquers, subdues, &c.: and qahRaArN↓ signifies the same in an intensive sense. (Msb.) ― -b2- AlqaAhiru (TA) and AlqahRaAru↓ (K, TA) epithets applied to God, (K, TA,) meaning, The Subduer of his creatures by his sovereign authority and power, and the Disposer of them as He pleaseth, with and against their will: (TA:) or the former, the Overcomer, or Subduer, of all created beings. (IAth, TA.) ― -b3- [AlqaAhiru The planet Mars.] ― -b4- jibaAlN qawaAhiru (tropical:) Lofty mountains. (A.)

Oaqoharu c
Oaqoharu [More, and most, subduing, &c.: and, abasing]. (K voce OaxonaEu, q. v.)

Q. 1 qahoqara c
Q. 1. qahoqara, (K, TA,) inf. n. qahoqarapN, (TA,) He (a man) returned by the way by which he had come: (TA:) or i. q. rajaEa AlqahoqarI, (K,) i. e., [he returned backwards; or] he retired, going backwards, without turning his face towards the direction in which he went; (TA;) as also taqahoqara↓. (K, TA.) Some hold, [contr. to the general opinion,] that this verb belongs to art. qhr. (TA.)

Q. 2 taqahoqara
Q. 2: see 1.

qahoqaraI c
qahoqaraI A returning backwards; (S, K;) a retiring, going backwards, without turning the face towards the direction in which one goes: (TA:) the dual is qahoqaraAni; (IAmb, K;) like as the dual of xawozalaI is xawozalaAni; (TA;) without I, (K,) because this letter is deemed difficult to pronounce with the A and the I of the dual. (TA.) When you say rajaEotu AlqahoqaraI [I returned backwards; &c.], it is as though you said I returned with the returning which is known by this name; for AlqhqrI is a mode of returning. (S.) ― -b2- maXaI AlqahoqaraI He reverted from the state in which he was, or from the course which he was following; revolted; apostatized. (Az, from a trad.)

dictScrap.label: qhl qhw: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
1 qaAba AlOaroDa c
1. qaAba AlOaroDa, aor. yaquwbuhaA, (S, O,) inf. n. qawobN; (K;) and qwRbhA↓, (S, O,) inf. n. taqowiybN; (S, O, K;) He dug, or made a hollow in, the ground: (K:) or he dug a round hollow in the ground; (S, O, TA;) thus both phrases are expl. by ISd. (TA.) ― -b2- And qAb bayoDahu, (S, O,) inf. n. as above, (K,) It (a bird) broke asunder its eggs. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- qAb is also intrans., signifying jiloduhu tqwRb↓ [app. His skin became pitted, or marked with small hollows: see an explanation of 2, of which tqwRb is quasi-pass.]. (O.) ― -b2- qAbt AlbayoDapu: see 7. ＝ -A3- Also (qAb) He was, or became, near; drew near; or approached: and He fled: (O, K, TA:) inf. n. qawobN: (TA:) thus it has two contr. significations. (K, TA.)

2 qawRaba
2: see above, first sentence. ― -b2- One says also, qawRabotu AlOaroDa meaning I made impressions, marks, or traces, upon the ground, (O, K, TA,) by treading; and made indications [thereby, or thereof,] at its drinking-places. (TA.) And qawRabwA AlOaroDa, (A, TA,) or fiI AlOaroDi, (O,) They (i. e. persons alighting, A, TA) made impressions, marks, or traces, upon the ground, (A, O, TA,) by their treading and their alighting. (O.) ― -b3- And qwRb Aljarabu jiloda AlbaEiyri The mange, or scab, made pits, or small hollows, bare of fur, in the skin of the camel. (Lth, TA.) See also 5. ― -b4- quwRiba mina AlgubaAri means AigobarRa [i. e., app., He, or it, became sullied with dust]. (Th, TA.) ― -b5- And qwRbhu, inf. n. taqowiybN, He pulled it out or up, by the root; eradicated, or uprooted, it. (K, * TA.)

5 tqwRbt AlOaroDu c
5. tqwRbt AlOaroDu: see 7. ― -b2- tqwRb jiloduhu: see 1. ― -b3- tqwRb also signifies It became peeled, or excoriated, or became so in several, or many, places. (TA.) One says, tqwRb mino raOosihi mawaADiEu Some places in his head became excoriated. (S.) In the saying of Dhn-r-Rummeh,
taqawRaba Eano girobaAni OaworaAkihaA AlxaToru
taqawRaba may be for qawRaba↓ [q. v.]: or the phrase may be inverted, for taqawRabato girobaAnuhaA Eani AlxaTori. (S in art. xTr. [See guraAbN, in art. grb.]) ― -b4- It is also said of a place as meaning It became, in parts, stripped of trees and herbage; and so AnqAb↓. (TA.) ― -b5- And it signifies also It was pulled out or up, by the root; was eradicated, or uprooted. (S, O, K. *) ― -b6- tqwRbt AlbayoDapu: see the next paragraph.

7 AsqAbt AlOaroDu c
7. AsqAbt AlOaroDu The ground was hollowed out in a round form; (S, ISd, O, TA;) as also tqwRbt↓. (ISd, TA.) ― -b2- See also 5. ― -b3- AnqAbt AlbayoDapu, and tqwRbt↓, (S, A, O, K, TA,) and qaAbat↓, (TA,) The egg broke asunder, (S, A, O, K, TA,) and disclosed the young bird within it. (TA.) [Hence] one says AinoqaAbato biyoDapu baniI fulaAnK Eano Oamorihimo [lit. The egg of the sons of such a one broke asunder, and disclosed their affair, case, or state]: meaning (tropical:) the sons of such a one revealed, or manifested, their affair, case, or state; a phrase like Oaforaxato bayoDatuhumo. (A, TA.)

8 AqtAbhu c
8. AqtAbhu He chose, made choice of, selected, elected, or preferred, him, or it. (O, K.)

qaAbN c
qaAbN The portion, of a bow, that is between the part that is grasped by the hand and the curved extremity: to every bow there are qaAbaAni: (S, O, Msb, K:) or, accord. to El-Khafájee, it is [the space] between the string and the part that is grasped by the hand, of the bow; as also qiybN↓: (TA:) in the Kur [liii. 9], fakaAna qaAba qawosayoni accord. to some, is an inverted phrase, meaning fkAn qaAbaIo qawosK [i. e. And he was at the distance of the measure of the two portions between the part that is grasped by the hand and each of the curved extremities of a bow]: (S, O:) [but] qaAbN signifies also a measure, or space; and so qiybN↓: (S, O, K:) one says, bayonahumaA qaAbu qawosK and qawosK qiybu↓, [Between them two is the measure of a bow], and likewise qaAdu quwosK and qiydu qawosK: (S, O: *) and it is said that qaAba qawosayoni [in the case mentioned above] means at [the distance of] the length of two bows: or as Fr says, at [the distance of] the measure of two Arabian bows. (TA.) [qAbu qawosK is also a term often used in astronomy to denote the distance between two stars; and seems to be syn. with ciraAEN (q. v.) as so used, thus meaning A cubit; which is the measure of each qAb of a bow, or nearly so.]

quwbN c
quwbN A young bird; (S, A, O, K;) as also qaAYibapN↓ and qaAbapN↓: (K:) or qaAYibapN↓ signifies, (S, A, O,) or signifies also, (K,) an egg; (S, A, O, K;) and so does qaAbapN↓: (K;) qaAYibapN↓ is used in the latter sense as meaning caAtu quwbK, i. e. caAtu faroxK: (Az, * O, TA: *) or it is like raADiyapN in the phrase EiyXapN raADiyapN [meaning maroDiyRapN]: (A:) [or as being originally the part. n. of qaAbat in the phrase qaAbati AlbayoDapu: and it may be used in the former sense as being originally the act. part. n. of qaAbat in the phrase qaAbati AlbayoDapa said of a hen-bird:] and qaAwibapN↓ signifies an egg from which the young bird has come forth: (Az, TA:) or quwbN signifies an egg: and qaAbapN↓, a young bird: (AHeyth, TA:) the pl. of quwbN is OaqowaAbN. (K.)
It is said in a prov., mino quwbK bariYato qaAYibapN↓, (S, A, O,) or mino quwbK taxalRaSato qaAYabipN↓, (K,) or mino quwbK qaAbapN↓, (tropical:) An egg became or has become, freed from a young bird [that was in it]: (S, A, O, K:) or a young bird, from an egg: (AHeyth, TA:) applied to him who has become separated from his companion. (A, * K.) An Arab of the desert, of the tribe of Asad, (S,) or Asd, (O,) said to a merchant who asked him to be his safeguard, mino UicaA balagotu bika makaAna kacaA bariYato qaAYibapN↓ quwbK, meaning (assumed tropical:) [When I shall have reached with thee such a place,] I shall be clear of obligation to protect thee. (S, O.) El-Kumeyt says
lahunRa walilomaXiybi wamano EalaAhu
waquwbu mina AlOamovaAli qaAYibapN↓
[To them (i. e. women), and to hoariness and him upon whom it has come, relates, among the proverbs, “ An egg and a young bird ”]: he likens the fleeing of women from old men to the fleeing of the quwb, or young bird, from the qaAYibap, or egg; and [virtually] says that the beautiful woman will not return to the old man, like as the young bird will not return to the egg. (TA.) And Aboo-'Alee El-Kálee mentions the saying, mino quwbK laA waAlRaciI Oaxoraja qaAYibapF↓, as meaning [No, by Him who has produced] a young bird from an egg: but Aboo-'Obeyd El-Bekree says that this is inverted. (MF, TA.) ― -b2- OumRu quwbK [in the TA said to be bAlftH, a mistranscription for biAlDRamRi,] Calamity, or misfortune. (O, K.)

quwabN c
quwabN [in the two phrases here following is probably pl. of quwbapN↓]. You say, fiI AlOaroDi quwabN In the ground are hollows [app. meaning round hollows: see 1, first sentence]. (A.) And fiI raOosihi wajilodihi quwabN In his head and his skin are pits. (A, TA.) ― -b2- And hence AlquwabaMCu↓. (A.) See quwabaMCu, in two places. ― -b3- It signifies [also] Egg-shells. (O, K.)

qiybN c
qiybN: see qaAbN, in three places.

quAbapN c
quAbapN: see quwbN: in four places.

quwbapN c
quwbapN: see quwabN: ― -b2- and see also quwabaMCu, in three places.

quwabapN c
quwabapN: see quwabaMCu, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) applied to a man such as is termed maliIoCN [app. as meaning “ rich, ” or “ wealthy ”], One who remains constantly in his abode, (S, K,) not quitting it. (S.)

quwabaMCu c
