quwabaMCu, (S, O, Msb, K,) fem., and imperfectly decl., (S, O,) and quwobaMCN, (S, O, Msb, K,) which is masc., and perfectly decl., as quasi-coordinate to quroTaAsN, said by ISk to be the only word of the measure fuEolaMCN except xuXRaMCN, (S, O,) both originally of the measure fuEalaMCu, (O,) but to these may be added muzRaMCN, (S, O,) [and perhaps some other instances,] and quwabapN↓ and quwobapN↓, (O, K,) both of which are said by Fr to signify the same as quwayaMCu, (O,) [Ringworm, or tetter; so called in the present day;] a well-known disease, (S, O, Msb,) characterized by excoriation and spreading, and cured by spittle, (S, O, TA,) or by the spittle of one who is fasting or hungry; (TA; [see an ex. in a verse cited voce filoqN;]) a cutaneous eruption, in which scabs peel off from the skin, and the hair comes off: (K, TA:) see quwabN, above: quwabN↓ is [also] pl. of tuwabaMCu [like as nufasN is of nufasaMCu], (S,) [and] so is qawaAbiIRu: (KL:) ISd says, accord. to IAar, quwabaMCu is sing. of quwobapN↓ and quwabapN↓; but I know not how this can be: and he [i. e. IAar] also says that quwabN↓ is pl. of quwobapN↓ and quwabapN↓; and this is clear. (TA.) The dim. of quwabaMCu is quwayobaMCu↓; and that of quwobaMCN is quwayobiIRN↓. (S, O.)

quwbiIRN c
quwbiIRN Fond of, or addicted to, the eating of young birds, (O, K, TA,) which are termed OaqowaAb [pl. of quwbN]. (TA.)

quwayobaMCu c
quwayobaMCu and quwayobiIRN: see quwabaMCu, concluding sentence.

qaAYibapN c
qaAYibapN and qaAwibapN: see quwbN; the former in eight places, and the latter in one place. qaAYibapu quwbK means An empty egg: to such, in a trad., Mekkeh is likened when devoid of pilgrims. (O.)

OaroDN mqwbpN c
OaroDN mqwbpN [i. e. maquwbapN or muqawRabapN, being written without any syll. signs,] Land upon which rain has fallen, and in consequence thereof, in some places, trees that were in it formerly have been carried away: mentioned by AHn. (TA.)

mutaqawRibN c
mutaqawRibN Peeled, or excoriated; or so in several, or many, places. (K.) ― -b2- And One from whose skin scabs have peeled off, (A, K, TA,) leaving upon it marks, (A,) and whose hair has come off [at those places]. (K, TA.) ― -b3- And A serpent (S, O, K) of the species termed Oasowadu (S, O) that has cast off its skin. (S, O, K.)

1 qaAta c
1. qaAta, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) aor. yaquwtu, (S, O, Msb,) inf. n. qawotN (S, O, Msb, K) and quwtN (Sb, K) and qiyaAtapN, (S, O, K,) the last originally qiwaAtapN, (O,) He fed, nourished, or sustained, (S, Msb, TA,) or fed with what would sustain the body, (S, O, K, * TA,) [or with food sufficient to sustain life,] or with a small supply of the means of subsistence, (TA,) him, (Msb, TA,) or them, (K, TA,) or his family; (S, O;) he gave him [or them] what is termed quwt [q. v.]: (Msb:) and AqAthu↓ signifies [in like manner] he gave him his quwt. (TA.) It is said in a trad., kafaI biAlmaroCi UivomFA Oano yuDayRiEa mano yaquwtu i. e. [It suffices the man as a sin, or crime, that he destroy] him whom he is bound to sustain, of his family and household and slaves: or, as some relate it, mano yuqiytuhu↓; using a dial. var. [of yqwt]. (TA.) [And lahu AqtAt↓ app. signifies, primarily, He supplied to him food. (See this verb below, near the end of the paragraph.)] ＝ -A2- And qaAta and qwRt↓ and AqAt↓ and Oaqowata↓ [sometimes] signify He straitened his household, by reason of niggardliness or poverty. (TA in art. znq.) ＝ -A3- quwtuwA TaEaAmakumo yubaAriko lakumo fiyhi, a trad., thus related by some, by others quwRituwA↓, [loosely expl. in the TA,] means, accord. to some, Measure ye your corn, [and] He will bless you in it: or, accord. to others, make ye small round cakes (OaqoraAS) of your corn, &c. (El-Jámi' es-Sagheer, and scholia thereon.) ＝ -A4- See also 8, in the middle of the paragraph.

2 qawRata
2: see the preceding paragraph, in two places.

4 AqAthu c
4. AqAthu: see 1, first and second sentences. ― -b2- Also He kept, preserved, guarded, or protected, him. (TA.) ＝ -A2- And AqAt EalaI AlXRaIoCi, (S, O, K, *) and AqAth, (K,) He had power, or ability, to do, effect, accomplish, attain, or compass, the thing. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A3- See, again, 1, latter half, in two places.

5 fulaAnN yataqawRatu bikacaA c
5. fulaAnN yataqawRatu bikacaA [Such a one feeds, nourishes, or sustains, himself with such a thing], (S, O,) or biAlqaliyli [with that which is little]: (Msb:) or tqRwt biAlXRaIoCi he made the thing his quwt [or food]; and bihi AqtAt↓ and AqtAthu↓ signify thus likewise: (TA:) or bihi AqtAt↓ signifies he ate it; (Msb;) and so does AqtAthu↓. (TA.)

8 AqtAt c
8. AqtAt signifies He was, or became, fed, nourished, or sustained; being quasi-pass. of qaAta signifying as expl. in the beginning of this art. (S, A, Mgh, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And it is trans. by means of bi, and by itself: see 5, in four places. One says, humo yaqotaAtuwna AlHabRa [They feed upon, or eat, grain]. (A.) ― -b3- The saying, of Tufeyl,
yaqotaAtu faDola sanaAmihaA AlrRaHolu
is held by ISd to mean, (assumed tropical:) The saddle [as it were] eats the remainder of her hump, [as though] making it to be food for itself: accord. to IAar, he says, the meaning is, takes it away thing after thing [or piecemeal]; but I have not heard this [meaning] in any other instance: hence, says IAar, the oath sworn one day by El-'Okeylee, [said in the A to be an oath of the Arabs of the desert,] nafosiI AlbaSiyri maA faEalotu laA waqaAYiti↓, for, he says, AlAiqotiyaAtu [the inf. n. of AqtAt] and Alqawotu [inf. n. of qaAta↓] are one [in signification]; and AM says that the meaning of this is, [No, by] Him who takes my spirit, breath after breath, until He has taken it wholly, [the All-seeing, I did not that thing:] and the saying of Tufeyl means the saddle, while I am riding upon it, takes by little and little the fat of her hump until there remains not of it aught. (TA.) ― -b4- One says also, AlHarobu taqotaAtu AlUibila (tropical:) [War makes the camels to be food]; meaning that [in consequence of war] the camels are given in payment of bloodwits. (A.) ― -b5- And fulaAnN yaqotaAtu AlkalaAma (tropical:) Such a one retrenches, or curtails, speech, or talk; [said of one who speaks, or talks, little;] syn. yuqilRuhu. (A.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, latter half. [Hence,] one says, Aiqotato linaArika qiytapF↓ (assumed tropical:) [Supply to thy fire ali-
ment;] feed thy fire with fuel. (S, O, K.) And Aiqotato lilnRaAri nafoxaka qiytapF↓, and Aunofuxo fiI AlnRaAri nafoxFA quwtFA↓, (assumed tropical:) Blow thou the fire with thy blowing, and with a blowing, gently and little [as an aliment]. (L.)

10 AstqAthu c
10. AstqAthu He asked of him quwt [i. e. food, or victuals]. (S, A, O, K.)

qaAtN c
[qaAtN A species of tree, of the class Pentandria, order Monogynia, of the Linnæan system; belonging to the natural order of Celastraceæ; mentioned in botanical works under the name of Catha edulis; and fully described by Forskål in his Flora Ægypt. Arab., pp. 63, 64; in the latter page of which he says: “ In Yemen colitur iisdem hortis cum Coffea. Stipitibus plantatur. Arabes folia viridia avide edunt, multum eorum vires venditantes, qui copiosius comederit, vel totam vigilet noctem: asseverant quoque pestem ea loca non intrare ubi hæc colitur arbor: ” &c. ― -b2- And in the same work, p. cxviii., Forskål mentions qAt AlrEyAn (by which is meant qaAtu AlrRuEoyaAni) as the name of A species of lettuce, lactuca inermis. ― -b3- Respecting the former plant, see also De Sacy's Chrest. Arabe, sec. ed., i. 462, 463.]

quwt c
quwt Food, aliment, nutriment, victuals, or provisions, by means of which the body of man is sustained; (S, A, * O, K; *) as also qiytN↓ and qiytapN↓, (S, O, K,) as used in phrases here following, (S, O,) with kesr to the q, and the w changed into I, (S,) and qaAYitN↓ and quwaAtN↓, (K,) the last mentioned, but not expl., by Lh, and thought by ISd to be from quwtN: (TA:) what is eaten for the purpose of retaining the remains of life; (A, * O, * Msb, TA; *) thus expl. by Az and IF: (Msb:) or food sufficient to sustain life: (TA:) pl. OaqowaAtN. (Msb, TA.) One says, maA Einodahu quwtu layolapK and layolapK qiytu↓ and layolapK qiytapu↓ (S, O, TA) He has not a night's food sufficient to sustain life. (TA.) And jadRu QmoriYK fiI qaAYitihi↓, a prov., meaning A man's lot in life is manifest in his food. (Meyd.) ― -b2- See also 8, last sentence.

qiytN c
qiytN: see quwtN, in two places.

qiytapN c
qiytapN: see quwtN, in two places: ― -b2- and see also 8, last two sentences.

quwaAtN c
quwaAtN: see quwtN, first sentence.

qaAYitN c
qaAYitN [act. part. n. of qaAta; Feeding, &c. ― -b2- And hence, Sufficing]. AlqaAYitu mina AlEayoXi means What is sufficient [of the means of subsistence]. (K.) And one says, huwa fiI qaAYitK mina AlEayoXi He is in a state of sufficiency [in respect of the means of subsistence]. (S. O.) ― -b3- See also quwtN, in two places. ＝ -A2- See also 8, former half. ― -b2- AlqaAYitu is an appellation of The lion. (O, K.)

muqiytN c
muqiytN [Giving, or a giver of, food, nourishment, or sustenance. (See 1, first sentence.) ― -b2- And hence,] Keeping, preserving, guarding, or protecting; or a keeper, &c.; syn. HaAfiZN [as signifying thus; and app. as signifying also watching; or a watcher]: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) and witnessing; or a witness; syn. XaAhidN; (S, O, Msb, K;) or XahiydN: (A:) and AO says that it signifies, with the Arabs, one acquainted (mawoquwfN) with a thing (EalaI XaIoCK). (TA.) Th cites the following verses (of Es-Semow'al Ibn-Ádiyà, O):
layota XiEoriI waOaXoEuranRa UicaA maA
qarRabuwhaA manoXuwrapF waduEiytu
OaliIa AlfaDolu Oamo EalaIRa UicaA Huw
sibotu UinRiI EalaI AlHisaAbi muqiytu
[meaning Would that I knew, but I shall assuredly know when they shall have set it (namely, the SaHiyfap, or record, of my actions,) near, unfolded, and I am summoned, whether superiority be for me or against me when I am reckoned with: verily I shall be a watcher, or a witness, of the reckoning, or, accord. to some, as is said in the TA, acquainted with the reckoning]: i. e. I shall know what evil I have done; for [as is said in the Kur lxxv. 14] man shall be a witness against himself: (S, O, TA:) IB says that, accord. to Seer, the correct reading is, rabRiI ElI AlHsAb mqyt [meaning my Lord is able to make the reckoning] because he who is submissive to his Lord does not describe himself by this epithet: but IB adds that Seer has founded this remark upon the assumption that mqyt is here used as meaning muqotadirN; and that if it be understood as syn. with HaAfiZN and XaAhidN, the former reading is not objectionable. (TA.) ― -b3- Almuqiytu is one of the best names of God: (TA:) and [as such] signifies The Possessor of power; (Fr, Zj, S, O, Msb, K, TA;) as He who gives to every man his quwt [or food], (F, S, O, K, TA,) and likewise to everything: (TA:) or (as one of those names, TA) the Preserver, or Protector, (Zj, TA,) who gives to everything such preservation, or protection, as is needful. (TA.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 87], wakaAna QllRehu EalaI kulRi XaIoCK muqiytFA, (S, O,) meaning [For God is] a possessor of power [over everything, or is omnipotent], (Ksh, Bd, Jel,) so He will requite everyone for what he has done: (Jel:) or a witness, [and] a preserver, or protector, or watcher. (Ksh, Bd.)

1 qaAHa c
1. qaAHa, aor. yaquwHu, said of a wound, i. q. qaAHa, inf. n. qyH, q. v.; as also tqRwH↓. (K.) ＝ -A2- And qAH, (K, TA,) inf. n. qawoHN, (TA,) He swept a house, or chamber; (K, TA;) a dial. var. of HaAqa; mentioned by Kr; (TA;) as also qwRH↓. (K, TA.)

2 qawRaHa
2: see what next precedes.

4 AqAH c
4. AqAH He (a man, TA) kept constantly, or perseveringly, to refusing, after the act of asking, or begging; (K, TA;) mentioned by IAar, but in art. qyH. (TA.)

5 taqawRaHa
5: see 1, first sentence.

qaAHapN c
qaAHapN The court of a house; a spacious vacant part, or portion, thereof, in which is no building; syn. saAHapN; (S in art. qyH, and L, K, in the present art.;) and baAHapN, q and b being interchangeable in this case, as in TiynN laAzibN and laAziqN, and in nabiyvapu AlbiYori and naqiyvatuhaA: and the middle of a house: (TA:) pl. quwHN; (K, TA;) like [its syn.] suwHN pl. of saAHapN. (TA.) It is related of 'Omar that he said, mano malaOa Eayonahu mino qaAHapi bayotK qabola Oano yuWocana lahu faqado fajara [He who satisfies his eye by the sight of what is in the court of a house before permission is given to him to enter verily transgresses]. (TA.) And [the pl.] signifies Lands giving growth to nothing. (TA.)

1 qaAdahu c
1. qaAdahu, aor. yaquwdu, inf. n. qawodN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and qiyaAdN (Mgh, Msb) and qiyaAdapN (Msb, K) and maqaAdapN and qayoduwdapN (S, L, K) [originally qayowaduwdapN, of the measure fayoEaluwlapN, like dayomuwmapN &c.,] and taqowaAdN, (K,) [an intensive form; or, accord. to some, inf. n. of qawRada;] He led him; (namely, a horse &c., L;) contr. of saAqahu; Alqawodu being from before, and AlsRawoqu from behind; (Kh, L, Msb, K;) he drew him (a camel) after him; (L;) as also AqtAdhu↓; (S, L, K;) and qwRdhu↓, inf. n. taqowiydN; (K;) or AqtAdh signifies he led him for himself: (Msb:) and qwRdh, he led him much: (S, A, L:) you say qwRd farasahu he led his horse much. (A.) [One says also qaAda bihi; app. by poetic license: see a verse of Jereer cited in the first paragraph of art. rDE.] ― -b2- OaSobaHotu yuqaAdu biIa AlbaEiyru (tropical:) [lit., I have become in such a state that the camel is led with me; i. e.,] I have become old and decrepit. (A.) ― -b3- qaAdati AlrRiyHu AlsRaHaAba (tropical:) The wind led on the cloud, or clouds. (L.) ― -b4- qaAda, inf. n. qiyaAdapN (Mgh, Msb) and qawodN, (L,) (assumed tropical:) He led an army. (Mgh, L, Msb.) ― -b5- AlnRabotu AlvRawora AqtAd↓ (tropical:) [The herbage attracted the bull by its odour;] he perceived its odour and rushed upon it. (A.) ― -b6- qaAda, aor. yaquwdu, inf. n. qiyaAdapN, (tropical:) He acted the part, or performed the office, of a pimp, or bawd; or, of a pimp to his own wife, or of a contented cuckold. (Msb.) Ex. qaAda EalaI AlfaAjirapi, inf. n. as above, [He acted the part, or performed the office, of a pimp to the adulteress, or fornicatress]. (A. [Not given there as tropical.]) ＝ -A2- qaAda, aor. yaquwdu, inf. n. qiyaAdapN, (tropical:) It extended along the surface of the ground; said of a mountain, and of a dyke [&c.]: (T, L:) and so AnqAd↓; said of a mountain, (the Lexicons passim,) and of a tract of land, (L,) and of sand; (TA;) and tqAwd↓ and AqtAd↓. (L.) You say, ZahorN mina AlOaroDi yaquwdu kacaA wakacaA miylFA, and yanoqaAdu, and yataqaAwadu, A rugged and elevated tract of
land that extends such and such a number of miles. And hecaA makaAnN yaquwdu mina AlOaroDi kacaA wakacaA This is a place which stretches along (yjAdb) such and such measures of ground. (L.) ＝ -A3- qawida, [aor. yaqowadu,] (L,) inf. n. qawadN, (S, L, K,) (assumed tropical:) He (a camel, and a horse, S, L, or other beast of carriage, and a man, L) had a long back and neck. (S, L, K.) See Oaqowadu. ＝ -A4- qiyda It (flour) became compacted together in a mass; syn. takRatla and takabRaba. (K.) [See also art. qyd, to which it probably belongs.]

2 qawRada
2: see 1.

3 marRa wafulaAnN yuqaAwiduhu wayusaAwiquhu c
3. marRa wafulaAnN yuqaAwiduhu wayusaAwiquhu [He passed by, or along, such a one vying, or contending, with him in leading on and in driving on]. (A.) [See also 6 in art. swq.]

4 AqAdhu xayolFA c
4. AqAdhu xayolFA He gave him horses to lead: (S, L, K:) and in like manner, maAlFA [camels]. (TA.) ― -b2- AqAd Algayovu (tropical:) The rain spread wide: (L, K:) or, had a cloud, or clouds, leading it on. (L.) ― -b3- (tropical:) He (a man) advanced; went forward: (L, K:) as though he gave the means of leading him to the ground and it attained thereby its want. (L.) ＝ -A2- OaqaAdaniI, (L,) and AqAdnI mina AlqaAtili, (Msb,) He retaliated for me upon the slayer. (L, Msb.) AqAdhu AlsRuloTaAnu mino Oaxiyhi [The Sultán retaliated for him upon his brother]. (S.) ― -b2- AqAd AlqaAtila biAlqatiyli, (inf. n. UiqaAdapN, TA,) He slew the slayer for the slain. (S, L, K.)

6 tqAwdA c
6. tqAwdA (assumed tropical:) They two went away quickly: as though each of them led the other. (L.) [See also 6 in art. swq] ＝ -A2- tqAwd (tropical:) It (a place) became even. (A.) See also 1.

7 AnqAd c
7. AnqAd, [inf. n. AinoqiyaAdN,] He (a beast) suffered himself to be led; (Msb, K;) as also AqtAd↓ (K) and AstqAd↓. (A, TA.) You say AnqAd liI, and AstqAd lI, He was, or became, tractable to me; gave me the means of leading him. (S, L.) ― -b2- AnqAd, (A, K,) inf. n. UinqiyaAdN, (S, L,) (tropical:) He was, or became, submissive, resigned, manageable, easy, humble, or lowly; (S, L, A, K;) as also AstqAd↓. (TA.) ― -b3- AnqAd AlsRaHaAbu, and lilRiryHi AstqAd↓, (tropical:) The cloud, or clouds, became led on by the wind. (A.) ― -b4- AnqAd (tropical:) It (a road) was easy and direct. (TA.) ― -b5- AnqAd liIa AlTRariyqu Uilayohi (tropical:) The road to him, or it, was, or became, plain, or obvious, or manifest, to me. (L, K.) ― -b6- AnqAdt Uilayohi AlmawaAridu (tropical:) The roads, or ways, continued uninterruptedly to it. (As, AM; from a verse of Dhu-r-Rummeh.) See also 1.

8 Uiqotawada
8: see 1 in three places. ― -b2- And see 7.

10 Uisotaqowada
10: see 7 in three places ＝ -A2- AstqAd AlOamora minohu He retaliated the thing upon him. (Lth, L.) ― -b2- AstqAdhu He asked him (namely a judge, or governor,) to retaliate upon a slayer; to slay the slayer for the slain. (S, L, Msb.)

qaAdN c
qaAdN: see qiydN.

qawodN c
qawodN Horses: (S, L, K:) or a number of horses together: (A:) or led horses; horses led by their leading-ropes, not ridden, (Az, L, Msb, K,) but prepared for the time of want. (L.) You say, marRa binaA qawodN [A number of horses together, or of led horses, passed by us]. (S, L.)

qayodN c
qayodN, contr. from qayRidN, see munoqaAdN.

qiydN c
qiydN [originally qiwodN, if belonging to this art.,] and qaAdN↓, Measure; syn. qadorN. (L, art. qyd; and K in the present art.) Ex. huwa minRiI qiyda rumoHK, and rmH qaAda↓, He is [distant] from me the measure of a spear. (L, art. qyd.)

qawadN c
qawadN The slaying of the slayer for the slain: (Lth, L:) or i. q. qiSaASN [which signifies the retaliation of slaughter, and of wounding, and of mutilation;] (S, L, Msb, K;) or slaughter for slaughter, and wounding for wounding. (TA, art. qS.) Ex. Talaba Alqawada mina AlqaAtili [He sought retaliation upon the slayer]. (A.)

qawadN c
qawadN ― -b2- qatalahu bihi qawadFA He slew him for him (i. e. for the slain) in retaliation. (Msb.)

qiyaAdN c
qiyaAdN see miqowadN in three places.

qaWuwdN c
qaWuwdN and qawuwdN see munoqaAdN.

qiyaAdapN c
qiyaAdapN Tractableness; (tropical:) submissiveness; easiness; in a horse or camel. (L.)

qiyRidN c
qiyRidN: see munoqaAdN.

qawRaAdN c
qawRaAdN (tropical:) A pimp; a bawd: fem. with p: (Msb:) a pimp to his own wife; or a contented cuckold; syn. dayRawvN. (Msb, * TA.) ＝ -A2- AlqawRaAdu The nose; in the dial. of Himyer. (K.) ― -b2- In the following words of Ru-beh,
OatolaEu yasomuw bitaliylK qawRaAdo
[Long-necked, elevating himself, with advancing neck], qwRAd is explained as signifying mutaqadRimN. (L.)

qayRidapN c
qayRidapN A camel whereby a man conceals himself from the animal that he would shoot, previously to his shooting at it; (ISd;) i. q. dariyoYapN; (A, L;) as also sayRiqapN. (A.)

qaAYidN c
qaAYidN A leader of horses: (L:) and (assumed tropical:) of an army: (Mgh, Msb:) pl. quwRaAdN and qaAdapN (S, Mgh, L, Msb, K) and quwRadN; (K;) and pl. of qaAdapN, qaAdaAtN. (Mgh.) ― -b2- qaAYidapN [A she-camel] that precedes the other camels [or leads them on,] and with which the young ones keep company. (L.) ― -b3- saHaAbN qaAYidN (tropical:) A cloud, or clouds, leading on rain. (L.) ― -b4- qaAYidapN (tropical:) A wind [riyHN] leading on a cloud, or clouds. (A.) ＝ -A2- qaAYidN (tropical:) Extending along the surface of the ground; applied to a mountain, and a dyke, (T, L,) and a tract of land [&c.]: (K:) and so munoqaAdN↓, applied to a mountain, (the Lexicons passim,) and a tract of land, and of sand. (L.) ― -b2- A prominent part of a mountain (JK, L, K) extending upon the surface of the ground. (JK.) ― -b3- qaAYidapN A hill of the kind termed Oakamap extending upon the surface of the ground: (L, K:) or a hill cleaving to the ground. (IAar, in TA, art. xXE.) ＝ -A3- qaAYidN The largest of the channels for irrigation (fulojaAn) of a land ploughed for sowing. (L, K.) [In the CK, AlHaAriv is put for AlHarov.] ISd says, that he assigns it to this art. only because w is more common than I. (L.) [Pl. qawaAYidu, occuring in the L and TA, voce OaEoraAfN.] ＝ -A4- AlqaAYidu The last star [ η] in the tail of Ursa Major, banaAti naEoXK AlkuboraI: in the K, AlSRugoraI, but this is a mistake. (TA.) [The star ( ζ) which is the middle one of the three in the tail of that constellation is called AlEanaAqN, and by the side of it is the obscure star called AlsRuhaI, and also called AlSRayodaqu, and, as is said in the TA, nuEayoXN; and the third of those three, next the body, is called AlHawaru In the K, a strange description is given of these stars: it is there said, AlOawRalu mino banaAti naEoXK AlSRugoraI AlcI hw [AlqaAYidu] w MxiruhaA qaAYidN waAlvRaAniI EanaAqN waUilaI jaAnibihi qaAYidN SagiyrN w vaAniyhi EanaAqN waUilaI jaAnibihi AlSRayodaqu whw AlsRuhaI wAlvRaAlivu AlHawaru.] ― -b2- The qawaAYidu, among the northern stars, are, it is said, four stars forming an irregular quadrilateral figure, distant one from another, [as though ε, ζ, η π of Hercules,] in the midst of which is an obscure star, resembling a soil, and called AlrRubaEu, they being likened to she-camels with a young one such as is called rubaEN: they are on the left of AlnRasoru AlwaAqiEu [a Lyræ], between it and banaAtu naEoXK. (TA.) [But qawaAYidu, here, is evidently a mistake for EawaAYicu.]

qayoduwdN c
qayoduwdN, originally qayowaduwdN because from qaAda, aor. yaquwdu accord. to the Basrees; or, accord. to the Koofees, it is of the measure faEoluwlapN, and the I is substituted for w; A mare easy to be led. (IKtt, MF.) ＝ -A2- qayoduwdN (assumed tropical:) A long, or tall, she-ass, (S, L, K,) &c.: (K:) pl. qayaAdiydu. (S, L, K.) See also art. qd. ― -b2- qayoduwdN (assumed tropical:) A mare having a long and curved neck: (L:) not applied to a male. (ISd, L.)

Oaqowadu c
Oaqowadu A man (S, L) strong-necked: (S, L, K:) so called because he seldom turns his face aside. (S, L.) ― -b2- Hence, (assumed tropical:) One who is niggardly, or tenacious, of his travelling-provision: (S, L, K:) because he does not turn aside his face in eating, lest he should see a man and be obliged to invite him. (S, L.) ― -b3- (assumed tropical:) A man who does not turn aside his face. (L.) ― -b4- (tropical:) A tall, or high, mountain; (S, L, K; *) as also muqawRadN↓. (K.) ― -b5- qawodaMCu (tropical:) A road of a difficult place of ascent of a mountain (vaniyRapN) extending to a great length upwards, (S, L,) or, reaching high. (K.) ― -b6- qulRapN qawodaMCu (tropical:) A tall
mountain-top. (A.) ― -b7- Oaqowadu (assumed tropical:) A man who, when he applies himself to a thing, can hardly turn his face away from it. (T, L, A, K. *) ― -b8- (assumed tropical:) A camel, and a horse, (S, L,) or other beast of carriage, and a man, (L,) having a long back and neck: (S, L:) or a long-necked horse, (A,) or camel: (R:) or long, or tall, absolutely, applied to a camel: (R, TA:) fem. qawodaMCu; and pl. quwdN: (S, L:) or a horse having a long and large neck. (ISh.) See Xagaba. ＝ -A2- See also munoqaAdN. ― -b2- (tropical:) More, or most, addicted to the conduct of a pimp, or bawd; or, of a pimp to his own wife, or a contented cuckold. (Msb.)

jaEalotuhu maqaAda Almuhori c
jaEalotuhu maqaAda Almuhori (assumed tropical:) I placed him on the right hand: (L, K:) because the colt (mhr) is in most instances led (yuqaAdu) on the right hand. (L.)

miqowadN c
miqowadN A leading-rope; (L, Msb;) that with which one leads [a horse &c.]; (K;) a rope or the like with which one leads [a horse &c.]; (Mgh;) a rope upon the neck, for leading [a horse &c.]: (A:) as also qiyaAdN↓; (L, Mgh, Msb, K;) a rope that is tied to the cord of the nose-ring of a camel, or to the bit of a horse or the like, by which a beast is led; (S, L;) a cord, or a thong or strap, attached to the neck of a beast or of a dog, by which the animal is led: (L:) pl. maqaAwidu. (A, Msb.) ― -b2- OaEoTaI AlqiyaAda↓ (tropical:) [lit., He gave the leading-rope; i. e.,] he was, or became, submissive, or obedient, willingly or unwillingly. (Msb.) ― -b3- fulaAnN salisu AlqiyaAdi↓ (tropical:) [lit., Such a one has an easy leading-rope; i. e.,] such a one will follow thee agreeably with thy desire; (A;) [is submissive, obsequious, or obedient]: and SaEobu AlqiyaAdi↓ (tropical:) [signifying having a difficult leading-rope; i. e., refractory]. (L.)

maquwdN c
maquwdN and maqowuwdN↓ (the latter extr. [with respect to form], and of the dial. of Temeem, TA,) A beast of carriage led. (K.)

gayovN muqiydN c
gayovN muqiydN (tropical:) Wide-spreading rain: or rain having a cloud, or clouds, leading it on. (L.)

muqawRadN c
muqawRadN: see Oaqowadu.

OaEoTaAhu maqaAdatapN c
OaEoTaAhu maqaAdatapN He gave him the means of leading him; he was, or became, tractable to him. (S, * L, * K.)

maqowuwdN c
maqowuwdN: see maquwdN.

munoqaAdN c
munoqaAdN and qaWuwdN↓ (S, L, K) and qawuwdN↓, without C, (Ks,) and qayRidN↓ and qayodN↓, [the last but one originally qayowidN, and the last contracted from it,] like mayRitN and mayotN, and Oaqowadu↓, (L, K,) A horse, (Ks, S, L, K,) and a camel, (Ks, L,) tractable; (tropical:) submissive; easy. (Ks, S, L, K.) Ex. AijoEalo fiI OawRali qiTaArika baEiyrFA qayRidFA [Place thou at the head of thy string of camels a camel that is tractable]. (A.) ＝ -A2- munoqaAdN: see qaAYidN. ― -b2- (tropical:) A direct road. (A.)

1 qawra c
1. qawra, aor. yaqowaru, inf. n. qawarN, It (a thing) was, or became, wide: whence daArN qawraACu, q. v. (JK.) ＝ -A2- qaArahu, (A, K,) aor. yaquwru, inf. n. qaworN; (TA;) and qwRrhu↓, (S, A, Mgh, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqowiyrN; (Mgh, Msb;) and Uiqotawarahu↓; and AqtArhu↓; (S, K;) [of all which the second is the most common;] He cut a round hole in the middle of it; (A, Mgh, Msb, K;) as one cuts a jayob [or the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt], (TA,) and a melon: (Mgh, Msb:) [he hollowed it out; he scooped it out; he cut out a piece of it, generally meaning in a round form:] he cut it in a round form. (S.) You say Aljayoba qwRr↓ [He cut out, or hollowed out, the opening at the neck and bosom of the shirt]. (TA.) And qurotu AlbiTRiyxapa, and qawRarotuhaA↓, [I cut a round hole in the melon]. (TA.) And qurotu xufRa AlbaEiyri, and qawRarotuhu↓, and Uiqotarotuhu↓, [I cut a round hollow in the foot of the camel]. (TA.) ― -b2- qurotuhu, and qurotu Eayonahu, I put out, or pulled out, [or scooped out,] his eye; syn. faqaOotu Eayonahu. (TA.) ― -b3- qaAra AlmaroOapa He circumcised the woman. (L, K.)

2 qwRr c
2. qwRr He widened a house; made it wide. (A, * TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, in four places.

5 tqwRr c
5. tqwRr It (a cloud) became dissundered, and separated into round portions. (TA, from a trad.) See also 7.

7 AnqAr c
7. AnqAr It (the side of a cloud) became as though a portion fell from it, by reason of much water pouring [from it]. (TA.) See also 5.

8 Uiqotawarahu c and AqtArhu
8. Uiqotawarahu AqtArhu: see 1, in two places.

qaArN c
qaArN i. q. qiyrN [Tar: or pitch]. (S, K.) See muqawRarN.

qaArapN c
qaArapN A small mountain separate from other mountains: (K:) or a small mountain upon another mountain: such [or a knoll of a mountain] seems to be meant by qaArapu jabalK:) (TA:) or the smallest of mountains: (A:) or a small, black, isolated mountain, resembling an OakamapN: or a black Oakamap: (TA:) or i. q. OakamapN [i. e. a hill, or mound, &c.]: (S:) or the smallest of mountains and the largest of MkaAm; scattered, rough, and abounding with stones: (Lth:) or a small mountain, slender, compact, and lofty, not extending along the surface of the ground, as though it were a collection of stones, and [sometimes] great, and round: (ISh:) or a great rock, (K,) smaller than a mountain: (TA:) or a black rock: (K:) or a tract of ground containing black stones; (K, TA;) i. e., a HarRap: (TA:) pl. qaArN, (S, K,) [or rather this is a coll. gen. n.,] and qaAraAtN (K) and quwrN (Lth, S, A, K) and qiyraAnN. (Lth, K.)

quwaArapN c
quwaArapN What is cut in a round form (maA quwRira) from a garment or piece of cloth, &c.; (K;) as the qwArp of a shirt, (S, A, Msb,) and of a jayob [or the opening at the neck and bosom of a shirt], (TA, [but there written, by mistake, jnb,]) and of a melon: (S, A:) or particularly from a hide, or tanned hide; (Lh, K;) what is cut in a round form (maA quwRira) from the middle of a hide, or tanned hide, for a target to shoot at, like the qwArp of a jayob. (JK.) ― -b2- Also, What one cuts from the sides of a thing (K, TA) that is muqawRar [or cut in a round form]. (TA.) ― -b3- And, contr., A thing of which the sides have been cut. (K.)

Oaqowaru c
[Oaqowaru: fem. qaworaMCu: Wide in the inside; capacious.] daArN qaworaMCu A house that is wide (S, K, TA) in the inside. (TA.)

muqawRarN c
muqawRarN [Having a round hole cut in its middle: hollowed out; scooped out: cut in a round form. See 1.] ＝ -A2- A camel smeared with qaTiraAn [or tar]. (Sgh, K.) See qaArN.

muqawRirN c
muqawRirN A youth who hollows out the cakes of bread, eating the middle parts and leaving the edges. (A, TA.)

1 qaAsa AlXRaIoCa bigayorhi c
1. qaAsa AlXRaIoCa bigayorhi, and EalaI gayorihi, aor. yaquwsuhu, inf. n. qawosN (S, K *) and qiyaAsN, (S,) i. q. qaAsahu, aor. yaqiysuhu, inf. n. qayosN (S, K *) and qiyaAsN; (S;) i. e., He measured the thing by another thing like it; [both in the proper sense and mentally; but the latter verb is the more common, though the former, accord. to the JK, is the original;] (S, TA;) and so AlXRaIoCa bigayorihi AqtAs↓: (S, K: *) but you should not say Oaqasotuhu↓ for qusotuhu or qisotuhu. (S.) ＝ -A2- qawisa: see 5.

2 qawRasa
2: see 5, in two places. ＝ -A2- qwRshu, inf. n. taqowiysN, He made it bowed, or bent. (KL.)

4 Oaqowasa
4: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see 5.

5 tqwRs c
5. tqwRs It (a thing) became bowed, or bent; as also Astqws↓: (TA:) the ↓latter is also said, tropically, of the moon when near the change [&c.]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- (tropical:) He (an old man, S, A) became bowed, or bent; (A, * K;) as also qawRasa↓, inf. n. taqowiysN; (S, A, * Msb, K;) and Astqws↓; (S;) and Aqws↓: (A:) or he became bowed, or bent, in the back; as also qawRasa↓; and Astqws↓; (TA;) and so qawisa↓, aor.
qawasa
, inf. n. qawasN. (K.) ＝ -A2- tqwRs qawosahu He put his bow upon his back. (TA.)

8 Uiqotawasa
8: see 1. ― -b2- yaqotaAsu biOabiyhi, (S, K,) inf. n. UiqotiyaAsN, (S,) (assumed tropical:) He follows the way of his father, and imitates him. (S, K.)

10 Uisotaqowasa
10: see 5, in four places.

qaAsu rumoHK c
qaAsu rumoHK: see qiysu rumoHK.

qawosN c
qawosN [A bow;] a certain thing, well known, (A, K,) with which one shoots: (M, TA:) of the fem. gender: (IAmb, M, Msb:) or masc. and
fem.: (S, Msb:) or sometimes masc.: (A, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaqowaAsN (IAmb, S, A, Msb, K) and OaqoyaAsN, (TA, and so in some copies of the K, in the place of the former,) the I being interchangeable with the w, (TA,) and [of mult.] qisiIRN, (S, A, Msb, K,) originally quwuwsN, (S, TA,) which is not used, (TA,) of the neasure fuEuwlN, (S, Msb,) first changed to qusuwRN, of he measure fuluwEN, and then to qisiIRN, of the measure filiyEN, like EiSiIRN, (S,) and qusiIRN, (Fr, Sgh, K,) from the same original, (TA,) [like EuSiIRN,] and qiyaAsN, (IAmb, S, A, Msb, K,) which is more agreeable with analogy than qsIR. (TA.) The dim. is quwayosN, (IAmb, M, Msb, K,) without p, contr. to rule, as the word is fem., (M, TA,) and quwayosapN, (IAmb, Msb, K,) sometimes: (IAmb, Msb:) or the former accord. to those who make qws to be masc., (S,) and the latter accord. to those who make it to be fem. (S, Msb.) It is prefixed to another word to give it a special signification. Thus you say, qawosu nabolK An Arabian bow. And qawosu nuXRaAbK A Persian bow. And qawosu HusobaAnK [A bow for shooting a certain kind of short arrows]. And qawosu julaAhiqK [A cross-bow]. And qawosu nadofK [A bow for loosening and separating cotton]. (Msb.) ― -b2- [Hence the saying,] fulaAnN laA yamudRu qawosahu OaHadN [Such a one, no one will pull his bow;] i. e., (tropical:) no one will vie with him, or compete with him. (A, TA.) And ramawonaA Eano qawosK waAHidK, (A, TA,) or waAHidapK, (Mgh,) [lit., They shot at us from one bow: meaning, (tropical:) they were unanimous against us;] a proverb denoting agreement. (Mgh.) [In the Msb, ramawohumo and waAHidapK.] And huwa mino xayori quwayosK sahomFA; (S, L, K; except that in the L and K, for qwys, we find qawosK;) (tropical:) [He is of the best of a little bow, as an arrow; i. e., he is one of the best arrows of a little bow;] or SaAra xayora quwayosK sahomFA (A, K) (tropical:) [He became the best of a little bow, as an arrow; i. e., he became the best arrow of a little bow:] a proverb [See Arab. Prov. i. 718] applied to him who has become mighty after being of mean condition: (A:) or to him who opposeth thee and then returns to doing what thou likest. (A, K.) [Hence also the phrase in the Kur, liii. 9,] fakaAna qaAba qawosayoni And he was at the distance of two Arabian bows: or two cubits [this is app. an explanation by one who holds qaAba qawosayoni to be for qaAbaIa qawosK:] (K:) or the meaning is, qaAbaIo qawosK, i. e., [at the distance of the measure of] the two portions between the part of a bow that is grasped by the hand and each of the curved extremities. (TA.) See also art. qwb. ― -b3- Alqawosu (assumed tropical:) [The Sign of Sagittarius; also called AlrRaAmiI;] one of the signs of the zodiac; (S, K;) namely, the ninth thereof. (TA.) ― -b4- qawosu quzaHa The rainbow: the two words are inseparable. (TA.) See qzH. ― -b5- qawosu AlrRajuli (assumed tropical:) The bowed, or bent, part of the back of a man. (IAar.) ― -b6- OaqowaAsu AlbaEiyir (tropical:) The anterior ribs of the camel. (A.) ― -b7- Also qawosN (tropical:) What remains, of dates, (S, A, * K,) in the [receptacle called] julRap, (S,) or in the bottom thereof, (K,) or in the sides thereof, like a bow: (A:) or, accord. to Zeyd Ibn-Kuthweh, the fourth part of the julRap, of dates; like rizomapN: (TA in art. rzm:) in this sense, also, it is fem.: or a number of dates collected together: pl. as above. (TA in the present art.) ＝ -A2- Also, A cubit: (S, K:) sometimes used in this sense: (S:) because a thing is measured (yuqaAsu) with it. (K.)

qiysu rumoHK c
qiysu rumoHK and qaAsu rumoHK The measure of a spear. (Msb, in this art.; and S, K, in art. qys.)

qawRaAsN c
qawRaAsN A hewer, or fashioner, of bows; and so, perhaps, qayRaAsN. (TA.)

qusawiIRN c
qusawiIRN is the rel. n. from qisiIRN, [pl. of qawosN,] because it is [before its last change] of the measure fuluwEN changed from the measure fuEuwlN. (S.)

Oaqowasu c
Oaqowasu Having a bowed, or bent, back. (S, K.) ― -b2- Sand that is elevated (K, TA) like a hoop or ring. (TA.)

miqowasN c
miqowasN A bow-case. (S, K.) ＝ -A2- A horse-course; a race-ground: (Ibn-'Abbád, K:) a place whence horses run (K) for a race; (TA;) i. e., (so in the K accord. to the TA,) a rope at which the horses are placed in a row (S, A, K) on the occasion of racing, (S, K,) in the place whence they run: (A:) or the extended rope from which the horses are started: (JK:) also called mqyS: the pl. is maqaAwisu. (TA.) Hence the saying, EuriDa fulaAnN EalaI Almiqowasi [Such a one has been put to the starting-rope]; meaning, (tropical:) such a one has been tried, or proved, by use, practice, or experience. (A, TA.) And fulaAnN EalaI miqowasK, i. e., EalaI HifaAZK [app. meaning, (assumed tropical:) Such a one is intent upon defending his honour or the like]. (Lth, L.)

muqawRasN c
muqawRasN and muqawRisN: see mutaqawRisN.

mutaqawRisN c
mutaqawRisN (assumed tropical:) An eyebrow [or other thing] likened to a bow; as also musotaqowisN↓ (K) and muqawRasN↓: (TA:) ↓the second of these epithets is also applied, in the same sense, or like a bow, to a gutter round a tent, and the like. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, A man bowed, or bent; and so muqawRisN↓. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, (K,) or mutaqawRisN qawosahu, (S,) A man having with him his bow. (S, K. *)

musotaqowisN c
musotaqowisN: see mutaqawRisu, in two places.

1 qawVDa
1: see 2: and see also 1 in art. qyD.

2 qwRDhu c
2. qwRDhu, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqowiyDN, (Msb, K,) He demolished it; destroyed it; threw it down; namely a building; as also qaADahu↓, (K,) aor. yaquwDu, inf. n. qawoDN: (TA:) or he took it to pieces, without demolishing or destroying or throwing down; (S, A, Msb, K;) namely a building, (S, A, Msb,) and a tent. (A:) or he pulled up, or out, its poles, or pieces of wood, and its tentropes: (IDrd, K:) or he pulled it up, and removed it; namely a tent. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] qwRD AlSRufuwfa, and AlmajaAlisa, (A, TA,) (tropical:) He separated, or dispersed, the ranks, and the assemblies. (TA.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] banaI fulaAnN vumRa qawRaDa [lit. Such a one built, then demolished, or took to pieces]; i. e. (tropical:) did well, then did ill. (A, TA.)

5 tqwRD c
5. tqwRD It (a house, and a tent, TA) became demolished, destroyed, or thrown down; (S * in art. qyD; and K;) and in like manner tqwRz; (TA;) as also AnqAD↓ [which see also in art. qyD]: (K; and in a copy of the S in art. qyD:) or it was, or became, taken to pieces, without being demolished or destroyed or thrown down: (A, TA:) and AnqADt↓, said of a well (bYor), it fell; fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed. (Msb: see also art. qyD.) ― -b2- [Hence,] tqwRD Almajolisu, (A,) and tqwRDt AlHilaqu, (S, TA,) and AlSRafuwfu, (S, Msb, TA,) (tropical:) [The assembly, and] the rings of men, (S, TA,) and the ranks, became separated, or dispersed. (S, Msb, * TA.) ― -b3- Also, (assumed tropical:) He (a man, K, and a bird, Az, TA) came and went, (Az, K, TA,) and would not be still, or remain at rest. (Az, TA.)

7 UinoqawaDa
7: see 5, in two places.

hecaA bicaA qawoDFA biqawoDK c
hecaA bicaA qawoDFA biqawoDK This is for that, as a substitute for a substitute. (K.) And humaA qawoDaAni [They two are substitutes, each for the other]: mentioned by Sgh: but Z says, hmA qayoDaAni [q. v. in art. qyD]: (TA:) or both signify they are exchangers, each with the other. (JK.)

muqawRaDN c
muqawRaDN Anything demolished, destroyed, or thrown down: [&c.: see 2.] (TA.)

dictScrap.label: qwE qwf qwl qwm qwI: See Supplement.

superEntry.entry:
quwolanojN c
quwolanojN, (Msb, * K,) with fet-h to the l, (Msb,) and sometimes qawolinojN, with kesr to the l, or thus and quwlinojN, i. e. with kesr to the l and with fet-h and damm to the q, (K,) a foreign word, (TA,) [from the Greek κωλικὸσ The colic;] a certain painful intestinal disease, in which the egress of the feces and wind is attended with difficulty; (K;) a violent griping in the intestine called the colon. (Msb.)

1 qaMCa c
1. qaMCa, aor. yaqiIoCu, inf. n. qaIoCN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb,
K, &c.,) He vomited (Mgh, TA) what he had eaten. (Mgh, Msb, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence one says,] qaMCa nafosahu [lit. He vomited his soul], meaning (assumed tropical:) he died: like lafaZa nafosahu. (A, TA.) And qaMCati AlTRaEonapu AldRama (assumed tropical:) [The wound made with a spear or the like spouted forth the blood]. (A, TA.) And vawobN yaqiIoCu AlSiboga (assumed tropical:) A garment that is saturated with the dye. (S, A, O, K.) And taqiIoCu AlOaroDu OafolaAca kabidihaA [lit. The earth will vomit the pieces of her liver], meaning (tropical:) the earth will cast forth upon her surface her treasures. (TA, from a trad.) And qaMCati AlOaroDu OukulahaA [lit. the earth vomited her food], meaning (tropical:) the earth disclosed her herbage and her treasures. (TA, from a saying of 'Áïsheh.) And AlOaroDu taqiIoCu AlnRadaI (tropical:) [The earth exudes the moisture]. (TA.)

2 qyROhu c
2. qyROhu He, (a man, S, Mgh, O, Msb,) or it, (medicine, K,) caused him to vomit; (S, * Mgh, O, * Msb, K; *) and AqMChu↓ signifies the same. (S, O, K.)

4 OaqoyaAa
4: see what immediately precedes.

5 tqyRO c
5. tqyRO He constrained himself to vomit; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, TA;) and he vomited intentionally. (TA.) See also 10, in two places. ＝ -A2- And taqayRaOato She addressed, or presented, herself to her husband, and threw herself upon him: (K:) or, accord. to Lth, she affected languor, or languidness, to her husband, and threw herself upon him: but in the opinion of Az, the verb with q in this sense is a mistranscription, and is correctly tfyROt, [q. v.,] with f. (TA.)

10 AstqMC c
10. AstqMC, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA,) or AstqyaOa, (thus in the O, in which the former is not mentioned, [and it seems from an ex. in a verse there cited that this may be a dial. var.,]) and tqyRO↓, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K, TA,) He constrained himself to vomit: (S, Mgh, O, Msb: [see the latter verb above: in the K neither is expl.:]) or the former is an instance of AisotafoEala from AlqaIoCu [i. e. it signifies he desired to vomit]: and ↓the latter signifies more than the former, i. e. he made what was in the jawof [here meaning stomach] to come forth, intentionally. (TA.) It is said in a trad., lawo yaEolamu AlXRaAribu qaAYimFA maA caA Ealayohi laQsotaqaMCa maA Xariba [If the person drinking in a standing posture knew what would be the effect upon him, he would desire to vomit what he had drunk: for the drinking and the eating in that posture are forbidden in more than one trad.]. (TA.)

qaIoCN c
qaIoCN originally an inf. n.: then applied to signify Vomit; i. e. vomited food. (Msb.) It is said in a trad., AlrRaAjiEu fiI hibatihi kaAlrRaAjiEi fiI qayoYihi [He who takes back his gift is like him who swallows back his vomit]. (S.)

quyaMCN c
quyaMCN a subst. (K, TA) similar to EuTaAsN and duwaArN [and many other words of the same form applied to maladies; indicating that it signifies A complaint that causes much, or frequent, vomiting]. (TA.) One says, bihi quyaMCN, meaning [In him is a complaint in consequence of which] he is vomiting much, or frequently. (ISk, S, O.)

qayuwoCN c
qayuwoCN One (a man, IAar) who vomits much, or frequently; as also qayuwRN; (IAar, K, TA;) the latter formed from the former, like maqoruwRN from maqoruwoCN. (L, TA.) ― -b2- Also, [dawaMCN qayuwoCN,] Medicine that is taken to cause vomiting; (ISk, S, O;) and so dawaMCN muqayRiYN↓ (K, TA) and muqiIoCN↓. (TA.)

muqiIoCN c
muqiIoCN and muqayRiYN: see what immediately precedes.

1 qaAHa c
1. qaAHa, said of a wound, (S, A, Msb, K, &c.,) aor. yaqiyHu, (S, Msb,) inf. n. qayoHN; (Msb, K;) like qaAHa, aor. yaquwHu; (K;) and qyRH↓, (S, A, Msb, K,) inf. n. taqoyiyHN; (A;) and AqAH↓; (A, Msb, K;) and tqyRH↓; (S, A, Msb, K;) and tqRwH; (Msb, K;) [It suppurated;] it became in the state of containing [or generating] matter, such as is termed qayoH [meaning as expl. below]: (S, * A, * K in art. qwEH, and Msb in explanation of qayRaHa:) or its qayoH ran, or flowed: or became in a state of readiness [to do so]. (Msb in explanation of qaAHa and AqAH and tqwRH.)

2 qayRaHa
2: and 4 and 5: see the preceding paragraph.

qayoHN c
qayoHN Thick purulent matter (midRapN) unmixed with blood; (S, A, L, K;) white, thick [matter], unmixed with blood: (Msb:) or, as some say, [contr. to the generality of the lexicographers,] thin matter (Sadiyd) like water, in which is a Xukolap [ or small admixture, or tinge of the red and white hue,] of blood. (L.)

qaAHapN c
qaAHapN, mentioned in this art. in the S, see in art. qwH.

1 qiyda c
1. qiyda: see 2.

2 qyRdhu c
2. qyRdhu, inf. n. taqoyiydN, He put a qayod [or pair of shackles] upon his (a horse's) [fore-] legs; he shackled his [fore-] legs. (Msb.) qayRadotu AldRaAbRapa [I shackled the fore-legs of the beast; hobbled him: and, in a general sense, bound him.] (S.) qiyda↓ (inf. n. qayodN, TA) and quyRida signify the same, [He had shackles put upon his fore-legs; he had his fore-legs shackled]. (K.) See also 5. ― -b2- qayRidohu biAloOaloti (assumed tropical:) [Bind thou him by oath]: said when one has not given thee thy right or due. (TA in art. Alt.) ― -b3- OuqayRidu jamaliI, (inf. n. taqoyiydN, K.) [lit., I shackle the fore-legs of my camel; meaning,] (tropical:) I fascinate my husband so as to prevent him from going to other women; as though I shackled his legs. (IAth, L, K, * from a trad.) ― -b4- (tropical:) It (fatigue) kept a she-camel from action. (A.) ― -b5- (tropical:) It (beneficence) shackled, or restrained, a person. (A.) ― -b6- qyRd AlUiymaAnu Alfatoka (tropical:) [The giving assurance of safety] inhibits assassinating, or assaulting, the muWoman [i. e. the person to whom assurance of safety has been given (bAlmuWmini in the CK is a mistranscription for biAlmuWomani)]; like as shackles inhibit the mischievous animal from doing mischief. (L, K, * from a trad. [See also 1 in art. ftk; where this trad. is cited in full.]) ― -b7- qyRd, (inf. n. taqoyiydN K,) (tropical:) He pointed a writing with the syllabical signs, or signs which point out the pronunciation and division of syllables: (S, A, L, K:) he pointed a letter: (L:) he restricted a word or phrase [in its signification or application] by that which prevented equivocation and removed ambiguity. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- (tropical:) He registered, or recorded, a matter of science [&c.] in a book or the like; i. q. DabaTa. (L.)

5 tqyRd c
5. tqyRd quasi-pass. of qyRd [He had shackles put upon his legs; he had his legs shackled: see also 2]. (A.)

qaAdN c
qaAdN: see qiydN,

qayodN c
qayodN [A shackle; or fetter: or, generally, a pair of shackles for the fore-legs of a beast, and generally made of rope, but some are of iron; a pair of hobbles; a pair of fetters]: (S, K, &c.:) pl. [of pauc.] OaqoyaAdN (L, Msb, K) and [of mult.] quyuwdN. (S, L, Msb, K.) ― -b2- UinR quyuwda AlOayaAdo Oawovaqu AlOaqoyaAdo (tropical:) [Verily the shackles of benefactions are the firmest of shackles]. (A.) [AlOayaAdo is for AlOayaAdiI.] ― -b3- What binds together [the two pieces of wood in a camel's saddle which are called] the EaDudaAni of [the two broad pieces of wood called] the muWaxRarataAni, (L, K [in the former of which, however, instead of mA DmR AlEDdyn mn AlmwxRrtyn, the reading in the K, is put mA DmR AlEDdtyn AlmWxRrtyn, which I suppose to be a mistake]) at their upper part, being a thong. (L.) ― -b4- A plaited thong between [the two pieces of wood called] the HinowaAni of a camel's saddle of the kind called raHol, at the upper part; and sometimes, of a horse's saddle. (L.) ― -b5- The thong that binds together [the two pieces of wood called] the EaroquwataAni of a camel's saddle of the kind called qatab. (S, L, K.) ― -b6- Anything that binds one part of a thing to another part. (L.) ― -b7- The extended thing at the lower extremities of the suspensory cords or strings of a sword, which is held by [the rings called] the bakaraAt. (L, K.) ― -b8- qayodaA AlbaAziI The jesses of the hawk or falcon; syn. sibaAqaAhu (S, O, K, all in art. sbq.) ― -b9- qayodu AlOasonaAni The gum wherein the teeth are set: (K:) quyuwdu AlAsnAn the gums: (L:) or the portions of the flesh of the gums that rise between the teeth; likened to the red quyuwd which are marks upon camels, made with a hot iron. (ISd, L.) ― -b10- qayodu Alfarasi A certain mark made with a hot iron upon the neck of a camel, (S, ISd, L, K,) and upon its face, and thigh, of an oblong shape, (ISd, L,) in the form of a qayod [for the legs], (S, L,) or of two rings with a line extending between them. (Nh, L.) ― -b11-
qayodu AlOawaAbidi (tropical:) [lit. Shackles upon the legs of the wild animals which shun, and take fright at, mankind &c.; or, accord. to the L, of the wild asses]: indeterminate in signification, though determinate in its grammatical form: (Sb, L:) an appellation given to a horse, (K,) or to a fleet, or swift, and excellent horse, because, by its swiftness, it overtakes the wild beasts, (T, K,) and prevents their escaping. (T, S.) qyd is here a proper subst. used as an epithet because it imports the attribute of a verb; or it is for taqoyid. (IJ, L.) [See also art. Abd and Ham, p. 455.] ― -b12- (tropical:) A wife: as also gulRN. (TA.) ― -b13- maA EalaI hecaA AlHarofi qyado (tropical:) There is not upon this letter a syllabical sign, or sign which points out the pronunciation, or the division of syllables. (A.) ― -b14- Alqayodu waAlrRatoEapu, a prov.: see art. rtE. ＝ -A2- See also qiydN.

qiydN c
qiydN A whip made of skin. (MF.) ＝ -A2- qiydN and qaAdN↓ (S, L, K) and qayodN↓ (K) Measure. (S, L, K.) Ex. bayonahumaA qiydu rumoHK, and qaAdu rmH, Between them two is the measure of a spear. (S.) See also art. qwd.

qiyaAdN c
qiyaAdN A leading-rope (S, K) for a beast of carriage. (S, K.) [But this belongs to art. qwd, q. v.]

qayRidN c
qayRidN Tractable; easy to be led. (S, K.) [But this belongs to art. qwd, q. v.]

qayRidapN c
qayRidapN: see art. qwd.

maqiydN c
maqiydN: see muqayRadN.

muqayRadN c
muqayRadN The place of the qayod in the leg of a horse; (S, K;) [i. e., the pastern]. Ex. farasN Eabolu AlmuqayRadi Tawiylu AlmuqalRadi [A horse large in the place of the shackle, or pastern; long in the place of the collar, or neck]. (A.) ― -b2- The place of the anklet in [the leg of] a woman; (S, K;) [i. e., the ankle]. ― -b3- muqayRadN [and maqiydN↓] A camel, or the like, having his legs shackled; having shackles upon his legs: pl. [of the latter] maqaAyiydu. (K.) You say heWulaMCi OajomaAlN maqaAyiydN, i. e., muqayRadaAtNe [These are camels having their legs shackled]. (S.) ― -b4- naAqapN muqayRadapN (tropical:) A jaded she-camel that will not be roused to action. (A.) ― -b5- And muqayRadN A place in which a camel is left with his legs shackled. (L, K.) Hence applied to a place abounding with herbage, or pasture. (L.)

muqayRidapu AlHimaAri c
muqayRidapu AlHimaAri (L) [in the CK, muqayRadapu AlHimaAri, and in most copies of the K, accord. to the TA, AlximaAri,] (assumed tropical:) A stony tract, of which the stones are black and worn and crumbling, as though burned with fire; syn. HarRapN: (L, K: [in a copy of the K, HurRapN] so called because it impedes the ass, [in the TA, art. Hmr, the wild ass,] as though it shackled him. (L.) ― -b2- Hence, (L,) banuw muqayRidapi AlHimaAri, (L,) in the K, banuw maqayRadapa [with fet-h to the I, and without AlHmAr] (TA,) [and in the CK, banuw muqayRadK,] (assumed tropical:) Scorpions: (L, K:) so called because they are in a tract such as is called mqRydpAlHmAr. (L.) [See an ex. in some verses cited voce rumoHN.]

taqoyiydN c
[taqoyiydN A note which determines the correct reading or meaning of a word or phrase or the like: and hence, any marginal note: pl. taqoyiydaAtN.]

2 qyRr c
2. qyRr He smeared a ship, or boat, (S, A, Msb,) or a jar [for wine], and a skin for wine or the like, (K,) with qiyr or qaAr. (S, A, Msb, K.)

qiyrN c
qiyrN i. q. qaArN [Tar: or pitch]: (S, A, Msb, K:) a certain black thing with which are smeared ships, (K, TA,) to prevent the water from entering, (TA,) and camels, also, (K, TA,) for the mange, or scab, and whereof there is a species with which anklets and bracelets are filled: it is extracted by melting from [the] SEd: (TA:) [SuEudN is the name of a certain tree from which tar is melted forth: (L, art. SEd:)] or i. q. zifotN: (A, K, TA:) and the best thereof is of the colour termed Xuqorap. (TA.) [See also kuforN.]

qayRaArN c
qayRaArN A possessor, (K,) or seller, (A,) of qiyr or qaAr: (A, K;) or a maker of it. (So in a copy of the S, but not mentioned in another copy.)

qayRaArapN c
qayRaArapN A place where qaAr is generated. (Mgh, in art. nfT.)

qayorawaAnN c
qayorawaAnN, an arabicized word, (K,) from [the Persian] kaArowaAno, (TA,) and signifying A caravan; a company, or an assemblage of persons, travelling together; syn. qaAfilapN: (K:) or the main part of a qAflp: and of an army: (A. IAth, and so in a copy of the S:) or of [such a collection of soldiers as is called] a katiysbap: (ISk:) and the companions and assistants of the devil. (IAth.) It has the last of these significations in a trad. of Mujáhid, in which it is said, yagoduw AlXRayoTaAnu biqayorawaAnihi UilaI AlsRuwqi falaA yazaAlu yahotazRu AlEaroXu mimRaA yaEolamu QllRehu maA laA yaEolamu [The devil goeth in the morning with his companions and assistants to the market-place, and the empyrean ceaseth not to shake in consequence of the assertions that God knoweth what He knoweth not]: meaning, that the devil incites men to say “ God knoweth such a thing, ” of things whereof God knoweth the contrary: [as for instance, “ God knoweth that such a commodity cost me (the seller) such a sum of money: ”] yaEolamu QllRehu being a form of asseveration. (IAth.) [qyrwAn is written qayoruwaAnN in some copies of the S and K. It is mentioned in this art., and in art. qrw, in the K: in the S, only in the latter art., and part of the above trad. is there cited.]

1 qAs AlXaIoCa bigayorihi c
1. qAs AlXaIoCa bigayorihi, and EalaI gayorihi, (S, A, * Msb, * K *; the first and last in this art. and in art. qws;) and UilaI gayorihi, (A, TA,) aor. yaqiysuhu, (S, Msb, K,) inf. n. qayosN (S, A, Msb, K) and qiyaAsN, (S, A, K,) [which latter is the more common,] He measured the thing (S, A, Msb. K) by another thing (S, Msb, K) like it; (S, K;) [both in the proper sense and mentally; often meaning he compared the thing with another thing;] as also qaAsahu, aor. yaquwsuhu, inf. n. qawosN (S, Msb, K; the first and last in art. qws;) and qiyaAsN; (S;) [the latter of which verbs, though the less common, is, accord. to the JK, the original;] and so AqtAshu↓; (A, K;) and qyRshu↓; (TA;) and so bihi qAyshu↓, (Msb,) and Uilayohi, (TA,) inf. n. muqaAyasapN and qiyaAsN: (Msb:) the first of these verbs is said to be trans. by means of ElI because implying the meaning of founding [a thing upon another thing]; and by means of AlI because implying the meaning of adjoining or conjoining and collecting [a thing to another thing]. (MF.) You say, qaAsahu biQlomiqoyaAsi [He measured it with the measure]. (A.) And qaAsa AlTRabiybu qaEora AljiraAHapi, (TA,) and qaAsa AlXRaHRapa, (A,) inf. n. qayosN, (TA,) The physician measured the depth of the wound, (TA,) and the depth of the wound in the head, (A,) biQlomiqoyaAsi with the probe. (A, TA.) And jaAriyapN taxoTuw qayosFA (tropical:) A damsel that steps with even, or equal, steps: (A:) or qayosFA signifies with measured steps, at a moderate and just pace, as though with equal steps: (IAth:) or qayosN signifies the walking with an elegant and a proud and self-conceited gait, with an affected inclining of the body from side to side. (K.) And fulaAnN yaOotiI bimaA yaOotiI qayosFA (tropical:) [Such a one does what he does, or says what he says, by measure, or by rule]. (A.) ― -b2- [Hence, (assumed tropical:) He determined, or judged of, the thing by comparing it with another thing; i. e., by analogy: and he compared the thing with another thing. And qaAsa Ealayohi He judged by comparison therewith. And He copied it as a model.]

2 qayRasa
2: see 1.

3 qAyshu bihi c
3. qAyshu bihi, and Ulayohi: see 1. You say, qabaHa QllRehu qawomFA yusawRiduwnaka wayuqaAyisuwna biraOoyika [May God remove far from prosperity a people who make thee lord, or chief, and who measure things by thy judgment, or by thine opinion]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- qaAyasotu bayona AlOamorayoni, (S, K,) or AlXRayoYayoni, (A,) inf. n. muqaAyasapN and qiyaAsN, (S,) I measured, or compared, the two things, or cases, together; syn. qadRarotu, (K,) or qaAdarotu biyonahumaA. (L.) ― -b3- qaAyasotuhu, (K,) i. e., qaAyasotu fulaAnFA, (S,) i. q. jaArayotuhu fiI AlqiyaAsi [I vied, or contended, with him, namely, such a one, in measuring, or comparing; app. meaning, in measuring, or comparing, myself, or my abilities, with him, or his: see qaAdarotuhu]. ― -b4- [This verb is mentioned in the S in art. qws.]

6 tqAys Alqawomu c
6. tqAys Alqawomu The people mentioned [and app. compared] their several wants (maMribahumo [but I
think it probable that this is a mistranscription for maMvirahumo their generous qualities or the like]). (TA.)

7 AnqAs c
7. AnqAs It was, or became, measured by another thing like it. (S, in art. qws; and K, in the present art.) ― -b2- (assumed tropical:) [It was, or became, determined, or judged of, by comparison, or analogy.] You say, hecihi masoYalapN laA tanoqaAsu (assumed tropical:) [This is a question not to be determined, or judged of, by comparison, or analogy]. (A, TA.)

8 Uiqotayasa
8: see 1. ― -b2- huwa yaqotaAsu biOabiyhi He follows the way of his father, and imitates him. (S, K, in art. qws; and mentioned in the K in the present art. also.) The medial radical is both w and I. (K.)

qaAsu rumoHK c
qaAsu rumoHK: see qiysu rumoHK.

bayonahumaA qiysu rumoHK c
bayonahumaA qiysu rumoHK (S, A, K *) and rumoHK qaAsu↓ (S, K) Between them two is the measure of a spear: (S, K: *) like qiydu rumoHK (TA) [and qaAdu rumoHK]. And hecihi AlxaXabapu qiysu UiSoyaEK This piece of wood is of the measure of a finger. (A, * TA.) [Both are said in the A to be tropical; but wherefore, 1 see not.]

qiyaAsN c
qiyaAsN: see 1 and 3. ― -b2- [Used as a simple subst., Measurement. ― -b3- Comparison. ― -b4- Ratiocination. ― -b5- The premises of a syllogism, taken together: and also applied to a syllogism entire. ― -b6- Analogy: rule. You say, hecaA EalaI AlqiyaAsi This is according to analogy, or to rule. And hecaA EalaI gayori qyaAsK This is contrary to analogy, or to rule. And EalaI qiyaAsi kacaA After the manner of such a thing.]

qiyaAsiIRN c
[qiyaAsiIRN Mensural. ― -b2- Comparative. ― -b3- Ratiocinative. ― -b4- Relating, or belonging, to the premises of a syllogism: and also, syllogistic. ― -b5- Analogous; regular: as also maqiysN↓, improperly written by some European scholars muqayRasN.]

qayRaAsN c
qayRaAsN A man who practises qiyaAs [i. e. measurement, or comparison, &c.,] much, or often. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Also, i. q. qawRaAsN, q. v. (TA.)

qaAYisN c
qaAYisN act. part. n. of 1. ― -b2- One who measures the depth of a wound in the head [&c.] with a probe. (TA.)

maqiysN c
maqiysN pass. part. n. of 1. You say, huwa maqiysN Ealayohi [and bihi, meaning, He, or it, is a person, or thing, whereby others are measured; to which others are compared; an object of imitation; a model, an exemplar, or a standard]. (A, TA.) ― -b2- See also qiyaAsiIRN.

miqoyaAsN c
miqoyaAsN A measure, or thing with which anything is measured; syn. miqodaArN: (S, Msb, K:) pl. maqaAyiysu. (A.) You say, qaAsahu biQlomiqoyaAsi [He measured it with the measuring-instrument]. (A.) And qaSura miqoyaAsuka fiI miqoyaAsiI Thy measure (mivaAluka) fell short of my measure. (TA.) ― -b2- A probe with which the depth of a wound is measured. (A, TA.) ― -b3- miqoyaAsu AlnRiyli The Nilometer. (TA.)

1 qaASa c
1. qaASa, inf. n. qayoSN: see 7, in two places.

5 taqayRaSa
5: see 7, in three places.

7 AnqAS c
7. AnqAS, said of sand, (A, K,) and of dust, or earth, (K,) It poured forth, or down: (K:) or it fell, fell down, or collapsed; and so when said of a building; (A;) and so AnqASt said of a well (biYor); (S, A, K;) it fell; fell down; fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed; (S, A, K;) as also AnqADt, with D; (TA;) and tqyRSt↓: (A, K:) which ↓last also signifies it (a well) inclined, and became demolished, or fell in ruins; and in like manner [tqyRS said of] a wall. (TA.) ― -b2- AnqASt AlsRinRu The tooth became broken: (A:) or became cracked, or split, lengthwise: (TA:) or fell out: (Lth, K:) and qaASato↓, (TA,) inf. n. qayoSN, (S, K,) it fell out from its root; (S, K, TA;) and so with D: (S, TA:) and AnqAS AlDRirosu, and qaASa↓, and tqRyS↓, the tooth became cracked lengthwise, and fell out. (TA.) ― -b3- AnqAS AlmaMCu fiI AlbiYori The water became abundant in the well (K, TA) so that it nearly demolished it. (TA.)

biYorN qayRaASapN c
biYorN qayRaASapN A well that has collapsed. (A.) And biYorN qayRaASapu Aljuwli A well having its wall, or casing, or sides, demolished. (Ibn-'Abbád, K.)

munoqaASN c
munoqaASN signifies Uprooted; (S, K;) and munoqaADN, with the pointed D, cracked or split, lengthwise; so says As.: but AA says, that both signify the same. (S, O.)

1 qaADa c
1. qaADa, (A, TA,) [aor, yaqiyDa,] inf. n. qayoDN, (K,) He clave, or broke or rent asunder. (A, * K, TA.) You say, qaADa AlbayoDapa He (a young bird) clave, or broke asunder, the egg: and he (a bird) clave, or broke asunder, the egg from over the young one. (Lth, A, * TA.) And it is said in a trad, respecting the day of resurrection, faUicaA kaAna kacelika qiyDato hecihi AlsRamaMCu AldRunubaA Eano OaholihaA, i. e., [And when it shall be thus, this lowest heaven] shall be cleft, or rent asunder, from over its inhabitants, meaning the inhabitants of the earth (AlOaroD), which is previously mentioned in the trad.:] or, as Sh says, shall be dissolved. (TA.) ― -b2- Also, first pers. qiDotu, (AZ, S,) or qaDotu, (IAth,) He cracked a glass bottle, without separation of the parts. (AZ, S, IAth.) ― -b3- And qiDotu AlbinaMCa is a dial. form of quDotu [meaning I demolished, destroyed, or threw down, the building]. (Sgh.) ＝ -A2- Also, inf. n. as above, It became cleft, or broken or rent asunder. (K, in which only the inf. n. is mentioned.) You say, qaADati AlbayoDapu The egg became cleft, or broken asunder. (TK.) [See also 7.] ― -b2- And qaADati AlsRinRu, inf. n. as above, The tooth fell out from its root; as also with S. (S, * TA in art. qyS.) ＝ -A3- Also, (TA,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He hollowed out a well (K, TA) in a rock. (TA.) And qiyDa signifies It was dug. (TA.) ＝ -A4- Also, (TK) inf. n. as above, (K,) He likened, or assimilated. (K, TK.) You say, qaADahu bihi He likened, or assimilated, him, or it, to him, or it. (TK.) [See also 5; and see qayoDo, below.] ＝ -A5- See also 3, in two places.

2 qyRD lahu kacaA c
2. qyRD lahu kacaA He (God, Msb) ordained, or appointed, for him such a thing. (Mgh, Msb.) And qyRD QllRehu fulaAnFA lifulaAnK, (S, A, K,) in [some of] the copies of the K, bifulaAnK, which is a mistake, (TA,) God ordained, or appointed, or prepared, such a one for such a one: (A:) or brought such a one to such a one, and ordained, or appointed, or prepared, him for him. (S, K.) Hence the saying in the Kur, [xli. 24,] (S,) waqayRaDonaA lahumo quranaMCa (S, K) And we have appointed, or prepared, for them associates (A, * Bd, * K, TA) whence they do not expect, (A, K, TA,) which shall have possession of them like as the qayoD, or shell, has possession of the egg. (Bd.) And so in the same, [xliii. 35,] nuqayRiDo lahu XayoTaAnFA We will appoint, or prepare, for him a devil [as an associate]. (Zj.) Accord. to some, the verb is used only as relating to evil; but this is not true, as is shown by the saying of Mohammad, maA Oakorama XaAbRN XayoxFA lisinRihi UilRaA qayRaDa QllRehu lahu Einoda sinRihi mano yakorimuhu [A young man hath not honoured an aged man for his age but God hath appointed for him in his age such as shall honour him]. (TA.)

3 qAyDhu c
3. qAyDhu, (S, A, K, &c.) inf. n. muqaAyaDapN (S Mgh) and qiyaADN, (A,) He bartered, or exchanged commodities, with him; syn. EaAraDahu, (S, O, L, and so in a copy of the K,) bimataAEK; (S;) or EaAwaDahu; (A, and so in some copies of the K; in the CK, EAyaDahu;) and baAdalahu; (A, K;) i. e. he gave him a commodity and took another commodity in its stead: (TA:) [as also qaAbaDahu, with b:] and qaADahu↓, aor. yaqiyDu, he gave him a thing in exchange. (TA.) You say, qAyDhu bikacaA [He gave him in exchange for such a thing]. (Mgh.) Hence, bayoEu AlmuqaAyaDapi The selling a commodity for another commodity. (Mgh.) And hence the saying of Mohammad, Uino XiYota qaAyaDotuka bihi AlmuxotaArapa mino durwuEi xayobara, or bihi OaqiyDuka↓, accord. to different relations; i. e. [If thou wilt,] I will give thee in exchange for it [the choice of the coats of mail of Kheyber]. (TA.) You say also, OaEoTayotuhu farasFA bifarasayoni muqaAyaDapF [I gave him a horse for two horses in exchange]. (JK.) And maA OuqaAyiDu bika OaHadFA (tropical:) [I do not give, or take, in exchange for thee any one]. (A, TA.)
And lawo OuEoTiytu miloCa AldRahonaMCi rijaAlFA qiyaADFA bifulaAnK raDiytuhumo (tropical:) [If I were given what would fill the desert of men, in exchange for such a one, I would not accept them]: (A, TA:) and the like occurs in a trad. of Mo'áwiyeh, as said by him, with reference to Yezeed. (TA.)

5 taqyRDt AlbayoDapu c
5. taqyRDt AlbayoDapu The egg became broken into. pieces; and in like manner, AlqaAruwrapu the glass bottle. (AZ, S.) [See also 7.] ― -b2- tqyRD AljidaAru The wall fell to pieces, or in ruins, or became a ruin, and broke down; syn. Uinohadama, and UinohaAla; as also AnqADt↓: (K:) or the former signifies the wall broke in pieces, and fell down: but the latter has a different signification, which see in its place below. (AZ, S.) ＝ -A2- tqyRD lahu It (a thing, TA) became ordained, appointed, or prepared, for him. (K.) ＝ -A3- tqyRD OabaAhu He resembled his father; (AZ, S, K;) as also taqayRalahu. (TA.) [See qayoDN.]

6 tqAyDA c
6. tqAyDA [They two bartered, or exchanged commodities, each with the other; like tqAbDA: see 3]. (JK.)

7 AnqADt AlbayoDapu c
7. AnqADt AlbayoDapu The egg cracked, without splitting apart; and in like manner, AlqaAruwrapu the glass bottle. (AZ, S.) [See also 1.] ― -b2- AnqAD AljidaAru i. q. tqyRD: (K:) or the wall fell to pieces, or in ruins, from its place, without being pulled to pieces: (Lth:) or cracked, without falling: but if it have fallen, you say, tqyRD: (AZ, S:) ― -b3- Accord. to AA, as related by ElMundhiree, AnqAD and AnqAS both signify It split, or cracked, lengthwise: but see munoqaADN. (TA.) You say, accord. to As, AnqADt AlsRinRu The tooth split, or cracked, lengthwise; and in like manner, AlrRakiyRapu the well: (S:) or it (the well) became broken in pieces: or fell; fell in ruins, or to pieces; or collapsed; (TA;) as also AnqASt. (S, A, K, in art. qyS.) AnqAD belongs both to this art. and to art. qwD. (TA.)

8 AqtADhu c
8. AqtADhu He extirpated it; destroyed it utterly. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- [Also, He received it, or took it, in exchange; like UiEotaADahu: see muqotaADN; and see also 3.]

qayoDN c
qayoDN [An egg-shell;] the upper hard covering that is upon an egg: (K:) or [an egg-shell cracked in pieces;] what is cracked in pieces of the upper covering of an egg: (S, * IB:) or one from which the young bird, or the fluid, has gone forth. (Lth, K.) ＝ -A2- A compensation, or substitute; a thing given, or received, or put, or done, instead of, in the place of, or in exchange for, another thing. (K.) You say, baAEahu farasF bifarasayon qayoDayoni [He sold to him a horse for two horses as substitutes]. (TA.) ― -b2- humaA qayoDaAni They two are likes; they two are like each other; (A' Obeyd, A;) each of them is fit to be a substitute for the other. (A, TA.) [See also humaA qawoDaAni.] ― -b3- hecaA qayoDN lahu, and lh qiyaADN↓, This is equal, or equivalent, to it. (O, K.)

qiyDapN c
qiyDapN A small piece of bone: (AA, K:) pl., accord. to the K, qiyoDN; but correctly, accord. to AA, qiyaDN. (TA.)

qayRiDN c
qayRiDN A barterer, or an exchanger of commodities: (S, Msb:) of the measure fayoEilN. (Msb.) You say, humaA qayRiDaAni They two are barterers, or exchangers of commodities; like as you say bayRiEaAni. (S.)

qiyaADN c
qiyaADN: see qayoDN.

maqiyDN c
maqiyDN The place in which is [an egg-shell, or an egg-shell cracked in pieces, or empty, or] the part of an egg called qayoD. (K, TA.) ＝ -A2- bayoDapN maqiyDapN An egg cleft, or split. (TA.) ― -b2- biYorN maqiyDapN A well abounding with water, having been hollowed out, (K, TA,) or cleft. (TA.)

AlmuqotaAD c
AlmuqotaAD in the following verse of Abu-shShees,
budRilotu mino burodi AlXRabaAbi mulaMCapF
xalaqFA wabiYosa mavuwbapu AlmuqotaADi
[I have been given in exchange, for the mantle of youth, an old worn-out covering; and very evil is the recompense of the receiver in exchange] is from qayoDN as signifying the “ bartering, ” or “ exchanging commodities, ” (TA,) [or rather the “ giving in exchange: ” see 3.]

bayoDapN munoqaADapN c
bayoDapN munoqaADapN An egg cracked, without being split apart; and in like manner, qaAruwrapN a glass bottle. (AZ, S.) As says, that munoqaASN signifies uprooted; and munoqaADN, with the pointed D, cracked, or split, lengthwise; but AA says, that both signify the same. (S, O, in art. qyS.)

1 qaAZa biAlmakaAni c
1. qaAZa biAlmakaAni, (S, Msb, K,) aor. yaqiyZu, inf. n. qayoZN; (Msb;) and bihi tqyRZ↓; (S, K;) and bh qyRZ↓; (K;) and AqtAZ↓; (TA;) He, (a man, Msb,) or it, (a people, K,) remained, or abode, in the place during the season called qayoZ, (K, * TA,) during the summer, (S,) or during the days of heat. (Msb.) Dhu-r-Rummeh makes the second of these verbs trans. by itself, [without a preposition,] saying AlrRamola taqayRaZa↓ [He remained, or abode, during the summer, or hot season, in the sands]. (TA.) ― -b2- qaAZa yawomunaA Our day became vehemently, or intensely, hot. (S, Sgh, K.) ― -b3- See also 3. ＝ -A2- qiyZuwA They were rained upon by the rain of the season called AlqyZ; similar to SiyfuwA and rubiEuwA. (TA.)

2 qayRaZa
2: see 1. ＝ -A2- qyRZhu, (S, K,) inf. n. taqoyiyZN, (K,) It (a thing, S, K, such as food, and a garment, TA) sufficed him for his [season called] qayoZ; (S, K;) similar to SyRfhu and XtRAhu. (TA.)

3 qAyZhu c
3. qAyZhu, inf. n. muqaAyaZapN, He remained, or abode, during the season called qayoZ with him. (AHn.) ― -b2- EaAmalahu muqaAyaZapN, and qiyaAZFA, and quyuwZFA, with damm, which last is extr., (K, TA,) not being an inf. n. of this verb, (TA,) [but, by rule, of qAZa↓,] He made an engagement, or a contract, with him for the season called qayoZ: (TA:) from AlqayoZu, like muXaAharapN from AlXRahoru. (K, TA.) And UisotaOojarahu muqaAyaZapF, and qiyaAZFA, He hired him, or took him as a hired man, or hireling, for the season so called. (TA.)

5 taqayRaZa
5: see 1, in two places.

8 UiqotayaZa
8: see 1.

qayoZN c
qayoZN The most vehement, or intense, heat of summer; (S, K;) from the [auroral] rising of the Pleiades, [which, at the commencement of the era of the Flight, was about the 13th of May, O. S.,] to the [auroral] rising of Canopus, [which, at the same period, was about the 4th of August, O. S.:] (K:) or vehemence, or intenseness, of heat: (Msb:) pl. [of pauc.] OaqoyaAZN and [of mult.] quyuwZN. (K.) ― -b2- Also, The quarter which people [commonly] call the Sayof; (Msb;) the summerquarter, commencing when the sun enters the sign of Cancer; so termed by some, who called the spring-quarter the Sayof, and the autumnal-quarter the rabiyE; others [in later times] calling the summer-quarter the Syof, the spring-quarter the rabiyE, and the autumnal-quarter the xariyf; but agreeing with the former in calling the winterquarter the XitaMC: (Mir-át ez-Zemán:) the Arabs say, that the year consists of four seasons, every one of these being three months; namely, the quarter called the Sayof, which is that called rabiyEu AlkalaUi, consisting of [the Syrian months] Ádhár and Neysán and Eiyár [or March and April and May, O. S.]; then, the quarter called the qayoZ, consisting of Hazeerán and Temmooz and Áb [or June and July and August, O. S.]; then, the quarter called the xariyf, consisting of Eylool and the two Tishreens [or September and October and November, O. S.]; and then, the quarter called the XitaMC, consisting of the two Kánoons and Shubát [or December and January and February, O. S.]. (Az, TA.) ― -b3- laA taquwmu AlsRaAEapu HatRaI yakuwna Alwaladu gayoZFA wAlmaTaru qayoZFA, a saying of Mohammad, meaning [The resurrection, or the time thereof, will not come to pass until the birth of a child be an occasion of wrath, or rage, and] rain be accompanied by air like the qyZ [or most vehement heat of summer]. (TA.) ― -b4- UijotamaEa
AlqayoZu is an elliptical and abridged phrase, meaning The people, or company of men, assembled themselves in the qayoZ [or summer]. (TA.)

qayoZiIRN c
qayoZiIRN What is brought forth [of sheep or goats] in the season called the qayoZ. (K, TA.) [See also SafariIRN, in three places.]

qiyaAZN c
qiyaAZN Seed-produce [or wheat] that is sown in the autumn and the beginning of winter [so as to be reaped in summer]. (JK, TA.)

yawomN qaAYiZN c
yawomN qaAYiZN A day vehemently, or intensely, hot: and qayoZN qaAYiZN a summer vehement, or intense [in heat]. (TA.)

maqiyZN c
maqiyZN A place where people remain, or abide, in the summer; (IAar, S, K;) as also maqoyaZN. (K.) And A place of pasturing in summer. (IAar.) ― -b2- Also, (JK,) or maqiyZapN↓, (K,) A plant, or herbage, that remains green until the qayoZ [or summer], (Lth, JK, K,) although the land and leguminous plants be dried up, (Lth, TA,) being a means of subsistence for the camels when other herbage has become dry. (Lth, JK, K.)

maqiyZapN c
maqiyZapN: see maqiyZN.

muqayRiZN c
muqayRiZN A thing that suffices one for the [season called] qayoZ. (S.)
